description:
Great tapas places near Embarcadero!

I came here with my friend without reservation and luckily we got seated right away. The staff was very friendly and attentive! I love having tapas because I get to try many different things!

We ordered salmon ahumado($9)! Smoked salmon was fresh and tasty! It was great way to start our tapas night!

Boquerones($2.75each; white anchovie, olives, onion and pepper). This one was okay for me. I would not order this one again because I am not a big fan of anchovy. It was bit salty for me.
Sunny side up huevo with shrimp and potatoes ($14) this prawn dish was good. Love how potatoes are so crispy like fries. Lots of flavors and perfect all together! Highly recommend!
Albondigas a la Feria ($15; meatballs) this one was on sweeter side. It was okay dish to try!
Ensalada de Kale ($14) this Kale persimmon pomegranate salad was outstanding! Surprisingly I really loved this dish! It was just perfect combination of kale, nuts and dressings! I would definitely getting this when I go back!

Overall, great ambiance, nice service and delicious food! I'd love to try their Paella next time! I heard so many good reviews from my friends. I will be definitely coming back!
author: Clare L.

description:
Came here on a Friday night for drinks and Spanish inspired tapas and love it. Great spot on Embarcadero by the bay, with a huge line outside when we arrived. Luckily we had reservations and got seated right away.

We tried four tapas, the octopus, prawns, egg-chorizo-potato-shrimp dish, and the razor clam special. All four were pretty dang good. The octopus was my favorite. It was grilled, and the slight char contrasted with the rich and luxurious octopus. The octopus itself was tender and tasted almost like lobster. My wife's favorite was the prawns, which came in a black acidic sauce and bread to soak up all the goodness.

I also tried a SF inspired cocktail that had whiskey, vermouth, and a bit of coffee liqueur with a glass smoked in anise. The coffee liqueur left a bitter finish that I didn't enjoy, but I could tell all of the components were good.
author: Matt H.

description:
This was our second time here.
We h've had taps before in Usa and Andaluz before.
It's not like any of those at all but the location and the service is good.
It's not romantic a romantic restaurant but great location.
author: Kim K.

description:
Loveeeeee this place!! The decor and ambiance are both so beautiful, inside and out. I usually opt for the outside tent seating more which is great for conversation, libations, and a cool casual tapas flair. Although during peak time the tent can get packed with hungry and thirsty ppl and they usually don't cut off a capacity early on, so highly recommend inside for more space and peace of mind. REGARDLESS service/food/drinks has always been consistent and great inside or out, no matter how busy. 

Food talk: overall I'd say some of the dishes may have been a tad bit salty but I feel like that is something given in this style of cuisine. All were still very tasty and memorable in every way. 

(1) Patatas Bravas - such an amazing super crispy exterior!!! While super warm and soft inside. The sauce was a unique mixture of flavors and spices. 

(2) Croquette de pollo - filled with a creamy tasty shredded chicken filling. Nice crunchy bite, and rich tasty center = addictive. 

(3) Octopus - perfectly charred and yet oh so tender! The flavor had a nice kick to it, although was a bit salty.

(4) Sunny Side Up Huevos & Shrimp - one of their House specials highly recommended and DEF. lived up to its hype. Yes I can say, it was a tad bit salty...but still so unique and tasty in every flavorful way. Also there were amazing texture combos at each bite - would order again for sure!

Libations: legit, WELL crafted cocktails at its best. Unique twist and so very tasty...there were some drinks I didn't actually favor - but it's def. more so a preference on the kind of liquor (and how potent you like it) the quality of cocktails was def. on another level here.

(1) Salt Air Margarita - the salt air was actually a sea salt foam which was freakn amazing!!! Such a different and unique approach to the classic margarita. The drink itself was light and very refreshing, while the sea salt foam added a nice kick to it!

(2) Infamous Gin & Tonic - strong as hell!! The strongest freakn gin & tonic I've ever had. Presentation was beautiful and the taste was def. very potent for that gin & tonic lover, but just a little too bold for me personally.
author: Saleen L.

description:
It's been a while since I contributed a bandwagon review for a spot with 1,000+ reviews already, but let's make this exception for a San Francisco classic. A wonderful choice for inviting a client you want to impress, or for a date to up the stakes, or for a gratuitous blowout meal for a random occasion. Reservations can still be had at the last minute surprisingly often, especially on weekends as it's somewhat FiDi-connected, especially if you're agnostic about seating options. Tables, bar, and patio are all fine choices, and this is one of the most consistently attractive restaurants I've experienced wherever you wind up, plus the water views alone justify a good share of the pricetag.

I've heard positively filthy things about the pork shoulder, hosannahs talking about steak, only the softest, chewiest steak on earth, infused with bacon. And the octopus is a generous portion and as straightforward and wonderful a presentation as I've seen outside of Spain.

For some more guilt-free options I'll offer full-throated endorsement for the wild mushrooms. I've also made to understand that the gin and tonic will never disappoint. If only someone had a photograph!
author: James D.

description:
I would have never thought to try this place since Spanish food isn't really my thing but I was blown away! Anyways, came here on a Sunday afternoon and it wasn't too busy. Bar area is separated from the main dining room. My friend suggested we sit in the bar area and it was decorated really nicely. 

Drinks are strong and good! They're known for their gin and tonic and I loved the Galleon! So refreshing and barely tasted like alcohol. White sangria was a little too sweet to my liking. 

My favorite was the salmon ahumado. They call it an open face sandwich but it kinda just looks like salmon bagel. But don't let that fool ya. It is to die for even though it's a tiny little thing. They add truffle honey and I have had nothing like it! 
The sunny side up huevo was really interesting. Mix it all up and the potato crisps are like French fries. 
Croquetas de pollo were melt in your mouth yummy. 
The only thing I could've passed on was the uni open faced sandwich. It tasted too fishy and didn't pair well together with the bread. 

All in all, this was a nice place for Sunday brunch and it's right along the Embarcadero. Perfect for a little walk after eating all that good food!
author: Kristie L.

description:
We love Spanish tapas and make it a point to stop by Coqueta either for lunch or dinner when we are in the Bay area.  

We ordered everything from pintxos, montaditos, tapas calientes to the paella.  The bite size skewers of the Boquerones (white anchovie, campo real olives, pearl onion and piparra pepper) and Manchego (jamon serrano and apricot-sherry conserva) were a nice start.  I love manchego cheese and gobbled that up quickly.

The Mar y montana, "sea and mountain" (Iberico lardo gently mented over sea urchin with Lomo Iberico) was so amazing we had to order a second.  I crave anything with sea urchin in it.

The croquetas de pollo were gently crusted and paired well with the english pea filling.  As for the "Bikini" (brioche of roasted eggplant and apply jalea), I wished they would have mentioned on the menu it had goat cheese as my wife is allergic to goat cheese and I usually bypass ordering anything with goat cheese as well since I don't like the taste of it.  Goat cheese aside, the eggplant was delicious and I slathered honey all over the brioche to take away the goat cheese flavor.  The Gambas Negras was a nice concept of prawns with black garlic but I felt they overcooked the prawns a little bit but it has great promise if they can execute better next time.

We had to order the paella right away when we were seated since it took 30-40 minutes to prepare.  I don't know if it was because it was missing saffron or if I was getting full, but this turned out to be a disappointing dish.  I wasn't feeling the mixture of romano beans and pickled yellow beans in the paella. The clams were fresh and the bomba rice was cooked nicely but there was just something missing I couldn't pinpoint from being able to say WOW about the dish. 

We ended the night with some bite size desserts.  The manchego cheesecake with caramel popcorn is a MUST ORDER and the Trio de Pintxos (salted caramel with pimenton, passion fruit gelatina & thyme sugar and chocolate fuet) was a nice way to end lunch on a sweet note.
author: Johnny N.

description:
What a great restaurant to leave you feeling as if you were well taken care of and well fed with an excellent variety of dishes. As you are probably aware, they have a lot of small dishes to choose from and that was exactly the reason we came. However, word of caution - they are extremely small dishes. So, if you are used to getting 4-5 tapas dishes for two people at other tapas restaurants, that's not going to be enough here. We had about 6 dishes for the two of us, plus dessert, and quite frankly I probably could have had a few more easily.

I won't give a dish by dish recap, as that would ruin the fun of you trying them all yourself, but I was not disappointed with any of them! They all had a great taste and a flavor that you would want to eat more of.  I would probably have a few more dishes next time and skip the dessert (Bizcocho de Arroz), as that was the only one that didn't truly stand out to me.

Overall a great meal.
author: Marc K.

description:
Such a satisfying and perfect dining experience in Coqueta! The atmosphere, the service, the drinks and the food! We are lucky enough to get seats for 2 ppl on busy Friday night without reservation. 

The space is fresh and adorable that you can feel comfortable and have a nice conversation with those you are dining with. 
Service was fantastic and attentive, and the server even brought us some dessert wine as compliment. 

Ordered:
Drinks: 
Barca Gintonic (5/5): very refreshing, and the presentation was stunning. The blooming flower, thyme, and sliced of grapefruit gave the gin some fragrance and fruity flavor. 
Red Wine Sangria (5/5): aroma red wine some grape, citrus, sherry and a hint of spiece.


Food:
Special tomato salad (5/5）: mind-blowing item, didn't expect tomato salad can have such amazing taste. 
Jamon Iberico de Bellota  (5/5): thin sliced cured meat imported from Spain, they are beautifully-marble and flavorful. 
Pulpo a la Parrilla  (5/5): Highly recommended!!!, the octopus was cooked perfectly, tender and seasoned well. 
Paella (5/5): The paella takes a bit of time to come out, but it's totally worth it. There are many seafood on the top of the paella. Every bite of rice has so much flavor going on.

Desserts:
Trio De Pintox (4/5): comes with Salted Caramel with Pimenton, Strawberry Gelatina with lemon sugar, Chocolate fuet. Didn't expect the salted caramel taste spicy, :( 
Carajillo (4/5): Spanish Brandy ice cream with espresso our over the top.

Also, love the nice night view of San Francisco!!
author: Regina W.

description:
This place is seriously highly overrated... great view, but less than mediocre food and service. I came here with no reservations on a Thursday night and waited about an hour. No problem with that.

I absolutely LOVE tapas, but this place was honestly just MEH. Everything was far too oily and nothing really stood out. We ordered:
x Patatas Bravas Freshly dug, lightly smoked, crispy
Jamón Ibérico de Bellota Imported potatoes, bravas salsa and garlic aliolI - The first few were good, but after awhile it was just boring.  Only good to order if you wanna fill yourself up.
x Sunny side-up" Huevo With Shrimp, crispy potato, garlic chips, pine nuts, chili de arbol and chorizo dressing - SOOO oily I could barely enjoy this thing.
x Huevos de Codorniz Quail egg "Diablo", pickled mustard seed and jamón Serrano - Bite sized item that was lacking in flavor. 

We also ordered the Croquetas de Pollo, but it NEVER CAME OUT. When we asked the server about it he said "it probably went to another table". Um.. ok. No apologies or anything. 

Also, when I asked him what "diablo" meant for the quail egg, he basically scoffed in my face and said "diablo is DIABLO.. like spicy". Not sure if he thought I could barely speak English or what, but not cool.

I personally would never come back to this establishment. I know friend who live this place, but just can't stand the service.
author: Anna M.

description:
Really liked this place!  You will to.

From awesome service, to awesome specialized drinks, the whole experience was quite pleasant!  We got some cool little unique drink called Agua de Valencia, which is basically like a mimosa, but with an extra kick of gin and vodka.  

It wasn't overwhelmingly strong, but it had a pretty good kick, and was quite refreshing.  To be honest, I really just wanted to get it because it comes in this super awesome container called a Porron, and I really want to fill my house with them now!

The service was awesome, and the waiters/resses seemed like they were all very lively and having an awesome time, which really made the atmosphere more enjoyable!  Would love to come back here and try other things on the next adventure.

KThxBai!  LuvYou!!!    :D
author: Michael S.

description:
This place is doing everything right. The atmosphere, THE FOOD, and the service were all amazing. 

Between two of us, we ordered the perfect amount of food to have us pretty stuffed at the end of it. The gaucho, although it is pricey, is so worth it, and massive!! It's a really good dish if there's 4+ of you and you want to try multiple items on the menu, but it's also good for two people if y'all are very hungry.

We started with the croquettes, four different skewers (chorizo, Manchego, anchovy, and quail egg), and the octopus appetizer. Although they are small, the skewers are packed with flavor, my favorite were the chorizo and quail egg! The croquettes were also fantastic and loaded with delicious gooey cheese. And the octopus was also very good!

This place is perfect for a date night, but definitely make a reservation in advance, as it was busy up until they closed! Sit at the bar if you can, you can see the chefs hard at work, and your food gets delivered quickly. I will definitely be coming back for this amazing food and experience!
author: Emma I.

description:
Went here when my sister was in town because she wanted good seafood, SF sights, and a lively vibe, Coqueta hits all three! On Pier 5, it has amazing views of the Bay Bridge. 

We had the salt and pepper shrimp, octopus, chef's choice cheese and charcuterie board, nut-fed pig, and paella. Everything was amazing and there was not a miss on the menu.

Everything was presented beautifully and all the dishes were very colorful. The paella was big enough to share with 4 people, but you definitely would need to get a couple more side dishes. It was perfect with the pork on the side in addition to the seafood in the paella. 

As for drinks, can we talk about the gin and tonic? I think it's the best gin and tonic in the city in terms of taste! They also put flowers in it, so it feels like a little work of art in a glass. (And not to mention the flower make it ideal for posting on social media!) 

Coqueta is a great place to come for a couple of drinks at the bar or dinner, and a must-try restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Liz S.

description:
Advice: try the Tapas...any of them and you will love it with any of the gintonic. 
The following pictures for suggestions
author: Elpie K.

description: While the service was great, the tapas and paella was just average. They don't have a good variety of Tapas. Paella was just okay.
author: Madhu J.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants that I've been to in SF. Don't listen to the waiter when he tries to convince you not to over order... We ordered the follow for lunch and could have eaten more

5 stars 
Croquetas de pollo- tasted like heavenly mini- potpies
Branzino- deboned and delicious
Pork shoulder loin- a little sweeter than I'd like but cooked medium-rare to perfection

4 stars
Salmon ahumado- simple but I love me some salmon
Sunny side-up huevo- so many different flavors and tastes combining for an awesome bite

3 stars
Octopus- decent but could be improved
Duck & pork meatballs- the texture did not taste like a meatball, more like meatloaf...

2 stars
Padron peppers- little spice and nothing special
Mushrooms- tasteless

The staff was excellent. Food was explained to us in-depth and it was prepared very quickly.
author: Phi N.

description:
Yes, it's way overpriced and the portions are small, but I'm obsessed with Coqueta and it's one of my favorites. I'm such a sucker for the tapas, gin and tonics and gorgeous ambiance.

I always get the barca G+T, very light and refreshing.

Must order:
Mar y montana-salty fatty iberico mixing with creamy pungent uni, melt in your mouth happiness
Salmon ahumado
Chicken croquetas-creamy cheesy chicken pot pie with crispy crust
Pulpo
Sunny side up huevos
Gambas negras
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Wow! We had amazing service and wonderful food at Coqueta. 

We didn't have reservations, but the host was kind enough to let us know the couple at the bar was going to be seated at their table soon. I can honestly say the bar seats seemed better than the main dining room. Great views, a European vibe and impeccable service.
author: Rachelle B.

description:
I'm going to go out on a limb and say that the outside bar at Coqueta might have the best bar seats in San Francisco. Granted there are only four seats and you have to get there early but, what a fantastic experience all around! 

In a recent visit, my friends and I occupied the coveted real estate and had a lunch for the ages. We started with the pinxtos platter where you're charged per piece on the medley of the day. My favorite of the bunch was the quail egg and jamon. We also split some of the warm tapas and all agreed that the pulpo was our favorite. On to the drinks...

Our bartender was super legit, friendly and made some tasty cocktails all afternoon. I'm a huge fan of the barca gin and tonic but, the conquistador was an overwhelming favorite amongst the group. Delicious and a not to miss. 

Epic afternoon all around and a must stop for anyone visiting our fair city!!
author: Benjamin F.

description:
After a long morning at the exploratorium my friends and I walked over to this spot for lunch. We did not regret it. All the small bites were a great hit with the group and the drinks were definitely enjoyable. 

I loved the paella and all the little tapas. 

They also have an outdoor bar area that looked like it would be great for happy hour.  The table next to us ordered what looked like a bone in ribeye and if I had seen it before we were already on dessert I definitely would have ordered it. I guess I'll save it for the next visit!
author: Joanne T.

description:
I love croqueta although it is a bit pricey.

I've been here a handful of times for different occasions - dates, work dinners, birthday dinners, etc.

Their drinks are great and so is the food. I like the tortilla de espincas, gambas, sunny side up huevo, octopus, etc. One thing I wish I got to try is the paella.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Wow.  My main takeaway was - why haven't I been here sooner?!

This place is gorgeous.  There is indoor seating, outdoor seating, and sort of a "greenhouse-looking" sort of seating area - which is in a smaller space but protected by glass.  We were sat inside the main area, which was absolutely beautiful.  We were all enamored by the very rustic/Spanish decor.

I highly recommend trying out the cocktails - we were literally impressed by every cocktail we tried.  My favorites (and if you like pretty drinks, like I do): "Barca Gintonic", "Spanish Holiday", and "The Sun Never Sets."  The Barca Gintonic and the Spanish Holiday are both very refreshing and decorated with beautiful flowers.  The Sun Never Sets is like a beautiful dessert with a toasted top - like a merengue!  

We shared the "Plat Cap" to start, which is the Chef's selection of cured meats & we added all 3 cheeses.  This was amazing, and I would definitely recommend.

The "Salmon Ahumado," which means smoked salmon - was great.  This was perfect because the dish offered 4 pieces, and each piece of bread had a great portion of lox on it.  Really delicious.

Now the "Pulpo a La Parilla" - holy smokes.  We had two people in our group who were not huge octopus fans, and were hesitant to try it...but I'm telling you - GET IT.  It's cooked so perfectly, that it's the perfect texture (not rubbery), and it has a deliciously charred flavor to it.  We all ended up fighting over this dish. 

If we thought nothing could top that, we then tried the "Pluma," which is acorn fed, Spanish Iberico de Bellota pork shoulder loin - and GOOD LAWD IN HEAVEN - this was PHENOMENAL.  I can't even begin to describe to you how perfectly cooked, tender, juicy, and flavorful this dish was.  It has a delicious honey flavor to it, and I'm telling you - GET THIS.

Lastly, we did share a bunch of desserts.  We tried the "Tres Chocolates," "Bizcocho de Arroz con Leche," "Carajillo," and the "Manchego Cheesecake."  Honestly, they were all delicious.  My personal favorite was the cheesecake. 

The service is PHENOMENAL.  Honestly, we went in there and basically told the server we would like to try his recommendations of the best dishes - and he did not disappoint.  He was very knowledgeable and informed and was very helpful.   

Overall - I'd say DEFINITELY COME HERE.  The venue is gorgeous.  The service is unmatched.  The food is delicious.  The drinks are amazing.  Coqueta truly provides an experience that I had not found in a while!  We had an amazing time.
author: Michelle S.

description: Cute, small bites. The octopus was very good and the drinks were amaaaazing.
author: Roxanna A.

description:
I decided to try this place out after seeing that they had potatas bravas on the menu. I had them in Barcelona years ago.  Everything I ordered on the menu was delicious.  My waitress was pleasant & attentive.  I called the restaurant before hand to make sure they could accommodate my sleeping 2-month-old wee person because one review said that it wasn't child friendly but that's not true. I called ahead and was told they were welcome and they gave me a seat where I could keep my stroller open. 

My waitress was accommodating and helpful.  I will definitely go again when we visit San Fran!
author: Deanna N.

description:
Coqueta is absolutely one of the best Spanish restaurant in San Francisco Bay Area! I am extremely pleased with the food, the service, the ambiance of the restaurant, this restaurant is a total package for me!
I am a fan of Michael Chiarello, I am always so excited to watch his show on food network, now I am so happy I got to try one of his restaurant!

This restaurant has many selection of drinks and food. Every single dish and drink are very well presented, taste delicious. The interior design is rustic yet modern, service is impeccable, this place has it all!! 

The server gave us good recommendation on food and drinks, she is very attentive as well.
I had 'Galleon' cocktail which is beefeater london dry gin, lime and strawberry shrub, put in a round stemless wine glass, it is very beautifully presented, also very refreshing.
The Salmon Ahumado is served on a crispy mini bun, mixed with truffle honey, the smoked salmon taste very fresh.
We also ordered hot tapas such as Pulpo a la Parrila (wood grilled octopus) mediterranian style which is very tender, very tasty.
The 'Sunny side-up' Huevo with shrimp is served uniquely, the server came and cut the sunny side up eggs in small pieces, mixed them with crispy potato and then rearrange them to create a beautiful presentation.

My favorite is 'Pluma' which is wood grilled pork shoulder loin with honey chili glaze.
I am definitely very pleased and can not wait to come back and recommend this restaurant to my friends and family!!
author: Irene X.

description:
This place is on the water near the Exploratorium. It is very small and it is always crowded, but you can generally find seating in the waiting area and even have a delicious meal. 

The paella is good, and will easily feed two, provided you order at least one or two other tapas. They serve patatas bravas with Okinawan potatoes from time to time. I recommend you get a carafe of something, they are delicious, if pricey.
author: Jenée S.

description: I sat at a grill seat on a busy Sunday evening, loving the attention paid to every single dish and the camaraderie of the staff and their obvious pride in the food and its presentation. My only problem, being by myself, was not to be able to sample more, as everything I had hit positive on all senses: sight, smell, and taste, as well as the energy and ambiance of Coqueta. It will take a few more trips to work my way through the menu - next time, hopefully, with my wife on my next visit to The City in a month or so. Jack
author: Jack H.

description:
I basically came here for the views, sitting at the bar, of the water. That was spectacular. The bartender was extremely nice and helpful. 

That being said, it's a tapas place. So, small plates. And fairly expensive for what you get. I've never been a fan of tapas places (like I said, I came for the view) and this place was no different than the others. 

The plate I got was good but still disappointed for the price. I think because of its location, it gets a lot of tourists that come in to spend money regardless so it works. 

I was underwhelmed though and think there are plenty of better options that I will go back to in the future.
author: Matt M.

description:
Coqueta is worth checking out. It's a very small place, so I'd recommend a reservation. We were able to find bar seating though.

We started with a couple of cocktails and the "El Plat Cap de Queso". We both really enjoyed this. It came with some bread, but it definitely should've had more. 

My colleague ordered the Patatas Bravas. This dish was just not good at all. The sauce was like a cold tomato paste and the potatoes definitely needed sauce. He also ordered the Albondigas a La Feri (meatballs). These were amazingly delicious. Don't go here without getting an order of them. 

I ordered the Pulpo a la Parrilla (Octopus). This was an outstanding dish. Everything went well together and the Octopus was cooked perfectly. I also ordered the Pluma (Pork Shoulder Loin). This was the highlight of the meal for me. It came with a Honey Chili Glaze, but it wasn't really needed. The meat can be eaten as is and still taste perfect. 

Service was pleasant, albeit a little slow. If you have lots of time to spend chatting with your table, this is a perfect place. If you're trying to eat and get out fairly quickly I'd think twice before dining here.
author: Alex B.

description: By far, one of the best dining experiences in my life! Every dish we had was fantastic and simply amazing! Definitely recommend the Gulf Shrimp, the pork shoulder, and Caprese salad.  Can't wait to go back!
author: john c.

description:
I traveled to San Francisco with my girlfriend last year because she was presenting at a conference, Im very keen on eating where the locals do. Wasn't really fond of doing the whole fisherman's wharf thing, been there done that before and it's the same old stuff with overpriced items. Well in my opinion.

Upon a friends recommendation I walked in for lunch at sat at the bar. Can't remember the young ladies name, but she was extremely attentive and very kind during My dining experience she offered a few recommendations, but I definitely knew I was going to get the octopus. She suggested a cocktail, in which I don't normally order these types of beverages. But, I saw quite a few go out to other tables and it looked incredibly refreshing on this warm today. Wasn't disappointed at all!!

Started with the salmon appetizer, super fresh and silky salmon with a lot of flavor. Well done!

Of course, I ordered the octopus I'm a sucker for some good tentacles. I enjoyed the dish and all of the flavor components that went with it. I've had better, but this was definitely a tender piece of octopus. 

Overall: I highly recommend this place, the view of the mountains and the bay is fantastic, plus service was great. The setting at the restaurant had a very comfortable feeling and the food came out promptly. Everything I ordered did not disappoint and I highly suggest dining here if you're in San Francisco.
author: Brian B.

description: This was such a great Spanish lunch! The Jamon ibérico was amazing and so buttery. Grilled octopus is cooked perfectly it's so soft. The pluma (pork shoulder) was fantastic. With a bit of their honey that comes with it, it had me salivating even as I was eating it! I had a variety of tapas and they were all delicious. The house gin and tonic is great as well. I definitely will be returning to try more.
author: Jeana Y.

description:
Undeniably exquisite, undeniably delicious...but also undeniably expensive.  Starting with the negatives, Coqueta is not a place you'd leave full and heartily satisfied.  You get small tapas sized portions for large entree prices.  You may find yourself at Burger King after spending $100 for a few small plates.

But the food, aww gawd, it's good.  We tried a variety of dishes, all of which were seasoned and cooked perfectly.  Pork Shoulder was amazing, even if you don't add a drizzle of the honey glaze.  (Again, you get a paltry 7 slices for $38).  It's the kind of good that will make your eyes close.  Octopus was also very tender, plus it had just the right amount of char.  

I love it here.  Absolutely delicious food.  I just wish it wasn't so expensive so I can visit more often.
author: Angel S.

description:
DRINKS ONLY REVIEW

I simply love the atmosphere of this upscale tapas restaurant located by the piers. So far, I only came here to enjoy a cocktail or two.

If you come here for a proper meal, I'd recommend to make a reservation in advance. Otherwise, for some after hour snacks or an appetizer combined with Spanish inspired cocktails, you can walk in and most likely find a spot by the bar. The view to the Bay Bridge is simply stunning.

My favorite cocktails so far are the Barça Gin & Tonic ($14.50) which is served with Spanish Indi Tonic and incredibly beautiful flowers. Further, I'd also recommend the Sangria ($9 per glass/$36 per carafe) - it has a very distinct flavor you easily can fall in love with!
author: Stefani K.

description:
This is a really great Spanish tapas restaurant along the Embarcadero.  We came here after a rather long day of walking around the city. Our reservations were at 5 pm but we got here around 4:15 pm. They seated us in a tent/bar area while we waited.  I wanted something non-alcoholic and the J&T tonic did the trick for me.  

Once seated, the server walked us through the menu and suggested great options for a party of three who don't want any seafood.  This fantastic meal included Manchego and chorizo skewers (4/5), Jamon Iberrico (5/5), kale salad (4/5), pan con tomate (4/5), patatas bravas (5/5) and the gaucho (5/5).  It was enough food for all of us but we did not have room for desserts. 

The restaurant is a bit loud but I really appreciate the tent lounge area before guests are seated.  Service was good.  This place is a bit pricey - it's about $90 per person including tax and tip. Highly recommended and I can't wait to come here with some of my seafood eating friends.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Came here for the food, but gotta go back for the drinks cuz damn they looked impressive. 

Snagged a reservation for the bar, interior was hip, cool, and trendy without being stuffy. 

Staff were attentive without being annoying, gave good recommendations, and thoughtful with banter and bday extras. 

Onto the food. Paella was good but smaller than I expected for the price, at least comparing it to some other spots I've been to. But the fried potatoes, broccoli, meatballs, and octopus were all really good!

Everything was great, excited to head back for round 2!
author: Mandi W.

description:
Delicious! Fresh! Vibrant flavors.

Coqueta is a small Spanish-tapas at Pier 5 Embarcadero. It's an intimate and fun place to hang out for a date or small group of friends looking for delicious food and yummy cocktails. Happy hour is a great way to try out their drinks, but it won't be enough to enjoy the seafood dishes here. That might be best on the weekend, when they have bigger shipments of fresh caught seafood. 

To decide how to order, my recommendation per party of 2 is 5-6 tapas without entrees, or 3-4 tapas with one larger entree. 

For the cocktails, everything is solid. I personally like the Barca Gintonic ($14.50). It's gorgeous with floating flowers, paired with London dry gin, special Indi tonic (this stuff is amazing), grapefruit, thyme and lots of beautiful flower blooms. It's a great palate openers and smooth.

As for tapa's I suggest a few of these: 
For prosciutto lovers, you have to explore Jamon Iberico if you haven't already ($29). I swear it will change your life. Different texture, flavor profile of aging. Mar y Montana open faced toast made with iberico lardo gently melted over Santa Barbara Uni (sea urchin) is unique and fireworks in the mouth ($15 for 2 toasts). Patatas bravas ($10) are little morsels of crispy balls of heirloom potatoes that are lightly smoked and served with a lovely bravas and garlic aioli sauce. It's a great way to round out the meal with a few carbs to fill the stomach. I think Gambas Negras ($15) are a must here- olive oil poached gulf prawns grilled with black olive and chili sauce, perfected prepared for you to suck the head and eat straight off without peeling. The prawns are big, tender, sweet and absolutely perfect. Razor Clams ($15/20) are a MUST if they are available as a special. They are freshly caught, so sweet with the texture of raw sweet scallops with delicious drizzle of Meyer lemon rind, herbs and perfect evvo!

Overall, you can't go wrong a delicious cocktails and plates of seafood here. Excellent breeze and view of the bay through the looking glass. I highly recommend coming here when you can during the warm summer season!
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Scored reservations at Coqueta for Monday night. We had the meat & cheese plate, skewers, salt & vinegar chips, potatoes and cocktails. The food was all good - meat and cheese plate had a nice variety. Loved the toasted bread with honey. 

My cousin, who is 13, found it challenging to pick something on the menu so maybe not the best place for kids. Our server wasn't particularly attentive, helpful or friendly but the cocktails were delicious!
author: Alexa S.

description:
I was in SF attending an event and after I just wanted to go somewhere for a drink 

Stopped there as it catches my eyes the outside seating right on the water!!

So I just got a drink and it was awesome 
Our table service was beyond friendly! 
I didn't try the food but it was to tempting from what I saw on the tables around me .. will definitely try next time 
Price wise it's a little above normal prices but why not or a special date or night out 
Highly recommended if you're around that area
author: Maha M.

description:
Great service, some tasty food and remarkable cocktails.
Amongst the 15 or so tapas/dishes we ordered, what most stood out were the:
Gambia
Croquettas
Salmon on mini bagels
Churros con chocolate

I think that it's definitely an amazing place to be if you want to eat right on the Pier. Even though I've had tons of other great Spanish food elsewhere, it carves its' own little space in SF in a landmark location.
author: Kinjal N.

description:
I would definitely make a reservation before coming here as it's a pretty small place and bustling with people! I made a reservation via Resy pretty quickly for a Saturday afternoon. Seating is a little cramped - our table was super close to another table. The ambiance is nice though - chic, hipster-esque, and right off the pier makes for good scenery! 

Food:
+ salmón ahumado - the truffle honey paired really well with the salmon! I would recommend ordering this! 
+ mar y montaña - I'm not a huge fan of uni, but this dish didn't taste so bad especially with the ham. My boyfriend really enjoyed this, so if you're an uni lover like him order this!
+ gambas negras - delicious! The sauce is a little too oily, but the flavor was wonderful! Shrimp tasted fresh as well! 
+ albòndigas a la feria - the duck and pork meat was very soft, however the flavor wasn't that memorable. Pass on this one! 
+ pulpo a la parrilla - easily my favorite dish of the meal. The octopus was very, very tender. The sauce was a great compliment to the octopus as well! 

Portions are a tad tiny, but it was fine as we left just content in terms of fullness. Service is a little slow in terms of dishes being served however everyone was very friendly and helpful!
author: Joanne Y.

description:
I am always in the mood for Spanish tapas, so visiting Coqueta with my friends while on vacation in San Francisco was a real treat! The restaurant is situated right on the water... I am sure it is beautiful in the daytime and perfect for outdoor seating when the weather is nice, but we opted to sit inside on a chilly, late evening in San Francisco.

The best thing about tapas is the array of options you have. It gives you a chance to try so many things! We tried (and loved) the boquerones skewers, gambas negras, huevos nacionales, and the salmon ahumado. For dessert - the churros are the star of the show, but the manchego cheesecake is interesting (in a good way).
author: Priya R.

description:
Quick dinner stop with several gfs...
If you come early (around 6pm) tables are still available via opentable. We sat at the back, large table by the chefs. Order head-on gulf prawns, devil eggs, wood grilled octopus, chicharron creamy crusted chicken. For dessert, we ordered square shaped churros with chocolate syrup and moist cake top with ice cream & berries. The girls said all the food was yummy, they sure look good.
author: Vee V.

description:
Came here with two friends on a Friday night and sat at the bar in the super cute casual space to the left of the main dining room. So glad we stopped in here before a night out (to put it lightly).

Service & atmosphere: the space is warm, with a communal feel as well as an open vibe due to the see through plastic tarp walls- will definitely come back when it's warm out to take advantage of the space. Service was fantastic, attentive, and friendly. Shout out to the bartender who suggested our next cocktail spot, which was phenomenal as well. 

Food & drink: My friends and I had a few rounds of their absolutely gorgeous and well-balanced gin and tonics. Beautifully presented and fantastic flavor no matter which ones we tried. In terms of food, we had the patatas bravas, mar y montana, and sunny side up huevo, The bravas were delicious as well as the huevo. The mar y montana bites were my favorite, the iberico and uni had an amazing flavor together (though I kind of wish they were on top of something a little more soft and flavorful). 

All together, everything was delicious and I can't wait to return during a warm summer day to enjoy the view!
author: Marissa F.

description:
I know this restaurant got a lot of good reviews. It really comes to me as a surprise that I was walking out of this restaurant today with a half-full stomach and disappointment. 

My husband and I planned ahead a week ago to make a reservation on Opentable. We got a reservation at 5:45 on a Friday. When we got there we were told they are overbooked because of Opentable (reminds me of United airline). They still managed to reserve the bar area for us. We were seated at the bar table that was at the center of the glass house. It was supposed to be a weekend treat and we ended up getting the most crowded area of the restaurant. Okay. So we said to ourselves we could tolerate this if the food is brilliant. 

We've ordered 3 tapas and 1 entree. Patatas Bravas and the sunny-side up Huevo are great not phenomenal. It goes really well with cocktail but we are not drinkers. For the entree we had Pluma and the meat is juicy and tender. The sweat sauce that came with me makes it even tastier. Yet, we never had our 3 tapas came. We ordered the octopus tapas and the chorizo in skewer but they never came. In fact, they messed up our order and gave us the sliced chorizo. It also took a long time for the food to arrive. We talked about getting dessert like churros but we ended up leaving feeling half-full because we waited for too long. 

If it wasn't we were seated at the bar area, they might have taken our order correctly. Because the bar area is so crowded and noisy.
author: Fontane Y.

description:
Meatball - was quite sweet so wasn't a fan

Deviled eggs - flavor profile was interesting and sorta refreshing

Croquette pollo - was really good, wished it had some sauce 

Smoked salmon - who would of known to put honey on smoked salmon! Not bad pretty good

Potato chips - best thing I had through the night! The cheese was not overbearing and the sauce was really good! It has alcohol so keeps you buzzing.

Branzino - was really good! It's quite small and expensive but good. I didn't care for the garnish but ate the fish! They even cut it for us!

White sangria - best sangria in the states ever!

Agua de Velma is - was really good, tart but very good

Churros - second best thing of the night! Must have!

Service was friendly and got seated quickly. I had a rsvp and sat at the chef table. Nice to watch people cook. Food came out in a decent manner.
author: Minerva L.

description: This was a wonderful brunch spot. Met girlfriends, we sat in the bar and had pretty cocktails (healthy amount of alcohol in them). Then ordered some small plates and just enjoyed the afternoon by the bay and good company. All the small plates we ordered were super tasty. All the small plates next to us and coming out of the kitchen look great! I will come back again.
author: Kati G.

description:
We stopped into Coqueta on a Tuesday night after making reservations using Resy about 4 days in advance. We were seated immediately, and had friendly service throughout the night that was both casual/laid-back but attentive and polished at the same time. If you leave to use the restroom, you'll return to find your napkin folded in front of your chair. Nice little touches like that. 

We made good use of the cocktail menu throughout the night - me digging the gin-and-tonics (each one is completely unique and all that I tried were great, especially the Galleon), him with the drinks that came with lime or rose-jalepeno "air" on top. Very ephemeral and light, but delicious! None of the drinks were especially strong, but you could get a solid buzz going if you're just stopping in for cocktails. We were mainly there to grub down. 

Not that this is a great place for that. If you're "fasted-all-day" hungry, you might want to pick another place unless you're looking to drop $300 on tapas. 

Would Order Again: The padron peppers, Albondigas, and mushroom dish. Each of these were uniquely prepared and brought in interesting elements, like little strips of pork with the peppers or the tiny wild mushrooms sauteed with garlic. The Churros are unanimously how every meal here should end - dipping them into the tiny cup of hot chocolate was a pretty fun craft after a few drinks.

Would Pass: The broccoli dish and the pork shoulder, while both delicious, didn't bring a lot of value to the table considering their price tags. $40 for a light serving of pork shoulder for each person is a little steep, but I'd be willing to come back and try the paella. The dessert pintxos were adorable, but pretty underwhelming. 

In all, I'd come back for cocktails and some light tapas, but would skip the larger dishes (short of trying the paella). Great service, gorgeous ambiance, and killer location makes this a primo date night spot. Bueno!
author: Laura B.

description:
Great place for tapas and sangria. We went before the restaurant opened so we sat in the bar. There were 4 of us and the waiter graciously moved us sitting from the outside bar seats to the middle table so we could talk to each other and share our food. The drinks were amazing. 

The red sangria was a little bit too sweet for me and I love sangria. I still drank it anyways ha ha. Their gin and tonic was also tasty and reminded me of a drink I've had in Houston. I can't remember the other drink my companion ordered but it was pretty and tasty! 

We ordered the jamón ibérico - 3 orders! That's how much we liked it! It came with little crackers for you to enjoy. We also ordered the goats milk to go with the jamón. We probably could've stayed there and eat and eat and drink and eat some more but we had reservations for sushi that night. 

Oh and if you are in bar area, you can only have the cold appetizers so just be aware of that.
author: Lisa B.

description: What can I say.. this place has my heart since the very first time I was there. Since then, I brought probably all of my friends there just as an excuse to eat and drink at Coqueta again while introducing them the place haha :) They signature drinks are amazing and so beautiful - they actually put some flowers intro your drink and it just makes it looks so much better. Besides that, location - right by the water, you can go for a walk on the pier right outside after lunch/dinner to start your digestion lol The food is great as well.. I love their potatoes with shrimp and eggs as an appetizer, the tapas are delicious, the meat and fish too! Everything. Make sure you save some room for dessert, if you can, because it is worth it. Love Coqueta!
author: Daffny V.

description:
Can't believe it has taken me so long to get my ass to Coqueta. I had a dinner date here with Sarah K. and we LOVED it. 

How would I even begin to describe the food here.. a modern take on tapas? Tapas, but elevated? However you want to describe it, everything we ordered was so, so good. 

- Potatas bravas: amazing garlic aioli 
- Sunny side huevo with shrimp and crispy potatoes
- Pulpo a la parrilla: I'm a sucker for octopus and this was amazing, so tender 
- Manchego cheesecake with caramel popcorn: very unique salty/sweetness, it's small so why not, amirite?
- Churros with drinking chocolate: loved the berry powder 

You also must wash all of this down with a Barca Gintonic. Tastes great, with flowers included that make it a very Instagram-able drink, of course it's a must get.

Definitely one of my favorites in SF!
author: Laverne N.

description:
I'm a fan of this place and usually I'm picky about my tapas joints. This place has great ambiance and a soothing atmosphere. They have two rooms; one for a more laid back & casual vibe out in the patio and of course the inside which is more of a restaurant feel. 

Their menu is unique and contains dishes that are influenced from Spain but also has it's SF twist with exotic mixing such as their "Sunny Side" which is chorizo buried under an egg yolk and crispy potato chips & garlic with jumbo sized fresh shrimp. This was my favorite along with their Manchego Crudo and grilled octopus. Food is prepared fresh and delivered to the table on time. Their plating is excellent as well as their presentation. 

I knew this was a great establishment by walking through the main lobby and observing the head chef and manager taking full control with the team and just talking about their plan for the evening and how great they are. They have excellent team work here; very professional. 

I'm definitely coming back again and this time I'll have some Spanish cocktails with another arrangement of tapas!
author: Allister D.

description:
These are some pretty cocktails for sure. Probably in my top 5 in terms of presentation. But taste-wise, they really are gin & tonics and call me a heathen but I personally would've just settled for Bombay and Canada Dry without complaint. 

We came here for Mother's Day brunch, having made a reservation in advance. They didn't have a booster seat for the infant with us. It was a group of about 8 and we were seated against a window facing the sidewalk - could be better but okay. 

The service was really good, and the food came out with the appropriate time gaps. We had some of everything. Paella, potatoes, octopus, mushrooms, just a bit of everything on the menu. To be completely honest none of it stood out. They were decent, just a tad above average maybe, but for the price it was hard to justify the amount of food we were getting.
author: Myles C.

description:
Came here with work for a tasting dinner for ~12-15.  Bill came out to be about $3K with drinks and everything including tip.  Kind of high but really not that bad and within our budget.

The food was good but I didn't think anything was that extraordinary.

It was also a tasting so the bites were small.

What was extraordinary was the drink presentation.  It was really quite cute.  Service was okay too.
author: Phillip N.

description:
Well done Coqueta! Despite being a hustling/bustling hip joint at the Ferry Building, you managed to keep your standards for food and drink VERY high.

Likely the best gintonics I've had outside of Spain. Food is top notch (a bit pricey, but ultimately fantastic and yes, you are paying a premium for the location).

Order and share EVERYTHING. Trust the servers too - they know what they're doing.
author: Jimmy S.

description: This was our first time in SF and I came across this place on yelp... OUTSTANDING is the best way to describe this restaurant. We called got in at 5, Johnny was our sever he was extremely personable and went out of his way to notice details! However the staff is matriculates and flow easily together helping each other like musicians. I can not say enough about the specialty drinks as well as the food, the experience was amazing food and service outstanding...I will highly recommend this place and ask for Johnny!
author: Kimberly D.

description: We was party of four big fan of food and didn't enjoy at all!!! Not really taps bar, poor service and very expensive!
author: Avi E.

description:
Looking back we really should've made dinner reservations. Luckily there were spots in the bar area open.

The restaurant is pricey for tapas but it's expected for a Embarcadero restaurant. Luckily we both weren't very hungry. 

I had high expectations for the croquettes, having had amazing ones in Spain. Of course it was a let down. They were ok and I'm not sure I'd order them again.

The sunny side up huevo with shrimp was interesting. It had these really crispy potatoes pieces that are like mini French fries.
author: Sophia L.

description:
If I were just rating this place on the dessert, it would be 5 stars. Service would probably be 3. We came here after a filling dinner to get some dessert and drinks. The inside was booked for a private event and smelled of drunk people, and the waiter handed us two menus that were completely irrelevant to what we wanted to order (it only had a list of hot foods). 

We perched outside on the stools and waited a bit before another guy returned with the dessert and drinks menus. After perusal of some overly expensive wines, we went with the Flaca Gin & Tonic, the Manchego Cheesecake, and the Bizcocho de Arroz con Leche. It brought back good memories of sitting outside in Spain and sipping on cheap wine, though it was obviously way colder. 

The Manchego Cheesecake was my favorite, with two small cakes on lollipop sticks and two pieces of caramel popcorn perching on each. Although they're mere bites, they are bites of cheesy, creamy perfection. The sharpness of the cheese could turn off some, but I found it to be sheer decadence. Cutting open the bizcocho to a flow of arroz con leche seemed almost perverse, but isn't that what dessert should be? The ice cream just tasted like vanilla to me, though, but I'm not one to complain about ice cream. The sour edge of the gin and tonic was a great pairing to the dessert. An expensive way to enjoy the city lights, but still a great way to spend a night.
author: Sophie W.

description:
Amazing! 
We went there for my birthday.
Decor is sophisticated and modern, service is fast friendly and efficient.
And the food is to die for! 
Really enjoyed ourselves.
author: Or B.

description: I'm definitely a fan. Made my way over here craving cheesecake and surprisingly found myself enjoying everything more than the cheese cake. Not because it was bad, but rather because other things were really tasty.  We had the Pulpo a la Parilla which were a real stand out, as well as some other dishes. I do have to say that they are small. If you expect to get full here, you're going to have to order a lot. So while you will be met with an amazing show of flavors, you will also be seeing a hefty bill at the end of the night.
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
High prices, tiny portions for everything (except maybe the steak), definitely not worth the price. Really good service though.

Salmon and such with truffle honey: comes as 2 tiny sandwiches. My favorite item on their menu, it's delicious, but too small to be satisfied

Quail egg: literally one quail egg with some cheese and pork, need to order a couple to be satisfied, pretty good though

Eggplant sandwich: even if you don't like eggplant you should still get this. You can't even taste the eggplant. It's very rich though, but tastes great

Meatballs: seems like it is cooked with a wine, not bad but probably wouldn't order again
author: Tom P.

description:
In a nutshell - fantastic food that gives you variety of flavor, simple yet elegant presentation, and a fun, lively atmosphere

Coqueta is one of those places that you go for something a little special. Not just a normal meal, you go here when you are dining with special people or want some fun mixed in with your experience. The variety is key here. There are so many items to choose from that you can craft your own little food adventure. Highlights for me - the pluma, for one. Incredibly delicious pork grilled (a wee bit too much) with an incredible, sweet glaze. The potatoes were excellent, but watch that you don't burn your mouth. Don't skip dessert if you like manchego - the manchego "cheesecake" was amazing.
author: Andrew J.

description:
Food: Jamon Iberico, chorizo skewer bites, boquerones skewer bites, croquettes, gambas negras (AMAZING) & paella were all delicious. Octopus and mushroom sides were ok. Things could be spicier in my opinion :) For dessert, my favorite was the manchego cheesecake. 

Service was great as well and the ambiance is awesome, right next to the water and has a nice covered outdoor area.
author: Laura D.

description:
Yelpnesia: Defined as one's lack of memory of ever reviewing a dining establishment you've been to several times before (blame it on the Sangria).

Coqueta is a great place to take out of town friends ( or yourself for that matter!). Located on the Embarcadero waterfront, Coqueta offers a warm and inviting place to have a lovely casual lunch or Dinner.

Coqueta is best for Drinks and Tapas imho!  The main dishes are pricey and hit and miss. I have had the paella here two or three times and I don't think it is that great...and it is expensive.

The appetizers I would recommend are: 

Patatas Bravas- freshly dug, lightly smoked, crispy new potatoes, bravas salsa, and garlic alioli.

Croquetas De Pollo- chicharon crusted chicken and english pea croquetas with cured valencia orange

Albondigas A La Feria- grilled duck and pork meatballs with tart cherry and tempranillo salsa and crispy shallots

Trio De Salchichas- grilled sausages glazed with cider, fresh apple, and mojo verde 

And most importantly the "El Gran Plat Cap" chef's grand selection of cured meats and cheeses. served with membrillo, marcona almonds, extra virgin olive oil tortas, and pan de cristal con tomate.

Definitely order a lovely bottle of wine or one of their House specialty Cocktails to wash it all down with.

I must tell you it is quite expensive ( funny how all tapas places are i.e, Bellota!) and all these small bites can add up fast.

However for a fun and festive evening with superb service in a warm and inviting atmosphere check out Coqueta.
author: David G.

description:
After reading rave reviews for Coqueta on Yelp, Calvin and I decided to give it a try. We made reservations for a Saturday afternoon lunch. We knew going in that it would be pricey but the pricey to portion and taste ratio was disappointing. 

I ordered the Barça gintonic ($14.50) since it seemed to be what they were known for. Calvin wanted a Bloody Mary but with Mezcal (upcharge of $2 to $14). My drink was beautiful and the best part of the whole dining experience. I like how that give you a small bottle of tonic water to refill. The presentation of the drink was beautifully crafted. 

We decided to order two of the Huevos de Cordoniz (quail egg with pickled mustard seed and jamón serrano) ($2.25 an egg/skewer), Mar y Montaña (ibérico lardo melted over sea urchin with lomo ibérico, $14), Gambas Negras (prawns with black garlic and chili sauce, $14), Albóndigas a la Féria (duck and pork meatballs with tart cherry-tempranillo salsa and crispy shallot, $14) and we ended with the Bizcocho de Arroz con Leche (warm molten arroz con leche cake with huckleberries and arroz con leche ice cream, $9). 

The quail eggs came first and unfortunately fell short of tasting anything more than just a tiny egg yolk. 

The ibérico over sea urchin was nicely plated and the sea urchin was fresh but the thick toasted bread made it hard to take a bite and the bread overpowered the taste of the ingredients sitting on top of it. 

Out of all the food dishes, the prawns were my favorite. They were a little on the saltier side but came with three little toast slices that paired well with the prawns and the sauce. $14 though is a bit pricey for 3 prawns and 3 slices of toast. 

The pork and duck meatballs were our greatest disappointment. We weren't sure if the meatballs were just extremely tender or really undercooked. For some reason, they just didn't taste right and looked mushy. 

The con leche cake was beautiful to look at as the waiter cut it in half and the rice pudding just poured out but the cake tasted stale and a bit hard. 

Coqueta is a beautiful place to grab a drink and maybe one bite but I don't think I'd return for a meal. The 3 stars are only because of my drink and the wonderful service we were given. $95 for a so-so lunch but I'd come back for a drink.
author: Olivia C.

description:
We had to come back for the croquetas de pollo and wow it was worth it! 

We ordered the bistec this time and it was so tasty and basically melts in your mouth. You could taste the grill on it and the seasoning didn't overpower the taste of the meat.

We also ordered the squash, which I did not really like much at all.

It was a good dinner. Thanks again.
author: Allyson L.

description:
Come here for vibes for SURE. Beautiful view of the water (sadly behind bar, not where seating/standing for happy hour is). 

Their hours are weird and misleading online. 3/4 of the menu is only available at 5 which on a Friday is weird to me given the happy hour setting. 

I was excited for my olives and almond sides to pair with my BEAUTIFUL gin and tonic, but they were both certainly not worth the two dollar signs. In fact, all the olives had the same flavor profile, which I didn't like at all.. oddly nutty but not in a good way. The almonds were good for snacking but there wasn't much to them.. I was definitely expecting some seasoning or something.

Salmon toast was good, interesting flavor combination with the truffle honey. We really didn't enjoy the deviled eggs.. the picketed potato base really throws the whole thing off in the wrong direction.. though it was pretty to look at. 

Octopus was ok.. chewy though. The potato bravas were my favorite tapas item we tried, absolutely delicious, moist and hearty. 

Drinks were delicious and strong which is always what you want when you're spending the money. The gin + tonic is decorated with flowers and fruit. Our waiter was a little all over the place but that is to be expected at hh. 

Good experience, fun vibes, food needs some cohesive love.
author: Tash B.

description: Have you ever asked a favor to somebody who doesn't give a shit about you? Well... service in this place is worse than that
author: Daniel U.

description:
My most favorite place in all of San Francisco for tapas! Everything is amazing - from the location to the food and the ambiance. And an amazing selection of Sangrias, too!

My favorite dishes are their patatas bravas, the bikini (brioche + roasted eggplant + smoked goat cheese and apricot jam) - these are a must try! Their paellas take 30-40 minutes to prepare, but they are so worth it!

And never say no to dessert; their churros are life-changing AND they come with a chocolate dipping sauce.
author: Marina C.

description: Tapas were amazing, service was on point and they sat us fast thanks to reservation no show. Would love to eat here again!
author: Amanda C.

description:
A newspaper rep took us here for lunch to thank us for the business.  I do love Micheal Chiarello, Tra Vigne was a favorite of mine back 20 years ago in its prime.

I got there a little late and I was surprised to see a HUGE platter of tapas on sticks in a block (super cool presentation BTW)  - What I did;t realize until I did a little reading was that they charge the table per piece eaten.

We ordered a few things to split: 
- potatoes Bravas -YUM
-the chicken Croquettes - YUM
-Padron Petters
-and the "gaucho" it was the biggest steak I have ever seen - 4 of us all had some, I took the leftovers home and I weighed it - it was nearly 16oz left (3 more meals)

Our server was a sweetie and it is a very pretty room.  The way to the bathroom is weird - and all clutter with shit like a coat rack and boxes for the restaurant.

Happy to come here any time on someone else's dime.
author: Amy W.

description:
Love Coqueta. We took my Mom to a lovely Christmas Eve meal at Coqueta yesterday afternoon. Unfortunately, I was unaware that they do close between lunch and dinner-so we were a bit rushed.

For starters, I had the most beautiful G&T ever. They are famous for their G&T, and I'm sure there are many pictures of them posted already but I'm obsessed with cocktail pics and I just can't help myself.....

Our server was awesome and made our tapas for 5, to fit our party.

In addition to the beautiful beverages, we had:

Ensalada de Kale- excellent technique in the preparation, I think it was slightly toasted first, altering the flavor and texture of the kale-for just enough wow.

Salmon Ahumado- house smoked salmon served open faced with truffled honey. The flavors were spot on. The toast was a little too hard and crunchy for me, the rest made up for it.

Chicharron Crusted Croquetas de Pollo-crispy little bundles of yum

"Bikini" Brioche- not sure why they call it "bikini", but it's an eggplant and goat cheese brioche sandwich to die for. The temperature was so that it melded everything together perfectly.

Albondigas- pork and duck meatballs, my entire party loved them.

Pulpo a la Parilla-octopus grilled over wood. This is the dish that brought me to Coqueta. Unfortunately, it was a little tough.

Paella-it was okay, really dry and hard on top.

We did another round of the tapas and called it a day--kitchen closed:(

Overall it was a great experience and our server was fantastic. I will most definitely return to try EVERYTHING else on the menu. 

Highly recommend.
author: Kris M.

description:
Came here today for lunch before our trip to the Exploratorium! We had a 11:45 am reservation, but it wasn't really needed because they were quite empty when the restaurant just opened on Saturday morning. We sat in their outdoor patio area (which is covered during the winter months) and still heated!  Ordered the following:

1) paella (family-size portion) $45; flavorful and came out in 20-30 minutes of waiting. They had a good amount of seafood sprinkled on top (clams, shrimp, carrots, chorizo, etc.)
2) patatas bravas (tapas) $8 - tiny potato balls, delicious and crispy!
3) pulpo (small portion) $14 - wish this was larger in size, but the octopus was lightly flavored w/ some type of chili oil; we asked for lime slices to give it a kick.

All of the items we got were delicious for the most part, with our favorite being the paella! It was just enough food for 2 adults + 1 toddler, so we were happy. 

We parked in the Pier 19 parking structure for $15 since we were going to visit the Exploratorium. Very friendly wait staff!
author: Yonnie C.

description:
This place has been on my bookmark for years now since my friends kept raving about this place. Its located in the Pier area in SF so parking can be a bit tough. We circled around a few times and we scored free street parking. The restaurant last a large patio and indoor seating but it gets packed so I recommend making reservations.

Since this is a tapas place, its meant to be shared. We got:

Patatas Bravas - this is a MUST get. Pretty amazing and flavorful. Didn't know potatoes could be this tasty.

Croquetas de Pollo - Deep fried goodness.

Bikini - This was our least favorite dish. The cheese overpowered everything and pair with the eggplant there was no texture.

Gambas Negras - Really flavorful and really garlicky dish!

Pulpo a la Parilla - Really tender and flavorful. One of the top octopus dishes I've had

Mar y Montaña - Uni with Jamon Iberico?! Enough said.

Definitely recommend this place for a date, foodies or tourists. Worth the hassle of driving in.
author: Juan F.

description:
The best way to describe Coqueta along San Francisco's beautiful waterfront: Delectable and interesting Spanish tapas and pretty exorbitant prices. But you're in San Francisco should this is the new reality and with a stunning destination like the reclaimed Pier that Coqueta makes its home, you better believe you are paying for the ambiance in addition to the food they serve. I went to Coqueta only once before, when Chef Michael Chiarello first opening his newest jewel a few years ago and I remembered seeing him cook in the small open kitchen and then walk around and greet his diners. Those days are long gone, but what isn't gone is the large crowds that arrive night in and night out. 

This time around, a friend asked where would I like to eat, and knowing it was a Saturday night, and I was taking BART across the bay, one of the easiest places to get a unique meal was back at Coqueta. With a 7:30pm reservation in hand, we made our way there, once again forgetting that their small entrance is right where the glass of their interior bar meets the cement blocks of where their main dining room and open kitchen resides. With our 7:30pm reservation, the best we could do is get two seats at the bar and I really liked sitting there as opposed to a small two top table because we could see all the cooking going on and you could see some of their handmade Pintxos, otherwise known as bite-size skewers, up close ready to be cooked over a flame. And judging by the size of those small little skewers we already knew we did not want to order those!

But first we knew we were deciding on cocktails as the bar makes some of the most unique drinks along the bay, with mojitos and margaritas in check filled with lots of visually tantalizing things like edible wildflowers you couldn't go wrong. My dining companion wanted something summery and was thrilled with the price of their Sangria made with red wine, manzanilla sherry, citrus, ginger berries, chamomile and local apples at 9 dollars a glass you couldn't beat this house recipe. I was looking for something more exotic, so I decided to go with the Beso de Carca made with Pueblo Viejo Blanco, lime, raspberry-jalapeno sugar Rose "Air" it was a smooth and spicy cocktail that went down just right at an affordable 12 dollars a glass.

For our dinner, they have a lot of choices on the menu at Coqueta that perfectly encompass what it's like to dine in Spain, from sliced cured meats to Iberian cheeses to Pintxos otherwise known as bite-size skewers they seem to be a fully realized concept that takes you to Spain and back. From their Hot Tapas menu we decided to go with the "Sunny side-up" Huevo with shrimp, crispy potato, garlic chips, pine nuts and topped with chili de arbol and chorizo dressing and the Albondigas a la Feria which were duck and pork meatballs with tart cherry-tempranillo salsa and crispy shallots. Both dishes were prepared with such detail, the sunny side up huevo was a rich breakfast dish made especially for dinner and the meatballs were tart yet tasty. For our entree, my dining mate and I decided to split the Lubina a la Brasa which is a wood grilled and semi-boneless Branzino with Manzanilla olive and preserved meyer lemon salsa paired with the Ensalada de Kale which had Lacinto Kale, cana de Cabra, pistachio, tangerine confitura, pickled green strawberries with warm fresh fava and English pea dressing. The branzino was seasoned so well and cooked to perfection and the saltiness of the fish went well with the tartness of the lemon salsa and it paired perfectly with the kale salad. In fact, it was one of the best salads I have ever tasted, yes it was that good.

Coqueta lives up the billing as a unique places for authentic tapas on San Francisco's Embarcadero. For a Saturday night in the freezing cold of winter, the place was packed. We loved sitting on the counter, although we didn't get a great view of the open kitchen, as we literally looked at raw skewers in a glass case, they still had a great energy with all those people inside. It was a little hard to move around but a fun experience nonetheless. I would consider returning for a special occasion as the prices are pretty high for the amount of food you get on your dish. But the menu is well-conceived and prepared with a lot of flavor and for that I think Coqueta is the jewel along San Francisco Bay.
author: Jason F.

description: Exorbitant priced drinks, $20 for a gin and tonic? give me a break! Food is tasty but overpriced and the staff are nice but lost. Lots of staff but slow service.
author: Sheila J.

description: Such a great experience! Jose Luis (Sexy Luis) and his team gave us exceptional experience!!! He is so talented and put love into his drinks! Thank you for some amazing drinks!
author: Mo R.

description:
If you're looking for a place with a great ambiance and tapas-style dishes, Coqueta needs to be on your list.

Two of our friends from Seattle have told us that they, literally, have flown to SF just to eat at Coqueta because they enjoyed the food so much. These same two friends decided to take us and enlighten us to the magnificence of Coqueta during their most recent trip to the Bay.

We made a reservation for a party of 4. We were a bit early, so we just grabbed a couple of drinks -- all of the mojitos are excellent -- and relaxed in the bar area. (There are also a couple of outdoor tables that appear to be first come, first served if you're willing to brave some of the strong ocean breezes.)

When we were seated, we mulled over the menu and decided upon
- El Gran Plat Cap - chef's selection of cured meats and cheeses
- Huevos de Codorniz - quail egg "diablo", pickled mustard seed and jamón serrano
- Pulpo a la Parrilla - wood grilled Mediterranean octopus
- "Sunny side-up" Huevo
- Paella (which takes 30-40 minutes to prepare, so order as soon as you sit down if possible)
- Churros "fantasia" - churros with hot drinking chocolate
- Sangria
- A bottle of white wine whose name is escaping my head at the moment

Everything, seriously EVERYTHING, was on point. My favorites were the grilled octopus, paella, and the churros. Flavors are so perfectly balanced in everything, and the portions are perfect for sharing. The sangria and wine also paired so amazingly with the food.

The price range scales a bit more towards the higher end, even for SF. But the restaurant is situated on the pier and serves up awesomely nomworthy food. Totally worth it.

Bonus fact that I just learned: this is a Michael Chiarello restaurant?! I grew up watching his shows on Food Network.
author: Yvonne K.

description:
Very nice..

Not your typical authentic tapas yet nice..
Gambas, Ensalada de Kale, Goucho, all a good pick!
author: Head Chef F.

description:
UPDATE! Finally was able to come here for dinner(&sober), still sooo good! Chose a few of the same items from the first couple times I came here& amazing they are.

Not sure of the names of the plates but my favorite one has a fried egg& shrimp. 

Let me not forget, our waiter was very helpful and polite, also very quick with service. I will definitely be back again soon!
author: Ashley J.

description: Have never had a proper sit down meal here but love this restaurant and location. I look forward to those few hours of the day when it's sunny enough to sit outside at a high table and have a couple of drinks and appetizers. They have good charcuterie and skewers. Cocktails are good as well, sangria is a big on the sweet side. The service is hit or miss. The servers always seems to be running around frantically even when the place isn't very busy.
author: Yin H.

description:
View/ambiance: 5/5
Food: 4/5
Value: 3/5
Drinks: 5/5

Definitely a place you come to for the view, but which also happens to have good food that is overpriced but you are willing to shell out cuz of aforementioned view/vibe. Recommend the grilled octopus. The vermouth based drinks are delicious!
author: Michelle R.

description: Perfect place to have good food in good company. Their tapas taste great and the same can be said for their homemade sangria. Can get a little busy, but that's probably because everybody wants to eat here :).
author: Ludwig D.

description: I would recommend their Iberico Ham, Asparagus dish, and the paella. The food was absolutely delicious, the service was great. A tapas place I would definitely come back to dine again.
author: Rene C.

description:
Wait to get a seat at the bar is not so bad. All the tapas, wine and cheese board - YUMMY. Way tastier than it appears!!! Thanks!

I'd come back.
author: Pam L.

description:
We have been going to coqueta for a while now. We are very familiar with the menu and know what to order. The service is usually good but we've had some hits and misses here and there.
There was a change in the kitchen management as Jeffrey took off to ROOH but we have started to build a relationship with the new team. 

Please remember to ask for their specials as the servers usually tend to forget to offer you that! If they offer the scallop special, order them. They don't disappoint. 

What we usually order: 

Patatas bravas 
Octopus 
Branzino 
Pork

Tip: although they usually push for the side items with your main dish, we haven't had much luck finding a side dish that we absolutely love and thought was worth the price. For $14 side of mushrooms we usually opt in for another order of the octopus that we love. 

Their hot part of the menu is available after 5 pm so if you are there early make sure to stick around till 5. 

As for dessert, our favorite is afogato which is coffee with a scoop of vanilla ice cream. Pretty tasty !
author: Dan P.

description: The food is mediocre and overpriced. Not recommended if you are looking for big wow. The appetizer grill octopus is an highlight but I'm totally disappointed with their Seafood Paella since they only has 4 shrimps and 6 clams inside rice
author: Jerry Y.

description:
Coqueta features many authentic Catalan and Spanish tapas dishes that are sure to make you miss that trip you took to Barcelona 2 years ago, or long for a vacation in Spain. It's on the expensive side for tapas, which is the only caveat, in my opinion. (There are cheaper places in the Mission.) But it's a classy on the San Francisco Embarcadero, so what do you expect?

It's recommended to make a reservation as this restaurant can get VERY busy, especially on weekend nights. While waiting to be seated, feel free to grab a drink in the bar area and consult the friendly and knowledgeable bar staff if you're unsure of what to get (or if you'd like to switch out the gin to something in their drinks as the majority of their specialty cocktails use gin).

My biggest recommendations for the tapas dishes are the patatas bravas (fried potato dressed with garlic aioli on top and plated in a cute, circular fashion around a hearty tomato-like brava salsa), padron peppers (green shishito-like peppers covered served with tiny strips of jamon with a delectable vinegar and seasoning to give it a bright, lightly spicy flavor), and pulpo (grilled octopus served with fresh potato and covered with a delicious olive oil to complement the pulpo's flavor).

Overall, highly recommend Coqueta if you're able to make a reservation and afford the high price. Do some research on your traditional tapas dishes before coming here to figure out what you'd like to order. Don't be scared to try something you don't eat often!
author: Phillip V.

description:
Welllllllllll I have a confession Snapchat has taken over my need to Yelp but our impromptu meal here the other night has brought me back to my roots! 

Soooo after an early evening perusing the strip clubs on Broadway my main lady and I were hungry and I wanted Zarzuela but they close at 10 and Yelp led us to Coqueta. 

We sat ourselves on the bar side of the restaurant and enjoyed views of the bridge and people watching the late night crowd on the Embarcadero. 

We ordered white sangria which was so yummy and came out fast. 

I ordered for us and we had the potatoes, the chicken croquettes, the pork and duck meatballs, the octopus and for dessert the churros and cheesecake. 

Everything was great! Food came out fast, presented perfectly as tapas can be and service was efficient and nice. $85 bucks for two people before tip is fair to me! We will definitely repeat.
author: Anne C.

description:
$100/person later and I'm still hungry. Not "I could still eat", but actually hungry. There were just so many little things wrong with that meal that added up to a culmination of pure disappointment. It's that feeling you get when you go to an obviously tourist-trap, price-gouging restaurant in a foreign country.. except this time, it was in my own hometown, with the extra cost funding the rent for the tourist-hotbed location, or perhaps the chef's legal fees from some appalling sexual harassment claims.

Pintxos were okay. Drinks were average but expensive. Patatas bravas were great, and the pulpos (octopus) tender but tiny. The gambas negras (shrimp) was good, but it comes out to $5 a shrimp.
