We were suppose to get the sunny heuvo which the server recommended but that tapa never came out instead they took it off the check and brought out our paella.

Paella:4/5: I actually liked this dish. Sit was flavorful and tasty. It looks like a lot of toppings are on top but not really, it's actually more rice than toppings. I did enjoy the shrimp, clams and veggies on top. 

This place was just ok, I probably wouldn't come back anytime soon. But I would give this place a second try in the future and hopefully it tastes better. 

Total for 2 with tip: $120
author: Stella J.

description:
TLTR;  

1) Poor Customer Service & Management (Johnny the Manager - made up some lie about not having eggs to be able to make scrambled eggs....What's in your Sunny Side Up dish??
2) Tiny/Small servings 
3) Tasteless Food
4) Diva Chef - Not about making his customers happy, but rather preserving his "signature" dishes that no one would notice a difference one way or the other 
5) Chef's way or the highway 
6) Not vegan or vegetarian friendly AT ALL 

The one star is for the interior designer who set this place up. Outside of that, I had a very disappointing experience here. The menu is very limited and if you are hungry and looking to satisfy your cravings, this is NOT the place for you. This is a place where the chef is a diva and management is rude. Management lied straight to my face and said they do not have eggs to make a simple scrambled eggs (however how did they make the Sunny Side Up Huevos dish right next to me? - it was a straight faced lie). They literally had the manager come out all to tell me that the chef will NOT make any changes to his "signature" dish and that my request to take out all of the "fun" stuff (the dead pig and shrimp) would not be entertained. I was completely offended. For him to insult me and use the word "fun" to describe the dead animals in the food is absolutely ridiculous. A simple "no" would have been fine. The chef here is clearly not out to please his customers (who are paying over priced for this tiny food plates) This place was an absolute disappointment - The food that we did end up eating/ordering was so small and tiny and tasteless. I will never go back to this place!
author: Tiana B.

description:
Had been wanting to try this place for a while and finally lucked out with a Saturday reservation at a reasonable time.  The restaurant itself is very trendy and attractive.  We had:
- Pintxos (3/5) - We tried all five of these skewers, and they were all fine, but not memorable
- Lardo and uni "sandwich" (3/5) - The lardo and uni were great, but they were placed atop a toasted, crunchy mini-bagel that crumbled apart with one bite, which detracted from the dish
- Mushrooms (5/5) - Well seasoned with a great range of different textures due to the different cuts.
- Duck and pork meatballs (4/5) - Really soft and moist meatballs that fall apart (in a good way), with a unique flavor
- Branzino (3/5) - Nicely grilled fish
- Deviled eggs (3/5) 
- Arroz con leche cake (3/5) - I think the menu indicated there was supposed to be something molten inside but there was nothing molten about it.

Very nice ambiance and good service.  Certainly glad we tried it.  But the food wasn't clearly better than other tapas places in SF...
author: Simon L.

description:
Coqueta was a lovely experience for me and my girlfriends. We got paella and three tapas and it was plenty of food for us three. 

**Salmon ahumado: this was probably the best plate we got. It was a generous amount of smoked salmon and all the flavors blended in perfectly.
**Croquetas de pollo: it was good, but nothing memorable. Nothing memorable as in I literally cannot remember how it tasted like so neither horrible nor fantastic. 
**Albondigas a la feria: it had a very strong wine taste. I couldn't really taste anything else but the wine. 

Most importantly, their customer service was excellent. every interaction we had with any server left a positive impact. 

I'm reserving the fifth star because I didn't LOVE everything I got. But I know they have plenty of tapas to offer so I'll definitely be back!
author: Becky M.

description: Love this place SO MUCH! It is a staple when I come to the city. The tapas are absolutely delicious. You must try the mar y montaña and the smoked salmon. Their sangria is so tasty. If you sit at the bar inside you can watch the chefs. They also have outdoor seating and are right on the water. Seriously, you won't regret coming here!
author: Julianna S.

description: I want to start with Marco in the bar and the bartender too - whose name I unfortunately didn't get. It was a Friday at 6:20. I was waiting for a friend and dinner reservations. It's easy when it's that crowded to not get to everyone, especially people (me) standing in the center. Marco was amazing and took time to come over and take an order - the bartender made sure I was taken care of too. It was a great start to a night that got even better. Our waitress was wonderful. We just put our evening in her hands and she kept coming back with dish after dish and recommendations that were perfect and to our liking.  What a spectacular evening - thank you to everyone from the hostess to Marco, the bartender, and our waitress Annel.
author: Sheryl F.

description:
It's an awesome place, love the interiors. Have been wanting to eat here for 3 years but couldn't plan ahead enough to make a reservation.
Was able to walk in today at 1:30pm for lunch. Felt the traditional offerings were good, but nothing great (given the portion size and price). The gambas with huevos rotors was good.
The duck and pork albondigas sounded good but tasted sweet because of the chutney like topping.
I just had an EXCELLENT paella in Manila and felt that the chef recommended paella wasn't anything great unfortunately.
$123 for 2 people: 5 one to two bite apps plus paella and drinks.
author: Cay A.

description:
I've walked by this place so many times and finally stopped to have dinner here because it was the only place open past 10pm. We enjoyed all of the tapas so much and really loved our barça gin and tonics! The drinks are so beautiful and taste just as great.

We had the chicken croquettes, salmon 'sandwiches', deviled eggs, and paella. All were so delicious. Our server was also so accommodating of dietary restrictions. I do wish it wasn't so pricey for the small portions but at least the flavor made it worthwhile. Only thing I didn't quite enjoy was our churro dessert. The raspberry powder that accompanied it was tasty but the churro itself just felt drenched in oil. 

Overall, I'm excited to come back and try more of the menu, but it may have to wait for a special occasion to justify the price. Is there a happy hour here??
author: Anjelica C.

description: I wasn't going to write this review, but I really think people should know how employers treat their employees and gets away with it. We strolled in to Coqueta on a Wednesday evening hoping to sit outside since it was a beautiful day in SF. We couldn't find any seats outside but we were able to grab couple of sits inside the bar area. Gin & tonic was delicious and beautiful presentation. Food was yummy, service was impeccable. Reason for 1 Star is I saw this guy yelling at our waiter in front of other customers and co workers. I later found out that he is the assistant gm of the restaurant. I can't believe that work abuse still exists in this day and age. Nobody deserves a yelling or screaming at work no matter what.
author: Charlotte M.

description:
Get shameless and ask for the dessert menu first. Just do it.

Why? Because Churro Fantasia x Pluma = DIY pork shoulder Mexidonut sandos.

(^_^) Pluma $38 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/coqueta-san-francisco?select=lnQOG4qqY5kezpXNfDcXwA)
(^_^) Croquetas de Pollo $9 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/coqueta-san-francisco?select=SPFONTZhdsoIH7OJ3C6IGg)
(^_^) Setas al Ajillo $10 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/coqueta-san-francisco?select=iatoeOEcI3zAe8CReuorTA)
(^_^) Calamares a la Plancha $10 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/coqueta-san-francisco?select=8l-uQOkZm2forHlzsXQ5xQ)
(^_^) Cubiertos $0 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/coqueta-san-francisco?select=wf9SobuVUtpZXBPg4xSHmw)

(-_-) Albondigas a la Feria $12 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/coqueta-san-francisco?select=HiXFcirEjTEIjHG9DwyUQw)
(-_-) Mar y Montaña $14 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/coqueta-san-francisco?select=cosXqOmzEqGsm8dwiX2fqA)
(-_-) Iced Tea $3 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/coqueta-san-francisco?select=L_I16jpUX9mW6sDZinUkMw)

(v_v) Huevos de Codorniz $2.5 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/coqueta-san-francisco?select=bvhcQ5OIMfQctV2LiXWsiw)
(v_v) Tortilla de Esparragos $2.5 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/coqueta-san-francisco?select=VZptWTjPDwBR1BLQOiugrQ)
author: Dan B.

description:
Bizarre experience at a place I used to really enjoy. Tonight was a miss.

Have gone here several times for business lunches, casual corporate dinners and for social time with friends. The menu has good variety, and the food is pretty good, not James Beard, but tasty. They have a decent cocktails, beer and wine selection. I like the ambience on the Embarcadero, the shared concept, and usually the service is good, so I usually have a fun time here. I have always had a nice lunch or dinner here and leave happy and have turned several people on to this restaurant. 

However, tonight, it was very disappointing. Had a 5:30PM early dinner res.  The check was dropped despite we had not asked for it, and ordered another drink.  Not an issue, we were served, but then shortly asked to move. What restaurant moves you at the tail end of your dining experience from the restaurant to the dark, cold bar section on the other end? Again, we had a reservation, which were 2 barstool seats at the bar in the restaurant (yes, NOT EVEN a table). We both found it odd that we were asked to move to the back bar, even though there were 4-5 other barstool seats open in the restaurant. We were very civilized and we assumed it was for a future seating, but we did see other open spots....

When we followed the instruction of our wait server we moved to the Bar which was a different section of the restaurant. As we were about to grab a stool, they told us we can't sit there. 
It was actually still early after 7, but dinner was still in full swing. It was awkward, disruptive and rude to go from enjoying dinner to having nowhere to sit to finish the meal.  

They sloppily grabbed two stools and placed it by the door in the entry way as a solution. Mind you, it's December on the Embarcadero and we're on the Bay, it's freezing cold! My coat was in coat check and isn't that a fire marshall code violation to have people finishing their meal in the walk way/entry way by the door? We both were so confused and felt that this had to be a mix up and there had to be a different solution. Luckily after realizing what was done, the gentlemen who might have been the manager "allowed us" to sit at the bar after all to complete our dining experience, which went from lovely to awkward. 

I rarely Yelp when I get bad service, however, this was just awkward and a total downer on what was supposed to be a lovely night.  Had to share with others to be aware that this may happen to you.  This is a place where many locals, tourists and nearby folks from East Bay BART in for, or from Marin take the Ferry in to enjoy a meal with friends. I just wished they'd let us finishing enjoying.
author: Grace B.

description: Wow. My husband and I went here on a recommendation, and we were extremely happy! The location is fantastic and the view beautiful of the bay. You definitely need reservations, this place was packed on a Thursday night! We got here early and had a drink at the bar. What a fantastic selection of gin cocktails! I got the conquistador and my husband the cocktail with Iberico infused gin. Mine was very light and fresh with notes of fennel and anise, and his savory with ham and citrus. So different and delicious. We were seated and decided to start with the meat and cheese board. Fantastic selection! It had tomato sauce, marcona almonds, some breads, and an amazing sugar crusted thin bread. We then proceeded to the quail eggs bites that were pickled and had mustard seeds. Freaking delicious. We also had the croquettes and meatballs- both were recommended and both delicious. The duck and pork meatballs were so juicy and had an amazing cherry sauce with bits of fried shallots on top. We shared the pluma- an Iberico pork shoulder loin with honey chili glaze. It was cooked to perfection! Our server recommended the wild mushrooms with chili and garlic. Sooo good. They were perfect alongside the Pluma. It was my husband's birthday, which I mentioned and they brought out the manchego cheesecake bites. It was so amazing. Bits of cheesecake and and carmel corn were fantastic. The only strange thing is, they charged us for it, and we actually didn't order it. We thought they just brought it out on the house. A bit strange, but it was $4 so we shrugged. We ordered the churro donuts with chocolate sauce for our actual dessert. They were chewy and moist! The chocolate sauce was not too rich and added the right amount of sweetness to the donuts. All in all, it was an amazing foodie experience and we definitely put this on our must go back list!
author: Megan S.

description: Fantastic drinks -- the Sutter and the Company particularly. I had the grand charcuterie plate with both meats and cheeses. Everything was delicious, and the view of the water is absolutely fantastic. The bar fills up quickly, so get there early.
author: Loyd B.

description:
2ND ROUND (update)

My favorite place for tasty liberations and tapas. And the first time SUCKING SHRIMP BRAINS OUT OF THE HEAD!

We came here without reservations (on a week night) but it was only just the two of us so it was easy to get a seat. We sat at the bar area which had a nice view of the waterfront and bay bridge. There's something special about breaking bread with those that you are un-explainable connected too. It's one thing to get into deep conversation and then having one teach me how to suck shrimp brains LOL.

BARCA GINTONIC ($13) - bloom London dry gin, fever tree tonic, grapefruit. The presentation is beautiful, tastes good and garnished with flowers. Highly recommend if you looking for something not too sweet.

HOUSE CURED BORQUERONES ($2.50/skewer) - white anchovies, olives, pearl onion, guindilla peppers. This was the tiniest skewer I had in my life but the tastiest. Flavorful to the palate, one can taste each layer and then the anchovy towards the end. Recommend if you want a quick bite of saltiness.

HUEVOS NACIONAL ($7) - devils eggs filled with spring pea, smoked pimento aioli, on pickled saffron potatoes and olive oil pouched bonito. Literally, how fancy can you get with a devils egg?! I've had many variations of a devils egg but nothing like this. We ordered another serving because it was very good. Highly recommend.

GAMBAS EL NEGRO ($14) - olive oil pouched head-on gulf prawns with black and garlic chilli sauce. WOW!!! This was the best dish of the night. The sauce drizzled over the prawns did not look anything special but it was. The was the shrimp was prepared was perfect, not under or over cooked. They say the shrimp head has all the juice and flavor. Was never my thing to peal my own shrimp, let alone, suck a shrimp head. I was missing out all my life. Shrimp head is SO good, it was packed with flavor. The texture reminded me of a very thin purée. The the color was a tan color. Highly recommend!!!!!!

"FANTASIA" de FIDEAU ($15) - puffed vermicelli with gulf prawns, crispy baby octopus, jamon gamba broth en gel, lemon aioli. This was also delicious, however the gulf prawns weren't as exciting as the Gambas el Negro. It was enjoyable to have more than one seafood in the dish. I actually enjoyed the crispy baby squid over the prawns, it picked up the other flavors and added a different flavor to the bite. Recommend.

ALBONDIGAS AL LA FERIA ($14) - grilled duck and pork meatballs with tart cherry and temprannilo salsa, and crispy shallots. Didn't take a bite, I don't eat duck. But from what I've heard, it's delicious!!!! 

PULPO A LA PARILLA ($14) - wood-grilled octopus, fingerling potatoes, pimento olive oil. I'm more into baby octopus than regular octopus. I'm not into anything tentacles but this was a large tentacle. It was very soft to cut into and it has less flavor than a baby octopus but it was still good. Highly recommend.

Will I be back?! Yes!

Until the next review.....
author: Jane A.

description: Great ambiance with petite tapas that happen to melt in your mouth. Enjoyed the red wine sangria with the paella and sunny side up huevos. The cheesecake dessert was definitely worth it
author: Pratik R.

description: This is a review of the bar only.  If someone else is paying, by all means go here.  However if drinks are on your own dime, consider going elsewhere.  The cocktails were mildly interesting, but rather weak and overpriced.  The tapas were comically small.  Also, the service has lots of room for improvement.  Our server was friendly enough, but I don't think ever checked in with us.  I had to flag down someone who was more or less a busboy each time we needed another order.  As soon as I paid, and before I had even gathered my coat, the hostess swooped in to place a "Reserved" sign on our table, with no explanation.  It felt rather tacky, which was surprising given how expensive the place is.
author: Lucullus L.

description:
Every time I walk or run along the Embarcadero I make a mental note to snag a reservation.  I'm ashamed to admit that it took me a year of living in SF before I finally tried Coqueta. Why in the heck did I wait so long and deprive myself of such a fabulous dining experience? Why?  

Reservations are essential here-- the dining area is small and tables are quite limited.  

My friend and I started at Coqueta to have a cocktail or two.  After we enjoyed our cocktails we decided to see if it was possible to score a seat in the dining room.  Luckily for us, the hostess found us a place at the dining room bar facing the kitchen.  

The menu is a delightful celebration of various tapas dishes.  We picked a few hot plates to share and decided to skip the cold snack style plates.  

The octopus and fingerling potatoes were cooked to near perfection.  I commented that the dish could have had more salt, but of course that's an easy fix.  The patatas bravas are essentially uber fancy homemade potato chips.  They were a nice break in the action before the next plate!  The grilled steak (I believe this was a chef special, not a mainstay on the menu) was juicy, well-seasoned, and cooked to perfect medium rare. The verdure a la catalana salad accompanied the steak dish very well.  We finished our meal with the apple pie dessert.  The pie is not a traditional pie slice, rather a small tart.  Nonetheless, the treat was a sweet finish to a fascinating meal.  

I also must mention the drinks!  Ah, the drinks, the glorious drinks!  The cocktail menu contains a robust selection of sweet, spicy, and boozy drinks.  Highlights for me were the Castro and Spanish Holiday-- I took several pictures of our cocktails as they were almost too pretty to drink! 

The plating of all dishes was sublime.  Please take a peek at my photos!  

I will certainly be back to Coqueta.  In fact, I hope to share it with my visiting friends next month!
author: Andrea H.

description: This is an excellent place for dinner. I had the paella with a sangria to wash it down. Both were delicious! The place was crowded but we were able to find seats at the bar and were served almost right away. We started the meal with some great tapas, they have several kinds that are well explained on the menu. The ambiance is noisy but cheerful, and the location overlooks the bay so there is a good view. I would recommend this to anyone who loves Spanish food. My compliments to the chef.
author: Susan M.

description:
Recently I went back to Coqueta and the food was significantly worse than what I remembered in previous visits. The grilled octopus had little flavor; The Albondigas duck and pork meatballs was severely undercooked (I almost gagged eating it) and too salty, the salad was so-so.

Feeling very disappointed that one of my favorite places has deteriorated so much - I hope that the chef will come back to revive this place (otherwise the business will start to dwindle given enough time) if this was a representative night. There are just many other excellent restaurants to flock to in SF to take mediocracy here.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
The food was quite good. Really enjoyed the ambiance - it was not spanish at all though, more like a rustic mountain cabin. Maybe it was inherited from the previous restaurant's decor. 

We arrived a few minutes before our reservation time and were put at the bar area. We ordered some smaller plates to snack on there, then was seated when the table was ready. Some people next to us had their kids with them, and it very quickly became annoying with the kids talking loud next to us. I guess this is not a kid friendly place. 

I posted some food pictures - cauliflower steak was tasty. The pulpo (octopus) was very nicely cooked - smoky on the outside and tender inside. We didn't get the paella though. 

I have to mention the desserts - they were definitely the highlights on the meal! Especially this blue cheese ice cream, it was soooooo good. We just got a scoop of it as a side and it was heaven.
author: Wendy K.

description:
I've been meaning to write this review for the longest time, but I've committed a Yelp felony (not reviewing as actively as I should), thus I shall now try to review all my new favorite spots that have been accumulating for quite some time. 

Coqueta has got to be one of my favorite places to grab a drink in SF. Call me girly but I am a sucker for pretty little flowers garnishing my beverages. And it's not just aesthetically pleasing, the drinks taste good too. 

The first time I came here was to catch up with a BFF for happy hour. I suggested we go to Coqueta after seeing an IG post of a flower drink. We both LOVED it. A lot of San Franciscans do too, it was jam packed on a Friday night. I ordered the Spanish Holiday, my friend ordered the "famous flower drink" which happened to be a gin & tonic (Coqueta version of course), and we shared a cheese platter. Afterwards, we also ordered a party pitcher between the two of us. After we completely devoured and drank every sip of everything, we paid ~$35-40 each (tax and tips included). 

The second time I went to Coqueta, it was to get a quick bite just before my first ever Elite Event (yay!) which was just yesterday. Anyway, I couldn't figure out where to get a quick bite to eat and I really wanted that gin & tonic, so I had to come back. I got bite-sized items to go with my gin & tonic and I ended up ordering a Tariff too. Surprisingly, I think I like the tariff more. But it might be because I'm getting bored of gin tonics recently. I am a million percent certain that I will come to Coqueta again. 

I cannot wait to try the food at the actual restaurant part, and the service is truly exceptional.
author: Denise L.

description:
4.5 stars. 

This is a long overdue review, so I'll keep it short and to the point. 

1. Michael Chiarello is unbelievably dreamy and yolked in person. He came by to chat and his hotness left me tongue-tied. 

2. The cocktails are delicious and artfully presented. 

3. REALLY good tapas. I did not have a single mediocre, let alone bad dish here.

4. Do not skip dessert! The churros and Manchego cheesecake pops are to die for!

I hope to see Chef Chiarello again when I return in the near future. He is truly a beautiful creature who cooks some bomb ass food. Swoon!!!
author: Suany W.

description: Their sangria was the best I've ever had. I was so impressed with the depth of flavor and the presentation to boot! The service was phenomenal. We didn't get a dish we ordered, and we were fine with it, but they brought us adorable individual dulce de leche cakes to apologize. I would come back again for a special occasion.
author: Serena W.

description:
Coqueta translated from Spanish, means flirt, flirty, flirtatious and it is very suitable to its fun name!

I love how it is by the Pier and near the dock!  It simply sets the mood and ambiance on having a splendid time here!  

Their gin and tonics cocktails are so colorfully vibrant and pleasant on sipping while admiring the view of the bay!  You can tell that they put effort in their drinks here!

I do suggest reservations, otherwise, it may take awhile for limited seating and precisely ask for chair support compared to no back support.  It's just uncomfortable without support.  There is a side indoor patio with a bar, which you are more than welcome to dine at as well.  It's open seating so whatever pops up, is available.

We ordered aplenty and to start out, we ordered hot tapas, such as the Patatas Bravas (crispy potatoes with garlic alioli), Pulpo a la Parilla (grilled octopus with fingerling potatoes), Albondigas a la Feria (grilled duck and pork meatballs with crispy shallots all meshed together) and Croquetas de Pollo (like bite sized chicken pot pies served with cured orange).  The presentation for all of their dishes were impressive and displayed the restaurant's name, Coqueta, accurately.  I would say I like the duck and pork meatballs the most and the grilled octopus tapa.

As for their Arroz Cremoso de Verano, which was cooked with saffron bomba rice mixed with tomatoes, squash and corn, was a filler and may feed well over 3 people (counting that you will be ordering up other dishes as well). Do order it up with their mushrooms tapa with grilled seasoning.  It complimented well with the Spanish rice.

Last, but not least, their freshly tossed and fun take on a fruity sorbet, which was made on the spot by a refined expert was eye-entertainment.  The cold steam that was exuding from the Gazpacho iciness was catchy and the sorbet, itself, tasted tarty, delicate and refreshing.

Service was on point and I love the homely Spanish decor of this place!   

Coqueta does offer up a charm that makes you feel giddy inside!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
If you love tapas and want to have a drink or two by the piers then you have to check this place out! The owner of this restaurant has some other ones in yountville which are completely wonderful experiences ! 
We had a couple glasses of Sonoma county wines! After we shared a charcuterie board and headed of to dessert , yum yum the churros and the arroz con leche where delicious !
author: Marilin S.

description:
For my bday we had to try Coqueta as it makes top 100 restaurants in SF, so it has to be good, right? Sure. If you're looking for small bites that won't break the bank, read no more--this is not it. 

Service here is excellent. We chanced the opportunity to eat here as a walk-in at 6pm on a Friday night. They were fully booked but due to a last minute cancellation, the hostess seated us immefiately as long as we agreed to be done in time for an 8pm rezo. Our water cups never went empty, wait staff periodically checked in, and we received a complimentary birthday dish- delectable, little manchego cheesecake bites to share, which were actually really tasty.

Tapas normally add up, especially these, being a few dollars a bite. A few standout dishes include the salmon ahumado with truffle honey --perfect balance of sweet and savory smoked salmon on two slices of crisp baquette and the paella! Oh the four gulf shrimp were so sweet and juicy! That's some pricey shrimp, but the paella was cooked with just the right amount of smokiness and crunchy rice stuck to the bottom of the pan. 

I'm not sure I would be back on a regular basis, but it was worth the visit. Located at the Embarcadero on Pier 5, it has a great view of the water and the rustic interior with the high beam ceilings give an inviting feel. A hip place to take your out of town visitors for drinks and apps after a day at the Wharf.

Overall, I would give it a 3.75, but due to such awesome service, I'll round up to a 4.
author: Amy L.

description:
We really loved our dinner at Coqueta. Went with 4 people which allowed us to try a bunch of different things...highly recommend!

Bests:
Kale salad (with figs I believe, pistachios, fresh garbanzo beans...yum)
Duck and pork meatballs
Croquetas de pollo
Bikini (my very favorite dish of the night!)
Huevo with shrimp, crispy potato, garlic chips, pine nuts
Pork shoulder loin with honey-chili glaze
Churros
House cured chorizo (eaten with an order of manchego)
J & T nonalcoholic drink


Good but not a must-order:
Deviled eggs
Bizcocho de arroz con leche dessert
All the pintxos - I'd probably just skip the pintxos altogether next time. Not great bang-for-your-buck anyway.
Broccoli side

Total came to $250 for 4 people including tax/tips and included a few nonalcoholic drinks.
author: K. D.

description: Coqueta is my place to go for occasions. I never got disappointed. The food is amazing. I went last for my birthday, I booked a table (always book if you want a spot), I didn't like the table we got and after telling them, they nicely find us another table. Service was great.
author: Morea P.

description:
Manager asked why we tipped only 15% - not appropriate! This is the second time it's happened, apparently that's their MO. Again, not appropriate!
Overserved us food that we struggled to finish.
Not coming here again.
author: Ray r.

description:
a) duck meatballs(pass)
b) octopus tentacles(yums)
c) paella(a bit pricey)
d) pork shoulder(yum but pricey)
e) salmon(yums)
f) cheesecake bites(ok)
g) mushroom thingy(just okay)

Overall, I like this place. The food is good but it is pricey(or maybe i'm just cheap). The ambiance and decor is nice. Two thumbs up for the service. I would recommend you make your reservation slightly after sunset so you can enjoy the sunset on the pier prior to pigging out. What are you waiting for?? Make your reservation now
author: Ronald C.

description:
Very much enjoyed my dinner with the Spanish Holiday cocktail. 

Highly recommend the meatballs which were flavorful, moist and cooked perfectly. 

Lovely atmosphere, an excellent date spot, delicious foods and wonderful service. 

Suggest booking in advance.

Would definitely come back. 5 stars - yay!
author: Eunice M.

description:
On business travel I arrived early to find a more or less empty restaurant. That said I was told they couldn't seat me given I was an individual and the restaurant was savings the seats for parties of at least two, including the bar.

Thus while I would like to have commented on the food I never got past reception.
author: Scott S.

description: Drinks at Coqueta are super yummy. I really enjoyed their prawns!! Paella was good, not the best but good. Waiter that helped us was super dry but I appreciated it lol. Will def come back.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
If it weren't for the $200 gift certificate here, my bf and I wouldn't have returned after walking out the first time for being ignored.  However, this time the service was better, and the urban legend of excellent food became a reality.

We chose a seat outside in the sunshine, indulging in our tapas, sipping on sangria and people watching.  We kicked off our feast with the chef's selection of cheeses and cured meats.  I wish I had taken a picture of this plate in all its varietal glory, but I assure you this is one of the best meat and cheese plates ever.  It came with some bri, bleu cheese, a couple slices of bread, tiny bread sticks, bits of  flat bread, fancy Marcona almonds, chorizo, prosciutto and quince cheese or membrillo.  

Next, we ordered the deviled eggs which were an interesting, delectable concoction filled with spring pea and smoked pimentón aioli, topped with tuna on a pickled saffron
potato.  The Abondigas a la Feria (duck & pork meatballs) were pretty good too but not one of my faves.  The tart cherry tempranillo salsa it came with made the meatballs somewhat sweet.  If you're not a fan of sweet meat, this won't be a hit.  The best for us was hands down was the grilled octopus and fingerling potatoes.  The pliability of the octopus made for blissful bites.  We enjoyed this dish so much we ordered another.

Overall, the food totally makes this place and even the ambiance is great with hip lounge music, but the service still needs help.  It wasn't awful, but it wasn't consistent.  The busser was probably the most attentive in keeping our water glasses full and switching out our plates.  Our waitress was personable and nice enough but came out to the tiny patio which wasn't at full capacity multiple times and failed to see our attention directed her way despite the visibility of our empty glasses and pitcher.

Towards the end, the service seemed to improve with various servers coming to our table to ask if we needed anything, but by then, we were finished and tapped out.  That will be our last time there.  It was too much  work to keep having to get a server's attention to order more and have our drinks refilled.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
I had come by a few months ago and wanted to drop in for a quick bite but the bar was full at 5:30 on a Monday. What do people do in the City where they can have happy hour so early. So I decided to go somewhere else instead and make reservations online instead. 

Even reservations for one were hard to make, but alas I found a day that worked with my schedule and headed out to the beautiful Embarcadero restaurant for dinner. I was offered a seat at the chef's counter - amazing!

I started with the Castro (fitting since I live in the neighborhood and love tequila). It was like a spicy margarita which I actually really enjoyed. It wasn't a hard spice that was on your palate all the time; it was more light and refreshing with a sprinkle of spice from the pepper which I enjoyed. 

Foodwise I decided to go with their recommended 2-3 tapas per person. I started with the pinxto which are these small bar bites that were recommended highly. I ordered all 5 that were available since I wanted to try everything. My two favorite were probably the one with the quail egg because it had this great flavor and felt bigger than the other bites and the chorizo with artichokes and peppers. The other three weren't bad, just not my favorites. 

I ended up getting two more tapas since the above were really just 5 small bites. I got the meatballs and the croquetas based on the suggestions of yelp. The meatballs were so delicious. After having these meatballs that were mostly made with duck and some pork now I realize I must have all meatballs that have duck in it. It's so juicy and the little bit of cherry salsa they had on top was such a great counterpoint to cut into the fattiness. The croquetas were mini chicken pot pies and I've had some bad ones before but these were so good. Breaded and fried, the inside was still so moist and had a bit of that chicken pot pie broth that everyone loves. 

I ended up having to get dessert because the churros just looked so good. The kitchen staff/my waitress was so sweet and also gave me two additions (the strawberry gelatina and the manchego cheesecake with caramel popcorn). They were interesting and the strawberry was definitely my favorite. I'm all for mixing a bit of savory into my sweet but the cheese in the cheesecake bite was just slightly too pungent for me. Overall though so kind for them to add those to my dish!

At the end of the night, it was a wonderful meal (slightly on the pricy side), and I had a great experience with the staff. 

Protip: Pinxtos and sit at the chef's counter if you can. It's amazing to watch them work and be able to converse with the chef as well.
author: Nina Y.

description: Maybe its the items that were chosen and the fact that I wasnt able to pick but this isnt my favorite tapas place. I had some salmon on bagel, cheese platter, uni roll, greens, duck meatballs, octopus, shrimp and egg plate, paella, and this blueberry dessert, and churro. Nothing really stuck out to me other than the greens. It came out to be $250 including tip for six people and 10 litto plates and some drinks. This is located at Pier 5 so after you can take a nice stroll along the wharf which is nice.
author: Amy H.

description: I absolutely love Coqueta. The salmon with truffle honey is amazing, and you won't be disappointed by any of their tapas. Fantastic for dinner, but I also like stopping here for happy hour. Just make sure to come early as they fill up quickly.
author: Natalie S.

description: 5 stars for Coqueta! Had what I, and the group that was with me, would consider a phenomenal meal. This place is great if you like tapas and/or if you're with a group. We tried 5 or 6 items on the menu and all were full of diverse flavors. Our servers poured basque-style calimotxo in our quirky copper  cups, while we enjoyed artfully crafted tapas. All of the tapas were very different and served to perfection. Favorites at our table were the pork shoulder, brioche with eggplant, and chicken croquetas.
author: John R.

description: Perfect location for Delicious Spanish food & jamón iberco infused drinks on the with a nice view on the water. One of the best paellas I've had the pleasure of tasting. Perfect date spot especially in the glass-encased bar. Take a little walk after to enjoy the views.
author: Kristy F.

description:
My team came here for a business lunch and it was surprisingly not crowded. I need to come here for lunch more often! 

I love everything about this place and really wish I could try the whole menu but this is what I've tried and loved so far 


Sausage trio- blood sausage was surprisingly good 
Croquettes - fried heaven 
Patatas Bravas- delicious and unlike the typical style I've had
Meatballs- amazing! 
Brioche tapa- I forget the exact name but it had goat cheese so its an automatic win 
Desserts- get the cheesecake bites!
author: Daniela J.

description: Went to Coqueta for my birthday dinner, which was my second time dining there. The one dish everyone was looking forward to, and I highly recommended,  was of course the pork shoulder so we ordered 2. When it arrived, everyone grabbed a piece quickly and were super excited. Sadly, the meat was cold. We're guessing it had been sitting out for about 20 mins longer than it needed to. Cold meat is just not delicious no matter how good the quality is. Everyone was disappointed but at that point, we couldn't send it back since it was mostly eaten already. The prawns were overcooked and mushy and the bread/toast that came under the uni was way too hard and stale. The paella was not that impressive as it didn't have much flavor. The only good dishes were the peppers, croquetas, and the octopus. Then when the meal was done and the table was cleared, our server (who everyone at our table thought had the fakest smile ever) came to our table to double check that we were aware of the $5/pp cake cutting fee. My girlfriend was mortified. She had went through all the trouble of trying to make the cake a surprise, and the hostess had already made her aware of the fee when the cake was secretly given to them, our server still managed to ruin everything. When dining in restaurants, most birthday cakes and desserts come out as a surprise, so I would think someone who works in the service industry should know this?!  After this experience I don't know if I'll go back, and would be hesitant to recommend my friends try Coqueta.
author: Julie Y.

description: We were excited to try out Michael Chiarello restaurant on my husband's birthday. I called in the daytime to make reservations but they informed us they were fully occupied. However, we could sit near the bar area with our baby and order the same food served in the restaurant. We tried two tapa's which were Octopus and Shrimp. They were delicious. The paella was okay but it came with two types of sauces which was interesting. Next time, I'll go there then will try out different tapa's. Overall, the service and food was good. Definitely, going back here.
author: Ashi C.

description:
I was a bit disappointed with Coqueta. My +1 and I decided to snack here and get some light eating in before heading to the hornblower cruise event as it was very close by. 

We basically sat ourselves and it took me to getting up and walking to a waiter for them to acknowledge us and give us a menu and water. 

We ordered:
*sunny side up huevo* - you're suppose to break the egg and mix it all up. This was just okay. There's a kick to the dish, which I liked, but there was nothing special.
*grilled octopus* - after seeing the raves on this dish, I was a bit disappointed. The octopus was on the chewier end and tasted kind of bland, with sauce very similar to the sunny side up huevo.
*lemonade*- mixed with rosemary and accompanied by blueberries. This was sadly the best thing there. The herb infused and paired surprisingly well with the lemonade (I would have never imagined)! I'd skip this place though. Pricey, below average service & extremely small not-memorable tapas.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
Coqueta is one of my newer favorites in San Francisco.  Labeling something as a 'favorite' is really difficult for me- such a restaurant must be the following-

-Delicious- and serving things I can't make at home!
-Hassle free- from reservations to parking
-Experience matches the price-tag

Coqueta delivers on all fronts.  From 'salt air' margaritas to the final chocolate-dipped churros- Coqueta brings great food and service together in a special location along the waterfront. 

Despite being located across the city from my home, I enjoy the visit as I know the parking is not problematic on the Embarcadero and with a paid lot across the street as a fall-back.  And once you are settled in the food will hit you in waves.  We've ordered wide cross-sections of the menus, and they have been winners.  And most importantly- they have been great with kids- and our daughter has eaten well and without fuss from 2yrs old on...

We love this restaurant so much it has become a place for family celebrations with kids, date nights without the kids, and rendezvous's with out of town friends- so that said, I'll be back for sure.
author: Andy S.

description:
Yum!! Yum!! Great atmosphere. I sat at the bar. Ordered the most delish red sangria. The patio bar has an amazing view and the severs are great. Love the community table at the middle. 
Then came the octopus tapas. I wish I would have ordered two. So yummy and well cooked. I'm coming back here for sure.
author: Carla G.

description: My dining experience at Coqueta was perfect. We had reservations for a group of 8 and were seated in the covered outdoor section at a long bar top. Our server was top notch and explained the menu to us and made suggestions. Everything is served family style to share but he was thoughtful enough to make sure there were 8 bites for each person to have on the smaller tapas plates. The charcuterie and cheese board we started with was delicious with my favorite being the aged bleu cheese. Best cheese I've ever had! We also had the heirloom tomato salad (fresh), the octopus tapas plate (delicious), and the huevos rancheros tapa plate (tasty). For our entree, we split the rib eye steak which was prepared medium rare and was amazing! We also ordered 2 plates of paella which was good. For dessert, churros with cinnamon gelato which was freakin tasty. The server also gave us butterscotch cheese cake bites to celebrate my girl's birthday. So sweet! Overall, the food and service were excellent and Coqueta was the perfect spot for our group dinner.
author: Mymy N.

description:
8/30/15: What a beautiful meal!!!  After bringing some friends to the Ferry Building to check stuff out we took out our handy Yelp machines and brought up this place.  So happy to have came--everything was amazingly beautiful.  Food was really great.  And the service was amazing!--the place was full but every waitress and server was so polite and happy, and even encouraged me to take more photos! (and I soooo did!  it was so easy to make everything look great--check my pics out!)

1. Sangria (White Win, Roasted Apples, Spices, House Recipe) 750ml Porron $36:  Despite the involved craft, the taste was not as complex as I was hoping.  It was of course good tasting as expected, but probably not as amazing as the description.  5/10.

2. Salmon Ahumado $8:  Ha ha, so they called this an "open face sandwich" but seriously, just call it an hors d oeuvre!  Anyway, these will probably be some of the best smoked salmon hors d'oeuvres you've ever seen.  The honey makes it taste a lot more special.  7/10.

3. Huevos Nacional $7:  Like many of the others, this is a masterfully re-envisioned version of a traditional dish.  Never had any deviled eggs like this!  Stuffed with spring peas and smoked pimenton alioli they say.  Very unique.  8/10.

4. Patatas Bravas $8:  Hmmm, very interesting one here.  I would say this would kinda be like an ultra fancy version of tater tots, you know, if you used purple potatoes, smoked them, and made up a fancy dip.  You do taste the special taste of the fresh and fancy potatoes, but personally to me I'd go for a bit more kick.  Sauce is very slightly hot, but barely--could use a bit more heat.  The meat looks beautiful though!  7/10.

5. Croquetas de Pollo $9:  Mmmmmm.... kinda reminds me of similar creations from Porto's in Glendale, but for 2x the price, ha ha.  Probably would fall in the "comfort food" category.  Tastes yummy though!  7/10.

6. Albondigas a la Feria $14:  The most unique and complex meatballs I've ever had.  The meat is very soft and juicy on the inside, and though does resemble an Italian meatball, somehow manages to taste and feel totally different!  The outside flavor and sauce is quite strong and distinct.  I think for my personal taste I could use a slightly toned-down version so I could taste the amazing and delicate meat inside, but as is, still amazing.  And of course, they looked spectacular--never seen meatballs look so amazing!  10/10

7. "Bikini" Brioche $10:  Like an ultra-fancy vegetarian grilled-cheese sandwich, cooked to perfection.  The bread was perfect--lightly crispy on the outside and very moist and soft in the middle, with the eggplant adding a soft but comforting texture.  And of course all the cheesy goodness.  Mmm.  Unfortunately I totally forgot about the cooked peaches on the side 'till I finished the sandwich, so I ate them separately, which were great too.  8/10.

8. Mar y montana, sea and mountain $14:  Holy crap.  I've never seen sea urchin (uni) outside of Japanese and other Asian cuisines.  I'm so glad we tried this--totally beats the pants of typical uni sushi.  The uni is great--maybe not the very fanciest and freshest out there, but definite quite good quality.  But the fact that they somehow incorporated their fancy house-shaved cured meat along with some other melty-goody stuff, man, this is a totally uniquely top-notch dish!  10/10

9. Paella (vegetarian + seafood on the side) $45:  This a seafood paella but my friend doesn't like shellfish so the waitress was very quick to suggest they could make a vegetarian version and then put all the whole shrimps, clams, and pork sausage on the side.  It wasn't on the menu, but I get the impression they can modify any of the dishes as needed since they also made some adjustments on the previous orders in respect to portions.  That's really great of them.  Anyway, as for the paella, I haven't had too many over my life, but maybe it's the fact that they separated all the meat, but I feel there could be more flavor in the main rice.  The shrimp however was amazing!--so much char flavor and completely perfectly cooked such that the meat is cooked JUST enough to not be raw, and wish some good brains left for you to suck.  Maybe some of the best shrimp I've ever had!  Clams were a little meh though.  Sausage was dense artisan type.  I dunno... I think the vegetarian thing really hurt them, so I'm gonna give them the benefit of the doubt that if cooked properly it would have been better.  7/10.

10. Churro "Fantasia" $8:  Of course, you guessed it, churros done fancy.  Unfortunately, I didnt't quite like the texture.  The outside is wonderfully crisped, but the core was kinda overly soft.  Flavor was great though, but unlike the others maybe somewhat traditional.  The drinking chocolate was good but could use more spice.  The sour powder was badass though--great kick.  5/10.

Works of art to eat.  Wonderful service.  Totally amazing experience.

5/5

#tapas #spanish
author: Dean C.

description:
Yum!! I'm truly satisfied with this spot. Great place for brunch! It's in such a great location at the Embarcadero with outdoor seating. Super cute and great views.. of course great food too! Everything if tapas style just the way i like it. 

Food:
Uni & Jamon - Great starter
Duck Meatballs were so tasty! Comes with 3 peices
Prawns with garlic sauce was so good too! Had to get more bread to dip the oily sauce with it
Deviled eggs - what beautiful looking eggs
Manchego cheesecake bites for dessert is a must! 
Churros was good too

Definitely coming back to try the paella and have some alcohol
author: Christine T.

description:
This place is my absolute favorite. We order a bunch of stuff off the menu and not one thing tasted bad. The bikini is amazingggggg and everything else's is just perfect. 
Will be coming back
author: Michel G.

description:
Our evening at Coqueta was colored by the more than absent service.  We found out much later that our server had had a very distracting issue and had to leave, but in the meantime we were rushed through part of our meal and then had to wait a very long time for our last dish (for which one of the staff (manager? he did not tell us who he was) offered us complementary desserts.)  We ordered cocktails but not until we were nearly ready to leave were we asked if we wanted another drink - we weren't even offered a wine list (I work in the wine industry so was particularly dismayed).

Apart from this, the food is good.  The room is modern but cozy. The music a bit loud.  There are better options.
author: Liz C.

description:
Great place to go at evening for wine and small tapas with a beautiful view.

Wine comes in a cute little personal decanter!!
author: Hanna L.

description: One of my favorite tapas places in the city - it serves delicious small plates that are delightful and delicately made with good balance in taste. The smoked salmon toast with truffle honey and cheese is one of my favorites, so is their meatballs. A little on the pricey side but worthwhile. Great for big groups but you'll need to call in advance for reservations.
author: Min S.

description:
Have been going to Coqueta for years for the amazing cocktails.

Recently I went for dinner and there was a bit of a delay because of a private party taking longer than expected and the manager, Daniel, decided to comp a round of drinks and some appetizers for us - exceptional service!
author: Basil S.

description:
The cocktails were AMAZING.  Unique takes on old classics.  I got a gin and tonic with grapefruit and pine.  Refreshing and delightful!

We started with the Patatas Bravas, which were the best I've ever had. Little potatoes  lightly smoked, encrusted with salt crystals, and served with a garlic alioli and smoked paprika sauce. The Croquetas de Pollo were served with a sliver of cara cara orange.  Very tasty, like nothing I've had before. The "Sunny side-up" Huevo With Shrimp were in a sauce that had lots of little chunks of chorizo, topped with a sunny side egg that oozed over the whole dish. 

The Arroz Cremoso really stood out to me. It was a saffron rice in a cauliflower-corn sauce -- think soupy risotto where the cauliflower has been pureed and with sweet summer corn swimming in it. Absolutely heavenly!

Skip the deviled eggs and "bite sized" Chorizo Skewer. The chorizo was cold and the skewer was teeny tiny.

For dessert the Churro 'Fantasia' was freshly made, rolled in cinnamon sugar, and served with a side of melted chocolate.  OMG so good.  I didn't care for the Flan Española; it was so creamy and rich, but I expect my flan to be more egg-y.  

Reservations are not too difficult to get if you're willing to eat a little early.  We got a 5 pm reservation 3 weeks out.  I will definitely be heading back to Coqueta to try more tapas...and to get the Arroz Cremoso again!
author: Jaching H.

description: Beautiful place. All who work there are kind, attentive, highly professional and a lot of fun! :) What a great dinner! :) For those who are gluten free and vegan you have options. The staff are very willing to help you find what is right for you! :)
author: Sue S.

description:
Coqueta is a special place, located on on Embarcadero waterfront.

The building itself is very cool.   The bar section has lots of windows windows with views of the bay.   The dining room is very inviting, with open kitchen and interesting design details and decor.   It's also conveniently located next to the Waterfront restaurant, which is a great place for a pre-dinner cocktail.

The menu features Spanish inspired tapas and family style offerings.   This was our second visit here, and both times everything we tried was absolutely delicious.

One small knock...I made a reservation for two a couple of days in advance using OpenTable.   Upon arrival, we were brought to our seats... at the bar.    I was a bit surprised when the hostess explained that tables are assigned by priority, based on the order of which they receive the reservation.   In other words, if you make don't make your reservation early enough, you might be seated at the bar!    I think Coqueta may be slightly misunderstanding the purpose of OpenTable....as in Open "Table".  In my experience, bar seating is never included in the OpenTable inventory.   If having a table is part of the romance/ambiance you are trying to establish, you may want to confirm this detail upon making your reservation. 

But I'm over it.   We had a great time here and plan to come back.   I highly recommend Coqueta.
author: Peter G.

description: Very good, friends and I split the paella. It was spot on. You cannot go wrong with the chorizo dishes there. The croquettes tasted like soul food, fried chicken pot pie flavored. Yum!
author: Courtney H.

description:
Great place for tapas and hand crafted cocktails. Stumbled upon this gem for a quick drink while walking the Embarcadero..stayed two hours. 
Meet will be back
author: keith s.

description:
3.5 stars.

For the price, I expected much better service which is why I knocked it down a half star.
The food itself was good overall with some that were just average.
Four of us were here so we had a nice sampling as their menu is best enjoyed tapas style.
The chef's selection of cured meats and cheeses is awesome dish and totally reminded me of my time in Spain.
Loved the bikini sandwich (a little oily) and the pork and duck meatballs (the duck really adds a unique twist to this). Pain con tomate was average. The patatas bravas was not what it looked like in Spain, but it was nicely presented and very tasty. The potato chips were pretty good as well. The sea urchin open faced sandwich was okay but definitely not worth the $14 for the 3 little circles.

I was still a little hungry after we finished here after spending $50 pp for lunch, so keep that in mind before you come here!
author: Katie F.

description:
I am exceptionally good at being whiny and bratty.

I am excellent at emptying M's wallet.

I am gracious when it comes to stuffing my face ( or so I hope).

After 40 days of dedication and discipline, I'm ready to binge on dessert, making up for lost times...KIDDING...I will eat in moderation. Only 3 desserts for dinner, okay???

Starting our dinner right with some gin and tonic beautifully garnished to some nicely mixed concoction called "The Castro" was quite tasty. We ordered small plates to share:

- Chorizo, roasted artichokes, and piquillo peppers = bite size skewers. Perfect pairing with our drinks. 

- Jamón Serrano, Manchego, and apricot-sherry conserva = bite size skewers. 

- Crispy shrimp = with chickpea flour pancake and saffron alioli. I was eying this the moment I saw them making it in the kitchen. Crispy, fried goodness!

-Duck and pork meatballs = extremely flavorful, tender, and moist. A must order!

- Manchego cheesecake with caramel popcorn = remarkably light in texture and highly addictive. This dainty fun cheesecake pop was phenomenal. 

- Flan Espanola with fennel-citrusfritura = a rich and deeply satisfying decadent flavor. One of the best dessert of the night. Highly recommended!

-Churro 'Fantasia,' crispy Spanish doughnuts with drinking chocolate and mixed berry powder was so delectably delicious. 

Beyond a delightful meal at Coqueta, it was the company that made it much better. Thank you M for surviving the 40 days with me. Muah!

I hope you give this place a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description:
Overall this was a really underwhelming experience. We were SO excited to be dining here after hearing such wonderful things from other patrons for so long. We were sat late to our reservation at a table that was clearly made to accommodate a party of two. There were three of us. Our server basically ignored us. When he did show up he was short, flighty, and clearly uninterested. However we noticed him spending great lengths of time at other tables. Granted we were on the younger side but we still spent a lot of money there. Service was really disappointing. 

Food was okay. Nothing was really that great with the exception of the kale salad. For the price and service we expected, I would much rather go to the Slanted Door or Kokkari, where food is consistently excellent and service is incredible. I'm really confused why this restaurant is held in such high regard.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I wish I could give this place negative stars for the horrible way the manager treated us. 

Truth be told, we did not have reservations and tried to get into the restaurant and my husband was being difficult. However, I tried to explain to the manager how the hostess told us one thing, but basically said it to appease us and make us go away. My point is, her JOB is to deal with customers, even the difficult ones. If she has no intention of giving us a table, then she have been honest to begin with vs. LYING that she would give us a table. 

The manager basically said it was our fault the hostess lied because my husband pressured her.  Really?  Is she a child or an adult? Then the manager told us we are not welcome if we kept calling her staff liars. Here's an idea: how about you hire a grown up who can deal with problems vs. a child who chooses to lie when she can't handle the pressure. 

Let's not tell the hostess she doing a great job when she's doing a shitty job. This is not little league, where everyone is a winner.  This is the restaurant biz, where we have REAL responsibilities.  We need to put on our big girl pants on. Grow up Coquetta! And hire someone who has a brain.
author: Katherine L.

description: The food was good. Price acceptable. The service was poor. The waiter did not attend well. We had to beckon him to order several times, and remind him to bring the dessert and drink menu. Wine service was slow. Two plates seemed to have cooled off excessively.
author: L J.

description:
I've always been a fan of Michael Chiarello since I first saw him on his cooking show Easy Entertaining on the Food Network a long time ago.  Planning for my trip to SF, I had to make reservations at his new restaurant Coqueta! As it was Valentines day weekend, it wasn't easy getting a reservation but luckily managed to get one.  

Coqueta is a waterfront Spanish tapas bar located right on the Embarcadero pier with a semi-enclosed outdoor patio/bar area and of course the dining area inside. I loved everything about the restaurant including the atmosphere, food and service.  

bite size skewers: tried the chorizo, jamon serrano and the quail egg skewer.  My favorite was the jamon serrano with manchego and apricot sherry preserves.  Such a great flavor combination of sweet, salty, savory :)

salmon ahumado: open face sandwich with smoked salmon, queso freso and truffle honey: Perfect balance of the saltiness from the smoked salmon and sweetness off the honey with a hint of the fragrant truffle :) So simple yet delicious.  I could literally have like 10 of these :)

sunny side up egg with shrimp: crispy julienned potatoes,  sunny side up egg, shrimps with a chorizo dressing.  You mix it all up, take a bite and it will be an explosion of different flavors and textures in your mouth! Perfect combination :)

croquetas de Pollo: chicharon crusted Chicken and English pea croquetas with cured citrus.  Another winner but I was a bit disappointed by the extremely small portion size! The croquetas were literally as thin as my pinky but flavor wise, they were a winner.  

ensalada de kale: loved the lacinato kale salad with roasted butternut squash, pomegranate seeds and a warm garbanzo dressing! Subtle flavors but still very good.  

pulpo a la parilla: grilled octopus was nicely seasoned and perfectly cooked.  They were tender and definitely not chewy or hard in a bad way. The dish also came with fingerling potatoes but thought they were rather bland and needed more seasoning.  

Overall, I had a great experience and can't wait to return to try their churros and paella:)
author: Grace K.

description: Great place for dinner.  Four of us went there at opening time for the restaurant, which is 5:00.  We enjoyed 4 different tapas dishes.  Each was unique and very tasty.  We will be back.
author: Glen R.

description:
Incredible decoration and ambiance, and really good service. Only issue is that they served our order to other people by mistake twice in a row.
The waiter did apologize and brought us some delicious pinchos in compensation.

Drinks were definitely the highlight of the dinner. They have small but very delicious plates, especially the cheese plate and patatas bravas.
author: Pablo A.

description:
Completely out of expectation, as we didn't even think we can book the space given the short time horizon...must be someone cancelled theirs so we had our space at a golden time.

Anyway food was fabulous, especially the paella. We eapeically enjoyed the spicy sauce over the lemon one, which went perfectly well with the rice and shrimp. Sausage was another extra credit point. The dessert flan was a bit too sweet though.

Well attentive service, will visit again during my next time in San Francisco.
author: Elaine H.

description: My fiance brought me here for my bday, I was skeptical initially due to the fact that I'm very picky with Spanish tapas. We got the open face salmon sandwich, the uni and iberico open face, the sausage trio, croquetas, manchengo and membrillo.  Everything was great, however the uni and iberico I will never forget, it was beyond amazing.  By the way did I mention that you could see the bay bridge from the restaurant? Yup quite a view.  Granted it was very pricy, however my palate was more than satisfied.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
I absolutely love Coqueta, both for sit-down dining and in their more casual bar space. It's one of my favorite restaurants in SF, especially as it's right near the water, with an inviting space and amazing, sharable food. 

Everything on the menu is delicious. The paella is worth the wait (make sure to order it early, as it takes 40 mins to prepare). The patatas bravas are a staple you simply can't miss. My #1 all time favorite dish though is the Pork + Duck meatballs with a tart-cherry tempranillo sauce and crispy shallots. I have fantasies about them - they're that good. 

Only complaint is that the restrooms are public and I've always run into a line. Also, the bar area is usually extremely crowded and it's hard to move around or get a spot to eat.
author: Claire S.

description: The place has become a victim of its own success... the tapas got boring, the service was absent, the only thing positive was the location. This place needs to reflect ...the design elements are still cool, what turned cold is its soul...
author: Fermin N.

description: One of my favorite locations to visit every time I'm in SF.  The food, cocktails and view are all amazing and the service is really attentive.  They do get busy early so it is hard to get a table walking in unless you get there early but I don't mind waiting for a seat in the open air bar while enjoying the sun & water.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Not a great experience....
I'm very forgiving when in comes to service because I'm in the industry, but the basics were not there. 
We were so excited to try the place, and have had good experience at some of his other places, but this was so underwhelming and so disappointing to have as a celebration dinner for my husbands birthday.  In fact, I specifically called to say it was a birthday, and there was no sort of acknowledgement! And even the coffee served with the raw churros was slightly muddy water.  My husbands espresso was good, so I asked for one instead and she brought me an Americans that was almost as watery as he press. It literally was not a memorable meal at all.  I don't even feel like talking about the tough broccolini, tiniest most shriveled up padrons, gloppy croquettas, pulpo that was such a let down and ridiculous version of papas bravas.  Whatever...
author: Neda M.

description:
TL;DR version: 
Get the deviled eggs and a pitcher of sangria.

The regular version:
I always feel a little rebellious when I come to a popular spot in a big city with no reservation. I come from a much smaller city, and reservations aren't really necessary. So I didn't think I'd actually be able to eat at Coqueta when a friend and I flipped a coin (tails: Coqueta; heads: Foreign Cinema) and came here. Upon arrival - let's say it was 7:30ish - they couldn't seat us in the restaurant (which was - of course! - full of people who had made actual reservations for the evening) or in the side room area because there was a private party until 8pm. At 8pm they suggested we could "come back and try our luck."

At about 8:30 we came back and squeezed into two spots at the middle raised bar area in that side room. We found it slightly weird that all the private party's food was still out... especially when the servers made it a point to pull it away from us. Which, let's face it, is kind of weird. Take it away entirely or let the public pick at it, too. Mmmkay?

Our first server clearly hated us and so we were thrilled when we suddenly got a new one - short, tattooed, and thoughtful about how loud and how packed it was. When I ordered the first plate I asked her if it was vegetarian. Without being prompted she suddenly ran through everything on the menu that was safe for me to eat and what they could alter - this was SO accommodating and made it so much easier on me. Usually I order something, ask if it's vegetarian. Order something, ask if it's a vegetarian. All servers everywhere should take a lesson from this woman. She also informed us - totally randomly but so serendipitously - that their food was cooked in peanut oil. Wouldn't you know, my dining companion has a peanut allergy. They then re-tailored the tailored options to suit her needs, too.

Damn. Fine. Service.
(After that first miserable dude.)

The food was okay:
+Huevos Nacional: deviled eggs filled with spring pea and smoked pimentón alioli, on pickled saffron potato with olive oil and poached bonito, $7 - (sans bonito) this was definitely the most memorable thing. I could have probably just eaten these all night long and been entirely satisfied. Loved the different textures, loved the different flavors, loved the different colors. Perfection!
+/- Coliflor con Romescu: yellow cauliflower steak a la plancha with coal roasted romescu sauce, $11 - this was very good, don't get me wrong, but I felt like the cauliflower could have been trimmed down a bit more. Not sure it was worth the price.
- Patatas Xips y Salsa Aperitivo: smokey potato chips with shaved manchego and membrillo-Vermouth vinegar, $4 - I actually ate one and then didn't touch the rest. Just a little underwhelming for me compared to everything else we got. I really wanted a bit more punch here, but it was kind of all one note.
- Patatas Bravas: freshly dug, lightly smoked, crispy new potatoes, bravas salsa and garlic alioli, $8 - again, kind of just "meh"; we didn't finish it and I nothing about it really sang to me.

Oh, and our drinks were fabulous:
+ Sangria: red wine, manzanilla sherry, citrus, ginger berries, chamomile, and local apples, $9: This is one of the best glasses of sangria I've ever had in my life. Fruity, refreshing, flavorful, interesting, diverse... maybe next time I'll just order a pitcher (#formyself). Oh, it also came in this amazing glass that reminded us both of something our grandmothers would have kept on a shelf as a tchotchke (we mean this in the BEST way possible, trust me).
+ "Costa Brava": arehucas rum, lime, minted cane sugar, tarragon, lime, $12: my friend's drink was lovely as well, strong and delicious.
author: Steff D.

description:
No need to add to the chorus of praises for Coqueta, but I can't help myself. It was as lovely & delicious as I hoped, with beautiful expensive cocktails, little carafes of Spanish wine, pretty plates of exotic bites, and a tranquil view of the Bay (not to mention lovely people to match). If you want to up the ante with happy hour or date night, Coqueta is the place to do it. 

The gin & tonics are legendary here, with little bits of herbs and flowers added for botanical bonus points. Starting at $14, you need to really love gin to justify this one. What you're really paying for is the seats at this hot hot table. That said, the bar area is usually open seating, so arrive before 5pm to get lucky.

Caveat: I thought the service was a bit on the uppity side. When I asked the front of house dude if there was a coat check area to store my computer bag, his response was "yes, but not right now. It's too busy...". He never came back to check on me, so I just cluttered up their dining room with my big ol' laptop bag (really, I can't be the only one coming here straight from work). 

Coqueta is super special, so dress and act accordingly or you might not get the gracious treatment they reserve for their overtly upscale guests.
author: Nique F.

description: Was excited to try coqueta_sf tonight...unfortunately the hype exceeded the delivery. Wonderful hospitality but the food took over an hour to come out and was average at best. The best dish was lukewarm, meaning our meal died at the pass. The shrimp was definitely subpar - not fresh and mushy (seemingly frozen), meatballs were delicious but didn't hold, the bread overpowered the uni, potatoes with the octopus were under cooked. Saving grace was the desert but not worth it.
author: Vincent B.

description:
This place is the bomb!  It's a little too pricey for my average meal (and wouldn't try to do this in a group- mainly because I would want to eat everything on the table).  But, as an occasional delight, this place has some of the best tapas i've ever had.  

I highly recommend: salmon ahumado, el gaucho bistec (wow!!!), and the croquetas.  They also have this amazing caramel cheesecake skewer that you just can't walk away from.
author: Evelyn T.

description: Drinks were great but the food was meh and over priced. Our server got our order wrong three different times. The low point had to have been the ambiance- we were stuck next to a group of eight millennial foreign tourists who were loud, obnoxious, rude, and HAMMERED!  Not since my college days (100 years ago) have I seen such a hot mess get over-served booze to the point they were spilling drinks on themselves, breaking glasses, and falling down (while placing another drink order).  Oh, almost forgot the broken door to the patio that sounded like a bomb going off every time it slammed when a member of the aforementioned group went outside to take a selfie.
author: BL G.

description:
I went here last night for my best friend's birthday and we had a blast. We had reservations at 930 a for a specific waitress but they didn't seat us till 1010 which was a little bit disappointing but they made it up in high quality service and quality food and drinks. 

Brooklyn was our waitress and she was a delight. She was great and she paced the meal well!

Everything we ate was amazing. I recommend saving room for dessert and you gotta try the little things on the stick! The drinks were wonderful and beautiful as well!
author: Kristine D.

description:
So the problem here is they have only 50% table seating and the rest are these uncomfortable bar stools 
No guarantee of a table

Then the food while delicious is sooooooo small
36 dollars for 7 small slices of pork
I was truly taken aback as it is positioned as a large plate

If you are looking to leave hungry then this is the place for you
Wouldn't go back
author: Tracey F.

description:
Coqueta is not for the cheap. A few bites of food and a drink will lead to a $30/$40 bill. But it is a nice atmosphere and all the food comes out picture perfect. 

We ordered...
- Jamon Iberico de Bellota
- $2.50 Skewers (I tried the chorizo bite - small small table side hors d'oeuvres)
- Uni and Iberico Open Face Sandwich [ RECOMMEND! ] $7 per little cracker
- Heirloom Tomato Salad
- Arroz Cremoso [ RECOMMEND! ] 
- Pork Shoulder [ RECOMMEND! ] 
- Ribeye [ RECOMMEND! ] $24 per person
- Gulf Shrimp
- Octopus
- Flan
- Churros

I liked the uni open face sandwich but it was slightly bitter. Same with the octopus. They do their meat dishes really well though. By far, the PORK SHOULDER was the best thing out of everything we ordered. Super tender and tasty with the chili sauce. Dessert was average. I saw a picture on Yelp of the sangria popsicle and wanted to order that but it wasn't available :/ 

Since it's super hard to get a reservation here for dinner, come during a weekday lunch! It was pretty empty at 12 PM. I'll be getting the smoked salmon open face sandwich, the paella, and the pork shoulder next time!
author: Ingrid C.

description: Definitely a fan of this place. I went here and sat outside. It is a perfect location on a sunny day. The paella is AMAZING. this dish was huge and easily fed four of us. They have these little potatoes too that come with an aioli on top. Those are fantastic. We ordered a second serving! I was not a fan of the deviled egg, but everything else was great. Their sangria is good too!
author: Makenzi B.

description: I'm not sure what I enjoy more here, the food or the drinks but can say without doubt that every visit to Coqueta is a special time. While the prices aren't for the faint of heart, the execution and flavors justify the cost. The changing menu keeps it interesting and at times mysterious, and the patio vibe and rustic interior atmosphere adds to the overall experience.
author: Sonya B.

description:
Coqueta was such an amazing experience. Hands down, so far, Coqueta is my #1. After fellow yelper, Rodney's review, I knew this was a must pit stop while in SF. I was in luck when I got reservation!

We got there early and was seated in a room that is adjacent to the actual dining area, this area has the bar and a few seats where people sat and drank as well. We ordered a drink to start the night, the Kalimotxo which has Mexican Coke, Red Sangria, and Cinnamon. This drink was full of flavor but resides a bit on the dry side. It is only served in a party pitcher (500 mL). 

We were shown to our seats promptly, matter of fact, 10 minutes before our actual reservation time.  Our server, Lowell was AWESOME from the beginning. He is very knowledgeable of all the amazing food and drinks Coqueta serves. After we looked at the menu and made our choices, he picked and chose the order of our food and he was spot on! 

Unfortunately, I really wanted to try the "Mar y Montana", but they were sold out of the sea urchin (this gives me the perfect excuse to come back!).

The patatas bravas (freshly dug, crispy new potatoes, lightly smoked, bravas salsa, and garlic alioli). It was flavorful and the potatoes are perfect bite size pieces. The garlic alioli and salsa help brought out the flavor of the smoked potatoes. There was a great balance of salty and sweet.

Chicken and English pea croquetas (served alongside with cured cara-cara orange) (3 pieces). These puppies were like mini pot pies, bursting with richness in flavor! Super creamy and packed with great seasoning. The cured orange was served alongside with the croquetas, but I didn't try them. 

Gambas al negro (olive oil poached head-on Gulf prawns with black garlic and chili). This was an amazing dish. Super delicious and the portion was perfect. The prawns were big and succulent. Dipping the prawns in the olive oil with the bread was heaven! This is a definite dish that deserve another round!

Sunny side-up egg with shrimp (served with crispy potato, and chorizo dressing). I was so involved in my conversation with Lowell, that I forgot to take a picture before he mixed the sunny side-up egg with the chili pepper! I was only able to take a photo once he served it onto my plate. You get to choose how spicy you want this dish to be. Lowell sliced a small piece of the pepper and infused it into the yolk and mixed it into the crispy potato and chorizo dressing. The yolk definitely added a creamy texture and flavor to the dressing and onto the shrimp. It was a thumbs up!

Whole Monterey calamari on the plancha (with onion jam and squid ink alioli). We are so used to having calamari fried...this was an exceptional dish and the ink alioli was delicious. The onion jam was sweet and help balanced the flavor of the calamari and alioli. Delicious!

Wood grilled octopus (with fingerling potatoes, pimenton, and olive oil). This octopus was super tender! I was really surprised at how well the octopus was prepared. It was made simple but full bodied flavor.

Grilled albondigas (duck and pork meatballs with tart cherry and tempranillo puree and crisp shallots). Easily another favorite!! This dish was exploding in flavor! I think the mixture of the duck and pork added such amazing flavor. From the fat of the pork and the flavor of the duck, it was soooo good. It was perfectly portioned as anymore than what we had would have been too much because it was rich in flavor!

Whole grilled branzino (green olive oil and preserved meyer lemon salsa). Branzino is my favorite fish dish! It couldn't have been served better! The branzino was so moist and the meyer lemon salsa was perfection. I can eat the whole thing by myself. It was perfectly grilled and the smokiness from the grill added another component to the dish.

Pluma (Iberico de bellota pork shoulder loin with honey-chili glaze). This dish was also served with freeze dried pepper strings....it was interesting. It reminded me of saffron but it did carry a lot of flavor. The pork shoulder loin was cooked perfect. Moist, tender, and flavorful. The honey glaze chili paired well with the shoulder loin.
