Now, I'm one of those people who add my own salt to everything because I love sodium.... But this paella was just inedible. Did not even make a dent since my tongue dried up. How disappointing... I wish someone did some quality control before the food came out! 

I would not come back for the paella... But I might consider coming here for the steak.
author: Betty T.

description:
Waiter expected you to know every single thing and scoffed when you ask the littlest question. Like, jeeze sorry guy for having you HAVE to do your damn job.  Rude, curt and impatient. Didn't get his name, but he was average height, short brown hair, full beard, skinny and pale.

Asked for recommendations and he said them so quickly I didn't hear him (loud music and right on the pier by loud cars and motorcycles and people) so I kindly asked him to repeat himself. I've never seen someone look so fucking irritated by doing their job. 2 drinks took forever to get to us.

I got the Castro which was absolutely amazing and one of the only things I gave this place stars for. Other two stars are for the view and the ambiance with good music.
author: Danielle D.

description:
Coqueta, I love you. I loved you before going to Spain. And I thought I wouldn't love you as much after coming back from Spain. But I do. I really do. Your Sangrias lure me in. Your bikini brioche consistently seduce me, and your octopus leaves me foodgasming and coming back for more. Please never leave me. 

Sincerely,
Me
author: Michelle S.

description: My friends, my husband and I had a reservation for 5:30 pm. We got seated at 5:40 and were enjoying our conversation with drinks, tapas (ordered a bunch of them to share) and a cool atmosphere. However, at about 7:30 pm, a man who introduced himself as the assistant manager came to our table, and as I thought he was going to ask us how everything was (or say something nice), he was actually telling us to hurry up to vacate our table since other people had reservations. The tone with which he spoke was discourteous, not to say demeaning. There are ways to rush people out of their establishment when they think we are staying too late or not spending enough? (which we did, and this is a pricey restaurant). Being nice is one of them.
author: Marina T.

description: Wonderful, delicious food - meatballs and churros a must. Octopus was good too. High chairs available for toddlers - YAY! The hostess was friendly and accommodating, as was most of the waitstaff EXCEPT ours - nothing wrong, just lacked the warmth everyone else had. Beautiful decor. Will return.
author: Jen K.

description:
Reservations are a little bit hard to come by, so make reservations at least a month in advance. 

From yelpers reviews I wanted to try the razor clams but alas, they were not available.

I'll not go into the details of what I ate (I had all the highlights of Coqueta's menu except the razor clams) but I do have to say their Barça Gintonic (Bloom London Dry Gin, House Made Tonic with Grapefruit and Pine) is THE most beautiful gin and tonic I've ever had - putting an orchid in the glass made it almost too pretty to drink.

Service was on point and for a restaurant that got crowded really quickly it was very efficient and friendly.
author: Nette T.

description:
Coqueta was a phenomenal meal and one of the best tapas places I've tried. The amount of detail paid to both the food and presentation was outstanding. The dining room space wasn't too shabby either. Reservations were hard to come by, thus we snagged an early 5:00 pm dinner. 

Dinner started with complimentary sparkling water (my favorite!) and an offering of pintxos or bite-size skewers. I tried the house cured boquerones with white anchovies, olives, pearl onions, and guindilla peppers. It was full of flavor and set the tone for an amazing meal. We shared everything family-style with the following:

Chicken and English peas croquetas - these were wonderful and rich. They reminded me of fancy jalapeno poppers. The cured cara-cara orange was a nice contrast in flavor and as a palette cleanser. 

Gambas al negro - great flavor from the gulf prawns and masterfully done with the black garlic and chili.

Sunny side-up egg with shrimp, crispy potato, and chorizo dressing - probably my favorite dish of the night. Everything blended well together. It was very reminiscent of a Spanish-style breakfast. 

Grilled beef shortribs - this was my least favorite dish. The ribs were nothing special. They tasted texturally like Korean shortribs, but lacked the flavor. The glaze, pomegranate, and seville orange didn't add anything.

Paella - this was the star entree of dinner. Made to be shared for two, there was easily enough to split amongst a party of three. If you like crispy bomba rice and seafood, this is the best.

For dessert, we opted to try the warm pimenton chocolate cake and the churros.  I really liked the churros servied with raspberry powder and chocolate sauce. It was excellent with a cup of Four Barrel french-pressed coffee. 

Coqueta was a joy to dine in. It's the perfect location for a nice date or a special occasion. They have a seasonal menu so I'm definitely excited to see some of the new offerings when spring or summer rolls around!
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Amazing dinner, over the top service from host to bus person and our server Brooklyn was the icing on the cake to a perfect birthday dinner! 
Pork special on Saturday night was so tender, the wine recommendation spot on and the surprise birthday treat was heart warming. Can't wait to come back!
author: Naomi F.

description: Had the Tapas. Good service, interesting food and a good view. This is like an American dim sum. You get one bite of everything they have in the restaurant. You can ask for more but with so many things to try you don't get a chance to or have the space in the tummy. There were some exotic seafood and good desert. Make sure you order a 2nd plate of what you like because you may leave hungry or wanting more. The key here is to enjoy every bite and feel the taste rather than just eating a big plate of one thing.
author: Mu H.

description:
Celebrity Chef Crushes.

First, there was Tyler Florence. I froze up and nearly keeled over when I met him, not once BUT three times. Then, there was Ryan Scott. He was taking my order at his food truck when I got tongue tied and blurted something that wasn't even on the menu. When I went to his pop-up restaurant, I sat there mesmerized. Like a Kelly Kapowski-Jeff crush, I had a silly grin on my face while batting my lashes the entire time during brunch as he sat at the table next to us. 

And, then there's Michael Chiarello. I grew up watching him along with Yan Can Cook on PBS and followed him on the Food Network while rooting for him on Top Chef Masters and The Next Iron Chef. He's like the Richard Gere in the foodie world with a charismatic personality that's super lovable. So naturally, when I read he was opening a new restaurant in SF, I JUST had to go.

Although Chef Chiarello specializes in Italian influenced Californian cuisine, his new baby, Coqueta focuses on Basque cuisine (Spanish tapas). Considering it's located in a prime real estate location, expect prices to be high because you're paying for the ambiance and the waterfront view after all. The menu is quite extensive with small bites, cold tapas, hot tapas, and larger family style plates: http://www.scribd.com/doc/136022919/Coqueta-Final-Opening-Menu. Two to three dishes per a person is recommended but portions are small so if you have a large appetite, definitely skip the skewers and open faced sandwiches (they can easily rack up $$$) and get a rice or pasta dish as a filler.   

There was some mixed reviews so we were conservative with our order. I'm glad we didn't over-order as we usually do because the food was good but not as spectacular as Lolinda and Contigo (my two favorite higher end tapas restaurants in SF). I expected a bit more from Chef Chiarello in terms of flavor and execution but the creative menu, presentation, amazing cocktails and impeccable service more than made up for it.

C O C K T A I L S:
Hats off to the mixologist for making AHHHH-MAZING cocktails. I started off with the Tariff Cocktail ($12) made with jamon iberico infused gin which had a delicious smokiness: http://bit.ly/13kNED8. But the remarkable Barca GinTonic ($12) is what will bring me back to Coqueta: http://bit.ly/ZCb3vM. Who would have thought something as simple as gin, tonic, and grapefruit would be so ahhh-mazing? Seriously, it was one of the best and most simple cocktails I've ever had. 

F O O D 
*Chorizo & Grilled Artichoke Skewers ($2.50 each): http://bit.ly/17rOjmv
*Smoked Salmon Open Faced Sammie w/ Queso Fresco & Truffle Honey ($5): http://bit.ly/Z62duu
*Chicken & English Pea Croquettes ($9): http://bit.ly/XTnwAH
*Wood-Grilled Octopus w/ Fingerling Potatoes ($12): http://bit.ly/13kHmU2
*Vineyard Greens w/ Golden Raisins & Pine Nuts ($6): http://bit.ly/15iqwsx
*Pluma: Pork Shoulder Loin w/ a Honey-Chile Glaze ($38): http://bit.ly/11D42yn
*Sangria Popsicle w/ Pop Rocks ($4): http://bit.ly/15iqHnV
*Manchego Cheesecake Pops w/ Caramel Corn (two pops - $4): http://bit.ly/ZC0qsA

The best dishes of the night were the chicken & english pea croquettes and the pluma: pork shoulder loin. The croquettes which were like fried pieces of chicken pot pie; super mouthwatering with a decadent creaminess. As one of my favorite cuts of meat, the pork shoulder was rich, fatty, and full of intense porkiness. I absolutely adored the glass honey jar it was presented with. The vineyard greens were a good dose of fiber with a lovely sweetness from the raisins and the nutty crunch from the pine nuts. The chorizo was like cold salami chunks and the too smoky octopus needed a citrus punch so skip these. And, while the smoked salmon open faced sammie was delectable, $5 was excessive for an amuse bouche sized sammie. Dessert was wildly creative. The sangria popsicle with nostalgic pop rocks definitely won me over the too pungent manchego cheesecake pops.  

S E R V I C E
Michelin-star quality service, the genuinely warm staff are well-seasoned and run a tight ship. You would have never known that last night was only their fourth opening night. Special shout-out to our waiter, Kyle. He was super personable, down-to-earth, and attentive. He knew that menu like the back of his hand and even went as far as explaining some of the ingredients. Very impressive. Restaurant Stakeout's Willie Degel would be proud.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
High ceilings, rich woods, and an open kitchen makes this one warm and inviting restaurant. With a choice of counter seating, dining room seating, and an enclosed outdoor patio, definitely ask for a table near the window to bask in that waterfront view.  

P A R K I N G
Parking meters are enforced until 11 pm. 

Thankfully, the delightful hostess sat us at a window table with a picturesque view. Otherwise, there's no telling what CelebrityChefStarStruck Cherylynn would have done...especially after 'em ahhh-mazing cocktails.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I was ready to be all jaded about Michael Chiarello's new waterfront restaurant since it is an intensely tourist-centric location run by a Food Network celebrity chef who sells his own set of cookware. Need I say more. However, my cynicism was tempered somewhat by a distant memory of a fine meal I had at Tra Vigne soon after he opened that restaurant in Napa back in the late 1980's. Now I've never been to Bottega, and with so many dining options in Yountville, it never hit my must-try list. But the buzz around Coqueta, his first foray into Spanish cuisine, piqued my curiosity enough for me to see if a reservation could be secured at the last minute on Friday. 

Sure enough, there was one at 5:30, so I grabbed it even if it meant Jamie W. and I had to hustle our butts out of work to get there on time. I'm familiar with the high-ceiling space since Lafitte served my favorite Pimm's Cup in the city, no small feat and alas only the Pimm's 74 at RN74 is left to salve my wounded liver. The decor doesn't look hugely different, but the heavy wood tables and colorful Fiesta ware definitely felt Madrileño to me (photo: http://bit.ly/ZInaY5). The menu of small and large bites was still on a folded piece of paper and included their cocktails as well (7 photos starting with: http://bit.ly/13rgn9m). Waiting for Jamie, I wasted no time in ordering the $12 Engine Co. #5 (photo: http://bit.ly/121Tw3Z).

It was a smooth mix of Dancing Pines Bourbon, Tobacco-Infused Sherry, Lemon and Zurracapote (a sangria-like drink). Refreshing and gone so quickly as the weather is starting to warm finally. I was convinced by a passing server to try a trio of the Pintxos at $2.50 a pop. After all, she was carrying a plank with all of the different selections organized like little soldiers with their sabers bolted into the wood (photo: http://bit.ly/XQxMaR). I chose the Quail's Egg 'Diablo' with Pickled Mustard Seed and Jamón Serrano, the Chorizo with Roasted Artichoke and Piquillo Peppers, and the Jamón Serrano with Mancheco and Apricot-Sherry Conserva (photo: http://bit.ly/15yzu5c).

They were delicious but almost too quick to appreciate the creation behind them. Also on the small side was the $5 Smoked Salmon Montadito with Queso Fresco and Truffle Honey (see photo). It was really a glamorously Catalan version of a bagel with cream cheese, and my only regret is that it wasn't a bigger nosh. The $8 "Tattas" Bravas were upscale tater tots made all the more alluring with Jamón and Bravas Salsa and Aioli (photo: http://bit.ly/15yzRNd). They simply melted in our mouths with little effort. The $12 Wood-Grilled Octopus was succulent with just the right amount of char as the pieces were accompanied by Fingerling Potatoes, Pimentón and Olive Oil (photo: http://bit.ly/ZDdq5l). Octopus has never tasted so savory good, and the main events had yet to arrive.

The $22 Arroz Cremosa was a wondrously luxuriant risotto with Slow Cooked Bomba Rice and Day Boat Scallops that were meltably tender accompanied by English peas (photo: http://bit.ly/ZImRMO). But the centerpiece of the evening was the $38 Pluma, incredibly tender slices of Ibérico de Bellota Pork Shoulder Loin which you drizzle with the Honey-Chili Glaze (photo: http://bit.ly/XQy1Tm). Even though the price was a bit mind-boggling for the portion, we wouldn't hesitate to order that dish again. What was nice was that Chiarello served it himself and told us he had to serve what is easily his favorite dish. He barely stayed to chat, but I was able to tell him I think he made the transition from Italy to Spain with ease. The $6 Catalan-Style Vineyard Greens with a Caper Raisin Puree made an excellent side dish among the excessive carnivery.

I was working my way through my second cocktail, the $12 Castro, a refreshing mix of Espolon Tequila Blanco, Curacao, Fina Sherry, Fresno Pepper and Lime (photo: http://bit.ly/ZDdBOf), when we decided to share the $8 Asturian Apple Pie, a rather Viennese-looking pastry with apples sliced on top and with a canela of Cabrales Blue Cheese Ice Cream (photo: http://bit.ly/17HBHIh). Tasty sweetness, but we couldn't stop there as there were $4 Dessert Bites to try. There was the Pan con Chocolate, a self-described ice cream sandwich drizzled in olive oil (photo: http://bit.ly/XQye99), and a pair of the Sangria Pop-Rocksicles, push-up pops topped with a sweetened crumble (photo: http://bit.ly/Zg6ywi). It was a mostly exquisite series of plates well worth a try.

FOOD - 4 stars...creative, authentic and rather pricey takes on tapas with the pluma the platinum standout (photo: http://bit.ly/17RtRyA) 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...still the same cavernous look of Lafitte with the loud bar tent but with even more tables to satisfy the masses
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...quite terrific and accommodating
TOTAL - 4 stars...Chiarello strikes gold in Spain and should stick around
author: Ed U.

description: Coqueta was a real treat. The atmosphere and location is great. Staff friendly and accommodating. Tapas and main dishes so well done. We split 6 Tapas between 2 adults - and we were stuffed. Most notably was how well done the dishes were. Fresh, great favors - super interesting. Great place to meet friends, bring a date. Awesome Sangria. Very casual. Only downside is that reservations are tough as there can be long wait times.
author: Patrick A.

description:
Food is tasteful and the location is very nice.  We ordered grilled octopus, pimientos padrón, chicken croquettes, potatoes, mejillones and paella (and drinks).  The paella, as featured in the menu, is for 2-3 people.  But there is a catch.  It's only good for 2-3 people IF each person also orders 2-3 tapas dishes as well.  So yes, people, do the math.

We were also asked to move out of the dining room so that the servers prepare for the dining crowd (past 5 PM already).  Their website and Open Table don't disclose closure times between services, to we were taken aback, specially since we were celebrating a birthday.

The first time we came here it was lovely, exciting.  I was pretty underwhelmed by this last visit.  I would recommend going to B44, excellent paella (and generous servings of it), as well as quality crafted food.
author: Carolina Q.

description:
What do you think of when you think of San Francisco?  Trolleys?  The bay?  The Golden Gate?    I think of an eclectic and artsy fusion of life, love, libation, and, of course, food. 

Coquetas sits on the iconic Fisherman's Wharf overlooking the always picturesque waterfront. They complement that view with Spanish Tapas and crafted cocktails infused with Spanish and California heritage.  

Try the sangria, the Iberian Hams, and the padron peppers.   Though it seems you can't go wrong with anything.   

You may need a reservation but it's well worth it, even if it's for a snack to tide you over until a late dinner in true Spanish fashion.
author: Mike R.

description: If you're in SF and looking for a place where you can get a lot of small plates to share, this is your place. Food and service were absolutely amazing here. If you do stop by, make sure you ask for Stephanie, all of her recommendations were spot on. The croquetas and gambas, along with the arroz con leche dessert among many others were some of my favorites. I hope everyone has as great of an experience as I did today. Thank you Stephanie for making our lunch so amazing.
author: Rosa M.

description:
I had no idea how in love with Coqueta I'd be. I am sometimes weary of these restaurants conceived by celebrity chefs, but Mr. Chiarello has a grand-slam on his hands. It's also worth a quick note to say that my friend and I were simultaneously attempting to get a res. I called. They had nothing. She looked on Open Table and there were PLENTY of tables. What the heck?

The atmosphere transported me to some places I remember in Barcelona. It's fairly cramped, but you're not going to feel it once your dishes and cocktails begin arriving. The house was packed, but the staff was able to deliver pretty consistent service. I appreciate how they did not hurry us so our table could be turned over. 

Every single cocktail we had (and there were several) were absolute smash hits. The gintonics are ethereal, especially if you dig gin. They're almost too pretty to drink. The grey salt margarita was exquisite as was The Castro. I'd come here just to drink. 

While I cannot recall everything we ordered (it was a lot), we loved every single thing we ordered. The calamari on the plancha was divine--whomever says they don't like calamari has never had it like this. The duck and pork meatballs were also a standout.  Then the paella---an absolute must. 

Well worth the price. Cannot wait to be back!
author: Mark M.

description: Great food! Great atmosphere and cocktails were also really good.
author: KB B.

description: Most dishes were quite good. Some, paella included, were not. It  was expensive for lunch but, everyone enjoyed the experience.
author: Paul B.

description:
Been here several times and enjoyed every experience thusfar. 

I'll keep it short and sweet: This place is trendy, great date spot, fun ambiance, outdoor covered bar with a great view of the water, the tapas are good, tiny unfortunately, but really good, and the drinks are great as well. I've had great service here - and though it's a bit pricier for dinner, you get a good overall experience worthy of coming back! All in all, great tapas spot to come check out at least once.
author: Raji R.

description: Located right in embarcadero!  Drinks well put together in taste and appearance.  Staff are friendly and attentive.  The place is perfect to hangout alone or in a group.
author: Say H.

description:
We arrived 10mins early for our reservation and were immediately seated at the bar right in front of the kitchen (best seat in the house). Our waitress was very prompt, polite and professional. 

Food came out super fast without too much of a gap between and each tapa was superb. Lots of bold flavors in each bite and they did a great job balancing both textures with their knife work and flavors with acidity/heaviness.

Dessert was really incredible... the best bite of cheesecake I've ever had and perfect churros dipped in a chocolate sauce. 

Drinks were really well made and beautiful to look at in addition to being interesting to taste. We didn't notice at first, but my wife's ice cube was shaped like a lung, veins and all. Quality in even the smallest details...
author: Rob P.

description: Superb meal...Starter Charcuterie , salmon bruschetta and octopus / sausage 1st plates were stand outs among 7 we had (all fantastic) and the entree meats were perfectly cooked with inspired side sauces  that will draw you back to try more... Add a great wine list, small plate desserts and great service ... My new tapas "go to" where ever and when ever I happen to be near SF. A+++
author: Kimberly K.

description: Enjoyable for dining with friends from out of town as it looks out on the water. Food is good if you like Spanish tapas style. Atmosphere and service were also good. A place where I can take a guest and have them be thrilled by the selection on all counts: food, wine, service, atmosphere,  gets 5 stars in my book.
author: Sharon L.

description:
Great food, nice atmosphere and friendly staff. 

A big shout out to our server, Sarah, who was EXTREMELY accommodating for our large group. I let her know I was on a restrictive diet and she took the time to properly explain every dish and all of its components. She even made sure to bring me individual specialized plates that excluded allergies. It's tough enough to service a table of 15, let alone customize dishes.
author: Jessica B.

description:
What is not to like? Nice ambiance, great service, amazing food... and the delicious smell of cooking!
We were here on a Saturday afternoon and they were very busy. Service was a little slow in the beginning but they definitely made up for it. 
We had pan con tomate, croquetas, huevos sunny side up, octopus, and mushrooms. We ordered the Arroz con Leche for dessert and they also brought a bite of the manchego cheese cake after the server saw me flirting with the desert on the table next to us (I said the service was great). 
Every item had something special about it and some of them transported me back to Spain. We each had our favorites so I guess you need to go and try for yourself. 
We also had a couple of drinks (monitor and margarita). They were good but nothing to rave about. But I'll try something else next time. 
We really enjoyed having Denis as our server. He along with his support wait staff made our visit that much special. 
I'm definitely looking forward to my next time here!
author: Sha L.

description: This restaurant was high on my list to try after a Spaniard recommended it to me. He said it was the closest flavors to what he experiences in Spain. He lives in Barcelona six months out of the year. My wife and I visited Spain about 17 months ago and fell in love with the people as well as the food. I also cook Spanish food and paella is one of my specialties. With that being said, I had high expectations for this restaurant. I brought my wife and my mom on this special trip. We arrived 16 April on a Saturday shortly after they opened at 11:30am. We didn't have reservations so they sat us in the bar, which is where we usually prefer to sit anyway. The first thing we noticed was the infestation of flies flying overhead. I mean there must have been close to a couple dozen flying in a group. My mother had a hard time getting up on the bar stool and with the flies near us we decided to sit outside on the bench and picnic table where not a single fly bothered us. I immediately ordered the seafood paella since I knew this would take some time to cook. We also ordered one each of white wine and red wine Sangrias. Both were excellent, but the white was my favorite. We started with El Plat Cap a Chef's selection of cured meats. It consisted of house cured chorizo, fuét, and Jamón Serrano. First of all the portions were minuscule. For $26 I expected a little more on the platter. The slightly larger than a match stick sized and rectangular shaped salami was underwhelming. The chorizo had little flavor, was not bad, but no wow factor. The Jamón Serrano was also underwhelming. All three lacked saltiness and more fat content. Next we ordered hot tapas. Patatas Bravas: very good with hints of smokiness and flash fried crisp served with Bravas salsa and garlic aioli, Pulpo a la Parilla: Wood grilled Mediterranean octopus served with fingerling potatoes and pimentón olive oil which was cooked perfectly. Although we weren't served a single tentacle, which is my favorite part of the octopus, but what was served was very good. Our last tapas was Albóndigas a la feria, duck and pork meatballs with tart cherry Tempranillo salsa and crispy shallot. These were slightly sweet, tart, tender, and moist. Good, but no wow factor here either. Lastly our paella was served. This was probably our biggest disappointment. I am use to saffron in my paella, which is synonymous with paella. Not a hint was detected. Not enough seafood broth was used either. First of all I couldn't detect any flavors of seafood. The paella had primarily tomato based flavors instead. As a result of not enough broth being used. the paella was dry. The clams were cooked nicely, but the shrimp was kind of mushy in texture, not firm. The house cured chorizo lacked flavor and probably did not belong in this dish. It provided a waxy tasteless texture. For $45 this was a huge failure. I had Mexican (Spanish) rice in a Mexican restaurant more flavorful than this. For $164 total bill including  a $20 tip, I am very disappointed.
author: Victor H.

description:
Great little spot if you're looking to be by the water!

Came here on a Sunday night around 9:30PM - you can make reservations online (: The place itself is much larger than it appears, driving by I had originally thought they only had their outside patio area - but there's also inside seating available. It has a nice artsy feel to it and tapas range in the $10-20 range for the most part. 

My favorite tapas were the chicken croquettes (Croquetas de Pollo) and the "Sunny side up" Huevo - which was like an egg with shrimp over crispy shoestring potato chips. The Bikini brioche was subpar. 

I got really excited when I saw octopus on the menu a la "Pulpo a la Parilla" - and it comes as one large chunk of octopus over potatoes. Which is nice because usually when you order octopus it comes cut-up and you can tell you got the leftover bits and pieces. 

In the end - 4 tapas was very filling for two people and we had to take an additional entree we ordered (Arroz Cremoso) to-go because we were so stuffed! Great place for innovative Spanish tapas and fun atmosphere all together.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Wanted to eat at Coqueta for a while now since it's been open a few weeks & saw it on Foodgal's blog I had to try it.  Well, got there after 6pm & I knew it was a bad idea since I had no reservation, but who eats out on a Sunday night right?  I didn't know that Sting was playing near there!  Place was Packed!

Guy said we could wait for a seat at the bar area side.  Dining room was for reservation only!  I think we waited about 30 min, I do have a tiny bit of patience when I want something so I waited & waited.  I noticed Don Bleu was right in front of me, omg!  He's a radio host I used to listen to & there in the flesh!  He was there for a light dinner then he went to see Sting!

Finally, we got one spot, then another.  I ordered a lot of stuff & B. didn't notice until it was too late, poor guy.  

They ran out of Sangria when I went - how the F-ck does a Spanish place run out of Sangria???

Quail egg "Diablo" - $2.50 ea little tiny egg.  I got 2 of those, yummy.  I wanted more, but didn't get them.

Jamon Serrano, manchego, & apricot-sherry conserva $2.5 ea - got 2 of those.  Tiny thing, it was fine.

Jamon Serrano House cured $12 - a bunch of sliced thin pork w/ some crackers. Fine.

Wood-grilled octopus w/ fingerling potatoes, pimenton, & olive oil $12 - it was good, small portion.

Pluma, iberico de bellota pork shoulder loin w/ honey-chili glaze $38 - yummy, it's 6oz, i could have eaten the whole thing!

Roasted pedron peppers w/ jamon serrano & sherry vinegar $8 - salty & bit oily peppers - meh.

Paella $40 enough for 2 servings.  It was good, though the chorizo was dry, gulf prawns were fine, rice was good.  Lemon alioli on the side nothing special & doesn't go with it I don't think, peppers meh.

One Poprockcicle $4- just ok, lots of my poprocks fell out before I could eat them.  Frozen part pretty bland.

Separate bathrooms in the main dining room on the Right of the kitchen.

Make Reservations or go Early!
author: Ann L.

description:
Coqueta brings back food memories of when I studied abroad in Barcelona.

Located on the beautiful Pier 5, it was the perfect spot for 4 girlfriends on a lovely Sunday afternoon.

Since it's tapas style, we shared:
500ml Pitcher of Clara, Smoked Salmon, Croquetas, Octopus, Patatas Bravas, Sunny side-up egg (very flavorful and our favorite), Paella (says for 2, it was enough for 4 since we ordered other tapas), Churros and Manchego Cheesecake bites (very sweet and cheesy).

The dishes may be small, but our tummies were all satisfied. Muy delicioso!
author: Christine C.

description:
Honestly we really enjoyed this place. 

We got a prime spot at the chefs counter and enjoyed our journey in Spain. 

We started off with the open faces salmon followed by the pork and duck meatballs. We also shared the prawns and a chefs selection cheese board. 

The salmon was simply amazing. We really enjoyed it. The meatballs were really tender and perfectly cooked. They did have a hint of nutmeg or something sweet that I can't put my finger on. 

The prawns were fishy and probably my least favorite of our selections. 

They finished solid with the cheese board. It was really amazing. The chef even told us how to make the more than wonderful tomato purée that was on there... We won't tell you have to go yourself to find out :)

I gave five stars because I don't want one bad seed to ruin such an amazing food journey. The hostess was snarky and not friendly.
author: Jeannette C.

description: Lousy service from the host (the guy with the blonde hair in a suit). He was condescending and we felt like second tier customers. Although everyone else was awesome and the food was a solid (3-4 stars) having our first interaction with him really made the whole experience unpleasant.
author: Lyn X.

description:
This place is delicious. I've tried almost everything on the menu and my top dishes are:

- Pork Shoulder: tender, juicy, and full of flavor
- Paella: big portion and contains just the right amount of seafood and veggies
- Open salmon bagel: it's just perfect
- Patatas Bravas: delicious
- Croquetas: Amazing, must try
- Peppers: beware, some can be really spicy
- Steak: pricey but very juicy and flavorful

Last but not least, you have to try their gin and tonic. Gin and tonic is not my choice of alcohol, but their gin and tonic has some herbs and it's very refreshing!!
author: Kristen F.

description: I've been here a few times. The atmosphere is nice, trendy. We sat at an odd table where one side was a bench of chairs and the chairs rocked. Not much space to squeeze in to. No dishes blew me away. Some of the skewers were good but each are pricey.
author: J. Karim A.

description:
Food was pretty good and unique. Service was fast and attentive, I think because we went on a Saturday right when it opened for lunch (we had come from the Ferry Plaza farmer's market) at 11:30am. 


What we GOT AND ENJOYED: 
- Sunny side-up egg with shrimp, crispy potatoes, and chorizo sauce (really tasty eaten with all components and extra pop of flavor with the pine nuts; shrimp was cooked perfectly)
- Grilled Albondigas (duck and pork meatballs) with tempranillo & cherry puree & shallots
- Olive Oil Poached Salmon Salad (simple, clean, stands on its own)

What else we got but was...MEH:
- chicken & pea croquetas (we didn't think this was absolutely amazing with the flavor, but the texture of the crispy outside with the creamy inside was nice)

DRINKS:
- barca gintonic: very pretty to look at...but for $12? Not sure if it's worth getting again.
- limonada (roasted sparkling lemonade with rosemary and seasonal fruit--blueberries): my sister and I love this non-alcoholic "soft libation". Very refreshing.

We all agree we would definitely come back to try more things on their menu...we were just there for a bite to eat because we had snacked on so many things throughout our morning at the farmer's market.

All in all, good enough to get me to come back to try more!

SERVICE:
Very good. Our waiter was very attentive to us, the runners got our empty plates out of the way when needed, and filled our glasses with water without having to ask or wait for us to run our glasses dry. 

Compared to other reviews about service, I think the reason why we had a good dining experience is because we were one of first parties to walk in the door when it opened, so it was definitely less busy than I would expect for a dinner or normal lunch time.
author: Shannon N.

description:
I love coqueta! The drinks are good! The food is amazing! You just can't go wrong at coqueta. 

Lets start out with drinks, they have 4 versions of their Gin and Tonic. You can't go wrong with any of them. They're both good looking and delicious -- A perfect instagram moment :P 

I'd love to come to coqueta with a small group of 2-3 friends. Each of their tapas com with 2-3 bites which doesn't get very sharable with a larger group. The most recent time I visited, I came with one of my girl friends. The table next to us got the steak which is a 32oz bone-in ribeye meant to serve 3-4. It looked amazing and we were ambitious so we ordered that preparing to take some home. We also ordered the egg bites, the coqueta, the jumbo prawn, and uni open-face sandwich. I loved all of our tapas and I'm not even a huge fan of prawns! (Oh, I guess with the exception of the egg-- the egg was just okay. I wouldn't order it again) 

Now for the steak, that steak was amazing! Super juicy and fatty and perfectly seasoned. The only surprise was that it was actually quite small. If we ordered the steak alone, it probably wouldn't have filled the 2 of us up. :( I'd definitely recommend the steak, it definitely also on the pricier side at $84 pre tip and tax. 

Finally for dessert, we ordered the chocolate lava cake. I can't eat much chocolate since I'm slightly allergic but I had parts of the crust with the milky sauce. I would recommend it if you like chocolate lava cakes :) 

Coqueta can definitely get pricey pretty quickly if you have a big appetite and love a variety. Try to make a reservation in advance so you own't end up standing outside for a couple hours!
author: Annie Z.

description:
I'm Spanish and I would not recommend this place to my enemies

Overpriced and flavorless food. The pa amb tomquet was done with fried tomato sauce, the paella had chorizo and lacked salt, the shrimps were undercooked.

Clearly never coming back, so many other better places in the city
author: Francesc F.

description:
Call my pallet unrefined...but I never really developed an affinity for tapas.  Maybe it's the combination of exceedingly small portions and typically high prices, but I have never been a fan and usually try to weasel out of social engagements at tapas spots.

I now realize that my lack of excitement over tapas was actually due to the fact that I had not experienced the "right" tapas place...that is until now!

We had the pleasure of dining at Michael Chiarello's Coqueta on a beautiful sunny SF Saturday.  Despite the hundreds of cars circling the Embarcadero, I scored primo parking right across the street from Pier 5...I should of known that this was a sign of good things to come.  Upon arrival, we were promptly seated to our reserved table.  The actual restaurant space is modern, stylish and airy.  The adjoining bar area is particularly cool with its breathtaking views of the Bay. 

We started things off with some drinks.  I had the Almond Joy which was a very tasty sans-alcohol concoction of almond, honey, fig and tonic.  My better half had a latte made with Four Barrel.  For an app, we opened with the cheese platter which featured 3 different cheeses, jam, almonds and bread.  This was quite good.

For tapas, we tried the Mar Y Montana (Sea Urchin Toast), Crispy Shrimp quesadilla, Croquettes, Duck & Pork meatballs and the Sunny Side Up Egg.  Every single dish was perfectly prepared and delicious.  If I had to pick one highlight, the Sunny Side Up Egg's artful combination of rich flavors with contrasting soft/crunchy textures made this the craze amaze dish of our meal.

For desserts, we went with the cheesecake and the sangria poprocksicle.  Of the two, I would recommend trying the sangria pop.  On a hot day, this is refreshingly unique.

Coqueta has single-handedly changed my take on tapas and for this I am grateful :)  We will definitely plan on coming back for more.
author: Justin L.

description: Yes what's up with this new "made reservation but still sit at the bar" new business?  The hostess was rude and was insisting to put us at the bar though we made reservation weeks in advance (shouldn't really matter when we made it anyways - reservation is a reservation for a table and not other nonsense).  Food is great though expensive.  They need to address this bs with reservation otherwise I would switch to going to Bellota.
author: Ruslan K.

description:
This is so far my favorite tapas place. It's a cute medium size restaurant overlooking the pier that gets very packed. Make reservations, or there is a bar for walk-ins as well.

Highlights of the night were octopus and shoulder pork loin. Will update this review once I come back for more!!

Ps. Their cocktails are super cute.
author: Mandy D.

description:
my sister and friends asked me to pick a place for my birthday brunch and this is my choice since I've been wanting to try here for AGES
came yesterday and our server was so wonderful 
we started off with the red wine sangria (yummy)
1. the chorizo skewer - this was no bad but was literally just two bites 
2. the potato chips - such smokey deliciousness esp. with the vermouth hot sauce that came with (will definitely order again next time)
3. the duck & pork meatballs topped with fried shallots- we liked them so much we ordered seconds! they were THAT good
3. the wild mushrooms- we ordered seconds of this as well - these were so flavorful 
4. the paella - there were generous amount of shrimps and clams in this dish and the portion was quite big to feed the 4 of us - the rice was delicious 
5. the roasted sweet peppers with slivers of Spanish ham - the peppers were so sweetly smokey 
6. Spanish ham with thin toasts - so glad we ordered this after we like the slivers of ham tat came with the sweet peppers
7. deviled eggs - this was not too bad 

we finished off by ordering 4 different desserts to share and the server threw in a freeby for the birthday girl 
the churro was delicious on its own - but it came with a chocolate dip as well (not needed)
the chocolate fudge cubes came with a delicious creamy chocolaty sauce - this was very enjoyable 
I picked some cake thing that was filled with a yummy cream 
there was one other (don't remember the name) but it reminds me of bread pudding - we like this as well
the free dessert was 4 lollipop things that turns out to be really great bite size cheesecakes 

so looking forward to returning with my BFF in a couple of weeks 

FYI it's easier to get brunch reservations than for dinner
author: Mia C.

description:
This place was by far our favorite restaurant  dining experience this time in San Francisco. 

Do yourself a favor and get:
*Salmon Ahumado - order at least 2 separate orders if you're with a date -- bc these are too good to share. 
*Mar y monatana - sea urchin with iberico. Melt in your mouth delicious 
*Patatas Bravas - always a staple in any tapas order but man oh man they really do it right here
*Chorizo - kind of skimpy on the amount they give you but it's still delicious 

Plus/Minus:
*Paella - good but just not $45 good 

Skip:
*Razor Clams 

Great ambience, good service, and great for a cute date night or night out with good friends. My Hubbie and I ate with drinks for ~$150 pre-tip.
author: Jacqueline L.

description:
I don't know why I didn't leave a review yet.. Not that I need to. 

I made reservations for a weekday at the end of November (2013) for two. I went with a friend to celebrate our birthdays and it lived up to the hype. I'm usually very skeptical about going to a restaurant or movie when I hear so much about it. I'm sooo so glad that I went!

The dishes were great! But what really stood out to me, oddly enough, was the limonada. It was so crisp and refreshing. And went exceptionally well with the rich and hot foods that we ordered. 

I'll keep this short since other Yelpers have so eloquently described many of the dishes that I ate. We ordered the patatas bravas, chicken and English pea croquetas, sunny-side up egg, whole Monterey calamari on the plancha, grilled beef short ribs, Manchego cheesecake pops with caramel corn, and churros! The churros had this raspberry colored powder that my friend described as "red velvet and raspberry goodness"! 

The presentation was just as amazing as the taste of all of the dishes. I'll have to find another special occasion to celebrate so that I have an excuse to order up the other portion of the menu that I have yet to try.
author: Venna Q. T.

description: I visited this restaurant about six months ago, so admittedly, things might have changed. I chose this restaurant due to the proximity to the Bay Bride Light Show and the Pier for an evening walk afterwards. However, I found the experience below average. I had made reservations and we arrived early only to find out that our seats had been given away and we were given the option to wait for a table or sit at the bar. Because we had been sight-seeing all day and were tired and hungry (and it was late- 9:30PM) we chose to just grab a seat at the bar. The restaurant itself was packed and bustling. Tables were crammed together and it seems like a hot Friday night spot. I chose a pinot noir which was terrible. I rarely ever ask for an exchange but I simply could not down this wine. I switched to a merlot which was fine. The food came out quickly and was just average. I will say that despite it being crowded and having to navigate through the throngs of people everywhere waiting to be seated, our server was exceptionally pleasant. Bottom line: choose somewhere else or arrive very early.
author: Priya S.

description:
Service: Friendly and knowledgeable. Waiters seem to work together and they all seem happy to be working there which is welcome and makes one feel valued. 
Atmosphere: It's right next to the water with a nice bar that looks over the Pier and it has a well-designed interior that is comfortable, lively and attractive. It seems to be crowded usually and it can be a tight squeeze or a little too close if the table next to you is loud, but I did not have this problem. 
Drink: They specialize in gin drinks, but all the drinks seem to be well made. I had a rum drink that was designed similar to an Old Fashioned and it was delicious. 
Food: They specialize in small plates that are meant to be shared. I recommend the Coles de Bruselas (Brussel Sprouts) and the Albondig as a la Feria (Duck/Pork Meatballs), which are both good and nice to share. I would give the skewers a miss though, since I don't think you get enough bang for your buck. People seemed to love the Charcuterie as well.
Overall: It's a fun spot and worth checking out. Good for groups, a date or drinks as long as people like to share. A little pricey IMO for the amount. I am torn between 3/4 stars because I sometimes feel I rate everything 4...
author: George S.

description:
I came here for a friend's birthday, and was very happy with the unique and delicious dishes as well as the excellent service. The lucky birthday boy had two champagne bottles waiting from his girlfriend who's currently in Singapore, and our server was super incredible for organizing the secret mission. In addition to the champagne, we indulged in some sangria which was suuper delicious. I could have had them forever but tried to be mindful of the two glasses of champagne that I had already consumed, oops. 

Absolutely loved our meat & cheese platter and was happy to try some cheeses and spices I hadn't tried before. Although I was super excited to try the bite-size skewers that our server brought to us to pick and choose from, I wasn't too happy with the quail eggs or chorizo one. There was consensus around the table that the skewers looked better than they tasted. Thankfully, the gastronomic experience was exponentially uphill after the skewers though, especially recommend the albondigas (I think they come in 3 so ask for more if you're a bigger party, you're not gonna want to share these), gambas negras and the paella. Save room for dessert for sure because the arroz con leche cake with the arroz con leche ice cream is a game changer!
author: Aradhana V.

description:
Very polite and humorous service. Excellent food. Great location.
Ate here right before my flight back home and wasn't disappointed one bit. I'll definitely be coming back
author: Sohee K.

description:
Excellent spanish tapas restaurant near Pier 5. The menu is relatively short, but everything I had was delicious. The ambience and service were excellent.

This is now one of my first choices for tapas in SF. It is particularly nice on a sunny day sitting in the glassed off addition that faces Embarcadero.
author: David T.

description: Goodservice. Best to get the pitcher of Agua de Valencia($19). It's the most bang for your buck and tastes pretty good. Also, there is outdoor seating but it doesnt face the water. I haven't tried their food.
author: Neil P.

description:
After a long day of urban hiking, we dropped by here for an early tapas dinner and some refreshing drinks. We ate at the bar, wanting a more informal setting, and it was quite nice (albeit a small area). The only thing is to remember that you ARE ordering tapas, so no looks of disappointment when the things you order aren't served as mountains of food.

We started with the baby beets with watercress, vinagreta, some chopped nuts, and a dusting of bleu cheese. Presentation-wise, absolutely gorgeous. The beets were flavorful and cooked to perfection, and it was a delight to eat the dish (leaving us wanting more, really).

After that, we wanted the AMAZING sounding Mar y Montana, but of course, they weren't serving it that day, so we settled for the pan con tomate with crispy bread and tomato fresco - very refreshing, and definitely worth trying for its simple deliciousness.

Next were the tattas bravas (one of my favorites) - crispy potato and jamon nuggets with an aioil - yet another dish leaving you wishing there was more, each succulent potato was topped with a drop of a creamy white sauce, and ready to be dipped in the creamy orange sauce in the center of the plate.

Finally, we had the wood-grilled octopus, with fingerling potatoes, pimenton, and olive oil. It came beautifully presented, everything was still warm, and it was fun stabbing up little delicious bites with the elongated toothpicks provided.

All in all, a delicious, light meal, at a location I would most certainly return to. My only confusion was why the afternoon bar menu (served until 4:30ish) had a bunch of amazing sounding desserts, including a manchego cheesecake, but on the dinner menu we received, there was only one?
author: Claire S.

description:
I rarely post anymore, but I am not in a particular impressed mood. Food is not only flavor, but the experience.

2 stars. Food was decent, captures a lot of the different flavors described in their menu, specifically the albondigas. We still enjoyed the pluma dish, although pork was slightly undercooked.

My issue is with the service. Very poor today unlike my other experiences there. Very long waits, less personable and frankly, just because we're not old, dressed in a suit, etc. doesn't mean we don't have the cash to blow. I guess the server was focused on the group tables because she was looking for tips. But if you are understaffed, then resource appropriately.

Also, we very unimpressed with how they were completing business paperwork in front of us. We sat there so we could watch the chefs, not watch you complete an invoice.
author: Angela K.

description: Ate here in April w some friends. Food is good but probably hyped. Tried to wait for table yesterday and hostess was extremely rude and obviously catering to certain types of customers. Don't waste your time or money.
author: S K.

description:
BORING FOOD
This place is over rated. The food is salty and insipid and the service is slow. All in all a big yawn.  There are many better tapas restaurants in SF.
author: James M.

description: very nice tapas place. The waiter was very attentive. Since we have 7 people, we ordered all the hot tapas from the menu. Everything tasted delicious. I think the highlight would be the octopus and the creme brûlée. A bit pricey for a lunch!
author: Sally W.

description: Went for dinner before going to see Hamilton.  a sweet time.  We had reservations at 5:00 pm on a Friday night and were seated promptly.  Already packed and jumping.  We enjoyed a great meal.  Patatas Bravas: great.  Paella: excellent (asked for the Chorizo to be removed as we are not meat eaters, no problem).  Fish: excellent.  Gambas Negras: excellent, not overcooked (!++!).   Service was smooth and professional.  You can spend a lot of money here just breathing but the food, service, and atmosphere of the restaurant and location on the beautiful Embarcadero make it a worthy choice for a special occasion.  Going back with family from LA.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Honestly after dining at bottega, Michael Chiarello's other restaurant in Napa I was a little bit disappointed. 
The restaurant is Spanish tapas/small plates style with good cocktails and a decent selection of wines.
It is very crowded and really loud. Service was overall pretty prompt. 
My husband and I dined here for our second anniversary and I was hoping as the location is on the water that we would get some romantic setting which we really didn't. There weren't very many seats to be had that had window views at all. The atmosphere is trendy but the tall ceilings made it very loud.
I husband ordered the Mojito which was nothing like a typical Mojito in all the best ways imaginable.i had the brut bubbly which was perfect.
Once we were seated over 40 minutes late when we had a reservation we were crammed into a very tiny space. The table was centered so that the person seating along the fabric benched side of the table was seating in the crack. The waitress did help us move the table but there were only about 4 inches to move it. The sitting part of my dining experience wasn't lovely :/

Our dinner began with the fuet which was fantastic.
We next received the Ensalada de Achicoria & Coliflor con Romescu- they were both good but the cauliflower dish was definitely our favorite. If I were dining there again I would probably only order the cauliflower dish.
At coqueta they bring around small bite-size bites on Toothpicks called and pintxos.  We were only able to try to of them and one was decent the other was horrible.

One of the Pintxos- Tortilla de Espinacas - i'm so glad they only had 1left it was disgusting I wish Ihadn't taken a single bite


The Jamn  serano pinto- manchego & apricot- sherry conserva- pretty good

Next we were brought the octopus which had been recommended to us- I'm so glad it was! One of the best octopus I've ever had. 

Duck & pork meatballs- they were a little sweet/ my favorite dish of the evening 
Our last item of the meal was the Lubina a la Brasa which is served with the head & with a large wedge of grilled lemon, flake salt, & a green olive & preserved Meyer lemon salsa on the side with a little salsa on top. I I understand this concept however I felt like we were doing a lot of the dishes work by seasoning it. I understand that sometimes people like to season it to their own tasting but it actually got a little messy and I really would have preferred for the kitchen to season our fish. This was my husband's favorite dish of the night I wished we had stopped at the meatballs. 
We chose churros for dessert & they were pretty good but not the best I've ever had. The berry powder was a nice touch.
Overall, I'm giving them 3 out of 5 stars due to our wait on a Wednesday night, the noisy environment and the fact that all not all of their dishes were 100% spot on. Admittedly I am a bit spoiled by some amazing restaurants we have in the city. I would give them another try.
author: Ashley G.

description:
Love the SF bay vibes coming from here and the wood fired grill makes you feel like you're tucked away in a cozy cabin!! We went for a little bit of everything and would not have had it any other way. 

The pixtos (small bites) change quite often but make sure you say yes when they come around. 

Finally, steer clear of getting too close to the raw wood walls. We walked away with some pretty nasty splinters that were not as friendly as the service.
author: Amy V.

description: Great spot, food is off the hook! Love this place. Can't go wrong with the bar seating especially on a sunny breezy day!
author: Fuey D.

description:
Well -- the drinks are beautiful, like little pieces of art in a glass. For that, I give Coqueta a few stars. The setting is also great -- on the embarcadero with some views of the Bay. Check, check. However, the scene was SUPER bro-ey (sp?) last Friday at Happy Hour. Like legit, there were dudes attempting to scale the walls outside of the bar, and they were somehow not kicked out. This is bay to breakers type behavior happening on average Friday afternoon after work. Not so cool. I'm not sure that I would return for that reason. 

Also, freshly dug potatoes are on the menu. Epically San Francisco. They were tasty. Definitely grabbed undertones of fresh earth ;)
author: Kate B.

description:
You got to know why you go in here. they are known for their tapas and the drinks.
Its a perfect place to grab a drink and have some tapas and then go on with your evening. I had one of there dinner entrees and wasn't really blown away. but their tapas were out of this world. The wait staff here does take there time to get to your table but i believe that its on purpose as the restaurant is a more of a social gathering spot. the ambiance is great and and location is ideal. 

the reason i have to knock down two stars is its expensive for not that much food, i know its expected by it still hurts. Also we got shrimp tapas but they left a big piece of one of those hor d'oeuvres sticks,   a round ball with red paint was left inside the shrimp. the waiter said that it was to make the shrimp straight for presentation. I really do think they should have used something other than the hor d'oeuvres sticks to do that. They did give us another order  of it, this time the shrimp was straight at all. 

Its still a great place, but some of our experience and expectations were kinda let down due to some one of things i think. i will give this place another shot and then update. but for now its a 3.
author: Anuj C.

description:
This place is amazing. 

First, Erica the hostess should get a promotion because she made us feel special even though it was so busy and kept checking up on us and her velvet dress was so cute. 

Second, all of the Alexes were so nice and funny and took time to take care of our ridiculous demands.  

The food was a 10. No complaints except that couple sitting across from us in that matching plaid picnic 

Go.
author: Julia T.

description:
The tapas here are delicious - love the meat and cheese plate. Gin and tonics are also super pretty, tequila drinks are bangin, and can't go wrong with the sangria pitcher.

It's usually pretty packed when I've gone by on Saturdays but haven't struggled too hard to find a couple open seats.

Outdoor seating is excellent for people watching.

Nice bay views, especially nice during sunset.
author: Katie N.

description:
Dined here twice within 7 days.
Ordered the uni cracker, calamari with squid ink aioli, and churro in addition to some of what we had last week.

Expensive for the portions. Oh well. 

Best churro EVER.  My dinner companion agreed.
author: Angelica C.

description: Don't understand the hype. The food was ok and overpriced. The cocktails were good. Would not return.
author: Arch D.

description:
Took the gf here for her birthday, we had a reservation and were seated promptly at our table. The restaurant is located on the Embarcadero with some partial views of the bay. The dining room is a lot more cozy and intimate than I thought it would be which gave a warm, comforting ambiance. 

We ordered a carafe of sangria which was delicious and refreshing; bonus points for it being served in an awesome looking vessel. I was eyeballing the gin and tonics our neighbors were sipping on as they looked quite interesting with lots of floral components thrown in. If I ever get the chance to come back here, I'm probably getting one of those. We each got some of the bitesize skewers that they brought around. I got the quail egg diablo, chorizo and artichoke, and the serrano ham and cheese. I would advise to skip these as I didn't think any of them were particularly impressive and overpriced in my opinion at $2.50 a pop. I did appreciate the concept of the small bites and the beautiful platter on which they were presented and served.

We ordered 3 small dishes and a paella. The grilled razor clams were a special that day. I think this was the first time I've had razor clams; they were quite tender and the sauce added some nice acidity.  The sunny side up huevo with shrimp was probably my favorite dish; the crispy potato strings gave the dish great texture and the chorizo dressing added some good heat. Next up, were the grilled duck and pork meatballs were solid and had great texture and flavor. Then came the paella which was quite massive, it probably could've fed a family of four. The flavors were excellent but I thought the rice ratio was a bit high compared to the proteins and veggies. If you know you're planning on getting this dish, order it first as it takes around 30-40 minutes for it to come out.

We capped things off with a decadent flan, they added a chocolate birthday card on the top of it for the birthday girl. This was the first restaurant of Michael Chiarello that I have dined at. I've heard good things about his restaurant in Napa but I thought this one fell a bit short. I thought the tapas were a bit small in their portions for the price and while flavors were solid for the mostpart, there wasn't anything mind-blowing.
author: Kevin N.

description: This place has a nice vibe/ambiance quick friendly service with a beautiful view. The menu has many great cocktails I had the Margarita and Mojito which were great. My girlfriend had the Sangria which was a bit sweet but otherwise no complaints. The food was exceptional; we had the meat and cheese board, crouquetas and prawns. Chef did a great job of combining flavors. Would definitely come back here!
author: Eric O.

description: Coqueta is a lovely restaurant, and the drinks are great.  We were able to come without a reservation on a Thursday night and quickly grab a couple stools with a great view in their lounge area.  The food was not really to my taste, but I recognize that it was interesting and probably pretty good.  I think they overused the sweet in the sweet and savory combinations, but I think I'm in the minority there.  Overall, the combo of drinks, view, and a pretty day makes up for it!
author: Salini N.

description:
Love the venue, and it has a great view. 

Food is pricey and that is expected if you are dining at one of the piers. Just note that the yelp photos make the food items look A LOT bigger than it is. 

We had reservations for 2 and was seated on time, although, service was slow. It was expected because it was about 6PM on a friday night, but still, it took like 10-15 minutes till we were even greeted by our waitress and another 10-15 minutes to get us water. 

The food was delicious, I recommend the Pluma (Pork shoulder loin). It was amazing. There were these red stripes of chili or something that you would put on the pieces of pork and it would add a spicy crunch to the meat, heavenly. The other dish I really enjoyed was the duck and pork meatballs. 

I could recommend that you go with a larger group, at least 6 people, then you can take advantage and get the larger dishes like the beef rib eye and the paella.
author: Allen C.

description: Wonderful Spanish food with a twist. Staff are friendly and helpful. As a Spaniard I am quite picky about the food served at Spanish restaurants but this was outstanding. Can't say enough about the staff, everyone was knowledgeable and "muy amable". The albóndigas and the croquetas were the best I have ever had in a restaurant. The whole experience was memorable
author: Doris L.

description:
83%

I've been here a few times, sat in the bar and the dining room -- my most recent trip was this week.

The food is prepared well, the menu is varied, the service was fine -- but the experience overall wasn't a 'wow'. 

The highlights: The albondiagas a la feria (duck and pork meatballs) were fantastic. For me, the high point of the meal. The gambas al negro (poached whole prawns) were delicious. 

Everything else we ordered - the patatas bravas, the padron peppers, some pinxtos, arroz cremoso, churros, two drinks -- were just okay. Nothing was bad.

So why the 83%? The arroz cremoso (saffron bomba rice) was under seasoned. The pinxtos (mini skewers) didn't have much flavor. The portions were particularly small, even for tapas. The bill for 2 was $100+ not including tip.

The restaurant and the bar are situated on a beautiful strip of the embarcadero.  The decor, the place settings and dining room are well chosen for the theme of the restaurant. Ambience on a weekday afternoon (first seating with a reservation), is bustling but not rushed or suffocating. 

I'd come again, but wouldn't go out of my way unless they switched up the menu.
author: Kay C.

description: Awesome atmosphere and good food, but can get a bit crowded and hard to track down a waiter.
author: stacy a.

description:
Really really really love the food and atmosphere. The red sangria is literally the best... each time I've gone I haven't been able to stop drinking it. I've gone with the chef and server recommendations each time and almost everything has been great. I continue to recommend and bring travelers to Coqueta as they always enjoy it and the area of town is great to walk around. Dessert is great too. 

Unfortunately the service is always a bit off and I get the vibe of, "we don't really need your business" whenever I'm there. They're terrible at seating you, even when the place is empty. Kind of bizarre each time I've gone. Whatever... luckily, the food/drinks make up for it.
author: Max C.

description:
If you want to sit at a real table, make a reservation ahead of time! Honestly, I have never had tapas before, and I had no idea what to expect. Also, I must note that I have never had a gin and tonic before - weirdly enough - and the Barça gin and tonic was so amazing!!! I will forever have a high bar for a gin and tonic for the rest of my life. (Their sangria was...okay, I guess...)

Since OpenTable and the receptionist made me very aware of how there were no reservations/tables available on a Saturday, my friend and I sat at the patio. It was so tiny, and the high chair was not very good for my back -- totally our bad for wanting to eat here for weekend brunch. Anyway, tapas - small dishes, also pricey here. 

We had (copying straight from the Winter 2014 menu):
1) "El Plat Cap" (Chef's selection of cured meats, $26) -- this was an "OK" starter. Having been spoiled with amazing French charcuterie at other restaurants, I was not impressed.
2) Patatas Xips y Salsa Aperitivo (House made smokey potato chips with shaved manchego and membrillo Vermouth vinegar, $4) -- the chips alone were delicious and had very nice textures. I did not enjoy the "salsa" though, as I found it too vinegar-y.
3) Patatas Bravas (Freshly dug, lightly smoked, crispy new potatoes, bravas salsa, and garlic alioli, $8) -- I am not a big fan of potatoes (trust me, it is hard to believe, especially since I've lived in Germany), and found this to be too hot (temperature-wise) at first, but it was yummy.
4) Gambas al negro (Olive oil poached head-on gulf prawns with black garlic and chili sauce, $14) -- OK, honestly, aside from the gin and tonic, THIS was my favourite thing!!!! It was SO flavourful and delicious. Sadly, there are only three prawns and three slices of bread, but the sauce is plentiful.
5) Pintxos (Bite-size skewers, $2.50 each):
5a) House cured boquerones (White anchovies, olives, pearl onions, and guindilla peppers) -- cold, but it was pretty good, a lot better than I expected.
5b) Huevos de Codorniz (Quails egg "Diablo", pickled mustard seed, and jamón Serrano) -- also cold, and was not what I expected, I preferred the other skewer I ordered.

VERDICT: Maybe Spanish tapas are not for me, or the Californian touch on some of the dishes threw me off, but I was definitely not on the same page as my friend. I will say, though: the gin and tonic and prawn dishes are enough to make me want to come back. All the other foods I ordered: I could care less. Because I sat at the patio, I felt really cramped, and there was no real nice view of the waterfront.

The service here was so-so. Never connected with the server, and it was fairly slow, but, whatever, I'll just enjoy my alcohol.
author: Kelley L.

description: Fourth or fifth time here and it never disappoints. Jamon Iberico, Pulpo, Gambas!!! Three must try tapas. Hostess was beautiful and made us feel special. Service by Scotty was as good as it gets...personal, professional, & amazing! This guy is at the top of his game and is one of the best servers I have seen, anywhere. Thought we might get a sub par experience dining on Christmas Eve, but it was the best experience here so far.
author: Markus N.

description: One of the first restaurants I tried when I moved to SF several years ago...it will always be a favorite! GREAT food and drinks, with a beautiful view of the water.
author: Shilps S.

description:
Great Location, ambiance, customer service ,and food. This is one of my favorite tapas restaurant in SF. They also have an amazing menu of Gin & Tonic cocktails. Im not a gin & tonic drinker, Im more of a bourbon drinker, but I still enjoy their cocktails. I have dined here before for dinner but today was the first time for brunch. They open at 11:30 am on Saturdays and I was able to make an 11:30 reservation at 11:00 am through Open Table. By 12:45pm, the entire restaurant was packed. Its also very hot inside because there are only 2 small windows that open to ventilate this restaurant. Luckily, we sat right next to these 2 windows. 

Today my dining experience was great but the only downfall is that they didnt have the Pork Shoulder today (and just to mention again we arrived when the restaurant opened at 11:30am). This is the second time this has happened to me so thats why Im not willing to
give this place a whole 5 stars. If its that popular why cant they have it?

For drinks I highly recommend the famous gin & tonic and the galleon. For food the croquetas, grilled octopus, the sunny side up, the duck & pork meatballs,  paella, and cheesecake pops. These items will not disappoint. I would recommend that pork shoulder but they probably wouldnt have it anyways. Just saying.
author: Sarina A.

description:
Coqueta has been on the top of my list for a long time now.  On a spontaneous sunny Saturday, we were walking our dog in the area and decided to stop by for a mid-day snack.

Since we had a dog with us, our only option was to sit outside at one of two available communal tables.  There were tons of bussers coming and going to refill water, but our server was nowhere to be found.  It took us almost 30 minutes to find our server so we decided to order everything at once, knowing they might not be back until we were ready to pay. [minus 1 star for slow service]

What we got:

Kalimotxo - Sangria mixed with coke and cinnamon that comes in a Spanish party pitcher.  The coke made it bubbly, which was a refreshing spin on the typical sangria.

Bite Sized Skewers - the menu says "offered at tableside", which we found out later, meant that they will pre-make a bunch of skewers and bring you the whole board to pick out the skewers you want.  I don't prefer it served this way, since I feel like the food isn't as fresh when it's been "chillin" on the board for who knows how long.  The 5 skewer options were: house cured boquerones, chorizo, jamon serrano, tortilla de espinacas, huevos de codorniz.  My favorite was  the tortilla de espinacas because the cana de cabra cheese was delicious.  

Sunny Side-Up Huevo - this dish BLEW MY SOCKS OFF, we were shamelessly scraping the very last bits off the plate.  The dish comes with 4 medium sized shrimps, crispy potato strings, a sunny-side egg and chorizo dressing.  The chorizo dressing, which is basically chorizo oil with crumbled chorizo, really makes the dish.   After combining the egg and the potato, the dish is spicy marriage of flavors and textures.

Around 5pm, the sun was beginning to wane, and the pier suddenly got REALLY windy and cold.  My advice would be to find seating indoors if you're able to.  Overall, the food was pretty good, I wouldn't say the skewers lived up to the hype, but I'd come back for the egg dish.
author: Michelle W.

description:
3.5 stars. Cocktails 5 stars.

Let's start with the $45 Paella. Rice underneath a pile of shrimp, clams, veggies. It did not blow me away and I didn't think it was that flavorful.

Next, the bagel bite looking uni (uni, bread, some type of ham) the uni was creamy and fresh but it was served on a semi hard circular bread which didn't add to the uni. I rather eat uni by itself.

Chicken coquette - hot cheesiness inside with thin strips of chicken was by far the best tapa of the night.

I went here during the thanksgiving break and the place was still very pack. 

The service was great and the waitress was very charming and friendly. She came around with samples of quail eggs and ham and cheese on a sick for us to try.

My favorite cocktail there was the conquistador which reminded me of a carribean vacation.
author: Kelly C.

description: Wasn't hugely impressed which is a bummer because I was really excited to check it out. The issue was mostly around the service. It took a long time to get our drink order and the bar area was mass confusion where we witnessed the wrong ordered getting delivered to the wrong table twice! It has the makings of a wonderful spot, but we paid too much for our average drinks and meat plate. I'm hoping to see if the dinner experience fares better than our afternoon cocktail outing. So close to being a dreamy place.
author: Katie S.

description: The charcuterie board with assorted meats and cheeses was definitely the star of the show. We had a ton of assorted tapas and plates that we all thoroughly enjoyed. The drinks were fantastic (took awhile to come out) and the overall vibe and setup made it a very welcoming environment. The only thing that my guests and I weren't too crazy about was our server. She seemed to start off okay. Her demeanor seemed friendly and welcoming. But as the evening progressed I was beginning to wish that we had a different server more and more. Bad service makes good food taste bad, it's as simple as that. We weren't greeted by her to begin with. Her extremely friendly and capable neighbor (awesome flamboyant guy with perfect hair) greeted us and made us feel welcome and comfortable from the beginning. But when she took over she took forever to come back to the table and take our actual food order. I understand that sometimes it's awkward to come back and take a food order when the drinks haven't come out yet and it's been a while...but if that's ever the case all you have to do is say your drinks should be out shortly but in the meantime may I get an order started for you? That's all you have to do. And throughout our experience her attitude just got worse and worse and she just dropped the pretense of caring at all and she was acting as if it was a hindrance to serve us. I never give yelp reviews less than 5 stars but in this case I feel that three is appropriate. If it had been solely based on our server (Sarah or something?) this would be a 1-2 star review. She only perked up when she dropped off the check realizing that oh yeah they have to tip me based off my SERVICE. The two other gentleman and I all work in the industry so for us tipping 15% is really not typical. But because it was so bad and affected our experience we really didn't feel that bad about it.
author: Jessica F.

description: Small plates for sharing give you and your party a chance to sample lots of options without gorging yourself. Be adventitious! You won't go wrong with any selection. The wait staff is intimately familiar with the menu and they will help. Bring your own wine if you like but try the signature cocktails; fun, delicious, interesting! The mojito is pictured here. Yum!! Leave room for dessert. Beautiful decor, great service,  perfect location on the Embarcadero, amazing flavors and presentations. We'll be back!
author: Lorraine P.

description:
Absolutely loved this place. Had a reservation for 2 on a Wednesday night. The place was pretty crowded but we got seated at our reserved time. We were seated next to the open kitchen so we got to see the chefs make all the amazing food =)

I didn't take a picture of the menu so forgot the actual names of what we had...

To start with, we had a couple of things on the small toothpicks. We ordered the quail egg one of the menu but then the waitress walked around with a wooden board that had a bunch of other ones so we tried two more. These were probably my least favorite part of the meal... they were nothing spectacular especially for the price.

Then we had the Sunny-side up egg with shrimp, crispy potatoes, chorizo which was amazing! The egg mixed really well with the shoe string potato/fries thing and everything was really well spiced.

We also had the wood-grilled octopus with fingerling potatoes, pimenton, and olive oil. This was probably my favorite dish of the night. Both potatoes and octopus were really tender and smooth - pretty much cooked to perfection.

Grilled Iberico Secreto - I believe this was the pork dish but it really tasted like beef... still absolutely delicious. 

We also ordered some rice dish with scallops in a tomato sauce. This was a pretty solid dish.


I loved most of the dishes we ordered here and I really want to go back to try some others!
author: Lily L.

description:
Every aspect of this little tucked away hot spot was on point. The atmosphere, soundtrack, lighting, cuisine, service and overall casual festive feeling of our experience made for a perfect place to have a end of year celebration.
We tried the paella which was stellar... Some say better than the paella we found in the big tourist cities of Spain. Fresh ingredients and food made with love. A few other faves were the Gambas negras, sunny side egg dish and croquetas. We ended the night with the manchego cheesecake bites which were amaze!!!!

Can't wait to go back for drinks.
author: Em G.

description:
They're getting away with murder-or rather soggy old olives and subpar cheese plates masked with beautiful thyme garnish. The flavors don't have a logical flow, lots of blandness and sugary awkward flatbreads. The steak was
$80 but mostly bones. Awesome view and great for a bottle of wine but pretentious cocktails and disappointing food. I'll be back for wine.
author: Lera D.

description:
Pretty great tapas restaurant located on the waterfront of the Embarcadero. Perfect for date night or if you want some delicious spanish fare with equally amazing drinks. The service was fantastic and the ambiance is great. You can go casual or dress up and feel comfortable and welcomed. 

Reservations should be made a few weeks ahead of time if you want guaranteeed seating. 

This place is a must try!
author: Susie O.

description:
I love this restaurant. Great place to get some tapas and a drink or even have dinner. The waitstaff is friendly and the service is good, too! The food is really great. Everything tasted fresh and had a lot of flavor. I love their drinks, too. Their GinTonic is not only delicious, but beautifully presented as well. 

My only complaint about this place is the bathroom situation. There are only two toilets for this restaurant and bar. The line was 8 people long when I went. There is even have a sign letting patrons know they can leave the restaurant and walk to a public restroom outside if the line is long.

I would recommend this place but just be aware that you may have to wait a while if you need to use the restroom.
author: Mandy C.

description: Top rate service and a symphony of delectable flavors made for a wonderful experience at Coqueta! I had to plan a birthday lunch and everyone was pleased with this choice. Very fun to share plates and enjoy the inventive and delicious drinks. I've always been a fan of TV chef Michael Chiarello who got me hooked on grey salt. He's got a home run on his hands with Coqueta and I'm going back to try the "Gaucho" Bistec wood grilled bone-in 32oz natural beef ribeye with aromatic Moorish pepper. Our server was fantastic and made the birthday very special. BRAVO!
author: Dawn D.

description:
Surprisingly good.
