I was kind of hesitant because the egg seemed random, but everyone had recommended it to me. It was SO good, the sauce especially. If you mix everything together- potatoes, egg, sauce, shrimp- YUM. Would for sure order it again. Lastly, we got the paella. For this I would say (4.5/5). It was really good and very filling, definitely for 3 people so we took some home. The shrimp was delicious. The chorizo was also surprisingly good. The lemon aioli to put on top was a little too much for me, so we asked for a side of lemon to squeeze over it. Our waiter brought us a grilled lemon, so fancy. I would have liked to see a little more seafood on it, maybe some scallops or pieces of fish.

Overall: Such a fun date night and really good food. I will definitely be coming here again.
author: Jenna G.

description:
I very rarely give 5's on yelp..but Coqueta deserves it. So far, it is my favorite restaurant in SF. The ambience, the food, the service, physical venue....everything exceeded my expectations. 

From start to finish my dining experience at Coqueta was impeccable. I made a reservation on opentable for lunch on a weekday and on the morning of, I realized I was running about 30 mins late. I called in to see if it would be possible to push back the reservation, and the hostess said it was not a problem but I would possibly get seated at the bar if there were no seats. I was fine with that, and when I got to the restaurant there was seating availability and we were seated immediately. 

I started with the Barça Gintonic (Bloom london dry gin, fever tree tonic, grapefruit). This was unlike any average gin & tonic I've ever had. First of all, it was the prettiest drink I've ever seen (please refer to picture). In terms of taste, You could taste the high quality in every single ingredient, each mixed in together so perfectly -- I wouldn't change a single thing about it. It was a cup of deliciousness. 

We then had the Ensalada de Kale Lacinato Kale (fresh garbanzos, grilled strawberries, Cana de Cabra cheese, cocoa croutons and warm Sherry vinegar dressing). This was the most delicious salad I've ever had. It was the perfect sweetness--almost like a dessert salad--with the strawberry, cocoa croutons and Sherry vinegar dressing mixed together, but the garbanzo beans and croutons gave it the perfect texture as well.

We also had the grilled octopus, croquetas de pollo (chicaron crusted chicken and English pea croquetas with cured cara-cara orange) and wild mushrooms dishes. Those were also amazing. The octopus was fresh and refreshing with a chewy yet light lemon-y taste. The croquetas were good but didn't blow me away (pretty standard), and I loved the mushroom dish mostly b/c I'm a huge fan of mushrooms. 

Lastly, we had the churros for dessert and they were phenomenal. The perfect fried crunchiness dipped in melted cocoa...couldn't have asked for a better meal.

On top of the food, the service and venue were awesome as well. Both the hostess and waitress were extremely friendly and helpful. The venue is a romantic and classy venue good for both a date, girls night out, or even professional lunch. Until next time Coqueta!
author: Heather Y.

description:
This place is more spacious than I expected from the outside. It is in a great location in embarcadero and the place is beautiful.

The food is very artistic and delicious...with many options to choose.
author: Sujung S.

description:
Coqueta lives up to my lofty self perceived perceptions. I have always enjoyed chef Chiarello's Bottega in Yountville and was eager to visit his SF establishment. 

The flavors of the dishes were spectacular. Every dish was very enjoyable. The pork shoulder and the steak were some of our favorites. The octopus dish was also one the best plates. We had a large group and the incredible attentive waitstaff made sure we were well fed. They helped us create a very balanced and filling meal. The duck and lamb meatballs were so tender and flavorful they were gone in an instant. 

The sunny side up stole the show! So good. Our table ended up ordering 5 of them. I might dream of this.
author: Gregory H.

description:
Delicious food, awesome drinks, and gorgeous location- what else can you ask for? =]

We came here on a Friday night, and it was packed. Luckily, we were eventually able to find seats at the bar area, but I would highly recommend making reservations! The restaurant had a fun ambiance. 

My friend and I split a pitcher of Kalimotxo and the paella. The drink came in a cute pitcher, and I'd highly recommend it! The blend of different flavors was amazing. The paella takes a while to cook so be prepared. The portion size wasn't as large as I would have expected, but it was very savory nevertheless.

I'll definitely be back! Some of their cocktails looked really good. =]
author: Aimee Z.

description: Walked in and had high hopes for this restaurant but was disappointed. The tables are so close together the servers kicked my chair every time they walked by. I can understand 1x or 2x, but after that it gets really annoying. The server seemed put off when I asked any questions about the menu, and when it came to the wine could only recommend $100 bottles. Food was good but way overpriced. Won't be going back anytime soon.
author: Aimee E.

description:
Highly highly recommend!

Ambience is very nice and food is amazing. Coming from Chicago which has some pretty decent tapas places, coqueta just brought my tapas standard to a new level. Everything is rich and super flavourful. 

We ordered the dishes that were recommended by the server, namely the sunny side up, the duck meat balls. I am a huge fan of roast mushroom when it comes to tapas, so I got the roast garlic and wild mushroom. We also got the pork shoulder. I was not terribly hungry so we opt out on the paella since the serving size is 2-3 ppl. I did ask for the paella since it is usually 30 wait for one. However, they do pre-hook some ahead of time, so if you are in a mood for paella, make sure that's the first thing that you order.

Everything is very delicious and you can tell the chef tried to include all flavors, savory, sweet etc. Sunny side up came the first and i was amazed by the flavour of the chorizo. Everything was perfectly cooked. 

The pork came the next. It looked a little raw so I was kinda worried. However, it was super tender and juicy with the perfectly crusted outside.

The mushroom is my staple tapas dish and the one at coqueta didn't fail me at all. 

I was not super impressed by the duck meatball as the duck flavor was not as strong as i expected.

We also got the dessert trio. It consisted of a salted caramel, a red pepper? jelly and fig chocolate. The salted caramel was so salty and rich. The trio embodied sweet, savory, sour, and spicy. A delight to my palates.
author: Ruxin H.

description: What a cool space this place is. The food is carefully laid out like a piece of art on cool plates. The flavors are strong and tasty in every bite. The Razor clams are seasonal so I couldn't order them this time. But everything else was delicious! Excellent service too.
author: Cecilia D.

description:
I love the location of Coqueta as it is right along Pier 5 - perfect happy hour spot on a sunny day.

I've come here for HH and for dinner and both were great experiences. For dinner, everything is tapas style, which is great since you'll get to try a little bit of everything. We ordered the a pitcher of sangria, cheese board, octopus, croquetas, cauliflower, and churros. I LOVED the churros - it came with melted chocolate for dipping and dehydrated berries which added a touch of sourness, paired very well with the chocolate. I was slightly disappointed by the service however, our waitress was not as attentative as i hoped for. 

Be sure to order their infamous gin and tonic, it's quite the visually pleasing cocktail.
author: Angela K.

description:
I was pretty excited about this place as the menu was filled with food you would find on menus in Spain, but after trying this place I didn't find anything particularly special about the food. Nothing stood out. 

We ordered:
- Chicken and english pea croquetas - Yummy! The best thing we ate here.
- Grilled octopus - Pretty good relative to the other dishes
- Cheese plate - Good
- Duck and pork meatballs - Mediocre
- Sunny side up egg with shrimp - Not yummy. Too greasy.
- Apple and pear salad - Meh

The service was also pretty slow. I was surprised by how empty the restaurant was when we went for lunch because it was always so hard trying to get reservations there. We even tried that day and they didn't have anything until 1:30pm but it was like empty when we walked in at noon. 

Sometimes I feel like maybe I ordered the wrong items at a restaurant and that's why I didn't like it as much, but I think even if we had ordered more items from the menu it would probably still be a 3 based on the variety that we got. Such a bummer though because if this place was a 4 I could be here like all the time since it's right next to my work, is cute on the inside, and has a nice view of the bay. Oh well.
author: Jeanie F.

description: We just had dinner here on New Year. everying was fantastic! I loved the vibe, food, drinks and service. We ordered four appetitezers and papella. They all tasted so delicious especially papella. Gin and tonic with flora was so wonderful. I think this is my new favorite restaurant.
author: Patti J.

description:
Goodness goodness goodness.... It's places like this that just make your day, thankful for being alive, and especially thankful to be living in the Bay Area.  Today was the absolute perfect day for a lunch here (I assume though that perhaps everyday is)... not only to have a lunch but to be treated to lunch here for my birthday.  My friend and I practically tried everything and of course I had to have the gin and tonic (MUST not only delicious but a botanical art).  There isn't a single thing I can knock about this place.  Location, preparation, service, offerings, view, utensils, lightening, kitchen, staff -- all beautiful.

I know what you are thinking - SIMMER DOWN GIRL.  Ok, I will.

GO HERE, li
author: Zin M.

description:
I have a lot to say about this place good the bad and the so so. 

Where to start?? Well it is always busy and you need a reservation or highly recommended. Which I understand because it's a small place. In fact I feel like I am on top of the table and people next to me. The atmosphere and decor is really nice and rustic. We were earlier then our reservation and lucked out and got seated within 5 min. Our waiter was nice and explained the menu cocktails and gave good suggestions. 

The food..... Was ok. I have had better and for cheaper. I loved the quail egg pickled skewer and the marinated octopus. We ordered the paella and I found it dry and had a burnt tomato after taste which thank god I had their specialty Gin tonic that cleared my palette. Or I thought. Burnt tomato followed me the rest of the night. The dessert we ordered the caramel popcorn cheesecake which was good but left much to be desired. However I think I am being biased because I really wanted the Austrian apple pie with blue cheese ice cream but it was sold out. 

Last but not least. The female bathroom was disgusting. Someone needed to attend to that and ASAP!! The garbage was overflowing. The mirror was splattered, toilet paper was on the floor and the towel dispenser was out and there was hand wipes on a wooden table but far away from the darn sink. For a higher end restaurant the bathroom should be maintained.
author: Marcella H.

description: Highly recommend the bite size skewers.  The chorizo and huevos de codorniz quail egg were amazing.  We also tried the croquetas de pollo, gambas negras, sunny side up, pulpo a la parrilla, the duck and pork meat ball and the paella.  I highly recommend the duck and pork meatball and the octopus.  The paella was ok.  Overall though, great ambiance and good food.  I'd definitely come back.
author: Vincent S.

description: Inside restaurant is small and sitting at the bar gave us the opportunity to watch the cooks at work. Great small bite portions. Full of flavor and well thought out plates. Great service and cocktails. I recommend the sunset cocktail.
author: Esther R.

description:
Alright, I hate to admit this, but the reason why I know about Coqueta is because... sigh... I saw it on the Cooking Channel. (I suppose it could've been worse. It could've been like... on the Food Network via Guy Fieri... Ick!) I was watching an episode of "Kelsey's Essentials." She was boasting about her recent food trip to San Francisco and observed that "Spanish cuisine is all the rage there right now!" Was it ever *not* the rage? I assumed Spanish food has been en vogue for some time... Anyway, she recreated a dish that she said was inspired by a meal at Coqueta. I was so intrigued I attempted to book a reservation ASAP... Alas, I didn't realize how popular Coqueta was/is and had to wait it out. 

My boyfriend and I ordered the red kale ensalada ($11). I enjoyed this and felt this was necessary given the amount of meat we anticipated eating that night. It was refreshing and somewhat substantive. The hazelnuts and squash added a nice textural dimension and bite. The chicken and English pea croquetas were lovely ($9). Nicely fried, hearty, and paired well with the cara-cara orange on the side. It was presented interestingly... three croquetas with three orange slices on a stick. I assumed it was meant to be eaten together at once on a skewer? So I tried doing that... eh, it wasn't very efficient so I stuck to the fork. Anyway, my favorite small plate of the night was the Sunny Side-Up Egg ($13). The accompanying shrimp were perfectly cooked --- plump, juicy, and just warm enough. Our server presented the dish and like a painter. She mixed all the flavors, ingredients, and colors together. Lovely. Our two meat-heavy plates - short ribs ($15) and albondigas ($12) - were also delicious. I will say, however, that the albondigas were common and they didn't look very appetizing. Nevertheless, if you want something hearty, order one of those. Another surprising winner of the night was dessert. The churros with drinking chocolate and dried berry dust ended the meal on a high note. It was fried, but also didn't make us feel immobile afterward. Dipping the churros in the chocolate sauce with some of the berry dust was fun and even more importantly, flavorful. 

Our server was a vibrant woman with a good sense of humor. She was very attentive, friendly, and thoroughly answered my questions. She was also a great promoter of Coqueta telling us of other dishes to try in the future. Coqueta's interior evokes warmth and intimacy... rich colors, dramatic yet suggestive furniture, and seductive art. The clientele were mostly out-of-towners, "girls' night out" pairings (a la Carrie Bradshaw), and the Financial District types. Coqueta made having a meal approximate to "tourists' central" worthwhile!
author: James Z.

description: Reservations highly recommended.  The dining area was completely booked but we found seats in the enclosed pateo/bar area.  We tried the chorizo roasted artichoke, pan con tomate & jamon, patatas bravas, croquetas de pollo, gambas negras, pulpo a la plancha, albondigas a la feria.  Tapas style so be prepared for small servings.  I probably could have eaten more food...our bill for 2 was $90 + tip.  My top re-order dish for next time would be the pulpo  a la plancha octopus and albondigas a la feria duck/pork meatballs.  Other than food, service was good and the view/location is beautiful by the water.  Make sure you walk around the area before or after you eat.
author: R F.

description:
I will preface my review by saying that I'm a sucker for small plates, good wine, and a nice view. Thankfully (for me) Coqueta has all three. 

The food is traditional Spanish tapas; lots of spice, rich flavors, and great seafood. You can pair the plates with selections from a strong wine list, or one of their many creative cocktails. The service was also top-notch. Everyone we encountered was fast, friendly, and made great recommendations based on our interests. 

Situated on the waterfront near the Ferry Building, Coqueta has mostly glass on the walls facing the Bay. This means that on a nice day there are few bad seats. While I went for dinner, I plan to go back for drinks around sunset another time to make the most of their fantastic cocktails and beautiful location.
author: Peter G.

description:
Great place especially when the suns out. They have some outdoor seating and gets pretty packed from 5:30pm onwards.
Every dish we ordered was great and the sangria was well balanced in ratio. 
Paella is fabulous but does take the usual 30-40 min to prepare.
Waiters are attentive and adjusted to dietary allergies and requirements.
author: Van-Anh N.

description: This is going to be short and simple.  By far this is the best gin and tonic I have ever had
author: Corinthian T.

description:
I finally went there for the first time yesterday.    The environment is amazing and the staff excellent.    But seriously folks......everything is cooked in peanut oil????    There is no need for this.   They can make anything by request in olive oil.....but this knowledge could fall by the wayside....& someone might find themselves on the way to the hospital!  
I am still not sure if this was printed on the menu somewhere, since I couldn't read it from the print being too small.  Luckily my waiter happed to say something when I told him I was allergic to nuts.    Alas peanuts are a legume!     
Allergies suck....but disaster was averted.....THIS TIME
author: phaedra g.

description: Been here for lunch and dinner and it's good for both. Good food and an energetic ambiance. Lunch is more mellow and less crowded and probably good for business lunch as well as lunch with friends. Dinner gets very packed, busy and loud. Food has had few misses for me but have been mostly good. Service is also good, but dinner service can be a bit amiss due to how busy they get (missed  add-on drink orders, pallela that fails to show up...etc.). Overall, it's a solid restaurant that I wouldn't hesitate to go back to or recommend.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: Chef Michael Chiarello's restaurant Coqueta is a must if you love Spanish tapas. Though impossible to get a table at a decent time, their first come first serve bar area may be your only option but its worth the craziness. What made our visit even more special was the impeccable service from Lowell, you must request him!
author: Dottie A.

description:
The dishes were painstakingly prepared and decorated. Food flavors were colorful and tasty to boot. 
Food portions were more of bite sized only so be prepared to order at least 3 dishes per person which will costs $75 per person
Patatas Bravas is excellent!
author: Soon W.

description:
4.5 stars 

I'm almost too embarrassed to catalogue everything we ate last night. At 10pm, there weren't too many people still in the building. 

* skewers: $2.50 each. Chorizo for him, manchego/Serrano ham for me (literally 1/20 of an ounce of ham)
* limonada: first choice was their almond joy. Yes, I was dry last night. 
* Spanish olives: 3 kinds 
* almond gazpacho: so unbelievably delicious 
* crispy shrimp: w/ saffron aioli & green onion. Reminded me of a Chinese dish. So good, but so greasy.
* Serrano ham & fuet (like salami): he liked both 
* smoked salmon: I don't usually eat this, but it was awesome
* pork shoulder loin: OMG, so nicely charred & crispy on the outside, yummy flavor. I liked the sweet marinade, but he said it was too much just like honey. For $38, the portion was laughable. 
* pan con chocolate: salty kick 
* manchego cheesecake pops: love. 

Total: $115 not including tip 
And a $74 parking ticket for not feeding the meter (feed it til 11 pm!) 

Definitely a date-nite type of place. I can't upgrade to 5 stars because most portions are ridiculous for the price. Won't stop me from coming back, though.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I made a reservation about a week in advance for a sunday night to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday. We were about half an hour early to our reservation and since they didn't have a table ready yet, we waited for about 15 minutes in the bar area. 

It was such a nice spot! Not very big, but it had a cozy feel to it. The food was all displayed so beautifully, even the cocktails were pretty! For our first time at a tapas bar, we definetely had a nice time. The open face salmon sandwich was tasty, so was the paella and the duck and pork albondigas! 

Beautiful location, great food, friendly and attentive staff... I would definetely recommend this place!
author: Ilsen M.

description:
I had a voicemail on Friday afternoon telling me to call to confirm my reservation for Sunday evening otherwise they'd cancel it. I called right away to confirm, no sweat. My group of four shows up at 7:56 pm for an 8 pm reservation and we are told to wait in the bar. 20 minutes later and our cocktails haven't arrived yet but our table is finally ready. The hostess was all bent out of shape for having to split the cocktail tab after she demanded we tab out before being seated. I didn't feel bad at all after we were made to wait for 20 minutes with no explanation or apology for a reservation that they threatened to cancel two days earlier.

The service during dinner was spotty at best. Our server was knowledgable and sassy in a fun way, but not very available for us. Cocktails continued to take way too long to arrive during dinner and we sat for a stupid amount of time after our entire table was cleared of food/bev before the check arrived. Also a pain is the bathroom set-up - one toilet for each gender so there was typically a line. Not cool. 

The food was good. A couple of the dishes were great, and some were inedible. We ordered a large charcuterie board per our server's recommendation and then one of each of the hot tapas. The meats and cheeses were great but not surprising in any way, but the bit of bread that came with was outstanding. The serrano pepper dish was far too spicy for even the spicy-lovers at our table - we had them take it away after a few tastes. The prawns were straight up not good and the octopus was tough. We very much enjoyed the Bikini Brioche, Sunny Side Up Huevo and the Croquetas. We sampled a good portion of the gin cocktails and would give a thumbs up to them all. 

If you can look past the unfortunate service there are gems to be found here. The atmosphere is lively and jovial, great for a group outing or double date. Just not sure it's the best option in a city full of options.
author: Meghan S.

description:
Spanish Tapas.... You can get similar stuff in the city for $10-20 less than this place. However, let me tell you, it is certainly worth to pay a little bit more if you are having some special occasion or having guests from overseas. I brought my Beijing friend and her mom to Coqueta and they just love it here. 

The cocktail , gintonic, all of them are very pretty~~ 

Food: Any orders will be a good one. You just want to bring more people here so that you can try all those small tapas. I am still working on it :P..
Last time i came with 8 people, so, I learned which is good ... i like the smoked salmon thing and the paella a lot
author: Chin Man L.

description: Loved loved loved it. Been trying to make it in and finally did. Went with husband and teenager. Everything was amazing. The octopus, meatballs and kale salad were absolute standouts. I don't usually like kale salads but this was ever so
author: Lisa H.

description: This is the second time I have eaten here. It is delicious! This trip included three adults and two children. We ordered the cheese and meat platter, chicken croquettes, meatballs, chips, potato and dessert. The staff was amazing and incredibly accommodating  with the children.
author: j m.

description:
If you live in SF & love tapas (like I do), you need to try Coqueta. The food is pricey, but definitely worth the visit.  We got the seafood paella, duck & pork meatballs, prawns, smoked salmon montaditos, uni montaditos, Cauliflower steak, churros, and manchego cheesecake.

Although I enjoyed everything, my favorites were the paella, uni montaditos (open sandwich with sea urchin), and the manchego cheesecake.  I definitely recommend these three dishes, unless you aren't a fan of sea urchin (which I know a lot of people are not).  I personally love sea urchin though, so I was excited to see this on the menu, and was not disappointed.  I also highly recommend the gin and tonic, which is not only delicious, but one of the prettiest drinks I have ever seen.  I'm not usually a gin & tonic fan, but I really loved all the variations my friends and I ordered.

Update: Finally returned to Coqueta and got the Sunny-Side Up Huevos (shrimp, sunny-side up egg, crispy potato, & chorizo), Patatas Bravas (crispy potatoes with salsa & garlic aioli), Paella, Sea Urchin Open-Faced Sandwich, Manchego Cheesecake, & the two specials (Lamb Meatballs & another Open-Faced Sandwich - with goat cheese, apple slices, & honey). The two specials were amazing, & I would definitely order them again. The Sunny-Side Up Huevos was also really great. The only thing I wasn't a huge fan of was the Patatas Bravas.
author: Cici A.

description:
Coqueta has great views of the Bay and is located right off of the Embarcadero. Came here with my co-workers for a team lunch and literally ordered everything off of the menu. We were all in a food coma once we finished! 

 Our server was prompt, attentive and offered several suggestions, due to the large size of our party. Hard to remember everything we ordered, but here were some of my highlights: 

- Pulpo a la Parilla: Grilled octopus w/ fingerling potatos
- Albondigas a la Feria - grilled duck and pork meatballs
- Croquetas de Pollo - Chicken and English Pea (DELISH) 
- Wood Grilled (32oz) bone-in Ribeye (AHH-MAZING) 
- Classic Paella

Every item we ordered was full of flavor and cooked to order! We wrapped our meal up with some of the mini churros w/chocolate dipping sauce! Can't wait to come back  for Happy hour!
author: Krystal C.

description: Stopped by Coqueta for snacks yesterday before catching the ferry back home. Over all, a terrific experience. Not a cheap place to hang out, but well worth the cost. Big flavors on their small bites. One of the best mojitos I have ever enjoyed! I'll be back for more!
author: Jason D.

description:
Mi recomendación: pan con tomate, Barça gin y cidra. 
Good music, nice ambience and friendly service
author: Santos C.

description: Pretty tasty but expensive. Dislike how the waiters try to push more food on you. My friend and I were obviously struggling to finish what we already had.
author: Chen W.

description:
This place is great! Our company had their holiday party here and we had tons of fun. Excellent food and drinks and service. The staff worked very hard to make sure our party was well-served and excellent. 

I loved the margaritas but would have also liked to try one of the drinks with the flowers in them. 

Everything is done with a mercurial mix of panache and care. I would return any day.
author: R. J.

description: I never wrote the reviews before just using yelp in order to find good restaurants; however, I have to write the review this time. I made a reservation like a week ago and came today, but I had to wait like 30 mins more. This is ridiculous and they didnt even give me a table. I sat the bar instead. Well, I can't believe that it's 4 star tho. Why do I need to make reservation then although I have to wait like people who just come in without reservation. I NEVER EVER COME BACK AGAIN.
author: Juno K.

description:
I love when restaurants meet expectations and I adore when restaurants surpass expectations. Coqueta definitely did both the former and the latter. 

When I heard that the famous Michael Chiarello from Napa opened up a hot new tapas spot on the Embarcadero, I shed a tear of joy, went to Opentable and tried to acquire a reservation. However, Coqueta only accepts reservations a month in advance and was completely booked except in the most inopportune times for me. Since I hate rejection, I had given up on my dream for quenching my Chiarello thirst for the time being.

But having heard an overwhelming amount of raves about this place from friends and acquaintances, I decided to try again. The trick is to skip Opentable and actually call the restaurant! They have some highly coveted secret spots that don't show up on Opentable. So I managed to snag the bf and me a reservation for a fine Saturday evening with the anticipation of having my taste buds tantalized. And tantalized they were...

The food is simply incredible from start to finish. I highly recommend ordering about 2-3 tapas and 1 main entree per person as the portions are quite meager. I highly recommend the following: 

1. Melt in your mouth chicken and english pea croquetas
2. Bursting with flavor sunny side up egg with shrimp, crispy potato and chorizo dressing
3. Intense gambas al negro with gulf prawns, black garlic & chilli
4. Tender and juicy pluma pork shoulder loin with honey chilli glaze
5. Silky smooth arroz cremosa (slowly cooked bomba rice with day boat scallops and summer squash & blossoms)
6. Drool inducing churro fantasia dessert
7. Classic flan espanola dessert 

But don't stop with just the food. Please try some of the delicious hand crafted libations from the fabulous mixologists. The cocktails here are simply to die for! Tell the waiter/waitress what you're in the mood for and you'll get the perfect recommendations! Also, don't forget to pair your dessert with a dessert wine - the ports here taste like spiked honey. 

And of course, the ambiance is classy & trendy and the views are great. 

So if you're lucky enough to snag a reservation, definitely check out Coqueta. You won't regret it! 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description: This was my first lunch stop on a recent visit to San Francisco, as this is my good friend's first spot to bring visitors to town and she's been going on and on about how I have to come here. Coqueta has a great selection of hot/cold tapas, all delicious (had the calamari, gambas negras, octopus, duck meatballs). The apple tart was a work of art, I felt almost bad cutting into it (but I did and it was so good, esp. with the sweet/savory blue cheese ice cream). The service was impeccable, the surroundings gorgeous. The menu pricing is on the high end for portion size and the paid parking nearby is outrageous, but you're paying a premium for the real estate. Bonus points for being able to book through OpenTable for convenience. Would I come again? For sure. Would I come again often? Depends on how much my dinner mate loves me (say that you love me, baby).
author: Alma C.

description:
I loved the food here! This is easily amongst the best food I have eaten since I came to America ;)

We ordered a lot of different tapas. We had the octopus. Not as nice as I remembered from Barcelona but that was killed-this-morning-fresh. We had the dick meatballs. Bit soggy but very tasty. There was a brioche and eggplant sandwich which was divine. Though the sauce was a bit sweet. We had the shrimp and the prawns. Nice. Then we go an fried egg and potato that was really complicated and exciting. We also had a chicken dish which was okay - little cutlets. 

and then we had dessert! We got the  tres con leche with rice pudding and jam - I cannot believe how beautiful this was. And I don't even like dessert usually. The edges of cake were crisp and pudding warm and ice cream melting in. And then we had tiny manchego cheese cakes with caramel popcorn. Perfect. Not too sweet and very light. We also had the affagato which was perfect.
author: Prerona M.

description: Finally I was able to try their foods. We ordered the Grilled Octopus, Prawns with garlic, meat balls, paella. Paella was excellent but everything else was just ok because the seafood wasn't fresh. I probably would not return.
author: Christy N.

description:
Every month, my friends and I like to go out and try a new restaurant. Lately, we've been having Spanish/tapas style food and it just so happens that Coqueta was also one of those restaurants. Anyways, we booked reservations about two weeks in advance for a lovely Saturday lunch. Upon arriving, we were seated immediately at one of the corner booths. The 4 of us each got our own drinks and shared these 8 dishes:

Barca Gintonic: A really beautiful drink. I'm actually not a big fan of gin in general because of its taste, but after having Coqueta's, I really liked it. It was very refreshing with a bit of a floral/fruity taste. A bit expensive for a drink though.

Chorizo: Just OK. The chorizo came as bite-size skewers with roasted artichokes and piquillo pepper. For the portion size, it was quite expensive and not worth it. Least impressive dish. 

Sunny side-up egg with Shrimp and Crispy Potato: YUM. One of my favorite dishes even though it was a bit oily... The server would burst the egg yolk and mix it with the shrimp and crispy potatoes. The potatoes were really crispy, so when you eat all three together in a mixture, it had the perfect crunch to it. Nice texture to it. I think this dish would be perfect for brunch. 

Whole Monterey Calamari on the Plancha: Not your normal crispy calamari. Really liked the squid ink alioli with the calamari. Calamari was fresh and chewy. 

Paella: I have had paella at several other restaurants before. Honestly, it was just OK. The paella came with root vegetables, chorizo, prawns, clams, and lemon alioli. The lemon alioli paired well with the paella. Otherwise, nothing really stood out. Some of the seafood tasted a bit too fishy for me. :/

Pluma (Pork Shoulder Loin): Just OK... It was pretty tender, but nothing too special. It was already flavorful enough without having to pair it with the honey-chili glaze.

Setas al ajillo: My other favorite dish of the night! Loved the flavors to the mushrooms. I felt healthy just eating it. It wasn't too heavy nor too oily. 

Grilled Albondigas: Duck and pork meatballs. At first bite, the texture was a bit weird for me.. It was a bit mushy, yet bursted with flavor... but past that, it was really delicious. A bit heavy, hearty, yet juicy.

Churros with drinking hot chocolate and mixed berry powder: Dip the churro first into the mixed berry powder and then into the hot chocolate. It tasted very yummy! I really liked the combination of the two. A good way to end a delicious meal.

What really bugged me was that there were quite a few flies at our table. Every time we tried to eat or drink, there was always at least one buzzing around. It was quite annoying.. :( Anyways, service was excellent. Our water cups were always refilled and our plates were changed each time we got a new dish. The overall meal was quite expensive as it added up. Nonetheless, I really enjoyed the food and I would say that Coqueta is one of the better restaurants for tapas style/Spanish food.
author: Philana C.

description:
They just completed their 1 year anniversary and I wish them many many more. Coqueta (flirt in Spanish) as the name suggest is a good place for a date. It is a good addition to the pier area.

Very nice warm vibe with great food,drinks and service. Everything I had was very good. I am looking to try them again and upgrade to a 5 star rating.
author: Sunil R.

description:
I had Coqueta on my list since opening about a year ago.  Chicago dominates the tapa scene in my opinion, and Coqueta certainly helps level the playing field for San Francisco.  Some of the items I had are no longer available on the menu, but everything I had was quite good.  However, the churros were just okay.  I still have not found a place with better churros than XOCO in Chicago.  D bar in San Diego, and Mesa Grill in Las Vegas are distant second.  Prices tend to be quite expensive, and this is the part where I think some of the competitors have the upper hand.  My second complain is the uncomfortable seats at the bar.  

We wanted to try the Paella, but opted to go with variety instead.  I recommend coming in with a few people, so you can try the Paella and still leave enough room for smaller tapas.  If uni sounds good to you, try the Mar y Montana.  It has lardo and uni.
author: Roger W.

description:
It's a unique restaurant by the embarcadero with a great view. It feels like it's separated into 2 different rooms both daily small; one it's just sitting area with the kitchen in front of you if you're sitting around the counter area and another seating area, you have a bar. They have a wide range of liquor sand also pretty interesting cocktails. We made a reservation and got there 10 minutes before but still had to wait 20 minutes for a table because they happened to have a huge group that's seated. The service was actually pretty decent. 

There's so many options in tapas whether it's hot or cold. They also have a few selections on cured meats, cheese platters, and the bite size skewers. They do have big plates (family/entree size). We were about to order the bite size skewers but none of them have meat in them so we passed on that. We wanted to try a lot of items on their menu so we didn't order any big/entree plates. 

We ordered the deviled eggs and it's pretty creamy, but I think they can do a little better on the toppings. The croquetas de pollo is a MUST try dish! It's deep fried and crispy on the outside but very flavorful and creamy on the inside. They also give you little orange  slices which I guess it's to cleanse your palettes. The patatas bravas is a little different. It's mini fried potato balls that has a smokey taste, but I do love the dipping sauce and it does make a difference in terms of taste. The gambas al negro (prawns in olive oil and garlic sauce with toasted French bread, is okay because you can eat this anywhere. The sunny side up surprisingly tasted a little like kimchi fried rice without the kimchi and rice and it's actually pretty good. It also comes with crispy thinly sliced potatoes which reminds me of very fresh hash browns. Our last tapas was the duck and pork meatballs. It's a little on the sweeter side, wish it's more savory.

Of course we ordered desserts too. We ordered the flan and the bite size cheesecake. The flan was perfect in texture and taste, not too sweet, and it has fresh blackberries with it so it's more healthy. On the other hand, the bite size cheesecake was way too sweet and heavy. It also comes with caramel popcorn and it's also pretty sweet. 

This restaurant is good with their drinks (alcoholic and non alcoholic) and savory dishes. Next time I'll come back and try other dishes and drinks.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Great place, we sat in bar area ouside, nice decor, goof service great flavors on the food. If were couple of bucks cheaper would b great hot an estrella damm( love it since Barcelona) meat balls( albomdigas)
Pork, duck, sour cherries. Super nice combination of flavors... The cherried are the killer in them, devil eggs. Creamy, smoky, nice presentation, tomato bread( pan con tomate)  a different aproach since in spain is serve toasted bread with fresh tomato kind of salsa, here they cooked the tomatoes and puree then so is more enfasis on the flavor, and the bread is nice crunchy, moist still. Could not try hot tapas
author: Larry L.

description:
The restaurant is absolutely lovely, lots of warm wood and leather and nice lighting, in a beautiful spot on the Embarcadero.

The food was a mixed bag of one of the best dishes I ever had and one of the worst, with everything else falling somewhere in between. I would go back just for the sunny side up egg over crispy potatoes and shrimp with chorizo dressing (however, I would tell them to hold the shrimp, which made no sense in this dish.) The whole appeal of pan con tomate is the raw freshness of the tomato and garlic, but this had a thick, stewed tomato sauce to spread on the bread...odd. The "black shrimp" were cooked perfectly, plain but good, and salted well. Valdeón cheese, well, you can't really go wrong with Spanish cheese, and the membrillo that came with it was excellent. The croquettes were also excellent, but lacked salt.

Now, the paella...likely the worst paella I have ever had. It had this weird tomato (?) sauce on top of the rice. The alioli (served on the side) was bland, flavored with lemon, not garlic (a sin, in my opinion) and who the hell puts huge chunks of (almost raw) cauliflower and broccoli in a seafood paella? 6 clams and 4 shrimp was the total seafood count in a paella for 3...very stingy.  I could have probably overlooked much of this except the rice, which should always be the star of the paella, was flavorless, overcooked and mushy. A very sad state of affairs when the waitress brags that paella is their specialty.

The little manchego cheesecake bites, no charge, were awesome.

Come here for a drink at the bar and a couple of tapas, but do not get the paella.
author: Elisa C.

description:
The short of it: Try Coqueta once or twice. They deserve at least that much, and hopefully you catch them on a good night. The good news is, there's a lot of options to choose from and something is bound to strike your fancy.

"It must have been a bad night." "Maybe they were short staffed tonight." "Well ,we did eat late, so that must have something to do with it." "Chiarello must not come around much." I find myself looking for reasons to give Coqueta a higher rating, but for now, I don't have one.

Need more info? Read on.

----


Here's what I took from this experience:

The Space and Staff.
There is an air of Chiarello's aesthetic all over the place; You'll recognize the Napa Style (his retail endeavor) merchandise all over the place. Animal hides on the walls. Hammered copper tumblers. Rustic wood tables. There is nothing unapproachable or intimidating about it.

The host and waitress were very sweet, but the waitress forgot an order and didn't check on us as frequently as we'd hoped so we could place another order before the kitchen closed. Though she asked just before this time came, we felt pressured not to order when she finally asked because the kitchen closed in one minute. We would have ordered more otherwise.

The Pricing.
Reasonable and expected. Some items were insanely overpriced, some were right on target. I'm not afraid to pay good money for a tiny, one-bite wonder, but not for something lackluster and ordinary. We ordered 2 alcoholic drinks, 4 skewers, 1 cold tapas plate, 1 hot plate, 1 vegetable plate, and 2 dessert items for about $100 with tip.

---

The Food.
It's hard to say anything other than "confused" here. There are some traditional combinations as well as some unusual pairings, but they didn't always deliver.

The Highs

Croquetas de Pollo
These were heavenly, and as many reviewers said, like chicken pot pie in a bite.
Very creamy interior, crispy exterior. The cured oranges on the side were a nice palette cleanser and were nice combined when combined with the Croquetas as well, but seem sort of haphazard on the side of the plate.

Churros
I'm happy that this was the last thing I had before leaving. The order came with four small-sized churros, served with a small cup of drinking chocolate and crushed mixed berry powder. This powder, while seeming to be nothing more than a garnish, really makes the dish. The acidity from the berries cuts right through the heavy body of the chocolate, and compliments the cinnamon and sugar on the churro. Spot on in flavor, but could have been warmer. They didn't seem fresh.

Manchego Cheesecake Pops
A smart combination and delicious. As a sheepsmilk cheese, Manchego has a small amount of tang that is reminiscent of cream cheese -- I think that's why these work and where the sweet and savory happily come together. The pops are served on a stick and with small bits of caramel corn on the platter to bring back the sweet side of things. Probably the highlight of the night.

----
The (Really Low) Lows--

Pintxos - Bite Size Skewers
These are a joke. We had 4 of the 5 options available, there were all forgettable and left me saying, "$2.50 for that?" It wasn't an issue of size by any means, but of flavor. Maybe our skewers had been sitting around for a while, and they certainly tasted that way. None of the flavors really stood out for how simple the ingredients were. I wouldn't order any of these again.

Seta de Ajillo
This was a tragedy. This should have been a simple, wonderful dish and was by far the biggest disappointment. I absolutely love mushrooms, and had to choke this down because of how insanely over seasoned and oily they was. Was it supposed to be like this? I should have sent it back.

----

The experience was pleasant overall, but there is a lot of room for improvement. What I was served wasn't a true reflection of what Chef Chiarello is capable of, and it's an issue of execution. I didn't love anything and the lows really put a damper on the entire meal.  I'm under the impression that this is a side project doesn't get much of the chef's attention. 

With some attentiveness and focus to the vision of Coqueta, I think this would have been a much better experience. Regardless, I'm curious enough about what went wrong to try again.
author: Panda B.

description: Enjoyed our evening.  Great food and service.  I love white anchovies and they fixed us a plate of just anchovies and salad that was not on the menu.   Thanks Coqueta for a delicious and fun evening.
author: Noella G.

description:
"OMG, Ken K is not eating Chinese or Japanese!!!" Apparently I gave at least one person an almost heart attack or something over the weekend when I checked in here.

Yeah I know, big shocker eh? Sometimes a brutha has to cross international boundary lines with the FOB palette. There's only so much Chinese and Japanese one can handle.  

Since "izakaya" has been remarketed as "Japanese tapas", it was high time to try the original Spanish version at a place that's been picking up steam...or shall I say Spanish Izakaya. Or Spanish "dim sum" meant to be drowned with alcohol and cocktails. As you can see I still have the FOB judge hat on!

And Coqueta is a pretty fancy one at that. Made a reservation via opentable about 5 hours prior and got seated at the counter. Other than the pretty uncomfortable seating arrangement, the upside was getting a full view of the action, and some interaction with the friendly kitchen staff which was really cool. Have no clue who Mike Chiarello is other than what I've read, and don't think he was there last night. But no matter, I was there for food and company, not for fawning. 

There are far more experienced Spanish food and tapas eaters who know this stuff hot and cold better than I do. 

King of FOB food was once again put in charge of ordering, which in foreign territory can be a bit daunting, but fun at the same time. With a little Yelp from my friends (thanks Cherylynn N!) I took the reins and ordered a bit too much food.

Jamon Iberico de bellota - F**K Kobe beef BS! This is it! Not to say that A5 Wagyu is bad...but a premium slice of pedigree Spanish ham is one of those must try before you croak experiences, particularly if you are a huge pork fan. One kitchen staffer described it as "Kobe pork" (word bleh) but yeah I am well aware of what this stuff can do to you and your wallet. Nutty (from the free range Iberico black pig being fed a steady diet of acorn), the right balance of salt, fat, umami, with a slight hint of sweetness...the paper thin slices are delicate and put so many other kinds of ham to shame. They say YOLO, I say try this! 

Jamon Serrano - this is a much cheaper ham that Coqueta cures in house. It's quite salty but otherwise good, and a staffer was kind enough to offer us a slice to sample. 

Beet salad - Good. If you mess up a simple salad using quality ingredients from down the street (Ferry Building Farmers Market) don't even bother.

House cure white anchovies (cold tapas) - The biggest downer of the evening. Super duper trooper SALTY. At least the sour accent shined. If it wasn't salty this could have been pretty decent. 

Crispy shrimp and chickpea flour pancake with saffron alioli - fried stuff may always taste better, but is not easy to nail down which these guys did. Not greasy...and good quality shrimp. I doubt you can even find good regional Cantonese fried lotus root slices stuffed with shrimp paste renditions in town, and this trumps most Korean style pajeons around. Bravo!

Wood grilled octopus with fingerling potatoes, pimento, and olive oil - Sweet fingerling potatoes, and a perfectly tender octopus with a delightful chew/bite. Only certain European (and Japanese preps) of octopus are truly noteworthy. Loved it.

Pluma - Iberico de bellota pork shoulder loin with honey chili glaze. Yes, 8 pieces for $38 is not cheap...but it's acorn fed Iberico free range black pig, shoulder cut. Plus woodfire grilling done right. Phenomenal texture and control of the flame, a little salt rub and it has a delightful juice bite with a smooth tender chew. It's not fatty, but it's not dry and skinny either (well marbled but you can't tell). It's basically Spanish version of cha siu (Cantonese BBQ pork, shoulder cut is used too), especially with the honey chili glaze you can squirt over. If anyone travels to Hong Kong, Tin Lung Heen does an Iberico pork cha siu

http://www.foodspotting.com/places/311881-tin-lung-heen-restaurant-hong-kong/items/342-chinese-roast-pork

To try next time: grilled branzino!

Vineyard greens - Catalan style, Caper raisin puree, with raisins, pine nuts, and garlic. Quite bitter and a touch salty with interesting textures and tastes from the other things inside. Probably needs to be washed down with alcohol.

Dessert: 

Churro Fantasia - crispy Spanish doughnuts with drinking chocolate and mixed berry powder. Solid, very nice and toasty. After this I don't want Costco, Flea Market, or County Fair churros ever again.

Strawberry plum gazpacho with liquid nitrogen frozen blood peach neblina. Pictures
describe it better than I can. Very nice.

Too full...all that was food for two. Had to cancel the skewers/Pintxos.

Lots of photography opportunities here...staff preparing appetizers with uni and lardo, desserts, cheese platters, the big ass jamon iberico leg to the side, good looking people eating around, the Pintxos tray, good looking people. Quite atmospheric!
author: Ken K.

description:
Finally, after months of failed intentions of dining at Coqueta, I made it here for a business lunch with a few folks.  We were seated at a long table along a window.  It was relatively comfortable, but it was a bit of a struggle getting up on the bench by the window.  The table is set really close to the bench, and if I was just one month more pregnant (or on the heftier side), I don't think I would have been able to squeeze through onto the bench.  The high chairs on the other side of the table were also a bit awkward.  You basically couldn't get in or out of the high chair without hitting a chair and/or person next to you.

Anyway, after getting ourselves situated, we shared and enjoyed several tapas:

Chef's Grand Selection of Cured Meats and Cheeses - Compared to the meat and cheese plates of other restaurants, I didn't feel that we got $38 of value.  I admit my value perception may be a bit tainted by the fact my preggers state meant I couldn't enjoy any of the cured meats or the manchego cheese since it was made with raw goat's milk.  I loved the Valdeon blue cheese, but it overpowered my palette, so I couldn't really taste any distinctive flavor with the Cana de Cabra soft goat cheese.

Crispy Shrimp & Chickpea Flour Pancake - I love all things deep fried, and this did not disappoint.  I like my citrus, so I probably would have enjoyed a bit more of the roaster meyer lemon to squeeze on top.

Wood Grilled Octopus - Super tender (not overcooked and rubbery), well-seasoned, and a delightful recommendation from someone else that insisted we order it.

Duck & Pork Albondigas and Beef Shortribs - Both good, but unremarkable.

If I come again, I'd skip the Apple and Pear Ensalada and Patatas Bravas.
author: Christina L.

description:
Holy YUM! I've been dying to try Coqueta for awhile now but could never get a reservation. I decided to go on a Friday after work and try my lock to snap some seats in the bar area as it's first come, first served. I totally lucked out and got one of the two big picnic tables outside, it was a killer day in SF! I ordered the gin and tonic, not generally a big person but had to try it after hearing so much about it. It was definitely good but the presentation is what made it great. It was honestly the prettiest drink I've ever had. 

We got a bunch of tapas to start -- there was four of us total, I would definitely recommend going with a group of at least four so you can try more things. The meatballs were hoenstly the best I've ever had in my life, we ended up ordering a second round because they were that good. The patatas bravas, chicken and pea croqettes and warm chocolate cake were there other all stars of the meal. The paella was really good but still wasn't my favorite, next time I think I'll just get tapas as those were my favorite. 

The restaurant itself is cute inside, not as big as I thought it'd be but has a very comfortable vibe. The bar inside is pretty small and super crowded post work which is to be expected. Sitting outside was perfect for us since we had plenty of space. Our server was a total doll, I spaced on getting her name but it seemed like all the servers were top notch. Add this to your list of must tries in San Francisco!
author: Lizzy U.

description:
I've been here three times already and I can say that I've left happy every time. Delicious food, good ambiance, high ceilings, great location and attentive service.

Perfect place for any occasion. I've been here with my bff, a group of friends and for a birthday celebration and I had a great time at each visit (chef Michael Chiarello was there 2/3 times--which was a plus).

Favorites:

Tapas:
Chicken and pea croquetas- comes with three servings ($9)
Gambas al negro--Poached head on gulf prawns in a garlic aoli sauce ($14)--full of flavor and absolutely delicious
Crispy shrimp and chickpea flour pancake ($12)
Grilled duck and pork albondigas- moist and juicy with a great balance of sweet and savory--3 pieces ($12)

Main dishes:
Arroz Cremosa: Kind of like a paella except it comes with scallops and squash blossoms. ($24)
Paella: takes 20 minutes to prepare ($40)-It says it serves up to two, but honestly, if you eat with a group of people I think it can serve up to four especially if you plan on getting a bunch of appetizers.
Pluma: Pork shoulder loin with a honey glaze. Portion is pretty small for ($38)--if you have a group of 10, you would probably want to order two. Good, but pricey for the portion you get.

Dessert:
Churros: comes with a hot chocolate dipping sauce and dried berry powder. Love the combination of the hot sweet chocolate and the tangy berry powder.
Manchego cheesecake: Another play on sweet and savory and oh so delicious. Comes with two pieces.

This is one of my favorite new restaurants of 2013 and favorite tapa restaurant in the city and would definitely recommend this place!
author: Sarah F.

description:
Guys. The gin and tonic. 

Don't do what I did, don't try to go big and get the fennel and anis situation - no, keep it simple. Get the classic one. It's perfect. 

Fair warning: it's kind of a green house situation so it can get a little warm inside, but the view and the location and the gin and tonic are a must-not-miss situation.
author: Caro D.

description: This is one of my favorite places in SF currently. It's not cheap but the food and drinks are worth it. It's tiny so make a reservation.
author: Ana D.

description: Horrible service!!!  Food was out before our drinks, and we ordered our drinks ten minutes before our food and then had some lame excuse on drinks that never even showed up! WOULD NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE
author: Krystal R.

description:
Usually when we dine out at restaurants of this caliber (ie. Wayfare Tavern) two of us would order 2 apps, 2 entrees, 2 desserts and 2 drinks for about $100 before tax and tip. So that's what we expected walking into Coqueta. Long story short, we ended up with a bill that was twice as much as we anticipated. 

The food was good, not great. Nothing stood out or blew my mind. It's expensive for what it is. Portions are really small (I know they're tapas but it's smaller than the usual tapas) so you'll need about 3 tapas plus an entree per person to feel satiated. 

The Pluma was $38 which is expensive for an entree to begin with. On top of that it's just 6 oz of pork (no sides). Yes, it's iberico. Yes, it's good but it was not $38 dollars good. It's more like $25 dollars good.

We had one of each of the pintxos ($2.50 each) none of them were any good.

Almond Joy ($4) drink was not good. 
The Castro (margarita, $12) was good.
Mini Manchego Cheesecake Pop ($4) was too salty. I usually like sweet and salty desserts but this was way too salty.

Everything else we had was good but nothing to write home about.

Service was standard.

I don't mind spending money on food but the experience has to match the price. In this case, it didn't. The food and drinks were visually stunning but taste did not justify the high prices.

If you are ever in Vegas, go to Jaleo. Similar food and prices but the food will blow your mind and you will walk out not feeling like you overpaid.
author: Andy W.

description:
Simply put, the best restaurant in San Francisco. From the moment you walk in you are greeted by the friendly staff. Always taking care of your needs. The cocktails are to die for. Full of so much flavor in every sip. The food is mouthwatering. It's tapas style food and great to order a handful of things. Each bite stimulates the mind. The bold tastes make you want to keep ordering. But save room for desert! The chocolate cake! I could just eat that everyday!

The reason this place is my favorite in San Francisco is the staff. Laurent Ertle who is the General Manager at Coqueta always pays special attention to each guest. A rarity in the restaurant business. I look forward to coming back again very soon!
author: Jonathan F.

description:
This is my second time here and the food was just as yummy the second time around. Our server was attentive and very helpful. We ordered a lot and it's hard to pick a favorite. The paella and ginormous steak is probably the winner or maybe it was the octopus or the shrimp with the crispy potatoes. I think I want to eat there soon. 
There's a constant stream of people and it can be quite loud in there. It's a great place to hang out with friends and share a pitcher (or three) of sangria.
author: Joie G.

description:
Great tapas and an amazing view make this place perfect for brunch of a nibble along the way.
Try the patatas bravas and the eponymous croquetas.
A well-run bar rounds off this little gem along the waterfront.
author: Phil T.

description: Back for the second time this year, and it just gets better and better. The restaurant is seriously FLAWLESS. Everything from the Food, environment, as well as the team that operates this restaurant is incredible. It is from every single table everyone is happy and satisfied and having a beautiful time. The chefs counter puts a whole different perspective   on the way a restaurant with pure passion is driven to create every single dish to perfection! The service is so incredible EVERYONE checks up on you. To the point to where you don't even have to worry about ordering another drink if you are due for one because when you sip the remainder bit of wine , there is more coming! Should try the Chiarello Family Vineyard pairs Zinfandel.. It pairs beautifully  with the Pluma Acorn fed Spanish Ibérico de bellota pork shoulder loin with honey-chili glaze. The chili Glaze is there, but try it with out the Extra Chili sauce to indulge in the flavor of the Pork. I swear  to god you will just taste pure raw talent! Next up is the Brotes de broccoli con romescu broccoli di ciccio a la parilla with coal roasted romescu sauce. HA! Im not going to explain how awesome that is, you just have to try it out! The process on that is unreal! Albóndigas a la Feria Beautiful, amazing  texture. "El Gran Plat Cap" Do a half size and enjoy it with some Chardonnay ; frogs leap. Even better, the Gin and tonic just because hahaha. The cocktail list is amazing. For dessert I think the best thing is the Manchego cheesecake with caramel popcorn. Churro 'Fantasia Is incredible with the dehydrated mixed berry. Crema Catalana al Fuego y Hielo Is so interesting tasting the vodka that pairs well with the Crema! Pan con Fresa Is amazing with the Ice cream! You have to stop by this spot and enjoy the environment! I honestly do believe out of all the 20 + Restauraunts I have been to in SF, this is my favorite and the best in town!!!
author: Aaron J.

description:
So, I'll admit to something: I haven't been this excited about a place since State Bird Provisions.  At the same time, I mean, how could you not be excited about Coqueta?  Add Michael Chiarello, a prime location on the Embarcadero, a beautifully crafted menu, and of course, Iberico pork, things are going to shake out pretty nicely.  I made a reservation for an early Sunday dinner about a month ago (after constantly checking and finally succumbing to a 5:15pm rez on Sunday).  After torturing myself with all of the amazing Yelp pics, I saved all my calories for this and it was going to a be a no holding back experience.  The results were as follows:

Cocktails:
Barca Gintonic: I chose this after seeing all of the beautiful pictures of it on Yelp!  This G&T is a little sweeter than what I'm used to, but I still drank all of it.
Tariff: Greg selected this after reading that the gin used was infused with Iberico jamon. After trying it, I couldn't really taste an essence of pork, but there was a strong flavor of apricots and orange.  A creative and new take on the G&T!
Engine Co. #5: Greg also selected this after finishing the Tariff since he enjoys bourbon, and was interested in trying tobacco infused cream sherry.  The drink was definitely strong, and I will say that to enjoy it, you must really love bourbon.

Ok, and now my friends, on to the food!

Tapas:
Chicken and English pea coquetas: The cheese to everything else was great, but was lacking a little bit of salt. The best way to describe this is a mini chicken pot pie inside a tater tot.  We were so-so on this.

Serrano ham & Manchego cheese: We elected this since pork is an absolute must here, and Greg's a fan of Manchego cheese.  Both items we selected were delicious, and the portions of both cheese and jamon were just right.  What was also great about this is that we selected these two items separately and it came out presented beautifully paired with some olive oil crackers, a fig paste, and some salted toasted nuts.  Absolutely delicious and would highly recommend.

Sunny side-up egg with shrimp, crispy potato, and chorizon dressing: I selected this dish because I really enjoy my fair share of camaron y huevo y chorizo.  Greg wasn't a huge fan of this dish mostly because he wasn't sure how all of the elements on the plate fit together, but I was sold on it.  The chorizon dressing on it really nailed it, and the runny egg added to the flavor of the sauce.  I recommend ordering this.

Duck and pork meatball: Definitely a unique flavor profile, the duck added some fattiness, the cherries were sour but added a great taste, and the crispy shallot on top added texture to the overall meatball.  This isn't your standard meatball you get - THIS IS A MEATBALL. Greg and I agreed that this would be a dish we'd order again.

Pluma: If you're only going to have one meal, make it this. Actually, if you're only going to go out for a fancy dinner and absolutely must have pork, you must eat this.  Of all the places I've been to (and I'd like to think I've been to a lot of places), I've never been blown away like this by a first bite.  First off, let's talk about the exterior. The crust of the pork is absolutely perfect and comes served with a light dusting of salt.  On top of that, the honey chili glaze, which comes with a warm bottle of extra in case you want more, gives it a little bit of sweetness to go alongside the juicy meat.  Next, the interior: If you were to look at this, you wouldn't know it's pork.  In fact, the juiciness and the beautifully cooked meat is similar to that of what you'd find in a prime cut steak.  And when I mean it's cooked perfectly, I mean, it is absolutely cooked perfectly.  Big ups to Coqueta for creating such a beautiful and delicious dish! Greg admits that he'd come back here just for this, and wouldn't share it with me.  #sorryimnotsorry

And of course, what is a beautiful Spanish meal without dessert!

Manchego cheesecake lollipops with caramel popcorn: Delicious (and was given to us on the house) but incredibly rich in cheese taste.  Having had the Manchego earlier, both of us were on cheese overload.  But we ate it anyway.  I do enjoy caramel popcorn, so the two combined were delicious.  I think if we had our choice, we'd opt for a different dessert, but wasn't upset about getting it.

Churros with chocolate sauce/berry powder: So, what about this combination seems odd to you?  Berry powder?  How does that work?  Surprisingly, it's an interesting way to eat a traditional dessert like a churro.  Accompanied with a chocolate sauce, the berry powder is meant to be used with the churro.  Like I said, really interesting stuff, and very thought-provoking concept.  The churro itself was just OK, Gitane's donuts are still one of my favorite items I've had recently.

Ok so, if you couldn't tell, I love this place and will be coming back. And you should go try it. Like ASAP. The End.
author: Lisa I.

description: Nice, noisy space with decent service.  But from a "value" perspective, this place is horrid.  $38 buys you seven tiny slices of allegedly pristine Spanish pork, and nothing else. $6 bucks a bite. Same for the Branziini fish. Nothing but a 1/4 of a fish that could barely be shared. Four of us ended up with a $450 tab and left hungry.  Terrible place.
author: Bill S.

description:
I'm a big fan of tapas because I like being able to sample many different dishes in one meal. So I was delighted when my mom and her friend treated us to Coqueta, Chef Michael Chiarello's tapas restaurant in SF. I was particularly looking forward to the Spanish-style gin and tonic concoctions. Some of the food items we had were: jamon Iberico de bellota (true acorn fed pig from Iberico), a classic paella, open faced salmon sandwiches, boquerones.

One word of warning: If you don't watch out, just like with any good tapas place, you may end up ordering more and more food and drinks, then at the end of the meal you will find to your horror that you had run up the bill. This might be the reason some other reviewers complain about price.

We were lucky enough to come during a night with live music. Not sure what the occasion was or who was playing, but everyone in the entire restaurant stopped eating to watch. Some kind of eclectic drum-based new world music. Now that does sound weird or hoity-toity but it actually made for a great vibe in the place.
author: Gail S.

description: My first visit to Coqueta last January was an extremely pleasant experience. The food was outstanding, the drinks were well proportioned and of high caliber, and most importantly, our waiter provided us with impeccable service. Tapas are tricky; you (or at least I) rely on suggestions as to what small plates compliment one another along the road towards a great full dinner experience. That being said, my visit last night to celebrate my two year anniversary was a disaster. It began well enough as we enjoyed a drink at the bar, but after we were given a table it was as if we had been cast away on a desert island, never to see our wait staff again. I literally had to flag down our waitress every step of the way: to place our initial drink order; to order first plates; to even get a glass of water. The waitress seemed to have minimal knowledge of the menu, and didn't take the time to recommend anything, except if you count the fava bean special that she apparently forgot we ordered after 20 minutes, when she told us that it was "on its way" only to retract her statement after another 10 to let us know they were out of fava beans. By the end of this meal my fiancé and I were sharing a single glass of red wine because no one bothered to check how things were going. Lastly, I don't know if it was the service that soured our meal, the the quality just wasn't there this time around--especially the tiger prawns that were offensively fishy tasting. All in all, a $150 mistake. Will not be back. Bummer because I was raving about this place 5 months ago.
author: Kip C.

description:
Do not go to this place, they will randomly charge tips on your bill. 
I was there with three friends a few nights ago. At the end we decided that two of my friends leave tip for all of us, so I did put zero dollars as tip. Then I realized that they charged my credit card with 25% tip, it is very very disappointing and unprofessional. I even called them and didn't get a proper response. I would not recommend this place at all.
author: Mohsen H.

description:
Great food, but I don't think $450 for six people for such a tiny tiny TINY amount of food is worth it.  

If you do end up here, the octopus is a must.
author: PB W.

description: A nice place to eat in the ferry landing area. We sat at the bar area and ordered drinks and tapas. The drinks were fairly expensive and not amazing but the food was great.
author: Matt E.

description:
We didn't get to sit in the real restaurant because we walked in without a reservation, so I'm going to go straight to the important stuff: the food... which is amazing!

The one dish we fell in love with was the "Sunny side-up egg with shrimp, crispy potato, and chorizo dressing."  The flavor bursting out of this tiny dish was incredible!  Such a satisfying dish, we had to order two.

Other ones I liked were the "Wood-grilled octopus" and "Diablo quail eggs."  The eggs are super small, like the size of a quarter.  You get two of them, so I recommend getting multiple ones if you're sharing.

The one dish that fell flat was the "Grilled beef shortribs."  It's utterly forgettable and will just take up space that you should be filling with the "sunny side-up egg" tapas.
author: Elle W.

description: If tapas mean tiny little portions of nothing the place Is just fabulous! I get that SF makes all their money off alcohol but the food was laughable. First off, for the prices, your dishes should not be cracked! 2 out of 4 water glasses had chips, our tiny ass prawn ( 3 shrimp- you call them prawn for the price but those were cup oh noodle quality)came on a broken plate. The server apologized for the pieces of glass floating in the water but that's it.  They had a decent espresso bar but for the price everything else sucks!!!!!!!!the bar costumes out front? Samuel Adams? You suck!!!!!!!x 1Billion.
author: Corey Jace W.

description:
Amazing service, amazing food.

We had a peanut allergy at the table and out waiter (forget his name) did an amazing job altering the dishes that could be prepared in an alternative oil than peanut oil (the standard for all their fried dishes), and was very cautious to warn us about he meals that could not be altered.

Also love that they could alter the tapas portions so that everyone at the table (we had 7 people) could have one piece each.
author: Kristen T.

description:
Our favorite restaurant in San Francisco 

Get a table at the bar and get the chef to take you through the tapas 

Nothing on the menu is bad - amazing Spanish dishes and great ingredients 

The wine selection is outstanding and service great
author: Scott B.

description: A fun place to go eat tasty food. Service was quite slow, especially drinks. It took forever until both first and second rounds of drinks showed. We had to ask to check. But gin and tonic was delicious and fun to see.  Grilled octopus was excellent and also I loved donuts for dessert.
author: Akiko O.

description:
Nothing can go wrong here! It's a fantastic restaurant with friendly staff. Enjoyed a lot and definitely come back.

Ordered wild mushrooms and chips for appetizer. Mushroom was great, but chips was nothing special - and not my cup of tea!

Then ordered octopus and "sunny side up" (shrimps) ... Both are extremely delicious .... I was told the first one is customers favorite and the second one staff's... I completely agree!!

Th place is very nice in pier 5 with a great view. You feel it's kind of vibrant!
Forgot to mention drinks are great too.

Overall great experience
author: Mahyar Y.

description: The food is good. Management needs some lessons in table management and etiquette.  Got in at 530 pm for drinks and tapas. Made a reservation for four. With so much on a very intricate menu, it takes time to pick what you want whilst enjoying the company of your friends.  After ordering over $250 of food and drinks for four people we were unceremoniously asked by the assistant manager in a very sardonic fashion to hurry up and get out because they had another reservation coming up.. "you understand don't you?" He asked. This after less than two hours? Of course this put a sour taste on the enjoyable experience we were having. Even our great waiter was bothered when he asked if we wanted dessert and I told him "well, we were asked to hurry the hell up".    I think this assistant manager could have handled things in a more professional manner-  keeping from topping off our experience with sour grapes.
author: Faisal Q.

description:
Come with a lot of money!Eat a snack before coming to eat. Photos on yelp can be deceiving, portions are crazy small but it was also very yummy. Two of us got the following:

Coquettas: They were the size of a big thumb, tasted like chicken pot pie in a light thin crust, delicious! 
Octopus: It was tender and tasty with potatoes, maybe 4 bites each person I would probably pass on this next time.

Peppers with Ham on top: There was a good amount of peppers and the ham was the perfect touch! I usually don't love this dish but is was real good! 

Crispy Potato with Shrimp and Chorizo sauce: BEST thing I ate and I would go back to eat some more! Portion was good, I wish I had some bread to soak up that sauce! I was literally drooling while eating this.

Churros: Holy crap! Best I've ever put in my mouth, they were light and delicious! The chocolate on the side was so amazing I literally licked the pot. The waitress was amazed by the way I cleaned it. Too good! 

Service was super slow and non existent when we first went in and seated ourselves at the bar area. I was disturbed by that, then toward the middle of service our waitress was very attentive and nice.
author: Karen T.

description:
Have been meaning to write a review! We liked it so much that we went two weekends in a row.

This is a great spot for good drinks and Tapas!

The gin and tonic here is the best I've ever had, and so pretty too.

Love the croquets, they taste like mini chicken pot pies. The steak here is also delicious, but both times i got it, it came at the end of the meal and I was too full.

Also, highly recommend getting the meat and cheese assortment. So many delicious varieties to try!
author: Jackie G.

description: Great cocktails and food BUT do NOT order the Pintxos! $2.75/skewer. Skewer Board is placed on a table, then people pick from it (just pray no one will cough/sneeze or pick one up then return it after the server leaves)...then it is replenished and reserved at other tables! Disgusting! This was confirmed by staff that they only reserve it 'some of the time.' Yuck!
author: Callie C.

description: Food wasn't bad, but everything else was.  Reserved for a birthday long in advance; got counter seats and attitude from a very haughty hostess.  I protested, and eventually, in the middle of the meal, got an even haughtier manager, who admonished me that "being rude to the hostess" was not a good way to get a table.  What table?  I only expressed grumpiness to the hostess after I was put at the counter.  Like his bitchy hostess, the bitchy manager just seemed to be fond of scolding, and being in the right.  Good for him...if his aim was to discourage any future patronage.
author: Bruno A.

description: Went here for a birthday with 4 girls. It was a could day but the space is quite adorable. Of course the gin and tonic with the cute fruit and flowers in it is a must, not only do they look good but they are yummy too. I ordered the Kale Salad and absolutely loved it. I was eating vegetarian that day so was did not get to try the other dishes the girls had but they said everything was really great
author: Eileen H.

description: Too expensive for mediocre food!!!  $5 for an open face tomato sandwich = dried out bread and some tomato confit on the side.  Salmon sandwich was two mini bagels. We asked for table bread for the kids. They brought it out at the end of the meal and it was hard and dried out and they charged us two dollars.  Mediocre food at outrageous prices.
author: Genevieve B.

description:
Located on the waterfront, the restaurant offers great views and is a good place to hangout with friends over a happy hour or so. 

Went there for dinner and found the setup to be a casual one with tables nested very close to each other so if you are looking for a private time/conversation it is not possible. The tables are close enough for you to overhear conversations and sometimes rub shoulders with strangers. 

Service was average nothing extraordinary. Food has a pretty decent selection and the following items were above par:

Classic Paella
Gambas al negro
Pimientos de Padron

Overall a decent experience but nothing that can't be found elsewhere. The outdoor views are definitely the selling point.
author: Tina S.

description:
This quaint little gem is definitely worth going to - the food is amazing, and the staff is very knowledgeable about the menu!! On the last visit we sat at the bar again, and the bartenders never seem to disappoint. We started off with the cured meat and cheese plate, wood-grilled octopus with olive oil, sunny side up eggs with crispy potatoes and shrimp, and two rounds of gin and tonic. 

The bartenders gave le bf and I a go at the porron, where you pour wine into your mouth with an extended arm. My bf (who's a bartender) did really well on the first try but with my horrible skills, I ended up spilling wine all over me and walked home smelling like spring break. :( haha! But it was very fun (on top of amazing food) Can't wait to come back here again and maybe get a chance to redeem myself!!
author: En L.

description: Drinks were good, seemed to be a very popular spot, friendly people and staff
author: Aaron M.

description:
