My first visit to this restaurant was for a co-worker's goodbye happy hour. If you go early enough, snag a seat outside at one of the two large wooden tables! They have creative drinks and quite a few options for "soft libations", which I appreciated since I wasn't drinking.

My second visit was for a late lunch on a Sunday - and it was awesome!! We got to meet the man himself, the great Chiarello. His buddies were sitting at the table next to us so he came out to sit and chat with them, and when their nitrogen-frozen dessert came out in all its smoky glory, he broke off a few chunks and handed them to us to sample. It was a very cool/unexpected experience.

As for the tapas, everything we ordered was perfect and beautifully presented (see my photos). Our favorites were the open-faced smoked salmon with queso fresco and truffled honey, and the manchego cheesecake dessert "bites"*.

I can't wait to go back to try the rest!!

*Points for offering both regular dessert and dessert bites, I find that often I really want  to end a meal with just a teeny, tiny taste of something sweet -and either leave without dessert because I am too full to eat an entire item, or let a lot of it go to waste.
author: Cristal M.

description:
Decided to go here for a first dinner date since my date said she was craving spanish tapas. I hadn't been to Coqueta before so this was a first for me. We had a 10:30pm reservation, which was all I could get for a saturday night, but it was fine, we got there around 9pm and sat outside to have cocktails while we waited. The drinks were fantastic. I had a Mojito and my date had a campari cocktail, not sure what the name was but they were both refreshing and yummy. By the way the weather in SF was beautiful and balmy, just like a night in Barcelona. I noticed the bar menu was the same as the main menu so you could easily sit inside or outside on the Embarcadero and have a lovely tapas meal. The wait staff was very good and attentive. We finally got to our table, which wasn't a bad wait since we were both chatting each other up. We ordered a cheese and meat plater to start, El Gran Plat Cap, which was yummy and had a fantastic variety of meats and cheese. We then received the Huevos National which was deviled eggs with a stack of delicious ingredients. I should mention that we ordered a number of tapas and the waitress was very good about seeing where we were at and bringing the next dish as we were finishing the first ones. The meal was nicely paced. We followed the eggs with  Croquetas de Pollo, Patatas Bravas, and ended with Albondigas a la Feria (duck and pork meatballs). We also added two glasses of Tempernillo Rioja, which was perfect with the food. My only complaint was with the meatballs; the duck and pork was way too rich together flavor wise and also they were a bit mushy. Might be a personal preference, not really a huge duck fan, but my date agreed they were very rich, almost too much so.
We didn't do dessert, too full from all the yummy food. Definitely want to go back and try more of the dishes.
author: Patrick M.

description:
When I heard about Michael Chiarello opening a new restaurant along the Pier, I knew I had to check out, especially since we love Bottega.  After a month of it opening we finally got to last night.  I tend to feel a little lukewarm towards tapas restaurants, but Coqueta blew us away.  The food was excellent and the service was knowledgeable and as top notch to match. I loved how we got a big round table to sit (table size for four), so he and I could sit next to each other making it easier to share.Since bf was so eager about being at Coqueta, we went a little crazy with our ordering.  

*White wine sangria ($9): Probably the best sangria I've ever had.  So light and refreshing, you don't really taste the wine much, but it's not sweet either..if that makes sense?
*He got a red..forgot which one!
*Chorizo & roasted artichoke & piquillo pepper bite ($2.50/each): How can you not like sausage?  The chorizo was a little milder than what I'm used to so the artichoke & pepper stood out more.  But all-in-all, a nice bite.
*Jamon Serrano bite ($2.50): Serrano ham with manchego cheese & apricot.  I loved this & generally I'm not too big on ham or apricot.  The cheese was mild yet distinct enough and everything tied well together.
*Smoked Salmon open faced sandwich ($5):  OMG this was one of my absolute favorites here & I usually don't like salmon because I find the "fishy" taste to be strong every time I've had it.  I absolutely loved the creamy queso fresca and the truffle and honey were divine.
*Chicken & English Pea Croquettes ($9): How do you not like something breaded and fried?  Our waiter perfectly put it, "it's like chicken pot pie filling."  And he was so right!  Creamy chicken and pea filling!  So good!
*Tattas bravas ($8): crispy potato and ham nuggets with aioli.  It was our least favorite, but still good nonetheless.  I liked how it was the perfect ratio of potato, ham, and crispiness.  
*Tortilla Andres ($6): Mix of sweet onion, potato, asparagus topped with piquillo pepper aioli.  This is a cold tapas.  I loved this.  Good carby but veggie filled tapa to fill you up.  The aioli was what this cold dish needed as well.
*Crispy Shrimp ($10): Little shrimps fried with chickpea flour to make a crisp pancake served with saffron aioli.  Some of the shrimps tasted a little seafoody, otherwise this dish worked.  Again, anything fried crisp is pretty much a winner.
*Pluma ($38): Our waiter described it kobe-like pork.  And it pretty much was!  It's a pork shoulder loin served with a honey chile sauce on the side.  The pork was so tender, juicy and had a wonderful nutty texture to it.  It was charred nicely too.  It looked more like steak than pork.  We wish there was more pieces of pork though of course!
*Churros: These were mini churros "u" shapped and came with a chocolate dipping sauce served alonside with a berry powder.  Fine with just the chocolate dipping sauce, the powder was a little on the sweet side.  They weren't greasy either.

After a visit to Coqueta, you'll be like Cha Cha who?  Coqueta sets the bar in my opinion for tapas.  It's a little pricey, but quality and taste-wise it's worth it.
author: Cat C.

description:
What can I say about this place that hasn't already been said?

Here is what you MUST do when dining here: 

1. Open the menu
2. Close your eyes
3. Point your finger
4. Place it on the menu 
5. What ever your finger lands on, order it
6. Eat it or drink it
7. Repeat

You can not go wrong with the above approach, your mouth and tummy will thank you. Everything is off the hook!
author: Michael W.

description:
I use Yelp to find special places to take special people on special occasions.

Usually this works out to procure pretty special evenings, but sometimes it results in really magical experiences. Coqueta gave my mothers day that extra magic this year. 

My mom and I came on Saturday, without reservations, and even at 5 pm Coqueta starts to jam. Eyes set to the front bar, we happily reserved our ocean seats for the evening. Not only did we have a view of the bay, we also had the ear of Joe, the loveliest bar manager I have ever had the good fortune of meeting. Joe did an excellent job of answering our questions about the menu, and giving recommendations about what we could not miss. His presence added to this special experience. Thanks, Joe! 

Coqueta means flirt or infatuation in Spanish; the space, drinks, and food will leave you feeling giddy, blushing and falling in love for the first time over and over again...

Here's what had us "mmmMmm"ing and "awww"ing:

The Castro - an excellent take on the classic marg
Championship Policy - a smoky elixir that grounded and lifted me at the same time. I love that the bartender pulls out a chainsaw in the mornings to cut these massive ice cubes. 

My favorite dish was the Wood-Grilled Octopus w/ Fingerling Potatoes, the octo is tenderized with golf balls, seasoned to perfection, and cooked with incredible care. 
The Chicken & English Pea Croquettes seemed to be a staple for all eating in the bar,  a flavorful bite of comfort was a great way to fill up a little post drinks. The Pintxos were also a favorite - tiny skewers carry bite sized combinations like Baby Beets, Quail Eggs Diablo and Chorizo. All delicious, I highly recommend coming with someone who adores you and food, the Pintxos is a great way to flirt with the menu, trying a bit of this and that. 

For Desert we had Manchego Cheesecake Pops w/ Caramel Corn, the over the top decadence that we had come to expect from our dinner was continued into the final bite. Coqueta left us two very happy gals who can't wait for more flirty evenings on Pier 5. 


Come here pronto. They're doin' something special.
author: Jocelyn B.

description:
If it were not for the flies buzzing around the "outside" bar I'd give this place 5 stars- Great service, Fantastic cocktails, and serious food. If you are a gin and tonic fan, they make the best rendition I have ever had. I think it was called the "Barca" gin and tonic.
It's one I will try to make at home for friends, it was that good.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
Went here for my daughter's birthday. 
Reservations had to be made a month in advance. Food was excellent. We were a party of four so we had a chance to sample quite a few items. 
The problem? The service was very mediocre. We ordered drinks, two showed up. Fifteen minutes later waitress noticed and went hunting for our drinks. We ordered two tapas plates of potatas bravas, one showed up. We ordered an appetizer of chorizo, never showed up. But we were charged for it. Then waitress got a little attitude because she gave us a sample of something on a stick. Food, A; Service, D.
author: Ray K.

description:
I am still dreaming about last night...from the sexy, uniquely complicated cocktails, to the superb service, and the AMAZING food. 

I felt like I was sitting in an elegant home along the coast of Northern Spain; wood smoke wafting through the rafters, warm atmosphere in the main dining room, and the edgy unknown in the windowed bar area. 

I can't stress enough how in love I am with this new resty. Impeccable service without any pretentiousness. Although there are the usual Marin ladies of leisure to add an air of general haughtiness, it felt homey with a glamorous sexy vibe. I don't know how one creates that, but Coqueta did it. 

Wine list: Excellent! With a Spanish focus, (although California varietals are available) there is a little something for everyone and every budget. 

Food: Although I am no expert, I have traveled throughout Spain and always get a little bit depressed when a San Franciscan attempt at traditional fare like Paella falls flat. Nothing fell flat here. Everything, from the grilled octopus, to a traditional paella, to a rich pork chop, rivaled my epicurean conquests in Spain. 

The desserts are equally as complex and tasty--they may just put you over the edge. If so, just curl up on one of the comfy leather benches...it's ok, you are at someone's home!
author: Pvn V.

description:
****************************** REVIEW 858 *******************************

         The former spot of Lafitte, now home of the hottest tapas spot by the water Coqueta of Napa Valley celeb chef Michael Chiarello. The decor of the main dining room, nothing changes, beside a few twists here and there. The add on bar outside is definitely new,  communal tables, only 4 seats at the bar facing the beautiful view of the water if you come here at 5 PM! Other than that, you will facing a jam packed bar with view of people head. 

        Impossible for servers and busboys to navigate with food, I sort of feel bad for them. Although each time, our servers and bus boys were so nice and tried very hard. It's crowded by 6 PM, an almost impossible to look for your server when you needed something, because it's so loud, and packed like sardines! 

        I know, I know it's a new spot, so I need to come back a few months later to see if it gets better. After a few times here, we enjoyed the food, the cocktails threw me off a little, the wine list is OK.

Embutidos - cured meat
- Jamon Iberico de  Bellota, imported, good.

PINTXOS -  bite-size skewers $2.50 each, a MUST TRY - good to sampling!
- House cured boquerones, white anchovies, olives, pearl onions, and guidilla peppers - yum.
- Chorizo, roasted artichokes, and piquillo peppers - love.
- Jamon Serrano, house cured, mancheco, and apricot-sherry conserva - good.
- Baby beets, cana de cabra cheese, citrus, and spring onion a la plancha - OK.
- Quail egg "Diablo", pickled mustard seed, jamon serrano - good. 

TAPAS FRIAS - cold tapas
- Baby beets with Sausalito watercress, beet vinagreta and tierra, and cabrales blue cheese snow - nice, refreshing - very small, for 1 person, a few bites.

- Clam and mussel escabeche, canned fresh daily, with fennel salad, green olives - surprisingly generous portion to share.

- Smoked salmon with queso fresco and truffle honey - 2 pieces, nice to share with friend. The salmon is beautifully tasty, the bread was too hard to bite on.

TAPAS CALIENTES - hot tapas
 - "Tatttas" Bravas, crispy potato and jamon nuggets with bravas sals and aioli, good portion to share, nice presentation.

- Roasted padron peppers with jamon serrano and sherry vinegar - nicely done, nice bites to share with friends.

- Grilled razor clams with pickled wild ramps and meyer lemon salsa, 3 pieces, this was really GOOD!

- Wood-grilled octopus with fingerling potatoes, pimenton, and olive oil, about 4,5 pieces of octopus, perfectly charred, well-balance and tasty, a MUST ORDER!

- Grilled Iberico Secreto, Spanish butchers' secret cut if pork, with tximi-txurri and watercress - this was a GENEROUS portion, beautifully cooked to medium light pink, sliced nicely about 7 pieces, tasty and probably the nicest dish we tried so far. If you come a few friends, MUST TRY this dish!

RACIONES Y VERDURAS - family style and market vegetables.
- Whole grilled Branzino with green olive and preserved rangpur lime salsa -  beautifully done, moist, sweet, buttery texture, really nice dish to share.

DESSERT
- Asturian Apple pie with Cabrales blue cheese ice cream - enough to share for 2 people, my BFF loves it. 

- Strawberry- rhubarb gazbacho, frozen blood peach neblina,  with berries - love

COCKTAILS - fascinating list from ingredients to presentation. 

- Silky Sangria - modern frozen red sangria, raspberry fizzy, apple gelee, blueberries - nice and you probably need at least 3!

- Pyreness Snowball - frozen sdra, gin meringue, pine, anise, yogurt, micro flowers, honey lace - about 3 tea spoons, I can do at least 5 of this, very good!

- The Powell Line - Isla canarias ron arehuca, orange luqueur, fresh apple, juice, lemon juice, refreshing and nice for a warm afternoon by the Bay.

- Tariff - Jamon Iberico infused gin, acorn & apricot tonic, orange, cava was quite nice! 

        Since it's a tapas place, your bills can add up if you eat like my BFF and I, but we enjoyed the food very much. Coqueta is definitely a spot for us to check back often when we hit the Embarcadero water front. We already tried half the menu, maybe a few more visits, it won't hurt! By the way, we only comes on week night and it's already this packed, don't even bother on the weekend! 

          Hot spot for Summer 2013!
author: Manda Bear B.

description: Pretty decent, but expensive for what it was. The octopus was salty and hard, the paella was bland and salty at the same time if that makes sense, the flan was too sweet and hard, and the churro sauce was bitter. The razor clams on the other hand was delish!
author: Lucks N.

description:
Think: the most photogenic tapas, delicious drinks, and a rustic-chic space with floor-to-ceiling windows and thick wooden accents.

Since the food and interior is to-die for, basically everyone one in the restaurant is either instagramming or snapchatting (ahem. totally guilty of both. We've all been there).

They serve a a modern interpretation of traditional Spanish tapas with a twist of northern California flavors. The menu features cured meats & iberian cheeses; cold tapas; open-face sandwiches; a dozen hot tapas; and family-style shared plates.

Pretty much, everything I ordered was a winner and there wasn't anything I didn't enjoy. The only thing I regret is not having room for more food (insert: crying emoji).

+ Croquetas de Pollo ($9)

Okay. Hands down... these are my favorite things here. It comes with three chicharón-crusted chicken and English pea croquetas with cured cara-cara oranges. Once you bite through the crispy outer layer, you get a creamy consistency with tender chucks of chicken inside.

+Salmon Ahumado ($8). Omg... that truffle honey... I die.

This was a nice little palate opener and my 2nd favorite thing here (I'm a huge fan of lox bagels). The combination of the sweet honey + the saltiness of the salmon + the crunch of the crispy bread made it a perfect bite.

+Albondigas a la Feria ($14)

So bomb. These are grilled duck and pork meatballs with tart cherry and tempranillo salsa and crispy shallots.  The meatballs were juicy and tender with a deep brown sear on the exterior.

+Paella: The classic ($45/ serves 2-3)

I can't even right now... (currently: writing this blog post while starving)

Honestly, it's one of the best I've ever had.

This version is made with bomba rice that nicely soaks up all the flavors of the jamón serrano-shellfish broth, topped with gulf shrimp, clams, chorizo, and broccolini.

While all that^ was already bomb, it wasn't until I tasted the lemon aioli till I was REALLY blown away.

So to sum it all up:

Coqueta is perfect for a nice brunch or dinner date (especially since it's located at Pier 5 along the embarcadero). I'd recommend coming here with friends so you can share everything and order more food. The paella is a MUST (you could prob split that between 4 people) and order more tapas to share. And since it takes about 30-40min to make, place your order right when you sit down!

Visit the blog for pics: http://cyneats.com/
author: Cynthia L.

description: Best meal and dining experience I've had in ages! My friend a I walked in with no reservations on a Thursday evening. We couldn't find a spot at the bar so we headed out. The host ran out onto the street to let us know a table had opened up! That was so kind especially given how busy they were. Our server, Ryan Patrick, and assistant, Dustin were amazing! I was completely lost over the wine list and menu but Ryan saved me. He asked what I liked & disliked and then ordered the perfect meal and wine pairing. And I still can't stop thinking about the paella; it was even better than anything I ever had in Spain. I don't live in SF but visit often for work. I'm planning on becoming a regular at Coqueta & you should too!
author: Mehrnoush Y.

description: So much good Spanish food! From Patatas Bravas to Paella and Pan con Tamate, this place had it all. Pretty stellar cocktails as well - highly recommend the Besos de Barca.
author: Michael C.

description:
This is a wonderful restaurant. My wife and I ate at the bar and found the food and service to be great. We had tapas and drinks. 

So here are the details -
- We managed to get a spot at the bar on short notice - so we got a same day reservation for two.
- All the tapas were wonderful. My absolute favorite dish was the plate of chicken croquettes. The fry was perfect - they came to us nice and warm. The fry batter included chichirones. It held together perfectly until you put one in your mouth and then they crumbled in a savory explosion.
- The cheese plate came with traditional quince paste. There was a lot of variety, and all the cheeses were tasty.
- The cocktails are expensive but very good and creative. I had one with gin infused with Iberico ham.
- We met the manager, and he's a nice fellow - he and I waxed nostalgic about the wonders of Cuban food in Tampa, where we've both lived.

So it was a great meal. And at the end I forgot my credit card and our waiter sprinted down the Embarcadero to catch me and return it to me! Talk about above and beyond the call of duty!

Great food, great staff. The only thing I would change is that I don't like barstools with no back support.
author: Carter S.

description: What a wonderful experience at chef chiarello's croquetta. We gave up our table to be served by Derrick at the bar and he made the experience memorable with gin drinks and sangria. His gin drinks were superb. We ate Spanish tapas. The egg with shrimp and potatoes was amazing. The albondigas withe the pardon peppers were great. Wonderful and welcoming.
author: Hector G.

description:
This is definitely more of a 3.5 review.

I was really excited about eating at Coqueta having heard all the great things and being a fan of Michael Chiarello in general. Full disclosure: I ate at Coqueta late last year so this month is about 4 months late.

I've been to Barcelona and Spain and I'm a huge fan of tapas in general, so I had high expectations for Coqueta, but everything was simply too salty! The interior of the restaurant is lovely and woodsy, it's in a great area next to the Embarcadero and the service was lovely, but everything I ate was just too over-seasoned.

I ate with my parents and boyfriend so I had the chance to sample many dishes- some that stand out include the paella, which didn't have the crunchy rice that comes from the skillet, and again, was just too salty.

I like that they come around in the beginning of the service with some tapas skewers that you can choose, amuse bouche style, but the food didn't stand out to me either. 

Price-point wise, it won't set up back too much, especially for the location, but in general, I think there are much better tapas places in the city, like the very underrated Alegrias.
author: Kate M.

description: Amazing! Savory tapas. The sangria is a must! Great service! We tried the Branzino dish with side tapas. I was here for a birthday celebration and the waitress brought out a complimentary cheese cake dessert with a piece of chocolate with a Birthday Note. My boyfriend enjoyed this place & we both plan on returning with a bigger party. Thank you Coqueta for the great food!
author: Anabelle F.

description: The mini lox bagels with honey truffle are literally to die for. Also tried the pork and duck meatballs and mmm mmm mmm! Cheese plate was bomb and my friend love the wine. A bit pricey but worth it. Will definitely going back!
author: Ezo W.

description:
Oh, tapas.  It is such a double-edged sword.  Yes, tapas makes it possible to try lots of menu items, which is all kinds of fun.  However, tapas sometimes takes small plates to a level where you spend a lot of money to get just a little food, and leave feeling unsatisfied.  Such was the case at Coqueta.  

Service was pleasant throughout our meal.  Or should I say, "meal."  The host and our server were friendly and helpful.  The interior of the restaurant is small but lovely, with soaring ceilings and decor reminiscent of a hipster-style vintage barn-inspired loft.  I dug it.  The issue here was the food.  Some plates were good, some were a little less interesting, but at the end of our lunch we'd spent $65 on little bites and were both still hungry.  And I am not someone who normally likes big portions.  Like, I am not a Cheesecake Factory aficionado who doesn't get the concept of tapas.  I get it.  But the plates at Coqueta are too small.

The best food item, in my book, is the Jamon Serrano Pintxos.  A small skewer of manchego topped with a touch of apricot preserve a tiny bit of serrano ham.  Wonderful taste, incredibly flavorful.  Absolutely miniscule.  I also liked the new potatoes with mojos verde and the churros with chocolate sauce that we had for dessert.  Less inspiring was a small salad with pears and a touch of ham, which was really underwhelming.  I don't actually see it on the current menu, which is a good thing.

This is really not a good place for vegetarians.  There aren't enough vegetarian options, and the ones that are available are just okay.  My lunch companion was a vegetarian, and he was bummed.  Maybe we should have looked at the menu more carefully before we arrived, but in San Francisco, you can eat well as a vegetarian just about anywhere.  Not at Coqueta.

I told a friend about my experience and she nodded her head and said, "Oh yeah, don't even bother going there for a meal.  Coqueta is all about the cocktails and a small bite or two before moving on to dinner elsewhere."  Interesting.  We didn't try the cocktails, although they did look pretty good.  I'd be willing to give Coqueta another shot for some cocktails and more of the jamon serrano pintxos.  Otherwise, though, it just didn't work for me.
author: Erin L.

description:
We went there for my birthday and I was impressed with food and service. Everything we had was delicious - the Sunny side up and the eggplant/brioche appetizers both were tasty and special - very interesting pairing of tastes. The paella was great - the combination of rice, spices and seafood/chorizo/vegetable was great - they provided additional seasoning to adjust the taste and everything worked out perfectly. We ended with the chocolate covered manchego bites on the stick - again, delicious! 
Service was very good as well - knowledgeable recommendations and we felt we were treated with care and attention.
Thank you, Coqueta!
author: VIORICA C.

description:
This review is so overdue.   For my birthday last year, I chose Coqueta to celebrate with my closest friends. 

I had very very high expectations of the place.   My girfriend made reservations for our party of 5 and we were seated right away in one of their larger tables.  It was a beautiful day in San Francisco so the place was packed.  We ordered so many things off the menu and everything was great.  I will definitely return and bring my husband with me the next time I go. 

Highly recommend
author: Christine P.

description: Amazing! I was hoping to get a peek at Chef Michael but alas he wasn't there but I was told he visits about every 3 weeks. Everything we ordered was divine. Service was a little slow but they were packed so I know they were working hard. The only downside is it's very popular so it's hard to get seating so book in advance whenever possible. I usually avoid anything touristy but the venue is beautiful rustic Spanish and I love the food so this is the only place on the Embarcadero I'd frequent.
author: Farah W.

description:
Went here on Friday 9/27 for dinner.   Started at the bar area and ordered an oracle-  very very delicious :).  This ended up being my drink for the evening.   The bartender was super nice and talkative.   We then moved into the dining area where we had the most awesome waitress.    Orders a ton of food:

Started off with the el plat cap - a selection of meat and cheese -   everything was delicious and paired together nicely

The second dish was the chicken & english pea croquetas with pickled tomatoes.   This tastes like chicken pot pie but the tomatoes were amazing!   I have never tasted tomatoes like that before.

Third tapas was the sunny side up egg.   I love the mix of textures and flavors in my mouth (crunchy shoe string potatoes with egg, shrimp and a lot of spice)
 The server offered to mix it up for us (which I suggest - its just easier
that way).  If you don't like spice, you can take out the pepper before the server mixes it.

The next course of the meal was the pluma.   Since its pork shoulder, I thought it would be pretty tough but the meat was soooo tender.   It was flavored just right.  

The finale was the paella and dayuuuum just when I thought the food couldn't get better.   The paella is just perfection.

So I know my descriptions were pretty basic but overall, I had a great experience here.   Now I understand why it takes a month to get reservations in the dining room.    I could eat here again and again....
author: Sherry C.

description:
My friends and I stopped by here for dinner to celebrate a friend's bday and other milestones. This was a restaurant we all looked forward to coming. Food was nice, drinks were good but the service wasn't impressive. (Our waitress was nice and I have nothing to complain there.)

First, we had 5pm reservation but the restaurant wasn't ready so we had to wait a bit to be seated, which was fine, not a big deal. Once we were seated, we waited awhile for our drinks to come. We ordered a total of 5 dishes and two drinks each among the three of us. 

But as the evening went on, different servers kept coming to our table asking if we were still working on our dishes. First, I thought they were attentive. Then at one point, 3 different servers came within like 5min of each other, and asked if we were still working on our dishes as if to say hurry up. It was almost obnoxious. 

Finally, the manager looking guy came to our table saying "I don't mean to be rude but other people are waiting for the table" and basically told us because we had been there for about 2 to 2 1/2 hrs we needed to finish and vacate the table. Well, his communication was rather rude and brash. Immediately after, another server came asking us if we cared for any desserts which we said no to since we had just been asked to leave.

I understand it is a busy Friday night. We would have been mindful of time, had they communicated upfront that the table needed to be vacated after a certain amount of time due to high volume of customers. Or they could have communicated it in a way that wasn't so unpleasant. It wasn't as if we were nursing one drink and one dish. 

Instead, they were passive aggressive, and left us feeling as if we were inconveniencing them. They could have handled it in a more professional way for sure. Moreover, when the manager came, the place wasn't particularly busy. We saw a bunch of open tables. Unfortunately, this experience left a bad taste in my mouth and I probably won't be coming back here.
author: C S.

description: We have been wanting to try this place for sometime now. I am so glad we made the trek over today. After dealing with all the tourist at the ferry building and labyrinth of one of the best Farmers market in the Bay Area. We headed over to enjoy the view and a light snack. The Chef selection cheese platter was on point it was simply amazing. Las Gambas al Negro was not my wife's favorite oh well more for me I loved it. We were lucky enough to score a couple of seats at the bar facing the Bay Bridge right in front of where all the action is. Luis is a master at his craft and is very welcoming and willing to explain any of the concoctions he is mixing up. Dont waste your time on the Sangria ask Luis what he recommends and go with it. We will be back soon and plan on coming hungry to try more of these flavorful and simply prepared tapas.
author: Manny G.

description: We came here for my husbands birthday with our baby daughter and felt super welcome dining with a child. The restaurant is beautiful with a view of the water. There were several families there with children and we felt that the wait staff was super friendly and solicitous.  We are big fans of Bottega in Yountville and were very curious about Chiarello's new restaurant. We were coming from a weekend of eating in Napa already so were pretty full of great food. However we were definitely not disappointed! First off, the drinks are colorful, fun and delicious. Many times non alcoholic drinks are pretty similar or for the most part not very special but that is definitely not the case here. There is a nice little selection of fun drinks and they're all very pretty!  We were super impressed with the paella and felt that it was the perfect portion for our small family of three.  The potatoes were delicious and the dessert was a churros dessert with a twist of different powders that were the perfect ending to our tapas meal.
author: Megan S.

description:
What a great location to have a meal; the view of the bay is really nice... the establishment is aware of that too and configured that into the price of the meal me thinks. 

Service: was just fine, nothing to write home about, so let's talk food.

Sangria: two words - go elsewhere.
Patatas Bravas: not worth it. It was such a NorCal interpretation of a classic Spanish tapa, that I felt that this was a pitiful representation of the superior no-frills versions that you can find at either Picaro Cafe or Contigo.
Kale & Persimmon Salad: again, this is not a Spanish dish. But holy shit, this was one of the best salads I've ever had. I wanted more. This is a must, no doubt.
Grilled Octopus: NorCalifornianized. Such a shame because the dish could have been great. Really small portion too.
Duck and Pork Meatballs: made me quiver they were so good and succulent. Shit.
Seafood Paella: really good. I recommend it; it had socorrat, which is the trademark of the best cooked paellas.
Churros & Chocolate: solid.

All-in-all, I think that our meal had some really nice moments to it food-wise. My problem is that it didn't feel authentic; it just made me feel like I was ripped-off for the authentic Spanish food that I got when I lived in Spain. So much cheaper over there with no frills, just need you to buy me a plane ticket there so I can revel within my nostalgia.
author: Charlie D.

description:
Came here for drinks with friends. I was severely disappointed with the alcohol selection (or lack there of). My fiancee wanted an  Amaretto Sour. They didn't have Amaretto. I asked for a Makers neat...they didn't have Makers. I then ordered a Jameson neat...didn't have that either. A friend ordered a Jack & Coke. They only had high end Jack. He then ordered a White Russian. No Khalua. Another friend ordered another drink & was told they only had pineapple rum & no coconut rum. What type of bar is this? It's not like we were asking for really unique drinks!

But, they did have some amazing sangria and their gin & tonic was fantastic. Our waiter was also very friendly and tried to accommodate us the best he could after we tried to go through a list of drinks we would've liked to have.The food looked great, but we were there just for libations. Based on our experience, I can't really recommend it. Maybe someone can convince me to go back just for a bite to eat.
author: Conor B.

description: The food was good. Definitely should try the uni open faced sandwich and the grilled octopus... but when you think about all the other options in SF and how expensive this place ends up being... it's just alright. You can definitely find much better for much cheaper too!
author: Ann Marie L.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to come here for a Christmas dinner. We had made reservations through OpenTable and somehow I canceled it and never re-reserved a table. Fortunately the hostess was extremely nice and helpful over the phone and told me they can accommodate us at the bar seating -- fine with us. It was a great first impression for us. When we got there, however, it went downhill. 

We were seated in the bar area as the hostess had informed us. The bar tables are very tiny and cramped but whatever. Not a big deal. We were given paper menus in which you open and presented with a bunch of drinks. I politely asked our server for the food menu and he replied in a condescending tone, "Open it". MAI BAD. I didn't know. 

We ordered the following:

"Sunny side-up" Huevo ($13): I love me some eggs, I love me some shrimps, and I love me some crispy potatoes. I would've loved this dish more if it wasn't so incredibly salty! I think they went overboard with the chorizo dressing. However, the egg did help balance out the saltiness a little bit but once that egg was finished, I think I felt my blood pressure rising. Still good nonetheless.

Albondigas a la Feria ($14): Three pieces of duck and pork meatballs topped with crispy shallots. The crispy shallots complimented the meatballs quite well but that may be a biased opinion because I just loveeeee fried shallots. The meatball was a little overcooked but still enjoyable.

Pulpo a la Parilla ($14): A wood fire grilled octopus that was actually really good, I just wish it was more grilled throughout the octopus and not just at the tip of the tentacle. 

Then the paella....

The menu, as well as our server, informed us that it would take about 30 minutes for it to come out which was fine. Lo and behold it only took 1.5 hours, guys. It had already taken almost an hour for our three tapas plates to come out and our octopus was almost forgotten about and our server never knew we haven't received it. Why? Because he never checked up on us to see how we were doing. Great service, right?

When paella came out, it was lukewarm like it had been sitting under a heat lamp. The rice was straight up burnt and hard to chew and shallow. All the ingredients within the paella was burnt and the sausage tasted like rubber. I called our the server to let him know about the paella and he said, "let me get my manager". The manager comes over and asks us what's wrong with it. I said nicely said, "all the dishes we had was really good except the paella. Everything is just burnt and it's difficult to eat." He says, "Oh really? Did you want another one?" And we said we didn't want to wait another hour and a half for it. He insists that it won't take that long but we said no. Then he left. Never once did we get an apology from either the server or the manager for the bad execution of the paella. 

The entire time service was incredibly slow and our server rude and had a bad attitude. We never complained about the service or asked where our food was. We waited patiently. And still the guy treated us like lower tier customers. After we had sent away the paella did he FINALLY smile and treat us like royalty. It was so incredibly fake and posh. He gave us complimentary dessert that consisted of cheesecake pops dipped in caramel. Whatever milk they used was so sour and rancid that I almost gagged it out on the table but immediately remembered that I was in public so I held it in. 

I rarely experience bad service (minus your hole in the wall Vietnamese/Chinese restaurant -- they don't count) and never have I sent back a dish no matter how bad it was...until this place. Considering the price of this place, I had expected better quality food and service and got neither of that.
author: Kristina D.

description: Although I wasn't a huge fan of the food, this 1 star review is for the restaurant (or waiter) adding in their own EXTRA tip, on top of the 20% tip I gave.  I still have a copy of the signed receipt, and it was easy to dispute with my Credit Card company. Based on previous reviews, looks like this resturant has done this before. That is complete FRAUD.
author: Candice M.

description:
You can seriously make a case for this place being a 2 star or a 4 star.  So I settle on 3... overall the place was good...but...

The chicken and pea croquettes were very disappointing.  I'd expect a dish like that in Wisconsin...at a diary farm... not in a tapas restaurant.  Plus, there wasn't anything chicken about it.  I was seriously comparing that to a breaded cheese curd I wanted to forget.  I've made MUCH better in my kitchen.

The tatas bravos is a joke...seriously...couldn't believe it... was nothing more than a few bland tater tots with melted cheese on top.

Those were the first two dishes to be dropped on our table...I was starting to see a theme here and disappointment was setting in...then...

The open face sea urchin "sandwich" was placed in front of me.  It was a special item on the menu today.  To call this a sandwich (open faced or not) is ridiculous.  It was fantastic...but in reality...three orders of this dish would have equalled a sandwich.  You can serve this "sandwich" as an h'orderve at your next dinner party and it would go over very well.

The gambas al negro was very good...seasoned perfectly.  I really wanted more of this dish.

A couple dishes were boring and uninspired, and couple were very good... all of them were over-priced.

Service was great, but not worth going back...not even to entertain out of town guests.
author: Zoran L.

description:
Went last night for dinner, late reservation had to wait about 15 minutes for our table, no biggie.

Had the amazing Barca gintonic, super refreshing, fragrant, looked great as well. I will try to recreate at home.

Wife and I shared everything - gran meat & cheese platter, the star of that was the Jamon. .. melt in your mouth delish. The deviled eggs were amazing as well, very complex. .. recommend to chew slowly so you can capture all the flavors of each ingredient. 

Sunny side up egg with shrimp was very rich, I ordered this at the end, I could eat this for breakfast every day.

Ordered the Sutter smash for my nightcap, it got sweeter as i sipped on it. 

Will mos def try again
author: Melesio M.

description:
WOW!!  Well done Michael Chiarello.

At first when we walked in we were seated at this side-bar area, continuous with the bar with stool seating on a raised counter, and I felt TOTALLY shafted.  I did get lucky making a last minute reservation, but I kind of wanted a real table...

Then later into the night I realized that we had gotten SUPER lucky.  The dessert person behind the counter caught me eyeing all the delicious-looking plates she was constructing, and later that night she let us try a caramel cheesecake on a stick.  And then after we went with the pan chocolate with EVOO ice cream, she asked us if we "had enough ice cream".  SUPER friendly staff in that regard, but I did think that our waiter seemed a bit preoccupied and haughty (hence the 4/5 stars).

Everything we tried here was phenomenal.  The octopus was tender, cooked to perfection, and slightly crispy on the outside.  The branzino was also cooked perfectly and served with the head, so I dug out the cheeks :) true Asian style!  The cauliflower with romesco sauce was also fantastic, and the two girls next to us let us try their brussels sprouts (which were apparently not on the menu, so ask if they have anything special that night!)

My boyfriend ordered a smokey-tasting martini off the menu per recommendation of the waiter, but he took a few sips and didn't like it so the waiter replaced it with a different martini, and I don't believe they charged us for the first one.

The wine by the glass list here is a bit scarce, and the wines run from $13 to $22 so definitely not easy on the pockets!
author: Kelsey H.

description: Amazing drinks & tapas! Incredible views of the bay from our bar stools. Try the Galleon cocktail- I told the bartender I didn't like gin, but he encouraged me to try it. So glad he did- delicious & refreshing!
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
Trendy atmosphere, beautiful Spanish gin & tonic concoctions, and oh-so-delicious tapas! What's not to love about Coqueta? This place serves plenty of creative dishes that'll surely catch your eye, so it's actually perfect that these are served as small plates so you'll have room to try a little bit of everything. 

- Barça Gintonic: Dare I say the best gin and tonic I've ever had? Love the refreshing flavors and elegant presentation. And it definitely kept my belly warm throughout dinner.

- Salmon Ahumado (Open-faced sandwich): Bite-sized toasted bread topped with the tastiest thick-cut smoked salmon, all drizzled with truffle honey. The perfect starter to our feast.

- Patatas Bravas: These are essentially glorified fingerling potatoes, but the dipping sauce made it special. Lightly fried and fun to eat.

- "Sunny side-up" Huevo: Juicy shrimp, crispy hashbrown potatoes, all mixed together with a yolky egg and spicy chorizo dressing. Yummy!

- Paella: I'm addicted to paella, and this dish was worth the wait. The portion is huge and can easily feed 3 people. I loved the flavor, and bf was dolloping that lemon aoli onto his plate. -1 only because our waiter did not remember to give us our leftovers!

- Churro Fantasia: Fresh sugary churros served with a decadent berry chocolate sauce. The perfect ending to our dinner.

Overall, a wonderful experience and my expectations were set pretty high! Do yourself a favor and make a reservation several weeks in advance. They do have a bar that serves the full menu, and yes it is first come first serve, but the tables are tiny and it would be difficult to fully enjoy all that food.
author: Nicole P.

description: I have done some research for dog friendly restaurants and decided to give this a try.  Marco was our server and he was very friendly and helpful.   I would give 5 stars for customer service.   The portion of food comparing to the price is a bit pricey but I love the food.   We do have to sit outside the of the restaurant in the cold weather due to having our dog with us so remember to wear extra clothing if come here for dinner with your beloved 4 legs animal.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Most authentic Spanish tapas restaurant in the bay
We had Jamon Serrano, pulpo, pork shoulder, 
Great sangria
Very good service and great environment
Perfect location and nice people
author: Sandy B.

description:
I've been hearing about this place for a while and made reservations 2 weeks in advance.  The place is definitely popular given how crowded it was on a Wednesday night.  We had 6 tapas between 2 people and it was more than enough.  Felt a little pressured by our waiter to get the 6th dish which we ended up taking home.  

I would definitely recommend:

- Sea and Mountain open face sandwich if you love sea urchin as much as I do.  Very generous portion of sea urchin!
- Wood-Grilled Octopus is absolutely stunning.  A huge piece of octopus made to perfection.  We've never tasted octopus that was so flavorful and so easy to bite into.  

The other dishes we got were just OK:

- Bikini brioche is definitely delicious, but also very rich and filling.  It really makes it hard to eat anything else after you've had it. 
- Sunny side-up huervo is an interesting dish in theory, but I felt that it was drenched in oil and made it less enjoyable to eat as a small dish.  I also expected more complex flavors, but I was just mostly tasting the "crispy potato" or as I like to call, shoestring fries.
- Duck and pork meatballs were again very tasty, but nothing too memorable.  It was also our 6th dish, so by then, we really had no stomach to enjoy it.  
- Yellow cauliflower steak lacked flavor.  I felt that the "coal roasted romescu sauce" would be much better on an actual steak, felt a little wasted on cauliflower.  

Lastly, the place is quite loud and can get pretty touristy.  However, the view is amazing and the food is definitely worth checking out.
author: Yue X.

description: This is another one of those "all hype no quality" places that,sadly, are opening all around San Francisco. They have an awesome location with view on the bay, very cool design, nice ambience, and a friendly service. Unfortunately they lack terribly on the most important thing: food quality. The tapas they serve are embarrassingly mediocre, and they don't come cheap at all. Their menu is pretentious, but the execution is absolutely disappointing.
author: George A.

description:
I've been here a few times, twice for lunch and once for dinner.  Each time I am surprised this level of service is allowed.  The waiters are cold and disinterested, often to the point where it makes the group uneasy.  When I went for dinner, it was for a group of five.  The dishes ordered sometimes only had 3 or 4 of each item, and we were fine with adding some so everyone got a piece for some dishes, whereas on other dishes we were fine with it as is. Later, as we continued to order, the waiter no longer asked us and simply added items to each dish and charged us accordingly.  As we didn't know how many each dish came with and we were fine with sharing, we had no idea until we received the bill. 

This is unacceptable.  We ordered a fairly large amount of items so was the waiter simply trying to pad the bill more?  Strange and tacky for this supposed caliber of restaurant.
author: whatever I.

description: This place is consistently outstanding. Excellent service at bar both bar and restaurant. Food and drinks are amazing. Everything delicious from beginning to end.
author: Maurita C.

description:
Good and nice atmosphere, but pricey and small portions. Good cocktails  and wines but by the glass prices were high. ($14 and up) but the bar appetizer portions were ridiculously small.  A serving of deviled eggs was Very pretty but just one egg very artfully prepared. The "skewers" are really toothpicks with micro sized bites of cheese and ham. 
The egg was also a little rubbery. 
On a Thursday night it was one of the few places still hopping at 10pm. Service was good.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
Food was fine. Service is rude. We were curious what a particular dish was; the waitress with a smug attitude: "that's actually a dish for one of our special guests. It's not available on the menu". Well, we could have become that special customer but now we won't. 

Bottom line: the food is not good enough to put up with the service. Not coming back.
author: Mehdi A.

description: Good regional Spanish food with excellent service in a lively and fun atmosphere. But the food is WAY overpriced for the taste and quantity served.
author: David N.

description: We've been here twice now, and I've been disappointed both times. You want to love it - it's Michael Chiarello, after all. I'm sure if Michael himself was back there cooking, it would be 5 stars, but the execution both times we've been here was below what we get at many lesser-known, less expensive places in the city. For example, we recently ordered the paella. Compared to your average paella, I would expect a Chiarello-inspired paella to have that extra something that just puts it in a master-chef category. Instead, it was barely average. The rice was cooked perfectly - crunchy on top and on the bottom of the pan, but the seafood was dry. It even looked dry when it came out. Given how expensive it is, I'd be willing to pay the little extra for something hard to find as good anywhere else, but that's just not the case.
author: Bib G.

description: Hands down the best server we have ever had.. Oswaldo! Ask for him (or to be seated in his section) he is literally amazing. Great drinks, great view, great food! The quail eggs are on point! Will be back. Arnel is really attentive and great too. I'm blown away with the service! Thank you
author: Gretchen T.

description: Love this place. Great Gin and Tonics and delicious food. Will come again when in town! Kale salad and Salmon appetizer dish exceeded expectations. Pork Shoulder was my husband's fave.
author: T. N.

description:
You pay for what you get here.

It's a nice setting, on the bay, the outdoor tent bar inviting, the dining/kitchen area lots of exposed weathered wood and hard surfaces. Not much as changed since it's previous incarnation...
The seating, a tall stool, very uncomfortable, and the banquet, so soft one is far too close to the table. There are other seating choices, I'd ask for them next time.

That folded piece of paper is your menu. Not easy to read, tres trendoid , and a bit like a cheap place. The book is a wine list, and it has some very interesting and good wines at not great prices, but, what the hey, you're out for some fun, eh?

The food, some of which is great, costs about $2.50 per bite.
That's the price for the cute little skewers that come out on a board, and they're so cute, and tasty, too, as Lucy said years ago. 

The wine comes in these complicated/clever beakers, and at $12 and way up per glass, the Dishwasher is welcome. Good wines, however. 

Last year in Spain I wondered when the cuisine would blow up, and here it is. This place is not less than 4-5 star pricing. The raw cost of the items presented gives you an idea of what it costs to open a place like this thesedays. At these prices, one might be better off saving ones funds and going to Spain. Or eating in other SF Spanish tapas places.

Sure, the rent's expensive, Michael Chiarello is around, and it's new. All the food puffers in town swoon, as one can see by some of the other Yelp reviews. 

Make up your own mind, that's my advice.
author: William M.

description:
Apparently this place has gotten a lot of hype lately, known for incredible Spanish food and impossible reservations. Somehow through a connection, we got reservations the night before V-day and had a fantastic time.

The cocktails, omg the cocktails... I had the "Sun Never Sets" and it was truly incredible. Everything the perfect drink should be. Then we had a delicious cheese & meat plate which was great. 

All in All, what stood out was the tapas - braised shorts ribs (like omg) and the sunny side egg... Both were perfectly balanced and mind blowingly delicious.

We finished our meal with the infamous Paella and while it was good, it wasn't great. I've yet to find one that is Spain quality in the states though.

Come for the drinks, stay for the tapas and enjoy this beautiful restaurant.
author: Krista K.

description: Food was great.  However, towards the end of our dinner, the manager came over and said the next guest is waiting for our table and offered to move us to the bar.  Really?  We were with an out of town guest too and wished the manager knew better!
author: Sherry H.

description: We love sitting at the bar on the left as you come in. We always meet interesting people to chat with. The drinks are going incredible.  My Zoloft will is their game. The food is fresh and spot on trendy tapas.
author: Kim M.

description: We made a reservation at Coqueta for our nice dinner out while visiting SF. We read somewhere that it was a hot location as of October (2016). We made reservations well in advance which netted us two seats at the bar which was alright. We had a few of the small plates, one tasted like deep fried cream of chicken soup and another would have been an excellent breakfast dish. Be prepared to drop a hundred or so for two people including a drink or two each. While it was tasty food I would likely make a different selection next time.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Love Coqueta!  It's sure to be a long-standing hit in San Francisco as Michael Chiarello knows how to orchestrate a wonderfully tasty menu of Spanish tapas in an elegant setting with a strong cooking team and servers.

We were lucky to be seated at the counter in front of the kitchen as the chef and his team turned out dish after dish, meal after meal impeccably.  I couldn't stop staring at Michael Chiarello as I was totally star-struck!  But we got to drink wine with him through these hand-crafted glass thinly fluted flasks (I was a little scared because you have to hold it up at an angle while it thinly streams to your mouth, it was red wine, I had a white cardigan on, you get the picture - but I did fine, woo!).  He gave us good food choice recommendations and we chatted a bit (nevertheless, I was still star-struck and could not staring at him, ha!).  

We ordered a number of small dishes, but these were the definite highlights of the night:

* Sunny Side-Up Egg with shrimp, crispy potato, and chorizo dressing

*  Grilled Razor Clams with meyer lemon and wild ramps

*  Cured Cod Crudo with tomato fresco, hearts of palm, arugula, and whole citrus dressing

Classy great-tasting dishes with that extra touch of something special.  I will definitely come back!  In fact, my friend are making plans to come back very soon because we want to try everything on the menu!  

Note: I would have given Coqueta 5 stars, but I was very turned off by the unprofessional hostess (I didn't catch her name, but by the time she reads this, she will know who she is and I hope she learns from her mistakes).  I make tons of reservations on Open Table, and I made my first Coqueta reservation on a Thursday evening at 5:30.  I checked OT that morning and yes, it was still there and confirmed.  When I arrived at the restaurant, the hostess said she did not see my reservation and that she saw that I supposedly changed it to the following Thursday.  No, no I didn't.  After "investigating" for a full second, she threw her hands up like there was nothing she could do and when my full party arrived that she could try to fit me in for a table but it would be a 45 minute wait (she cancelled the switched reservation for the following Thursday, I knew there must've been some kind of mistake and she probably cancelled somebody else's reservation).  

What?  Unheard of.  My friend was late so it wasn't like I could argue yet.  When she arrived, I explained my situation to a kind waitress who then went back to the hostess and then came back with the same answer.  I was already thinking about what I was going to write in my Yelp review regarding this.  But then! - the manager came up to me and apologized, said our drinks while we were waiting for our table were complimentary as a restaurant staff member had inavertently changed my reservation for someone who coincidentally had my same last name.  I guess there is some way that they can track changes made on OT.  So, the manager got us our awesome seating in front of Michael Chiarello and all was forgotten as I appreciated how he handled the situation and took the time to see what actually happened.  But!  I hope that hostess learns from this and realizes how unprofessional she was.  People remember how good the food was, but bad service, including *bad hostessing*, kind of stays with you longer.  Also, I had to follow up with OT to receive my 100 points for my reservation since she cancelled it in the system.  

Other than that whole experience, I would give Coqueta 5 stars for the food, the manager who handled the situation well and for Mr. Chiarello of course!!  I will be back!!
author: Maile N.

description: I'd almost say 4.5 stars. Came here for brunch, but I believe it's the same and full menu as dinner. Anyways, the experience was fantastic. From the service, where they really spent the time to go through the nuances w/ the drinks and dishes (without asking and not in a boring yawn fest, hurry up so I can get on with my nigh-- type of way). The drinks were phenomenal, from their balance and palate stimulation concoctions, to the attention of detail put into the presentation of them. The food was all amazing, not one thing I was not a fan of. Simple as that, this place rocks. Oh and the location and vibe inside doesn't suck either.
author: Drew F.

description: Incredible meal and service.  Octopus is the best!  But the 32 oz grilled steak was amazing!  The staff are lively, fun, and attentive.  I can't wait to go back.  Don't leave without having some sangria : )
author: Zach T.

description: Coqueta is absolutely amazing. Our group kept expanding and the Manager, Katja was very accommodating.  Our group continued to rave about the dining experience the next day. Very good cocktails, great food, beautiful atmosphere. One of the best restaurants in San Francisco. Thank you, Katja and team for making this night a memorable experience.
author: Erika R.

description:
Mum was in town, so we took her for some sightseeing and food-tripping at our fave local/tourist spot, the Embarcadero.  Went here on a whim and saw Coqueta with an almost empty bar -- miracles do happen.  No reservations -- just walked in with 3 adults and 2 young kids and were seated very promptly.  Wouldn't have guessed that this is a popular restaurant with tough-to-snag, 1 month-in-advance Opentable reservations. Mum is definitely a lucky charm!

Definitely had high expectations, considering that not only is this Michael Chiarello's first foray into Spanish cuisine, it also won him Esquire's Chef of the Year.  At the bar, service was unpretentious but very friendly.  Our server recommended the chicken and English pea croquetas and patatas bravas for the kids -- it disappeared in minutes (blame the adults); we ordered a second round!  The baby beets with watercress and blue cheese was artfully displayed, also gone in 60 seconds.  My husband and mom loved the grilled beef shortribs with sherry-chocolate glaze. We also ordered 2 of Michael's favorites -- the Whole Monterey calamari was soft and tasty, but the star of the show for me was the "Mar y montana -- sea and mountain".  This dish consisted of toast with iberico lardo and jamon iberico, gently melted over -- get this -- sea urchin. If there is one dish to define the chef's menu, I would choose this. I'm still dreaming about it.

Top that off with a great bar menu (we had the sangria and margarita), and we can conclude that Coqueta is worth the hype! I will need to come back for their paella and arroz dishes, hopefully when I get lucky on another line-free Sunday afternoon!
author: Dawne L.

description:
Great setting...really tasty food.  Will certainly return!
One awkward moment...bartender reached into a huge jar of peppers with his hands to fill his cup sitting on the bar.  I find this unsanitary...couldn't a spoon be used?  Why use your hands that have been handling a million other things. Yuk factor!
author: Maria D.

description: By far my favorite Spanish tapas place in the city. We ordered 12 dishes (including the seafood paella to share) among the 4 of us and it was the perfect amount of food! My personal favorite is the smoked salmon, deviled eggs and the duck and pork meatballs!!!
author: Anji S.

description: Loved the gin & tonic! The service was wonderful. Came here on a Saturday at noon and we were very happy with the food. We ordered the bite size tapas. Chorizo with artichoke was delicious, manchego cheese and prosciutto was so complimentary and the jamon was melt in your mouth perfection. The view of the water from the porch was breathtaking. Will bring family back here in the future without question.
author: Kerey J.

description:
Coqueta is AWESOME. Highly recommend coming here for drinks or dinner - make a reservation if you want to eat. Even with one, you will end up waiting around for your table, but the bar area is cool, so you can wait in there. It gets a little crowded because people are eating in there as well, but it's more than fine.

Drinks: get a porron to share with the table!

Food: "El Gran Plat Cap", Patatas bravas, pulpo a la parilla, seafood paella

Can't wait to return and try more off of the menu!
author: Lauren C.

description:
This is a popular place. I would not suggest coming to this restaurant without a reservation...or ANY hot SF restaurant for that matter. The bar is okay to sit at, but you wont get the full Coqueta experience.  

Sometimes Celebrity Chef restaurants can be a little iffy. Michael Chiarello, on the other hand, is a GENIUS! This place is phenomenal. 

Before the restaurant opened, I waited and waited for reservation announcements - especially because the restaurant was going to feature PAELLA! When they were finally announced, I was lucky enough to score a reservation on a Sat night at 9pm one week after they opened! Not going to lie, I felt like I hit the lottery.

It is located on Pier 5, waterfront, with one of the best views in all of SF. When you walk in, the bar is to the left and the restaurant to the right. It is dim lit, and a lot of wood decor. They took us a while to seat us, which sucked a little bit because I was hungry. Excuse me; STARVING! The manager made it up to us by buying rounds of drinks as we waited. A gesture like that from a manager goes a long way to me. That is what you call GREAT customer service.

The food is AMAZING! Even though I am a meat lover the item you should not miss out on is the CRISPY SHRIMP! We ended up ordering several of these plates. Wood-grilled octopus is a close second! All in all, everything we tried was great. The sunny side up egg, patatas bravas, and even the Pluma - Iberico Pork! I have been to Spain and must say this place is pretty damn good. Remember, this is a Tapas restaurant...which means small plates. But it is more about the quality rather than the quantity.

As If the food wasn't enough wait until you try the drinks! They have house-made gin and tonics!! I would have never thought you could get a hand crafted drink on the Pier! Think Bourbon and Branch, Novela, Bergerac, and/or Alembic. I would start with the Barça Gintonic and Tariff! Then move on to the Death of the Summer Love & Engine No 5! Instead of dessert, top of your stay with a Liquid Nitrogen Sangria! There is no where else in SF where you can get that!

What did disappoint me was they told me they had ran out of Paella!! That was the MAIN REASON why I came. Instead, the waitress suggested the Arroz Cremosa. That too was good, but my heart was set on having Paella. Regardless, the food was great and HAVE to be back to try the paella. Maybe then I can rate it higher. I guess it just gives me an excuse to come back.
author: Leonel B.

description: Pretty location on the Bay, cool looking inside. But I just wasn't impressed with the service or food. The deviled eggs have a couple of distinct flavors that were both horrible to me. The Sangria tasted syrupy sweet. Then I saw the bartender pouring a bottle of Coke into a decanter of red wine...um... ugh. I had a few people service my table, I wasn't sure who my server was. Then when I needed someone, no one was around.
author: Suzie H.

description:
Everything about our experience at this  place was mediocre, except for the service, which can be summed up as cold.  For months I heard local friends raving about this amazing restaurant, and our small group of 6 were looking forward to the dinner we had planned for 11/22.  

Made reservations 3 weeks out, gentleman on the phone nice and gave us the community table in the bar area.

Showed up on time but our table wouldn't become available until 30 mins after the time  we mad the res for, fine, no big deal.

The young man at the podium was downright rude and dismissive (picture included)-he was so nasty to us I wanted to leave before we even got to our table.

The food was decent but our waitress clearly wanted to be anywhere else than Coqueta that evening, geez, does anyone in this place crack a smile?

Just when I had given up hope, a very nice bearded man came by and asked about our meal-nice touch.

Overall disappointing-wouldn't go back, unfortunate because we had heard such good things from people, and judging by the other yelp reviews perhaps it was just an off night for them.
author: Michael B.

description: Went last night for my birthday! Super amazing service and food!! Loved it! Brooklyn was our server and she was great!
author: S. E.

description: The good thing about striking out at the Ferry Building is stumbling on to a gem like this. Michael Chiarello's flirtation with spanish tapas does not disappoint. The sunny side-up huevo with the bikini brioche had me practically licking the plate, although I must admit that the sexy cocktail prepared by sexy Luis, the incredibly charming and talented bartender, may have also had something to do with that. Great place filled with locals, this is a definite must if you find yourself in San Francisco!
author: Valeria V.

description:
Coqueta is a great dining experience reminiscent of meals in Madrid or Barcelona...

We had a little mishap where they lost our reservation. The hostess was kind and made sure that they fit us in even though it was extremely packed that night. 

In the meantime, we sipped on red wine Sangria (fabulous) and twists on gin & tonics. The drinks were fantastic - 5 stars

We also had the cheese plate, the meat plate, and olives, all of which were amazing. Highly recommend these as appetizers - 5 stars

Entree wise, we split the paella between 3 people. It was delicious, but not enough for 3 hearty appetites. I would get more if you have 3+ hungry people. -4.5 stars

Finally, we had dessert. I forgot what it was called but it was a mix between flan and creme brûlée. They gave it to us for free, due to the whole reservation situation. It was delicious and not too sweet. - 5 stars 

Overall 5 stars. A great dining experience. Cool restaurant, fantastic food, and great service.
author: Caitlyn R.

description: Tapas.  People like them. I get that.  There are a ton of places that try to do this right.  From trying to be authentic to the supposedly innovative.  Now, here's the thing. Coqueta has it done right in a very true to flavor Barcelona style.  Everything is about spot on to what I remember from my time in Catalonia. Everything except the price I should say but I suppose that's to be expected.
author: David S.

description: Yum. I can't begin to tell you what we had since it was a little bit of everything. Drinks on point. View spectacular. Vibe amazing and social. Interior purdy. Favorite item- dessert cheesecake popper with popcorn on the side. You'll thank me later.
author: Remy-Anne V.

description:
This place. 

We came last night (a Wednesday night) a little before 6:30 fully expecting to wait a long time for a table, or to be told they were full for the night. Instead, the host took my name, phone number, and directed us to wait in the bar area. He also told us that the middle table was communal and if something opened up, we could sit there.

We ordered drinks, wait. Check in around 7:15, and are told to keep waiting. Order a snack (a small, expensive, and underwhelming cheese/meat plate). By 8, we're still waiting and the host hasn't messaged us or come over. Only two of us have chairs in the bar area, and when we ask, the host tells us it's impossible to get more. At 8:15 we check in again, and the host says we're probably not going to be seated. Really? If you're booked for the night, don't tell people to wait, let alone for two full hours. 

Miraculously, some seating opens up at the communal table, and we sit down. Oh wait, no. Now, after waiting for two hours, those seats are also reserved and we can't sit there either. Naturally.

By far, the worst experience I've ever had at a restaurant.
author: Liz G.

description:
Great food and what an impressive staff and service. Not only did this restaurant exceed expectation but the staff was so considerate to us knowing that we had been waiting a while for a first come first serve with our 2 young kids.  Our server, Michael, was professional and attentive.

We've been disappointed with these tapas places before. Every time we would check out a new one, they end up being glorified appetizer dishes spun into the name "tapas".

This restaurant stayed true with actual small dishes and Spanish style dishes which were full of flavors!

We loved :
- the grilled octopus, you get a full tentacle
- the grilled shrimp head on with spicy olive oil sauce
- the gaucho steak , cooked to perfection and seasoning was simple
- the croquet potato, small...bite sized, addicting 
- white wine sangria

Definitely a must try and we can't wait to go back when we're in SF.
author: Steph B.

description: Everything is phenomenal here. Food was 5/5 and we tried most things on the menu. I could list everything we ordered and say how fabulous each dish is, but that's just too much work since every single dish will just be: "this is amazing". I enjoyed my experience here, will definitely come again!
author: Ingrid C.

description:
Beautiful spot for a happy hour on the water or late night dinner! However I experienced Coqueta while cohosting a private event and I was definitely impressed. 

Chef Chiarello was amazing. I loved the open kitchen and being able to watch him and his team work added so much to my experience. As I was not a regular dining patron, I was able to see behind the scenes. All staff were extremely friendly and went above and beyond to make sure our event went beautifully! 

We had the main dining area closed off so other diners had to remain in the (gorgeous) indoor patio room. I could tell that Coqueta is the place to be on a Thursday night as guests poured onto the small outdoor patio in front. They knew they could not leave without having tasted perfection. 

The wine was great, although I'm not a red wine drinker so I don't really have anything to compare it to. I'm not sure if they have them on the regular menu but the little donuts with raspberry sprinkle were like nothing I've ever tasted before! I love sugar donuts and the raspberry were such a perfect combination to give it a sweet flavor. 

The only reason I couldn't give five stars was because I was there for a private event but I have a feeling I will be updating this post to a five star in my future!  I really want to go back to San Fran just to go back to Coqueta! 

Ps I love the name! Flirt is how I felt about everything at Coqueta. Like a summer fling, the food, drinks and staff had me smiling ear-to-ear. :)
author: Michelle S.

description:
I'm HOOKED!!!!
Go for the Tapas and drinks.  The Sangria is authentic and the Tapas are well done.  The chef even does his own rendition of a tapa found in Barcelona's Quimet and Quimet.  It's a great place to go for a European experience in California.
author: Dominique T.

description:
Birthday Lunch! Womp Womp! This place has it all, ambiance from the minute you walk in with high ceilings and a warm rustic feel. While waiting to be seated I made a quick trip to the "loo" and on my way back I looked over to the bar/kitchen area and got a wink from the Man himself Michael Chiarello! (Wowwie wow what a hottie, what a great way to start any meal...sorry husband...) 
Okay back to the food...Everything we had was oh so delicious!
I'm jumping around here but the most memorable thing I loved was these slow roasted fingerling potatoes that were covered in a powdered salt and had a dipping sauce of cilantro....divine.
Garlic and bread soup with a hen egg...mmmmmm
Jamón Iberico De Bellota ($$$$) but worth it!
"Tattas" Bravas crispy potato and jamón nuggets with bravas salsa and alioli-these were like high grade tater tots, so delicious!
Chicken And English Pea Croqueta- so creamy inside and crunchy on the outside.
Grilled Duck Albóndigas-could only eat half of one, because I was already getting full! we also had a couple other dishes too...I just can't remember everything, but we had quite a few and nothing disappoints.
And I washed it all down with some lovely Sangria. They have a wonderful Bar with some choice Gin drinks or go for beer like the hubster...
And Michael was so charming when I asked to have him pose with our table for a picture, the whole dining experience was just fantastic from beginning to end. Only had minor hiccup of waiting for our table, even though we had 1:00 lunch reservations. But they comped us an appetizer, and it was soon forgotten once the food and drink started to roll out.
I can't wait to return. This was the real deal in dining, beautiful views, ambiance, great food and attentive wait staff.
author: Susan D.

description:
Ordered their Gin & Tonic and it was amazeballs. The presentation for that drink is always really really really pretty. PRETTY. 

Hung around the bar area until our reservation time. It was pleasant and quite cozy. 

Their food was okay... Nothing really stood out to me. I thought it was a bit overpriced on some things.
author: James N.

description:
Really lovely dinner date spot or for drinks with friends/coworkers after work. I love how rustic the restaurant feels. It gets pretty loud and packed, but it's still got a great vibe. If you sit at the bar area, you can see into the "kitchen" area which is a pleasant surprise. Coqueta is located along the Embarcadero, so a nice evening stroll after dinner is really romantic as well.

We ordered two hot and two cold tapas:

- Trio de Salchichas (grilled sausages glazed with isastegi cider, apple and mojo verde)
- Pimientos de Padron (Roasted padron peppers with Jamón Serrano and sherry vinegar)
- Ensalada de Kale (lacinato kale, roasted squash, fresh pomegranate and warm garbanzo dressing)
- Ensalada de Achicoria (grilled chicory greens, granacha poached pear, sliced apple, and serrano ham vinaigrette)

For drinks, we ordered: 

- The Castro (espolon tequila blanco, curacao, fino sherry and fresno pepper with lime)
- Conquistador (nolets gin, anise tonic, apple-celery juice with a spiced fennel salt rim and lemon)

Both drinks were $13 (there mixed drinks range anywhere from $12-$19). I loved their drinks. The food was pretty good as well, but their drinks were really unique and I loved the flavors of both. I'd definitely come back again for their drinks!! The cocktails were absolutely amazing. 5-stars for the cocktails themselves! The tapas are elegantly presented, but there wasn't anything too memorable. One problem we had was with the service. Although we sat at the bar area...our waitress neglected us for a good chunk of time....while I understand the restaurant was busy, but we were at the front of the house.
author: Rachel C.

description: Love the "outdoor" bar and flowers garnishing the drinks. Margaritas are the best! Excellent tapas and chz plates. This place gets busy after 5, but it's great to come on a day off, or early before the crowds descend. Well oiled machine. Great staff. Friendly manager.
author: Emily H.

description:
Michael Chiarello's hot new spot on the Embarcadero, Coqueta is a knowledgeable foray into world of Spanish tapas.  It is hard to get a table in the dining room and, unless you get there early, the small bar seating area is usually packed as well.  It's a bit hard to eat in the bar area, especially at the seats that line the perimeter.  

The drinks menu is quite interesting, with cocktails I'd never seen before.  There is also a section devoted solely to gin libations, which I found surprising since I don't associate this particular spirit with Spain.  One such drink was a small batch gin and artisanal grapefruit tonic water, served in a huge squat glass with juniper berries, flowers and wedge of pink grapefruit.  It was beautifully presented and actually quite tasty, especially considering that I generally dislike gin. 

Wanting to try the house Sangria, which had a very appealing description in the menu, I was disappointed to learn that they were out.  Mind you, this was at 4:30 on a Thursday.  How can a Spanish restaurant not have Sangria?  Particularly when they make it ahead of time and keg it.

Getting past that disappointment, it was time to focus on the food.  This is what was ordered for 3 people:

--Cheese and cured meat platter
--Beef and duck meatballs
--Tatas Bravas
--Pluma (heirloom pork loin, roasted and served with a chili glaze)

Everything was very tasty, although I found the tatas lacking.  They were prepared like tater tots, but not very crispy or flavorful.  The dipping sauce made up for this, at least partially.  I found the meatballs to be the best dish ordered.  They were incredibly juicy and loaded with flavor.  The crispy shallots on top and the cherry Tempranillo sauce providing an excellent complement.

I'd definitely like to come here again and hopefully eat in the beautifully rustic dining room with open kitchen.
author: Bryce B.

description:
You will pay handsomely for your experience here, but the place is fantastic.  Unique drinks and the food is exquisite.  I think I might book a trip to Spain after eating here!

We dined mainly on the tapas - both hot and cold - which were all delectable.  Personal favorites were the fuet (a house made sausage) and the grilled octopus.
