We also ordered one of the large plates - the quail - which was probably my least favorite of the evening but still delicious and well presented.

Going to have to take the wife here for sure!
author: Pink L.

description: The best meal we had in San Fran!!!!   Ask for Brooklyn....she was the best server we had!  Food AND drinks were amazing. Loved it
author: Kevin S.

description: I was super disappointed with Coqueta. I had heard great things and the reviews were fantastic, but I was not impressed. The restaurant itself is beautiful. They did a fantastic job with the decor and the location and view is unbeatable. The food wasn't bad, but it just was not very memorable. I liked the salmon ahumado, it was unique. I was not crazy about the meatballs. Really liked the sunny side up egg with shrimp. We had a few other things, but I can't remember what else specifically. My favorite thing was the Gin & Tonic. That is a fantastic G&T and it's beautiful. I also loved the manchango cheesecake. I'd come back just for the G&T.
author: Gabrielle C.

description: I was not impressed with either the service or the food... The atmosphere was very nice with great energy... I also have to mention my drink was one of the coolest drinks I've ever had... Simply beautiful... But the service fell short... And everything we ordered while OK was not worth $500
author: John S.

description:
From the outside, Coqueta is an unassuming spot along the Embarcadero, but once you enter Chiarello's restaurant you get the full Spanish tapas experience and the atmosphere to go with it. The menu has an extensive array of hot and cold tapas as well as larger entrees, which makes choosing that much more difficult since the prices are not exactly friendly.

We started with the famous gin and tonic, which comes in a beautiful glass decorated with flowers and grapefruit. The drink is mixed really well, so I barely tasted the gin and instead got fragrant floral and fruity notes. Next, we ordered both the smoked salmon and sea urchin open-faced sandwiches. These were essentially like crostini, and the better of the two was definitely the smoked salmon. The salmon was paired perfectly with goat cheese, which was then drizzled with a sweet truffle honey that brought it all together. The sea urchin was supposed to be a land and sea pairing, layered with thinly sliced prosciutto. The urchin was a little overpowering for me, with a disproportionate amount of briney flavor that wasn't exactly counterbalanced by the meat. We also had the English pea and chicken croquettes, which had a great flavor and was perfectly crispy on the outside. The dish that I liked the least was probably the shrimp and sunny side up egg over crispy potatoes and chorizo dressing. The chorizo was too salty for me, and the crispy potatoes along with the fried egg made the dish greasy and heavy. 

However, the meal as a whole was fun and unique. Coqueta is definitely a great spot to have drinks and snack on quality tapas, and I'll definitely be back to try their other dishes.
author: Ashley T.

description:
Another one of my favorite spots in SF. This is my go-to place whenever I am getting together with a couple of friends in the city. 

Coqueta has an amazing selection of tapas dishes and it's great when you have a couple of people and be able to taste a variety of dishes. I have been here enough times to taste majority of the dishes and I have to say that each time, the food has been absolutely amazing. My absolute favorite dish would have to be the smoked salmon with truffle honey open-faced sandwich -- definitely a must-order! (Forgot to mention, the Jamon Iberico and the Manchego Cheesecake dessert are both splendid!)

If you are looking for a place to get together with friends, this is the place to be! Coqueta has great ambiance and awesome food. It may be a bit pricey but it is definitely well worth it.
author: Erica Y.

description:
Overall excellent. Cool vibe and great drinks. The highlight was the charcuterie plate of all things, with some outstanding chorizo. The croquettes were also worthy.

Best part of the night was watching an Italian couple order various dishes and the look on their faces when they saw the size of the steak... It was massive as it serves 4 and not really considered a tapa I guess
author: David B.

description: Great food and the Gin and Tonic was awesome.   We were in Spain a couple of years ago and this is the closed I have found to the restaurants in Barcelona.   The grilled octopus is a must if you like seafood.     Also loved the patatas.   Would of gave five stars but the service was not as attentive as i would expect.   Great location on the water.   Highly recommend this place if you like authentic Spanish food.
author: Richard L.

description: This place is all about ambiance - really nice. I liked the little greenhousey annex. But the door kept on opening and I was freezing. And the food we had was kind of meh.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Was pretty impressed.

Had one of the gin and tonics and was delighted.  The Conquistador had anise tonic and apple celery juice.  Was really good.

Also had a a mojito costa brava with the tarragon lime air.  That was tasty too, although we asked our waiter for whatever cocktail they were making with liquid nitrogen over there, and the drinks were not cold so we are not sure if he understood what we meant because there was nothing liquid nitrogeny about them.  Either way, they were really good.

For food we had the shishito peppers with the serrano ham.  They were good, but I felt that the dish was more about the ham than the peppers, which may have been what they were going for.  Either way, I felt the shishitos were too mushy, and not turgid enough.  They were not toothsome.  Flavor combo was good as long as you had ham and peppers in the same bite, but the only problem was that there were more peppers than pieces of ham, so that was kind of hard to achieve.

We also had the manchego bites for a dessert dish and those were FAB!  I think they may have been coated in carmel or something sweet, and the manchego was nice and supple inside.  The saltiness of the cheese was cut nicely by the sugary coating.  They were served on a stick kind of like a lollipop that you didn't lick.  Totally unique dish.  I would order again.

I was pretty impressed with this place and would like to come back and eat a full meal next time.
author: Christian C.

description:
Why 3 stars....?  (NOT SO SURE ABOUT THE BARTENDER AND MANAGER)

I made reservations for Saturday, Oct 11 for my wife's 40th Birthday.  We arrived about 30 minutes early to have some drinks and quickly made our way to the bar.  I had read about the "Championship Policy" and wanted to try it while my wife had a "Galleon."  

When I received my drink it seemed like there was BARELY 2 oz in the glass which was disappointing considering it was $13.  I immediately questioned why people made good reviews about it.  My wife's drink was a watered down gin and tonic at best.

We were sat a bit early at our table next to three gals who were celebrating a birthday as well.  They immediately struck up conversation with us and wanted to show us their "glistening" drink.  I asked what it was and it turns out it was also a "Championship Policy."  I was confused as to why they had triple the pour and as I looked a table to my left I noticed another drink similar to theirs.  The girls said my drink was weak because I didn't show up in a short skirt, maybe they knew something I didn't...  

I called our server over and asked why such a drastic difference in how the drink was made.  I got a "beat-around-the-bush" answer and she returned later with a drink similar to the others I had seen.  I also ordered a "Sun Never Goes Down" for my wife which once again seemed short on the pour.  I now regretted the good tip I had left the bartender.  (Taller bald guy)

The food overall was great.   We both tried each of the bite size skewers - we probably could have ate a platter of them.  The "Sunny Side Up Huevo" was good enough to punch someone in the face or fight over, we should have ordered two.  We also shared the albondigas and gambas al negro which were very good as well.  My wife really enjoyed the salmon ahumado which I didn't think would be much but turned out to be outstanding.  (Another dish we should have ordered twice)  I was able to have the mar y montana dish to myself since my wife isn't a huge fan of uni.  To finish the manchego cheesecake is everything the reviews say it is and the churro was great as well.

When our check arrived I was about to sign it and add tip without even looking at it.  As I checked for the tax to help me calculate tip I noticed a number of drinks added to our bill that we didn't order which added up to an ADDITIONAL $95!

I called the server over and she told me the bartender had transferred those drinks to our tab.  I explained that I had closed my tab after my first order of drinks and showed her the receipt.  At that point the table next to us was listening in and offering their condolences as our server returned with our adjusted tab with little more than a "sorry about that."  The manager (blonde lady in all black) walked by right after that and I explained what had occurred from our initial drinks to the discrepancy in our tab.  She seemed to be bothered that I was sharing our experience and asked "well, did you get it fixed?"  I responded "yes" and she replied "great, hope to see you again."

I'd expect that type of experience at an Olive Garden.....
author: R K.

description:
I had been wanting to try Coqueta for the longest time, but you have to book relatively far ahead in advance to get a reservation because it's a popular place to hang out. Was far and away one of the best tapas dining experiences I've ever had! If you can't get a reservation, they also do walk-ins, but you risk a pretty long wait depending on how busy the night is, and they are constantly packed.

Ordered: cured Serrano meats, Mar y montana open face sandwiches, Huevos Nacional, Coliflor con Romescu, "Bikini", "Sunny side-up" Huevo, and Pulpo a la Parilla

Highlights included:
- Beautiful gin and tonics (I ordered three of them and thoroughly enjoyed all of them)
- Mar y montana open face sandwiches were to die for: essentially an open-faced uni sandwich and probably one of the most mouthwatering things I've ever eaten
- Coliflor con Romescu: a cauliflower steak accompanied by Romescu sauce.. never had cauliflower with such explosive flavors! It was definitely one of my favorite dishes that night
- Pulpo a la Parilla: the grilled octopus was tender and juicy and had great flavoring to it

I thought the Sunny Side-up Huevo was a little too salty, and everything else, though delicious, I could do without ordering again (just based on personal preference; they were still excellent dishes).

We wanted to try the Spanish rice dish but were told it takes a long time to prepare and that they had to free up our table for the next party. I believe they have a limit of 90 minutes when you're dining there and it's easy to see why. We had stayed for 2 hours at that point and were still trying to order the rest of the menu... haha. The ambiance is elegant but casual; perfect for some nibbles and drinks after a day of work.

One thing I will mention is that portion sizes are SMALL. These are tapas and are not meant to fill you up or serve as an entire main dinner. If you're looking for that, try some of their larger-sized items. The party next to us ordered a paella and it looked absolutely fantastic.

Total bill came out to $146 before tip for 2 people, inclusive of 5 cocktails between the two of us, and I thought it was well, well spent. I usually don't come to places like this more than once (one time is usually enough of an experience to satisfy me, and there are a lot of restaurants to try out in the city!) but I will DEFINITELY be returning to Coqueta.
author: Chrystal Z.

description:
We were seated at the bar. For this we needed reservations? The big water upsell began. So annoying...are you staying with just tap water for now ? Hellz yeah now and forever! Our water was refilled exactly once after asking and there were too many flunkies running around doing nothing.
 I ordered a plate of cured meats. It was small and just OK.  Next was a duck sausage that tasted like...sausage.

I had a cappuccino that was bitter. There was no Splenda just a small dish of brown sugar, probably because this was the bar and there's no room. The barista came by to ask me how was the cappuccino .  So I lied and said it was great . 

Dessert was just OK. Portions microscopic. Waitstaff disappears for long periods of time. So a big disappointment.
author: Henry C.

description:
Oh ma gawd...So good!

I went here last weekend and tried about 6 small plates, 1 dessert and 2 drinks per person (for two people). The waitress recommended a large dish and 5 small plates. I think that would have been way too much, but we luckily ordered just right. 

Often disappointed with Sangria, this place pleasantly surprised me! And, they had fantastic ice cubes which I adore. How did I know it was good? Well, I proceeded or North Beach after and had some really crappy Sangria! 

I'd recommend the cold salad tapas, meatballs and garlic prawns. Those were really to die for. The one bite skewers were OK, but not my fave, more like a mouth fulla cheese and meat (perhaps the veggie ones are best.) For dessert, we opted for the churros with chocolate and raspberry dippings! I had to ask my fiance to not drink the chocolate dipping sauce and try to maintain what dignity we had left after plowing through all the great food. Unconscious of my own food induced dreamlike state, I cheerily scooped up each bit of raspberry dust on plate, leaving none for him. :) He was very sad.

The atmosphere was also great and really consistent throughout and no detail was too small. I enjoyed sitting by the window looking out at the water. Great location for a date night with a late night stroll down the piers or a trek to North Beach after (just don't try to top the drinks you get at Coqueta-because it ain't gonna happen in North Beach honey.) :)
author: Heather T.

description:
Everything about Coqueta makes for a great experience and one that must be cherished and enjoyed slowly. The restaurant is quite beautiful especially with the ocean view, tall buildings, and night lights from the bridge.

We arrived at 6:30 PM and waited 20 minutes on a Friday night which was not bad at all considering it's the prime time on the prime day to eat out. Our seat was not bad and was actually quite desirable and much to everyone's liking.

This is what we ordered:

EL PLAT CAP ($26): This is the chef's selection of cured meats. This was excellent, I'll have to say but not that interesting. The meats specially selected were salami, prosciutto, and one that resembled salami but with a tinge of red orange. They gave 18 pieces, six of each type. The presentation was spot on with a piece of menu cut up and the wooden board it was served on giving a rustic feel. Though the quality was top notch, for $26 it wasn't worth it.

SUNNY SIDE-UP EGG ($12): This was very innovative if you ask me. I love the idea of shoestring crispy potatoes piled high with fried egg, shrimp, and chorizo dressing. I don't know why or what it so special but the combination worked. This reminded me of a breakfast item since there were hash browns (crispy potato) and fried egg.

GRILLED RAZOR CLAMS ($14): This was amazing and was one of the best dishes of the night. This is a very rare find and cannot be found at any place I can think of. The clams had the perfect consistency, were juicy, and given in a generous portion. Highly recommended!

WOOD-GRILLED OCTOPUS OCTOPUS ($12): This was amazing and the version at Evvia in Palo Alto was comparable. It was so simplistic yet so delicious. It wasn't rubbery and was tender and very moist. 

GAUCHO ($80): This was probably my least favorite dish of the night but was great for meat lovers. It was a special and was basically a hunk of steak cut up. It was cooked perfectly; not too done or too rare. However, it was filling and boring since meat I can go elsewhere for. They gave a generous portion of six pieces but again I wouldn't pay $80 for something I'm not too keen on. 

PAELLA ($40): This was so good in every aspect. They gave a great portion and the flavors from the shellfish seeped into the paella which made it tasty. The ingredients added, asparagus, chorizo, gulf prawns, clams, and lemon aioli, made sense with the dish. The concept was new to me and the moment I ate it I fell in love and have tried to find places that serve it let alone replicate it. The closest I've found was Jaleo in Las Vegas but that didn't even compare to the quality I found here.

JAMON PINTXO ($2.50): This was prosciutto wrapped around two pieces of manchego cheese topped with apricot jam. I never thought that a combination like this would taste so good. It was innovative, sweet (from the apricot jam), and salty (from the cheese and prosciutto).

WARM CHOCOLATE CAKE ($10): For any chocolate lovers, I recommend ordering a couple of these. It was very good and the assorted nuts on the side were a great touch to the overall presentation, which was beautiful as always. There was some sauce on the top; a perfect finish to the perfect presentation of the perfect dessert.

MANCHEGO CHEESECAKE ($4): I didn't try this but it looked very innovative yet a bit sweet for my taste. The addition of caramel popcorn was nice. My brother confirmed it was sweet but enjoyed it nonetheless. They provided two smaller pieces which was fair for the price.

PAN CON CHOCOLATE ($4): This had ice cream cookie on the bottom with olive oil ice cream on the top. It paired quite nicely and was delicious. My only gripe was that parts of the olive oil ice cream were saltier. It kind of threw me off but nevertheless it was a brilliant combination.

COFFEE ($6): They serve Four Barrel coffee which is top notch. Though, I didn't sample this, my dad enjoyed it. The cup they provided it in was very innovative because the glass around the cup prevented customers from burning themselves. 

SERVICE: They were really courteous which was expected. They paced everything out very well and made our night an unforgettable one. 

DECOR: There are two sides of the restaurant whereas one side is more of a wine bar where the exterior is reminiscent of a green house with beautiful glass windows. Another side is more like a formal dining hall and is for those hoping for a proper meal. Though a bit loud, it adds to the overall experience. No matter which side you get, you should make the most out of your experience because everything from the service to the atmosphere to the innovative creations courtesy of chef Michael Chiarello, is like none you've had before and truly is a "once in a lifetime opportunity".

Will I return? Yes please! Though the experience is over and it came out to $50 per person it was well worth it because as I said it's a "once in a lifetime opportunity". Everything about our experience made for an amazing night. Thanks, Coqueta!
author: Jacquie H.

description:
This place has a nice ambiance, good tapas. Service was excellent. Chef  Michael Chiarello was here, came up to the table, very friendly took pictures with my group. 

This is a fun place to try, the bar area outside looked cute too.

I've been here a few times since my first visit and I have really enjoyed the variety I the menu, surprisingly vegetarians who I have brought here like this place too :-) btw try their drinks are a must try- alcoholic or Virgin!!!!
author: Azizi A.

description: Awesome place! Decor, staff, service, drinks and food were all phenomenal. Right by the water, the location is unparalleled as well. A new favorite.
author: S T.

description:
I come here a lot as it's near the office, is great for lunch and the Barca G&Ts are awesome. 

We had a table booked after work last night to celebrate my birthday with some drinks and Tapas. We were a bit disorganized, quite a few more people showed up than expected etc etc. but our waiter, Scotty, handled it all in an extremely professional, helpful manner. He made everything work smoothly, and it was very enjoyable. Great drinks, great food, and outstanding service. Thank you Scotty!
author: MIke C.

description: Coqueta is one of my favorite restaurants. The Castro is the best drink I've ever had, and sometimes I'll go just to grab one of those. Of course, that doesn't work all the time because the bar still serves food. One dish leads to another, and you know how that goes. Everything on the menu is amazing and, for a couple extra dollars, you can add one extra to each tapa. Sometimes I do this because there's two of us and we don't like splitting that third one on the plate, and sometimes I do this because there's four of us; so three just isn't enough. The paella, croquetas, gambas, chorizo, and gaucho are my top picks.
author: Jessika V.

description:
This is a fun place to eat. The food is good quality and presentation is nice. Service was  charming and efficient (Nicolle). It's easy to over order in a tapas restaurant so piece meal ordering is recommended. Having said that its fun to go wild and keep ordering. 

The restaurant is smaller than I thought so dinner is a tough reservation. We opted for lunch and had a great time walking the embarcadero on a sunny Saturday. We even jumped on one of those bicycle rickshaws for a few blocks. 

The wine list has some good Spanish wines and there is a full bar. Salud!
author: alex f.

description:
I had huge expectations for coqueta. To say those expectations were exceeded would be an understatement!  While the setup of the restaurant is a bit odd, the real star here is the insanely good tapas bites. 
I was suprised how small the interior was. There didn't seem to be any tables that were away from the hustle and bustle of this restaurant that is constantly in motion. Almost doubling the square footage is an outdoor atrium area with communal tables, small bar tables and the bar. While it felt like we were in a perpetually busy SF bar, a few cocktails got us focused on the menu...
To start was the lamb/pork meatballs, branzino and the grilled mushrooms. The meatballs were crazy good. They had a sweet finish on the top that made these truly unique. I have never had branzino before but this fish was cooked perfectly. It seemed to lack a little seasoning but tasted fantastic nonetheless. I didn't know that so much flavor could be extracted from cooked mushrooms. I wasn't super excited for this course but it ended up being one of the best dishes of the night. Some awesome flavors going on there. 
After a couple more of their famous gin and tonics it was off to the cheese selection and the croquettes. The croquettes were a perfectly crispy mouthful of pot pie heaven. Finally the cheese was just eh. Nothing super unique. There was a manchego and a blue cheese. Probably the only dish I coulda done without. 
I somehow didn't have room for the churro that we were food porning all dinner but that just gives me a reason to go back soon.  The setup seemed a little clunky but as long as ur not looking for an ultra quiet date spot, coqueta hit all the points for a fantastic taste of some Spanish tapas.
author: Mark N.

description:
I had high hopes for here and must admit disappointment. We didn't have reservations for a Tuesday night but luckily quickly got an outside table (bar and outside seating are first-come, first-served). 

The cocktail menu is impressive on account of its extensive and creative combinations. I ordered the "Dirty by the Sea" martini, and the server immediately remarked, 'you know, it's very briny." I should have heeded his warning, as the drink, while beautiful, was essentially like drinking seawater. Is this drink intended to be enjoyed, or even consumed (I literally imagined a scorecard in back where they track who actually orders/drinks this drink). I ended up finishing it for the sake of my own pride, not in the least bit to complement any of our food (what goes with seaweed juice anyway?). My sister tried "In the Haight," which had far too many strong, complex flavors going on to truly appreciate it. Thumbs down on the drinks. I couldn't help but think they skipped the focus group part of testing out their cocktail menu. In retrospect, it's not a good sign if the staff is warning you against ordering something.

The food came out quickly and was presented nicely. They were out of uni, so we couldn't try the lardo/uni open-face sandwich. The chicken croquets and "fantasia de fideua" were nice and flavorful. The smoked salmon open-face sandwich was tasty, but my sister pointed it out it was much like eating a fancy bagel (the montaditos are curiously served atop what are akin to mini-bagels). Anchovy skewers, pimientos de pardon and the trio of grilled sausages were just ok. Sideways thumbs on the food.

The service - ugh - was on the brusque side. If it was possible for a server to smirk simultaneously at you and your order, that happens here.

I was expecting robust (perhaps even unique) flavors and tempting bites that left me wanting more. I was underwhelmed. They say "coqueta"means "flirt" in Spanish; needless to say, I won't be pursuing this relationship.
author: Janet W.

description:
Crazy busy afternoon in the City.  Nice weather & tons of cool events.  Came to Coqueta cause there's actually places to park around the Embarcadero.

Service is friendly and great overall.  The food and bar menu is unique but a hit or miss.

The order:

Liminada - refreshing & surprising with rosemary sprig & blueberries. Hit.

Hard apple cider Tilted Shed - awesome pairing with the food. Hit.

$40 paella! - totally not worth it.  Salty, burnt, and dry rice with overcooked sausage and clams.  The peppers served on the side & 4 prawns on the dish were good.  $40?!?!

Patatas bravas - crispy potato balls served with a dollop of aioli and a nice sauce.  Hit. 

The whole monterey Calamari was the best tapas dish we ordered.  It's served whole and seasoned with something that makes your taste buds want more.  Big hit.

Duck meatballs - soft tender juicy served medium.  Pretty good.

Smoked salmon open faced sandwhich - smoked salmon served with queso fresco and a touch of truffle honey on a crunchy toasted piece of bread, x2 mini bagel sized bites; twas was ok.

Churro fantasy - best dessert ever!  I wish it came with a dozen little churros.

The paella was unfortunately one big miss, big enough to make me NOT want to go back. Despite the other good dishes & drinks we had, I left feeling unsatisfied and that's  pretty disappointing after paying a $$$ bill.  If it wasn't for the $40!? paella this rating would have been a decent 4 stars.  

When it comes down to Chiarello's restaurants, I would rather go to Bottega in Napa.  That restaurant is 5 stars and never disappoints.
author: Edward A.

description:
Had an excellent birthday celebration in March 
Service ambiance and wine selection all excellent once we got dialed in.
author: John M.

description:
Let me preface this by saying:

MARCO IS AWESOME. He is the only reason I am giving this place an extra star. That and the food and drinks are actually delicious.

The biggest problem with this place is the service. This review is specifically for the evening service on Saturday, Oct 4.

We opted for outdoor seating. The service out there is horrendous. It took us forever to even get someone's attention to take our order. I actually had to go inside and ask someone if anyone was taking care of the outdoor area (after which I was told 'someone would be there soon'). 

Marco ended up taking care of us. He wasn't even a server or supposed to be out there, but he was helping out because it was so busy. He ended up taking our order, serving us, and handling our bill for the entire night. He was SO nice and apologetic and provided some really great service -- thank you Marco! It's awesome when people step up and do more than what's asked to help a team get the job done.

Unfortunately, the rest of the team didn't have the same mindset. There was a tall waiter with a ponytail/bun who was extremely unhelpful. The host that night was also really unhelpful -- we went to him to try to settle our bill since no one was coming to take it. All he said was "Uh, I think you should do that through your waiter." Umm... well, we didn't actually HAVE a waiter, and if someone comes to you and says that, that probably means that something is wrong with the service, and you should try to help us.

Oh, and another thing -- there were a few other servers who kept serving us the wrong dishes -- which was not a problem at all, we just had to tell them it wasn't for us. They were clearly exasperated with something and weren't happy with the service that night either. One actually rolled his eyes and sighed heavily when we told him the dish wasn't ours. 

Whoever is the manager of this place needs to get this act together. Staff better, train better, do something. It's such a shame because the actual food and drinks were great, as was the ambiance. Too bad the restaurant is just poorly managed.

In case you're curious, food we ate:

Sunny-side huevos - awesome
Pulpo - good
Uni open face sandwich - awesome
Croquetas - awesome
Arroz cremosa - meh, extremely under-seasoned
Albondigas - super awesome
author: Rhea K.

description:
Food- most dishes taste mediocre. Tiny portions come at high price. 
Ordered; 

-"El Plat Cap" Chef's selection of cured meats $26
Served with picos and pan de cristal con tomate confitura-Not worth the price.  
Three very thin slices of average prosciutto,  two large slices of salumi cut into strips- unpleasant fatty aftertaste and several dime size slices of average chorizo. 

-Albóndigas a la Feria duck and pork meatballs with
tart cherry-tempranillo salsa and crispy shallot $14
You get 3 pieces- Ordered an extra meatball which came at $4.50- Very delicious.

-Gambas Negras Olive oil poached head-on gulf prawns
with black garlic and chili sauce $14
4 gulf prawns served with two toasted slices of bread-Mediocre

Open face sandwiches. You get two half's of mini bagel.
-Salmón Ahumado Smoked salmon, queso fresco
and truffle honey $8-Delicious 
-Mar y montaña, "sea and mountain" Ibérico lardo gently
melted over sea urchinwith lomo Ibérico $14 -Pretty tasteless

-Setas al ajillo Wild and cultivated mushrooms with
garlic, chilli and sherry $10-Mediocre

-Pluma Acorn fed, Spanish Ibérico de bellota
pork shoulder loin with honey-chili glaze $38- Lacked flavor, was way too chewy and under cooked. Small portion size for the money. - Big disappointment.

-Lubina a la Plancha wood grilled (semi-boneless) Branzino
with manzanilla olive and preserved meyer lemon
salsa $32
Semi boneless-had plenty of bones-Mediocre

During course of our meal asked for extra bread several times(3). Each time, two thin baguette size slices were brought. Each slice came at $1 X 6. WOW!!!

Drinks- nice blend of flavors and presentation but no alcohol content.  More on a juice side than an alcoholic beverage, at $13 you decide.
Service- Not very attentive. Some tables get more attention then other.  
Pintxos Bite-size Skewers. Supposedly offered at table side. Not ones reached are table.
Ambiance- Small place, almost cramped sitting. On the noisy side.

Overall you pay for location not food.
Had better tapas at other places in the city.
author: Alexander L.

description: Hands down one of the best restaurants I've ever been to. So glad I came here during my trip to San Fran. The drinks that Miguel and Emilio made were EXCELLENT. I've never seen so much thought and love being put into bartending. Food was excellent as well. If I ever come back, definitely stopping by again.
author: Katherine M.

description:
Came for lunch with a coworker and the earliest reservation I could get was at 1pm. This was my first visit so I had no idea if a reservation is needed, so I made one just in case. 

We decided to split a bunch of tapas. Chicken & English Pea Croquetas, Wood-Grilled Octopus w/ Fingerling Potatoes, Tattas Bravas, Sunny Side up eggs with shrimp, crispy potato, and chorizo dressing, Mar y montana (sea urchin and jamon on bread). Each dish is small (probably around 3-4 bites per person split between two...for us at least). Out of these dished, I would definitely order the sunny side up egg and the octopus again. These two are the memorable dishes for me and I would come back for those. 

We also ended up getting the flan and churros for dessert after. The flan was rich and creamy and the churros were great with a dark chocolate dipping sauce. All this, plus a mojito and 250 ml of wine came out to just over $100. Expensive? Absolutely.  Would I come back? Probably, but only once in a while since my wallet can't afford a $100 lunch frequently.
author: Janny N.

description: Ambience was awesome. The restaurant is right by the water, and the bar is a great waiting area for patrons. My girlfriends and I ordered the octopus, patatas bravas, sunny-side up huevo, a carrot salad, duck and pork albondigas, smoked salmon and the branzino. Everything was beautifully plated and the service was great. I'd say my favorite dishes were the duck and pork albondigas, smoked salmon and branzino. For dessert we had the churro fantasia and manchego cheesecake bites - both really good!
author: Tuanh D.

description: Great tapas selections by the Bay. We were 4 and had the opportunity to sample many different choices. We started with the big cured meats and cheese tapa El Gran Plat Cap. Easily enough for 4 to share. The most memorable for me were the Albondigas a la Feria Grilled.,, duck and pork meatballs. Wow! As were the Jamón Serrano Manchego, and apricot-sherry conserva. An extensive wine list most notably were the alberinos and Tempranillos. Wonderful service by a delightful lady from Puerto Rico and always keeping a watchful eye was Jessica, the Assistant GM. I'm a big tapas fan and like to explore me use like this one. I will be back, and bring a group, so we can explore even further! Outdoor seating durning the warmer days of summer. Thanks again for a memorable evening.
author: John H.

description:
Located about 1/4 mile from the Ferry Building on the Embarcadero.  The four of us had a wonderful dining experience.   Great tapas and classic paella.  We shared everything. Some tapas only came three in a plate but the kitchen can add a fourth item to the plate if you so desire.  Yes, it's a nominal item charge.  We asked for bread.  Charged for it.  

Attentive service.   Frequent change of plates and flatware.  Food paced nicely.  

Minor con - my mojito.  Served in a champagne glass.  Mint tasting but no actual mint leaves.  Foamy top like a pisco sour.  

We completed our meal with coffee and dessert.  I had an espresso con leche with the apricot tartaleta. It was very good.  Rectangular shaped. The espresso was so strong that I had difficulty sleeping that night.

$72 p/p inc tax & tip.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I wasn't very impressed with neither the menu nor the wine options.

I had the "Pulpo a la Parilla" which was recommended as being on of the most popular dishes on the menu. It was just okay. One piece of grilled octopus for $14; nothing extravagant or tasteful about it. On the contrary, very small portion with a big price tag. I also had "Ensalada de Achicoria" grilled chicory greens, poached pear, serrano ham vinaigrette; fresh and tasty. My last and favorite dish was the "Trio de Salchichas". Grilled sausages glazed with isastegi cider, apple and mojo verde. Very, very good if you are into sausages and blood sausage to be more specific. I had a red sangria with my meal and it fell short of spectacular. The wine selection was very poor containing only three rioja spanish wines to select from.
In summary, the food wasn't bad at all; it was just okay. The service was attentive and cordial. If you are looking for a pricey option with an amazing view and superv decor then this is the place for you.
author: Moy V.

description:
My 85 year old Auntie loved it here last night!
The host greeted us nicely,  hostess that took us to the table was friendly. Waiter was kind to explain all the menu to the 7 of us.
Everything was beautiful and yummy. We didn't know how the skewers worked, that you pay for what you eat, we ate the whole tray!! $125 worth of skewers, it was Ok, they were a great start to our dinner and beautiful too.
Octopus was delicious everyone enjoyed this, meat balls, chips, brussel sprouts, mushrooms, salmon sandwich all very tasty! Dinner Ribeye beautiful, Branzino light fluffy crispy and Paella pan was eaten clean. 
Deserts I am not sure we would order again.
I would go back. I appreciate the host, hostess and wait staff being kind to us.
author: Sharon M.

description: Had cocktails outdoors on a Sunday afternoon. They must have been understaffed because service was just awful. Cocktail and wine menu was lovely but we didn't get to drink as much as we wanted because it never came.
author: Cam H.

description:
Okay so I'm not a big tapas fan, I usually order too many things only really like 50% of them and leave still hungry but not here.  It was a packed Sunday night, so we grabbed a seat at the bar.  This was blind luck and GREAT luck it was, because behind the bar was Miguel and his twin Milo. 
These two brothers kept us entertained, eating and drinking for the next 1.5 hours. The filthy dirty martini I ordered hit the spot and the tapas are clean and simple in taste and full of great flavor, but honestly I'll keep going back for the bar tending brothers! Their service was WITHOUT reproach, and i have high expectations since I work in the industry. The knowledge of both the food and drinks was right on, and I even got a small lesson in Gin that I thought I'd never want. 
Great night and I highly recommend this place to everyone.
author: Stephen F.

description:
Been here a couple of times--once for drinks and another for lunch. 

We ordered 5 tapas dishes to share for lunch --the highlight was eggs sunny side up with an explosion of flavors. The octopus is tender and the lamb meatballs were just okay .

The mocktails were delicious for lunch and for drinks they offer a wine list. Both times I was here the service was great! 

A little spendy but worth it.
author: Mimi T.

description: Love tapas and love the modern flare Michael Chiarello adds to his food. Everything was delish  but i did have my favorites. The chickpea and chicken croquettes were so creamy, it reminded me of chicken pot pie filling breaded and fried! The pork shoulder was delish as well. There was a sweet honey chili glaze that i practically drank up. Ambiance was super cute and the drinks were like none other! Great times!
author: Pauline T.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night to grab a bite before Exploratorium. The dining room was pretty empty but the bar outside was filling up. The bar is so nice with natural lighting and a beautiful view behind the shelfs of liquors. The wait staffs were super kind and quick to everything. 

I ordered the infamous Gin Tonic, which was super refreshing. It left a pretty great impression on me. There was a pine leaf, juniper berries, edible flower petals and grapefruit slice in there--visually and fragrantly appealing. 

I also had few of the tapas, and all of them tasted delicious! My favorite had to be the duck meatballs, and another one with grilled prawns and black garlic sauce. The duck meat ball was cooked medium rare thus super juicy and flavorful. The prawns were huge and the sauce was finger-licking good.

As I was walking to the bathroom, I saw Chef Chiarello walked pass me. AHHH! But when I came out of the bathroom, he was already back in the kitchen with his staffs. He's so handsome in person! So keep an eye for him! Anyhow, this is going to become one of my favorite restaurants in the city.
author: Mandy C.

description:
We stopped by after watching the fireworks along the Embarcadero and was happy to learn they were still seating at 10:30pm in the main dining room. Excited to be able to get in and try the new restaurant as it was booked solid for weeks going forward. Good ambiance -- love the decor. It was still buzzing with diners and revelers at the bar attached outdoors.  Enjoyed our late night tapa tasting, however, felt everything was overprice for what you get:

- uni/iberico ham combo open sandwich -- sandwich is a misnomer. It's pretty much an amuse bouche of 2 bite sized nibbles.  Flavor was great and uni was very fresh. My favorite dish of the night.
- Crispy shrimp was too oily, consisted mostly of dough and was hard pressed to find shrimp in the oily mess. Prefer the shrimp cake at Delica in the Ferry Building
- Woodfired grill octopus -- really tender and enjoyed the dish. However, for $12, we only had 8 tiny pieces that were roughly half the size of my thumb. =( Other posts had much larger portions. Wondering if they were just running out of ingredients at the end of the night.
- Greens with raisins and pine nuts - one of my favorites of the night. Great balance of flavors of sweet and salty and tanginess.
- Grilled pork ($23) with chimichurri sauce - Waaaaaay overpriced. One portion was tough and the other was better prepared but really, where is the rest of my food?
- Roasted limonada - yummy.

Glad we didn't wait weeks to try this. Checked off the list and moving on.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I was craving tapas and a good drink. Was not disappointed. 
We were seated at the bar, right in front of the kitchen. Some people don't like to seat at the bar, but for us, it's being in the middle of the action. We love it.
Prettiest gin and tonic I ever had, with a pine branch and a grapefruit slice along with flowers and a couple berries. Very tasty and refreshing. The "lung" shaped  ice cube was a nice touch. 
Everything we ordered was delicious, from the creamy goat cheese to the bites of chorizo and the deviled eggs and many more... And to finish we had the churros (heaven) and the cheesecake bite. 
Our waitress was very nice, checking on us multiple times, filling our glasses of water regulary. 
I will definitively come back!!
author: Lanéa P.

description:
Oh Coqueta. If only you weren't so small and exclusive for I would dine at you far more frequently. The few times I have dined at you, have been deliciously impeccable. From the cheesy croquetas, to sassy cocktails, to the bountiful paella, you are not only delicious, but edgy and exciting in your spunky adaptation of Spanish cuisine for San Francisco.

Your interior is gorgeous and trendy, making your diners feel a lot cooler than they actually are. (Thanks for the self esteem boost.) Service is a little on the slow side, but worth it for the great eats and drinks.

Astonishingly, you can often find street parking out front on the Embarcadero or just across the street in the big lot. Nothing better than saving the $25 you would have spent on Uber and using it towards an extra dessert :)

All in all, highly recommend Coqueta for a fun date night or special dinner. You can't go wrong here.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Great Spanish / Basque tapas experience in Embarcadero. Rustic, modern setting with one area characterized by typical Spanish bar loud socialization and one area, homely and casual. Michael Chiarello's formula (via Bottega) worked once, and his audacity was exemplified again, innovation shrouding every dish. Like SV's tech scene in Peninsula, chefs, too, must readily wear many hats to keep up with the staggering culinary challenges.  I loved the razor clams, grilled octopus, and paella above all for its sharp flavors and presentation.

El gran plat cap: Great selection of charcuterie.

Sunny side-up egg: Shrimp, crispy potato, and chorizo dressing. Great combination of flavors.

Grilled razor clams: Counterpoint grilled wild ramps and meyer lemon. Grilled taste excellent. Best dish here.

Wood-grilled octopus: Great grilled taste and texture. Tender.

Paella: Perfectly infused with flavors of seafood and Iberico ham. Love this dish.

Gaucho: Overpriced slab of meat.

Jamon pintxo: Skewers of manchego cheese and Iberico ham, enrobed with apricot jam. Beautifully done.

Chocolate souffle: Great flavor. Nice and soft just like the one at Alexander's Steakhouse, but much smaller.

Manchego cheese pops: Way small, but really tasted of manchego cheese. Accompanied by airy, carmel popcorns.

Pan con chocolate: Olive oil sits atop a chocolate brownie. Interesting contrast. Better than the average chocolava cake with vanilla ice cream.

French press coffee: Nice Four Barrel coffee.

The best meals in SF are always super casual, not formal and stuffy (sorry Gary Danko and Boulevard). Dishes were mostly hit or miss, with most being largely a hit.
author: Jay C.

description:
Would have loved to have eaten here last night, but that didn't happen. I did not have a reservation and I expected to wait for a lengthy period. The gentleman that eventually greeted me never asked how many were in my party, or if I was there for drinks or food. He did tell me to sit in the corner of the bar tent and never offered a wait time for a table or even asked if I wanted one. I was, however, told that there was full service in the corner to which I was directed. No, sir, there was not. After being ignored by the staff, I was boxed in by other people, leaving me no hope of getting service. I left completely unseen, even though I tried to get the attention of the man that told me to sit in the corner.

You know what people want? They want to be acknowledged as human and valid. That does a lot to make a good service experience.

I've dined here before. I've enjoyed it. I was also part of a group of restaurant managers, so we were actually taken care of. I'm still a restaurant manager, but this time I walked in without the group. Extremely poor. I don't think I will go back, even though I know people that are involved in that restaurant, and Bottega. I shouldn't have to call the people I know just to get service.
author: Catherine R.

description:
Absolutely a great experience. Upon entering the resturant we were met by a lovely host and the easier was good.

Food: It was great. The apps where much more memorable than the main dish. But the main dishes where good.

Service was good but the waiter could have been a little more attentive.
author: Teddy O.

description: I generally am not a fan of Tapas, however this restaurant has made me reconsider. The food was fantastic, the variety of options great, and the mixed drinks some of the best I've had. Add this to your bucket list.  Excellent!
author: Jeff R.

description:
Loved the octopus and tempernillo and flan. 
The cutlery and glassware were very Spanish. 
Only bad news is the parking situation. AVOID Broadway and Embarcadero its $25
Service was ok
author: Lisa M.

description:
I visited last wednesday for a fantastic lunch with my marketing team!
We had a customized preset menu for a table of 16 at $55/person. 

Cold Tapas:
1) Acietunas  Y Almenores - Toasted fennel and bayleaf manzanilla
2) Olives & Marcona Almonds
3) Tortilla De Espinacas - Spinach tortilla with piquillo pepper puree and herb salad.
4) Ensalada Kale - Roasted squash, picked apricot and warm carbanzo dressing.

Hot Tapas:
1) Patatas Bravas - Freshly dug, lightly smoked, crispy new potatoes w/Bravas Salsa & Garlic Aioli
2) Brussles - Sherry Vinegar and crispy jamon serrano
3) Gambas Al Negro - Olive oil pached head-on gulf prawns, w/ black garlic and chili
4) Albondicas A La Feria - Grilled duck & pork meatballs w/ tart cherry and tempanillo salsa and crispy shallots

Larger/Family Style:
1) Paella - Classic made w/ bomb rice, jamon serrano shellfish broth, shrimp, clams, chorizo, green cauliflower, and lemon aioli.
2) Verduras a la Catalana - Vineyard greens catalan style, caper-raisin puree with raisins, pine nuts, and garlic.

Dessert:
1) Machego cheesecake with caramel popcorn
2) Churro "Fantasia" crispy spanish doughnut with drinking chocolate and mixed berry powder.

The food and service was impeccable. I enjoyed everything and so did my team!I don't think there was one plate that I did not like. Each dish was unique and different from the other. My favorite was probably the paella, patatas bravas, kale, and Gambas al La Feria. (haha, I guess that's most of it huh?) I love the crispiness of the potatoes and the kale dish. The head-on shrimp was extremely fresh and well cooked. The kale was nice and crispy, the apricots/squash gave the dish extra dimensional and flavor.

4.5 STARS
author: Karen L.

description:
This review is for a light lunch and drinks only.

Had a few dishes and found some of them delicious: namely the smoked salmon with truffle honey bruschetta and duck and pork meatballs.  These were delicious!  The "tattas" bravas were just ok. Potatoes were cooked fine but lacked flavor--the sauces lacked flavor too.  Potatoes should have been a little crispier as well.

Their mixologist knew what he was doing, i enjoyed the cocktails.

I left out service since, between lunch and dinner service, seating was fairly informal.  However, the servers had major attitude.  If I was running this restaurant, I would fire them and promote the bus boy/runner that provided me with a linen napkin--a request I made to two different servers four times.
author: Natalia K.

description: I went here recently with a friend for appetizers and drinks.  We had a few plates which I found to be just OK.  The ambiance and view is beautiful.  I ordered the Sutter Smash twice because I loved it so much!  I would go back for cocktails but may have dinner elsewhere.
author: Catherine H.

description: So many things to try if you can understand what you are actually ordering!  The wait staff was helpful in explaining each dish and recommending favorite dishes ordered by customers. The sunny side up egg dish was absolutely delicious!  And the gin and tonic drink complete with juniper berries, pine leaf, grapefruit slice and a colorful flower was refreshing. And I don't even drink gin!  Wonderful little spot and you have to come back again and again to taste most of the menu. Three drinks, 3 tapas and a family plate totaled about $125.00 so come ready to spend a little money.
author: Faith B.

description:
Getting a reservation on Open Table can be tricky. I tried all summer and had to settle on a Monday at 5:30pm, which was the last table. Friends of mine say to just show up and ask how long the wait is and then wait a moment at the bar. The restaurant reserves some tables for walk ups. Well, we were on a date night with a sitter watching our kids at home so we didn't have that kind of time! We need certainty. 

Perfect ambiance. Great location by the Pier. 

We started off with the Barca Gin Tonic - very good and refreshing. Highly recommend. Then I had the Galleon which was a little more citrusy but refreshing. My least favorite was the Tariff a little too intense for me. 

El Plat Cap de Queso which are Chef's selection of cheeses was outstanding and served with olive oil tortas and marcona almonds (yum)

Gazpacho Gelatina - this was good as I had never had a dish like this. Sweet tomatoes with gelee of gazpacho consome. 

Patatas Bravas - crisy new potatoes in a salsa and garlic alioli.  This was ok. My husband said this was his least favorite. I guess he doesn't jump for joy for potatoes.

Croquetas de Pollo - my favorite dish. So crunchy on the outside and creamy inside. Delightful!

Pimientos de Padron- roasted peppers with Jamon Serrano. I really like this dish. Not spicy. 

Gambas al Negros - gulf prawns (head on) with black garlic and chili sauce. This was soo yummy. They serve with three little toasts.

Sunny side-up Huevo - basically an sunny side up egg, shrimp, and string potatoes which they mix table side. This was a little salty for me but my husband liked it. 

Our evening ended with Churro Fantasia which was a crispy Spanish donut (there are four bite size) with hot chocolate to dip and berry powder. The Manchego cheesecake was my favorite. Small and bite size and served with caramel popcorn. I love anything caramel popcorn. 

Fabulous dinner. Highly recommend.
author: Lauren W.

description:
The food was great. The price was decent. It lost two stars from me for the following reasons:

We made a reservation at 7pm, and didn't got to sit down til 7:30pm. Understand that it's a popular restaurant, but not good enough for 5 stars on Yelp. 

We wanted to order the uni burger, but it was sold out. Really? The most popular item on the menu was sold out by 7:30pm on a Saturday night? You need to improve your inventory management! 

Last but not least, our waiter spent the entire night socializing and sharing his personal stories with the table sitting right next to us. The other table was only a foot away, and we heard everyone of course. TMI! He paid so much attention to the other table that he forgot to check on us...

All in all, I liked the food we ordered, and would recommend it to people who like Tapas. However, my personal experience was a bit disappointing.
author: Cissy M.

description:
I wanted to try Coqueta for the longest time since I have heard wonderful things about the food. I treated my boyfriend out here recently, using our anniversary as an excuse. 

Reservations was relatively easy as I booked only a month in advance. Parking is easy now that on Sunday's, meters are free. 

We were seated at an awkward table - we kept falling off our table but that might have been due to our own clumsiness. ;)

We ordered the huevo with shrimp, pork & duck meatballs, and the gaucho steak. The huevo was delicious. The pork & duck meatballs were very underwhelming and I regretted the order. 

The steak was very, very good! They brought out the slab of rib eye and asked if we wanted to have it cut. We did request to have it sliced. While it took a long time to bring it back sliced, it was done excellently and topped with cilantro. 

I was very touched that at the end of our meal, the staff was nice enough to give us complimentary dessert: cheesecake bites with handwritten "congratulations" on chocolate. 

Overall, I felt the food was lacking for the menu prices. While some of the food we tried was good (the steak), I think there are better places to eat in SF for equal or less than what we paid.
author: Mina K.

description: In terms of just drinks, it's pretty goddam great.  I knocked off a star cause ho boy it is tough on the wallet. I think we had 4 drinks and it ran us around 50+ bucks. They don't have any vegetarian items, I believe. Service was prompt and the crowd was interesting- a mix of well-dressed people attending various... things? nearby and some tourists. The drinks were a-mah-zing though, and had very interesting combinations, etc. Would for sure go again!
author: Samir K.

description:
We've been meaning to try this place since it first opened, but reservations were hard to get for an 8pm seating. We opted to do a 10:15 reservation since we were going to get a few drinks at a new bar afterwards. 

We had the option for a table or at the chef's bar and since Michael Chiarello was in the kitchen, it was a no brainer to opt for the bar! He greeted us as we sat and chatted with him for a few min. Great guy, humble and easy to talk to. The place was buzzing and crowded as it should be! 

Service was great and impeccable. Drinks were refreshing and their food was pretty good. I can't say it was amazing but it was above average. I do want to come back with a larger crowd so that we can order some of the family style dishes, but this is what we had ordered: 

Pintxos
Baby Beets cana de cabra, citrus, and spring onion      
Quails Egg "Diablo" pickled mustard seed, and Serrano

Montaditos
Mary Montaña, Sea And Mountain ibérico lardo gently melted over sea urchin with jamon ibérico de bellota

Tapas Calientes
Whole Monterey Calamari On The Plancha with onion jam and squid ink aioli
Wood-Grilled Octopus with fingerling potatoes, pimentón, and olive oil 
Grilled Duck Albóndigas meatballs with dried cherry and tempranillo 
Grilled Ibérico Secreto spanish butchers' secret cut of pork, with "tximi-txurri" and watercress
Sunny Side-Up Egg with shrimp, crispy potato, and chorizo dressing

By far our favorites were the Uni, Calamari, secret cut of pork and the egg with shrimp and chorizo. The rest of the dishes were good, but can be forgotten. I don't consider Coqueta as traditional Spanish tapas, however I do appreciate the use of ingredients in exploring his style of Spanish food.  I would call it New Spanish perhaps?
author: Andrew S.

description:
i run by coqueta every morning, so i figured i should write a review for it. 

came here a while back and was veryyy excited to try this place since im a big Bottega fan, and was excited to have the same caliber of food without having to try an hour to yountville. sadly to say, i was a bit disappointed!

we were seated at the bar on a saturday evening. the noise level is pretttyy manageable considering how popular and sceney of a restaurant it is. we each tried two cocktails, and quite a few of the small tapas. the uni bite was probably the most memorable, but the uni to bread ratio is less than optimal. SIGH!

hefty price tag for what you're served. but given the lack of good dining options in SOMA and on embarcadero, i will be back to try more things. oh, the outside area is pretty sweet - good for fleet week!
author: Christina L.

description: Still the best resturant in the city, love Coqueta, awesome atmosphere and great service! All of that wrapped into an awesome enviornment with amazing food - Need to try the Octopus, Gin and Tonics, meatballs and more!
author: Rob P.

description: This place thrives on customer service and does it so well! The wait staff is constantly making rounds to fill up drinks, clean the table and just to see how you're doing. The ambiance is nice and The food was delicious! My favorite was the cheese platter and the bikini! It's a must try. I wanted to take pics of all of the food I tried but it was so good that I simply forgot to take pics. It gets busy so make reservations.
author: Holly D.

description:
Wow, what a great place!  I'm on a business trip and went there without a reservation to grab a bite at the "bar" by the kitchen.  The waitress was so nice and accommodating, I rarely have been treated so well when seated as a single patron in a restaurant.  

The food was delicious and creative while not trying too hard to be fancy (see Bellota which was over the top ridiculous - how many ingredients can fit in one dish?).  Back to Coqueta - simple, fresh ingredients done just right.  The grilled octopus was the best I've ever had.  Could use a little more flavor from the accompanying infused olive oil, but the tender meat was good enough to satisfy without anything else added.  The chicken croquetas were crispy on the outside, gooey in the middle - like a bite of fried chicken pot pie, but better.

The deviled eggs were good, although the yolk mixture seemed a bit thick and heavy, maybe a skip on this one next time.  At the end of the meal, a yummy bite of manchego cheesecake was perfect combination of sweet, salty and richness.  I can't wait to go back.

Why the missing star?  Well, there were hordes of flies in the restaurant.  I'm talking a swarm right in the middle of the seating area which was a real turn-off.  Get rid of those flies and you have a 5 star restaurant.
author: M. J.

description:
The food here is AMA-A-ZING.  My only regret is that I couldn't try more dishes. I plan to return to try the paella and grilled steak. But here was my dinner:

Chicken Croquettes - they look like like tater tots: crispy and delicious but way better. 3 croquettes come in each order.

Roasted Padron Peppers with Jamon Serrano - this is mainly a pepper dish, with just a few slivers of jamon sprinkled on top. It was one of my favorites. Simple and slightly lemony.

Gulf Prawns with black garlic and chili sauce - MUST ORDER if you're a shrimp freak like me. The head-on prawns were soft and super flavorful because of the sauce, which you can dip the accompanying 3 slices of toasted bread into. 3 prawns come in each order. 

Sunny Side up Huevo w/ Shrimp - by far the most unusual dish but really delicious. A small platter of shrimp, sunny side up fried egg, and slivers of shoe string potatoes (?) arrives at your table. The waitress then promptly mixes it all together so that the egg yolk blends into the dish, like a casserole. Really yummy. 

Wood grilled octopus w/ fingerling potatoes - this was good but not as spectacular as the others. 

Bikini - Best way to describe this: think small round warm flatbread, with roasted eggplant, cheese, and preserved fruit in the middle, then wrapped up like a taco.  It's a fun little dish that tastes surprisingly rich and decadent. 2 'tacos' come in each order. 

Arroz Cremoso de Verano - I think this is the spanish version of risotto. It's creamy and has chopped squash on top, with a sprinkle of some green herbs on top. Very good. 

And last but not least, churros for dessert. Light and crispy, it comes with a small side of warm chocolate sauce for dipping. 

I left Coqueta extremely satisfied. This is what the San Francisco dining experience is all about.
author: Jules L.

description: Had The Best lunch today at Coqueta.! Sat at the bar and Ordered Away. Croquettas were delicious, the pulpo was good, had 4 pintxos 1 with quail egg, tortilla de espinaca, my favorite was The Jamon Serrano w manchego and apricot. All 4 good tho. The Duck albondigas had good flavor. I had 2 Gin drinks both refreshing. Also had the Valdeon cheese w membrillo and ended with a complimentary manchego cheesecake with caramel popcorn. So glad we got to try this. Service was Great by Nicole and Very Attentive Runners and Staff.!
author: Steve R.

description: I loved the location, offering great scenic views of the ocean; the service was attentive and friendly; food was brought quickly and plated nicely. My favorite was the duck/pork meatballs--juicy, tender, flavorful! Must try the Beso de Barca crafted cocktail, if you like spice! Will visit again, for sure!
author: Leti M.

description:
After dining here with a party of 10, we tried a sizable amount of the menu. 
Everything was very tasty and enjoyable. I found that coqueta is more enjoyable and edgy sister of Michael Chiarello's italian restaurant, bottega, in Yountville. The dinner environment is more lively, yet warm and relaxing, plus the nearby pier walkway is great when waiting for a table. 

We had about 10-15 different shared tapas plates, all delicious 
Highlights for the night
the different sangrias and cocktails
Paella
Pluma iberico de bellota (steak)
Manchego cheesecake pops w/popcorn
author: Julie B.

description:
My date and I stopped for drinks at the outdoor area before going to the Exploratorium After Dark event. The drinks were super well made, although now they're running with 1/4 of their cocktail menu focused on gin drinks, so for those like me who hate gin, your options are a bit more limited (especially when the waitress tries to upsell you the gin anyways). I got a mojito and it was delicious but half foam (yeah- foam). The wine list is more expensive per glass than any of the cocktails (weird).  
4 stars for the great view and busboy that found my date and I chairs and provided extra menus and water without us asking for anything. Minus 1 for no happy hour and weird menu/pricing structure.
author: Shanna C.

description: The portions are smaller, which makes it super fun if you only go with two people.  You can try 9 or 10 things without getting stuffed ;)
author: Grace C.

description:
Review 175......

Second time eating lunch - first in the covered patio/bar area.  Most recently inside the main restaurant.  Staff is friendly and attentive.  Food was really good - only item I didn't take a picture of was the pork shoulder.  This item was really good but keep in mind the serving is barely for 1 person (if you're hungry).  Suggest ordering additional servings if 4 or more people plan to eat family style.  Of course it will be double the... price ouch!o
author: John C.

description:
What an amazing experience here at Coqueta. Coqueta is a modern styles Resturant that now has a refreshing and tasteful new menu introduced to us by top chef Michael Chiarello. You may know him from many popular tv shows on the food network. Mr. Chiarello delivers to you, with every plate an adventure for you're taste buds. A worth wild experience, one that my wife and I truly enjoyed.

This Restuarant specializes in high-end Spanish cuisine. There servings are styled in the form of Tapas, meaning small plates. This comes in handy because most of the entrées are in bite-size forms which allows the customers to experience and taste more items on the menu. It's refreshing and a welcomed break then the standard style, which is a singular dish with your traditional starter and appetizers.

My first bit of advice is to always make a reservation for this restaurant. Regardless of what day of the week or time it is, this Resturant is consistently packed and always busy. Although my wife and I made our reservation two weeks in advance, we still had a 45 minute wait time to be seated. Normally this would be the formula for disaster that would make anybody frustrated. But with the beautiful views it allowed us to relax and take in the beauty of the pier area. What made it even better was the fact that the host at the time (I wish I got his name) gave us a complimentary glass of champagne on the house. This was his way of apologizing for the long wait. That gesture alone speaks volumes of how they see there clientele. A definite great first impression.

When we finally were seated we were introduced to a young lady name Brooklyn. Her energy and knowledge of the menu was outstanding and one that I definitely tip my hat off to her for. She was professional and very attentive to my wife and I. She even catered to our needs (including photos with chef Michael Chiarello). She constantly made sure to check on us and ask if there was anything we needed. It propelled our experience from a fun dinner date to a great an enjoyable one. Now back to our meal, we enjoyed a 12 course dinner with all the fixings. Choosing from the cold plates menu of: chorizo roasted artichokes with and peppers, to the open faced sandwich menu of: smoke salmon cover with caso fresco and a truffle honey topping. We then ordered from the hot tapas menu. we ordered a couple of my personal favorites which are: the Sunny Side-up Huevo with shrimp, and the crispy potato with chorizo dressing. the grilled duck and pork meatballs with a tart cherry salsa is definite one of my favorite tapas of all time. After all these small dishes we then ordered the extremely popular Paello dish. We were full already but we had to because of its popularity. Poor us!! Haha

It is extremely important to know that this dish serves two to three people, and takes 30 to 40 minutes to prepare. Meaning if you know you're going to get it, make sure you order it early so that way you have enough time to eat it without waiting. The Paello has: culf shrimp, clams, chorizo with broccoli and a few other items that I won't list here. When you combine that with some of the more popular cocktail drinks it really all adds up to a pleasant and fulfilling evening. we certainly left the restaurant stuffed and happy.

Here's another little secret in case you don't want to take BART, taxi or even walk to the restaurant. It's $0.50 and hour for parking after 7 PM. This is a great break from the normal parking costs in San Francisco. Which normally will cost you up to $4.00 dollars for an hours worth of parking in certain areas in the city. To wrap up this review my experience here was amazing and delightful. The only downside I had was the long wait time, despite my reservation. But the way that the staff handled themselves made up for it and then some. The food is remarkable and I will say this has become one of my favorite restaurants to dine at.
author: Donald W.

description: We didn't eat here but the atmosphere and drinks were fabulous! We will be back and we will ask for Marco who does an amazing job and was so pleasant and helpful.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Best Service. Took my dad here for his birthday. Shoutout to our waitress (Arja? Anja? She was Croatian) who was accommodating all night.  I brought in some sparkler candles for my dad and she slyly added them into the dessert no problem. A little fuzzy on the waitress name from the good drinks! Had a Spanish wine and something bubbly too which were on point. Mom had white sangria which she enjoyed.  Hostess Chloe was sweet from the moment I walked in. Bar crew was swift too. Impressed. Management should be über proud of their staff)

Loved the interior of this place too. Thumbs up on ambiance. Perfect spot for a romantic date, girls night out or a family outing too.
author: Monica D.

description:
This was the best meal we had in San Francisco, and one of the best meals I have ever had frankly. The cocktails are AMAZING. My favorites were the Farmers Market Punch (tequila, roasted pumpkin, white chocolate and Mallorca salt) and the margarita made with salt "air". It was superior to anything I've ever had with a salted rim. The salty foam was just perfect.

The gambas al negro (olive oil poached head-on gulf prawns with black garlic and chili) were delicious and the server brought us more bread to sop up the decadent sauce left in the pan. Crispy shrimp and chickpea flour pancake with saffron alioli reminded us of okonomiyaki. Grilled albóndigas (duck and pork meatballs with tart cherry and tempranillo pureé and crisp shallots) were amazing, and I do wish we had just shared the order of 3 between us instead of allowing ourselves to be upsold to an extra one as suggested by the server because they were pretty big and I was getting full. The vineyard greens catalan style with caper-raisin puree with raisins, pine nuts, and garlic was a nice vegetable break among all the meat and yummy fatty goodness.

I'm taking away a star for two reasons. One, the pintxos are an absolute rip-off and I can't believe this restaurant has the cojones to charge $7 for a miserly bite of food on a toothpick. I found the menu listing for it confusing as well. Since it lists "One Of Each Bite-Size Skewer" and then describes three different skewers I thought one order (for $7 mind you) would include one of each skewer. Nope. I don't mind a hefty pricetag on great food when it is warranted, but this just felt like a sucker punch. Second, the shortribs should have been tender and falling off the bone. Instead they were tough and almost inedible. It was the only disappointing dish. 

I can't wait to go back and try everything else on the menu. Just watching the food being delivered to other tables was also a treat.
author: S A.

description:
Darnel is the best! #raise #crushingit #cantgetanybetter #micdrop

Great food, drinks, and service
author: Kyra M.

description:
I went to this restaurant this past weekend for the first time.  We made reservations over a month ago and had the corner round table for our party of four.   It's a crowded and loud restaurant, and the tables were really close to each other, but our corner table was the best.   Our reservation was on Saturday at 5:30 and we were able to find street parking nearby.  Since the meters were only required until 6pm, we only had to pay $1.50 for half an hour on the meter.

Here's what we ordered:
SUNNY SIDE-UP HUEVO:  Very good.  This was my favorite dish of the night.  It was like really thin shoestring potatoes with a few shrimp and a sunny side-up egg on top.  Our waitress came and mixed it all up for us.

CROQUETA DE POLLO:  This comes with 3 pieces, but the waitress recommended that we add one more.  Looked like tater tots, with a crunchy outside and tender inside.   It was very tasty.

PANTATAS BRAVAS:  Not too special.  Tasted just like plain thumb-size potatoes.    The sauce had little taste.

CALAMARES A LA PLANCHA:  Four small squid with a dab of squid ink.  This was just ok, nothing special.

SETAS AL AJILLO:  Wild mushrooms with a hint of chili.  This was pretty good.

ESPARRAGOS TRIGEROS CON ROMESCO:  Not sure what the green was, but it tasted like spinach.  Loved it!  

PAELLA:  We ordered this as soon as we got there because it takes 30-40 minutes to prepare.  This was the last dish that they brought out and it was a good size serving.  The four of us couldn't finish it.  It was average.

LIMONADA:  This was sooo good.  Lemonade with a couple of blueberries inside and a rosemary twig.

The portions are really small.  For four of us, we only got like a couple of bites from each dish, except for the Paella.

For Dessert, we shared the Churros.  There were 4 small pieces served with "drinking chocolate" and berry powder.  We dipped the churros in the chocolate and then dipped it in the powder.  The combination tasted like a cherry filled donut.

The staff were really friendly and did a great job explaining the dishes to us.  They refilled our water constantly.  Our bill was about $50 per person.  It would be worth coming again to try some of the other dishes because they have such a wide variety and each dish is so unique.
author: P G.

description:
The wife and I wandered into cocheta walking around on the piers. We did not want a heavy lunch, something light and tapas sounded excellent. 

The ambiance is decent, the tables are close but not so close that an intimate conversation is not possible. 

I got the vodka based cocktail which was okay - nothing to write home about. 

We got the prawns as a small plate and they were nice. Not fantastic, Nice - esp the taste of the black garlic sauce. 

The highlight was the fish which was grilled to perfection. It was delicious, breaking off into small bits and the seasoning on it was slightly spicy with a hint of lemon.

Cocheta is expensive though - perhaps not by SF standards.
author: Aprameya R.

description:
OMG this place is amazinggggg!

No wonder it's so hard to get a reservation any day of the week. 

- Their famous gin drinks are a must get 
- Uni on top of a mini toasted bagel- really good if your a uni fan
- Pulled pork shoulder meat dish- to die for!!! Must get!
- Fired eggs with shrimp, chorizo, and potatoes- not bad but the other items were so much better
- Deviled eggs- Best deviled eggs I have had, Prospect on Spear st. is the 2nd runner up
- Apple Pie with ice cream- really smooth ice cream and a delicious flakey crust 
- Caramel popcorn with cheesecake- since I'm not a huge cheesecake fan I would say it was just ok, but still good. 

Make reservations 2 weeks out minimum. 4 weeks if it's a weekend at peak hours.
author: Carrie Y.

description:
Seriously thank you Yelp!

Came here because of all the great reviews and it was worth it . I had the red wine sangria (yum!), two of the bite size skewers and they were certainly bite sized but so worth it .

Then I got the crispy brussel sprouts  omg ! They were crispy and spicy but well balanced with the yogurt dipping sauce and pink peppercorns 

If you don't have a reservation you can only sit in the covered patio or outside , but who cares it's worth every penny and bite
author: Jane L.

description: Went in for lunch and had an awesome time. chef Chiarello was in which was an extra treat! (Gave us hugs when we were finishing up). The Barça G&T was so well balanced and delicious! Favorite things we ordered were the deviled eggs, sunny side up egg (chorizo was so good!) and the manchego cheesecake pops with caramel corn. Only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is because our server took a while to get to us in the beginning and then blamed the kitchen about out meatballs taking a while when she clearly forgot to put it in. Otherwise great atmosphere and would definitely go back. Maybe sit in the bar area next time.
author: Samantha K.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy. This place has the best cocktails in town. I tried  the "sun never sets" and some of my friends' got the gin and tonics. The drinks were so delicious I could barely taste the alchy. Don't let the taste fool you thought, I left the restaurant pretty buzzed. ... 

The tapa portions are very small, but good. I loved the calamari and grilled octopus. I would definitely come back and maybe try their dinner!
author: Becky L.

description:
Been here twice and both times, great, love this restaurant!  Great food and great services, especially Bobby, ask for him!  

This restaurant was very accommodating which is rare during one of the busiest nights for restaurants- Valentine's Day.  Traffic was crazy, also couldn't get the ferry back in time...  We had to change the reservations 3 times and they were so nice about it and very understanding! Its hard to find good services now-a-days.., but, they got it down! Can't say I have had anything bad here...  

We will be back San Fran!!!
author: KendraHA B.

description:
Can you put no stars on here. First of all, I had reservations, and still waited an hour. The food was sub-par really!?!  And once seated, I still had to wait 10 mins before the server acknowledged me. I asked for a glass of red wine, the server showed me the wine list and insisted I selected!  Well thanks for the recommendation. 

Oh and by the way, they just dropped the food and never explained it.
author: Amy C.

description:
First time visit for lunch today and the whole experience was flat out awesome!  Being able to share great food and beverage with clients, strategic partners and friends is truly a great way to build and maintain relationships. Specialty spirits are the bomb!
Champions in salute of 5 49rs championships really seals the deal!
author: Natu T.

description: Recently went to Coqueta with the family and basically spent the entire afternoon there.  We love Spanish food and wine and Coqueta did not disappoint in any way.  The port shoulder was amazing and the paella was the best I've had outside of Spain.  We ate and drank a lot so maybe we shouldn't have been surprised by the $600 bill for 4 people.  But we'll definitely be back.
author: Raymond F.

description: I'm not sure how we spent over $100 here as the food was bite sized and I'm still hungry. Food was okay and service was friendly and quick, but it's very over priced.
author: Alex C.

description: Diner here 30 months after our first date and it was as solid as it was then. However this time, we had a 5pm reservation and enjoyed getting there before dusk so we could enjoy the view of the bay and the bridge. We started the chorizo and Manchego cheese bites, which literally are one bite so order two because these aren't for sharing. Then we had the Brussel sprouts which were uniquely spiced, battered and flash fried - delectable! We also had the octopus which came with more potato than octopus but still had great char and flavor. The prawns came with amazing sauce which we dipped the smoky toast in to savor ever last drop. The chicken chicharron croquettes were gooey and steaming - definitely our favorite until...the paella and the duck and pork meatballs.
