I can best describe it as a blockbuster movie that had all the hype (ie. James Beard nominee).  I bought my pricey ticket and sat down to enjoy the flick. 

There was a good plot, a good director in Michael Chiarello and the dishes were presented with a beautiful cinematography.  However, the need to conform to San Francisco fusion left me a bit confused....kind of like Shutter Island or Inception.

The patatas bravas were too abstract and missed the mark on the comfort aspect. The salmon ahumado was one of my favorites offering generous pieces of smoked fish with just enough truffle and honey favorites.  

Try the pintxos too...they are like watching the movie trailers. They are short and sweet and you're bound to like at least one.
author: Shawn P.

description:
I would give it 5 stars because of the food...but there were a couple of things that let us down a bit when my wife and I went there for dinner recently. I'll get down to that in a minute, but first the food. If you like creative and exquisite dishes, this place is for you. Everything we tried was fantastic, was well presented, had good flavor and overall was great. We had several of the tapas including the albondigas, gambas and croquetas. For our entree, we shared the lomo, which was very tender and came with this chili/honey sauce that was amazing. 
We had made a reservation and thought that meant we would get a table, but when we showed up, we got seated at the chef bar. At first we were a little disappointed, but it actually turned out to be pretty cool as we were able to talk to the chef and even got to try a couple smaller tapas for free. 
The two things that let us down a bit were that the second round of drinks we ordered to go with our food didn't arrive until we were done with our meal, and that we missed out on their chocolate cake dessert because the over became unavailable. The waitress did warn us about taking 20 min to make, but she failed to tell us that at some point during the evening, the special oven they use for that was going to be used for making their bread instead, therefore not allowing for any more chocolate cakes. Granted, this may have perhaps not been her fault, but it would be good for the restaurant to keep their staff informed of what's happening, so they can inform the customers. If we would have known that, we could have just placed the order a little earlier and there wouldn't have been a problem.
Overall the place was very good and we would definitely go back...and this time try the chocolate cake. I would recommend making a reservation as it gets pretty crowded for dinner and it's a long wait without a reservation.
author: George M.

description: terrible rat hole that dares to call itself Spanish restaurant. Having been to Spain well over a dozen times, including food heavens like Barcelona and Marbella, Coqueta wasn't even close in terms of taste to what Spanish cuisine tastes like. Patatas bravas missed the mark on everything (smokiness of the sauce, the weird looking potatos). Simple dish like the Gambas was poorly done. How can you mess up a cheese plate??? roasted almonds felt old. Other plates also fell short of expectations. Overall pretty mediocre food!
author: Eric G.

description:
Atmosphere: great
Food: croquettes, patata bravas, albondigos delicious! 
Anchovies, calamari - good, decent
Shrimp pancake - did not finish, tasted like long john silvers from back in the day
Sangria - eh
Clara - refreshing, a-ok
Portions: small
Hostess: not very welcoming
Waitress: depends on who you get

I would return for the three tapas above and to try other drinks.  The paella looked good-but neighboring table said it was too wet.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Some of the food was okay, most of it was ridiculously overpriced and proved to be wildly disappointing. Waitress was extremely pushy, she continued to insist that we HAD to order 2-3 tapas per person and would not leave our table until we did. When we did not order that much she appeared flustered and angry. We're very glad we didn't listen to her because we really didn't even like the tapas we did order. Honestly, I never want to think about how much we wasted on this restaurant ever again.
author: Kim R.

description: Reservations don't mean the same thing for this Resturant verses all the others.  We walked in tonight and gave our name to the hostess. She was very unhappy and would not speak another word to us.  The host showed up and said we have your seats at the bar.  I told the host we had a reservation? He said yes you do and our reservation policy to to seat people with reservations in any available seat and we have the bar available- otherwise wait.  We left and went to stones throw on Hyde and had much better service and meal!!
author: Tom O.

description: Great cocktails, ambiance & location on the Embarcadero are all great but...I am spoiled by having eaten at The Bazaar in LA & Miami Jose Andres has set the bar for contemporary Spanish food. Don't get me wrong the food is very good (Croquettes& Pork Shoulder were def highlights) but the portion for the price didn't match. $250 for two people (we did eat a lot & had 2 drinks Each) is a little steep.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Can you say FUCK YES on yelp?

I literally couldn't stop ordering and eating. I could feel my stomach distending - I started to dry heave - my hands trembled as I reached for 'just one more'... I felt like an addict that needed a fix. I ended up puking 3 times later that evening. (No, I only had one drink and half of it was SF FOG). I puked because I ate so much, because it was so good, so good that I lost all self control. I think I even dreamt of Coqueta as I drifted off into a food coma that night.
author: S. V.

description:
Came here for dinner on a weeknight, and we had a reservation.  If we had to wait, was it worth it?  I'd say "sure."

The food here was great and the drinks were good too, but the prices were a bit on the steep side.

I did try a few tapas that I highly recommend, including the croquettes, and the Pulpo a la Parilla.  The Gaucho" Bistec is also really good, but at $84, once you are buzzed from the drinks, you kind of power through it, thus making it harder to savor and of course, less worth your while.
author: Angela C.

description: Impeccable service. Asja served our table; she makes a difficult job look easy. She made recommendations and was attentive without bring intrusive.  Perfect.
author: John C.

description:
I was really let down by both the service and food at Coqueta. We (my dining partner and I) entered in right after the restaurant had opened and were barely given a glance by the hostess, let alone a hello. She was busy tapping away on her screen and when I approached to ask if we could sit at the bar she briskly told us that the main dining room wasn't opened yet and we could sit at the bar in the entry room if we wanted. We decided to hold off and wait for the main room to open, and in the meantime grabbed a menu to look at (without an offer of one, we had to just grab some from behind the hostess stand).

When the room was opened we were sat right in the middle of the bar in front of the kitchen. Where the front service lacked, the server we mainly had (a few seemed to help around the same areas) made up for 10x over with a great smile and a wonderfully helpful attitude about her.

Unfortunately, the food that followed barely perked us up any more. We both had a couple of pintxos (the spinach tortilla was by far my favorite!), the beet salad, brussels sprouts, and the grilled octopus. The beet salad was the winner of the few dishes we had, but only because the brussels sprouts were so charred you could not taste anything but smoke. The octopus had a few great bites but for the most part had, again, too much char to get anything but smoke flavor from.

I would possibly come back to try a few more small plates before I completely write this place off, but hopefully the next time will bring with it much more welcoming service.
author: Amy S.

description:
Everything was delicious and our server was amazing. We lucked out and got 

Loved:
1. Gambas al Negro (shrimp) - my favorite dish!
2. Monterey Calamari
3. Patatas Bravas
4. Ribeye - the server was super accommodating and gave us a smaller 10oz cut for 2

Just okay:
- wood grilled octopus - too tough & chewy
author: CL S.

description:
TL;DR: This place is freaking legit. So good. Yummy in my tummy.

My boyfriend wanted me to choose a place for a date night. I produced a list, this place included, and gave it to him. He decided here. I tried to get reservations last minute, but the earliest they could offer was 9:30.. So I decided to follow the advice of other yelpers and attempt to arrive between 6:00 and 6:30. We got there around 6:20, and the host was super nice. We're chill, we don't care where we sit as long as we get a place. The host gave us the option to sit at the bar or kitchen side. We're like, "Uhh.. Whatever is easiest for you?" Then the host made sure to ask whatever is easiest for us, so we both said,"Um.. kitchen please?" and immediately he gave us two seats at the kitchen bar and we're ecstatic! We got into a place that was rumored to be hard to get into! Sure, the bare stool has no back support, but whateves'.

So we're chilling with the menu, trying to figure out what to drink and eat. We were greeted by the bar waiter, and given water. He came back for our drink order while deciding on what to eat. In this time period, we figured out what tapas we wanted for the night and gave a full order. BTW go for their popular gin drink. Tastes awesome, looks beautiful, and convince whomever you're going with to get it otherwise they WILL STEAL SIPS FROM YOU (looking at you boyfriend).

El Capo Cheese plate: Huge cheese portions!! Seriously! Fat wedge of blue cheese, fat wedge of goat cheese, and then cubes of monchego(?) However, these kind of spoiled the appetite for the potential great things ahead. Also, we're cheese spoiled from Willi's Wine Bar three cheese selection plate (our old anniversary stop).

Deviled eggs: Meh for me, but I've never liked deviled eggs. So to receive a meh from me is an accomplishment. My boyfriend, who is a deviled egg fiend, loves them. The best he has ever had (sorry mom, you're now second).

Sea and mountain: Our first time trying sea urchin! My goodness! We can get why sea urchin is a hard flavor to describe! So creamy, with all the good, sweet flavors of seafood without it being gross, dingy seafood flavor! Our minds were BLOWN! GET AT LEAST TWO ORDERS OF THEM! THANK ME LATER!

Grilled octopus: Holy crap baskets.. this is the most tender cephalopod I have ever had with a smokey flavor. Like.. first octopus that melted in the mouth. Wat? I'm used to chewy stuff! Octopus can be freakin tender!?

Albondigas: I'm not into rich fatty meats, but oh man.. That was delicious. Fall apart on your plate, further fall apart in your mouth. The tangy sauces totally compliment the fat. GOOD. STUFF.

Dessert Churros: Meh. I prefer the fair churros. The berry powder was neat though. Go for another round of sea and mountain open sandwiches. Or any other savory tapas.
author: Heather H.

description: I was really looking forward to a date night here and made the reservation over a month in advance. When we showed up 30 minutes early for the reservation to have a drink they said they could seat us but I was really disappointed to not be at a table but the bar for dinner. I asked to wait but they said there was no guarantee so we stayed. The first thing we ordered was the gin and tonic (amazing) along with the foie gras special but the next 45 minutes we were never checked on and the server never returned to take our order. The highlights to the food was the sunnyside up egg and cherizo along with the pork shoulder. Not so good was the salmon on a bagel bite and the burnt mushrooms. Super disappointed on the food but would return for a cocktail.
author: Amy B.

description: Deliciously salty cured meat and cheese platter!
author: Susie B.

description: So I've been on a tapas kick lately. Strolling the embarcadero, and trying to avoid the tourist traps, I was looking for some sexy small plates and a strong cocktail. I've walked by Coqueta so many times but haven't tried. I was pleasantly surprised! Ate outdoors in the covered bar area at a communal table, which was nice. The dish that really stood out to me were the duck meatballs. WOW. They were seasoned and cooked perfectly. Their chorizo was great too. I'll be back to try more soon.
author: Jordan Q.

description: How can one trust someone who doesn't honor gift cards (NapaStyle) I'm out 100 dollars sent half a dozen emails and no reply. I would never eat a meal prepared by some I couldn't trust
author: Mike W.

description:
This place is special. The decor is unique, and the ambiance is electric. The view is spectacular, as it sits right on the water. We got reservations simply by calling the restaurant. The hostess wasn't the friendliest when we arrived, but that was my biggest disappointment of the evening. Don't be snotty. You lost a star for it. 

Our server (Brooklyn) was fantastic. She explained the menu, described different offerings, and made suggestions when we asked for them. We had the sangria (good but I've had better), and we tried a ton of items on the menu (gotta love tapas!). The food was exceptional. I would highly recommend the croquettes and the sunny side up egg with shrimp. The octopus at Wayfare Tavern was better (IMHO), but this wasn't too far off. The paella was amazing - probably the best I've ever had, and everyone at the table thought the same. The menu suggests it's for two people, but we split it among four and were perfectly sated. 

Whatever you do at Coqueta, save room for the churros!!!! These little gems are so yummy; we ordered four servings of them, and I could have eaten at least another round or three! They are light, have the perfect crunch, and are paired with chocolate sauce and raspberry dust for dipping. Oh. My. Goodness. Days later, I'm still dreaming about them.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Let's set aside the fact that this is a Michael Chiarello place, and examine it on three separate topics: Food, Service, Environment.

FOOD
The cocktails here are amazing. We ordered the Galleon ($12) and the special punch ($12), which was essentially the Farmer's Market Punch with a few tweaks. They also serve wine in the Porron, the traditional Spanish wine pitcher with a spout. We saw a few people trying to drink directly from the Porron, which is always entertaining.

We started our meal with one chorizo bite-size skewer ($2.50 for one), which my boyfriend loved. I had the Pan con Tomate y Jamon ($10 - the server totally upselled me on this one, dammit), which was fine. Instead of fresh tomato, the bread was served with some kind of tomato jam/chutney, which was decent.

Next came the Red Kale Ensalada ($11) with roasted squash, persimmons, pumpkin seeds, and a warm, Rancho Gordo garbanzo bean dressing. That was, hands down, our favorite dish of the evening. I'm all about kale salads, and I could have eaten about two more orders of this. Fantastic.

Then came the Chicken and English Pea Croquetas ($9 for three --- why is it always in threes?), which to be honest, were quite unremarkable. Crunchy outside and mushy inside, but I've never met a croqueta in my life that I've liked. The croquetas also came with the Wood-Grilled Octopus ($12), which was amazing. The texture of the octopus was perfect; soft, and not rubbery. The fingerling potatoes that accompanied it were properly cooked, creamy, and (naturally) buttery.

After that, arrived THE dish that made me want to come here in the first place: The Pluma ($38), which is Iberico pork shoulder served with a honey-chili glaze that comes in a bottle alongside, so that you can glaze to your heart's content. You can tell that this pig, this pata negra, lived a great life. The meat was sweet, although pork shoulder can be a bit tough, which this was. Slightly. The glaze itself is tasty, and I'm sure people love to slather their pork with it, but I used it a bit sparingly. I would have loved to have a side of Maldon/sea/kosher salt. I like my meat simple. I'm kinda like a cavewoman in that way.

I was pretty full by this point, but I *had* to have dessert. You know, for research purposes. We had all of the dessert pinxtos: Manchego cheesecake (YES!) skewer (BOO!) with caramel popcorn, salted caramel skewer (meh -- you've had one salted caramel, you've had them all), pate de fruit skewer (tasty, but you gotta be in the mood for pate de fruit), and two white and dark chocolate-covered olives (this is never a good idea, ever). We also had an amazing apple tart (OMG) served with some Cabrales blue cheese ice cream, which we devoured. I don't remember the prices, but they're in the $4-10 range.

SERVICE
Our server was a fantastic Latina woman with jet-black, lovely hair. She was fantastic. The rest of the team was also on point, making sure our water glasses were always filled, our napkins were folded upon returning to our chairs, clearing away empty dishes promptly, etc. We showed our appreciation by leaving them more than 20%.

ENVIRONMENT
I really love what they did to that space. The architects and designers managed to create a warm, casual and modern atmosphere out of essentially an old pier in a cold and foggy city. One would think that with all the diners in the room, with all this concrete and huge space, that it would be noisy. It wasn't too bad (and my boyfriend's kind of a low-talker sometimes, and I'm kinda deaf sometimes, and we managed to have a great conversation!). 

However, the kitchen looked disorganized: Boxes and boxes of I don't know what, stacked 5 high on top of this seemingly 2-story shelf behind the chef's counter, bottles of wine and mezcal on the shelves, mixed with huge jars of pimenton, Asturian beans, and other kitchen staples; behind that, the prep area, with bulk bins, unattended food being prepped (persimmons, peels, etc.) and various supplies. I'm already paying $38 for 8 slices of Iberico pork shoulder. Why do I have to look at this disconnected, disorganized shit? I'm big on details, and they totally missed this one.

All in all, if you haven't been, definitely go and check it out, whether you like Chiarello or not. I long for the days when the Bay Area can have true tapas bars that are casual, where one can linger with great drinks and nice tapas to nibble on, instead of the bougie "tapas restaurants" we're currently stuck with.
author: Cheryl M.

description: The grilled octopus was amazing! Great cocktails and sangria! The ambiance is great. Would definitely go back!
author: Marissa L.

description:
3 stars all goes to the quality food and cocktail.

Service was a shame. I walked in on a Sunday evening at 7pm. Coming in without a reservation, I asked for 2 bar seats. The restaurant was full but there was hardly any people waiting. The host (a tall & big man) was reluctant to even help me. All he could offer me was *I don't have any seats inside* and *You have to find your own seat for the patio bar*... 
Wow. I'm speechless. Thanks for nothing. 

So we waited around *awkwardly* - with no real spot to stand - hoping to find a seat at the patio. Thank my lucky stars a couple left the bar, just moments later. And we thought "Great, now we can expect it to go better".

Unfortunately the service we got from the waiter was equally miserable. 10mins to get the menu. 15mins to take our drinks order. Then 10mins to take our tapas order. And did not offer us any water. Did not check on us regarding the meal (of course the food was alright so no complains on that). BUT we had to flag him down to get anything at all! 

Pass... Next.
author: Pancakes D.

description:
As yelp says "Meh", seems to describe this place.  For the price you are paying, I expect top of the line quality, which did not deliver.  To begin the tiny appetisers offered table-side are $2.50 each and literally one bite of cheese, or an egg.  The shrimp "pancake" is a super fried and greasy plate, that should be on the menu of a cheap Chinese restaurant and our Paella had about 5 small claims, was burnt on the bottom.  On the bright side the service was good. 
    However, such a miss on food quality while charging ridiculous prices makes me feel like they are aiming for the tourist crowd and not us San Franciscans who really know good food.
author: Dani C.

description:
If you love spanish Gambas there's no better place in the city!

Coqueta is one of my favorite restaurants in the city love how small it is, the vibe, the smells, the great service and drinks selection.

Everytime I go I try new dishes on their menu but the Gambas are my favorite.
author: Angel J.

description: I like the view from Coqueta and the ambience. The octopus was good. I was disappointed that shishito peppers were used to substitute padron. They are quite different in taste and appearance. The restaurant should tell the customer when taking order. Other things we had were alright but not outstanding. I think the price is high and meanwhile the food quantity is very very little. Yes I know I'm talking about a tapas restaurant. But you have to order so many items here to have a meal for an average person. So you might end up spending a lot for a few bites. I love tapas and have been to many tapas restaurants. The experience at Coqueta was less than satisfactory. Fortunately I can easily find much better ones to meet my craving for Spanish food.
author: Roy Z.

description:
who care about the law suit of the chef!!
in this country, suing people is a business!!
the food and service are excellent, well price, well executed
author: Mina O.

description:
Coqueta is a solid restaurant, but it is definitely overpriced and over-hyped.

Everything about it was great -- the location, the ambiance, the service, the food -- except for the prices. Just to be clear, I'm more than happy to pay $150+ a person for a Spanish tapas restaurant, but there has to be a reason why a dish is so expensive -- a Celebrity chef shouldn't automatically skyrocket the price of 8 slices of grilled pork to $38. The pork should taste like it's $38, or maybe at least $30 with an $8 "Celebrity chef" tax. 

Honestly, though, as long as you know that you will be overpaying and you are content with knowing that you will be overpaying, Coqueta really is a solid Spanish restaurant in SF. There are many millionaires in SF who use $100 bills like Charmin Ultra sheets, so there will definitely be people who don't care, and for those people, Coqueta is great.

----------------
FOOD:

Pluma (Grilled Pork with Honey) =
Nicely grilled, but definitely under-seasoned without the honey. The honey gives the pork a wonderful, subtle sweetness, but the pork itself just isn't worth $38 for 8 slices. I don't care if there was an incredible scientific breakthrough that managed to reincarnate Julia Child and zombie Julia Child cooked up this meal for me, no celebrity chef should be charging this much for 8 pieces of bland pork that has to be drenched with honey.

Serrano Ham w/ Manchego Cheese Pintxo =
Good ham, good cheese -- the bite was the size of a tic tac, but it was a satisfying bite.

English Pea Croquettes =
Delicious chicken pot pie croquettes -- nicely fried with a strong, creamy flavor.

Paella =
Very good paella -- excellent texture of the rice, subtly spiced, and with lots of crispy rice to give it a great overall consistency. Goes amazingly well with the peppers and aioli they give you on the side.

Grilled Octopus =
The octopus was a bit too mushy, and not tender like how grilled octopus is supposed to be. The fingerling potatoes were tasteless -- I think this dish would go better with a puree or at least something with a bit more flavor.

Fig Tart with Blue Cheese Ice Cream =
Fig tart was just okay -- tasted like a stale pop tart. BUT the Blue Cheese Ice Cream was INCREDIBLE. Honestly, we spent about 10 minutes contemplating if we should try the Blue Cheese Ice Cream, because it sounded horrific but it definitely piqued our curiosity. Best decision of the night. Subtle blue cheese flavor, but the perfect amount of sweetness that ended with a satisfying end. This is one of my favorite ice cream flavors ever and I wish the fig tart wasn't there in the way.

Churros =
Perfectly fried churros. The chocolate sauce wasn't strong enough to do anything of substance, but the churros themselves were excellent. Again -- not sure if it's worth the $8 price tag, though.
----------------

Coqueta is an excellent addition to the Embarcadero and it definitely has its spectacular moments (Blue Cheese Ice Cream, Paella) but I was just expecting more, given the prices and the hype.
author: Roy C.

description: Booked through Open Table a few weeks out to snag a Saturday night reservation. We started off with a couple drinks. Their molecular cocktails are amazing! The barca gin and tonic is the best i've had. Between two people, 6 small plates and 2 desserts was enough. We overheard there was a smaller ribeye available that night and ordered to share for our dinners finale. Midway through our meal our waitress informed us they now only had a large cut available for a higher price and let us cancel. Good thing too! After sharing a beet salad, octopus, large razer clams, duck and pork meatballs, quail eggs and (my absolute favorite) the smoked salmon sandwich, there was no way i was going to get through a steak. I'd order almost all the same tapas again ... i'd probably skip the meatballs and order another plate of smoked salmon. That queso fresco and and truffle honey combo is too good! To end, we shared a hot plate of fresh churros with Tcho chocolate and flan. Can't wait to come back again.
author: Samantha L.

description: This place is okay. The food is good but it is way overpriced for what you are getting. For 50$ at lunch with a glass of sangria, I would expect the dishes to be amazing. Everything was solid but $14 for two prawns is a little bit ridiculous. You are paying for the location and atmosphere
author: Eileen W.

description:
Came here for lunch and was wondering if Chef Chiarello would have been able to 'enlighten' me with the Spanish influenced cuisine since he specializes in Italian so well at his Bottega establishment.  

I have to say that it helps that the location is right on the Embarcadero and it's a treat to have a meal here.  

Since this is a Tapas-style restaurant, shared some dishes including the following:

1) Salmon Ahumado - OMG, this brushetta like dish is great!  The salmon tainted with the honey glaze meshed with fresco is great.  I could eat more and more of this.

2) Gambas al negro - Nicely cooked shrimp in olive oil with lots of flavor. 

3) Pulpo a la Parilla - Wood-Grilled Octopus that tastes similar to the one dish that I've tried at Evvia and Kokkari.  Love the grilled taste from the octopus and the item is cooked so that it tastes soft in the mouth.  

4) Albondigas a la Feria - Duck and pork meatballs that tasted a little too sweet for me.  However the meatballs were great and cooked to order!

5) Lubina a la Brasa - The highlight of my meal.  Fish is cooked perfect on the inside and the exterior has that wood-oven grilled taste that's just 'terrific'!  I could have this again as a meal in itself.

I would recommend coming here.  The atmosphere is great and next time, I'll need to do happy hour here on a Friday afternoon.  Let's go!!  =)
author: Edward L.

description:
A couple of my buddies from work were out here from Texas for a trade show this week  and came by for dinner on Wednesday. It was a great experience, the views and the food were fantastic and the friendliness of the staff made us feel right at home.  

We started off with a Mojito in the scenic bar  which has a well deserved reputation for being awesome. When I come back I am going to try the Tonic de Cortez - they looked outstanding. 

We sampled so many terrific dishes it was hard to keep track of them all, but my favorite was the Tortillita de Camaron - delicious!  

Special shout out to Michael Chiarello and his staff for making this an outstanding dining experience for us.
author: Randy J.

description:
Delicious food and drinks. Didn't try the entrees as we stuck to the tapas. The Sunny side up was amazing. I forget the name of it now - it is an eggplant "burger" with grilled peaches - to die for. Those 2 are must-tries. Had the seafood risotto stuffed piquillo peppers also - yummy! 
The service was very good also. They are very attentive and gracious.
author: Jenna Z.

description:
Came in without any expectations...just looking for lunch when every resto was packed out at the Ferry Building. Wonderful lazy late lunch on Christmas Eve. Sat at the bar and watched the cooks...everyone so intensely focused on their craft. Enjoyed paella, shortribs, soft cooked egg with crispy potato, kale salad...would order any of these again! A bit spendy for tapas but we would do it again happily for a special outing.

Dessert menu perhaps a bit wanting. Would have enjoyed  a bit more barstool seatage under my butt--they are the size of a box of Sees candy! 

Great atmosphere in a 130 year old building,  high ceilings and immense timbers, views of the Bay Bridge through rippled glass...pretty much everything we Santa Cruzans want on a visit to the city. We will be back.
author: Peggy B.

description:
Fabulous experience! From the moment we sat down and the pinchos came around we were loving it...the service, ambience etc...even the dishes and flatware are fun! Our group tried many cocktails and some of the favorites were the farmers market punch, engine #5, margarita...we honestly didn't have a bad cocktail. The food was amazing and full of delicious surprises! The highlights were the sunny side up egg, the gaucho, paella, wood grilled octopus and patatas bravas,...but I am certain that everything on the menu would be excellent. I can't wait to go back and try more. 
Our hostess and server, nicole e., was extremely knowledgable, attentive and helped make the entire experience really great. 
We will absolutely be going back! If you get nicole e you're guaranteed a great dining experience.
author: A.c. D.

description: Delicious!! One of my favorite tapas places. After eating excellent oysters at Hog Island we came here and were blown away by how good the food and drinks were. The gin and tonic is amazing.  Food comes out quickly and service is impeccable. We had the uni w Iberian ham, prawns with the head on (omg so delicious - the head especially was juicy and amazing) , the pork shoulder, octopus etc.  Everything was fantastic. Coming back again next week!!
author: SHOU LIN C.

description:
This place was pretty good, but very expensive for what you get. you're definitely paying for the open-air chic ambiance on the embarcadero moreso than the food, though it was tasty. i went for a business lunch and we had an array of tapas: salmon, papas bravas, cured meats and cheese plate, this fried shrimp cake thingie, steak, and of course paella. My favorite was definitely the papas bravas. how can you go wrong with fried potatoes with aioli?! at it's customary for me to order paella everytime i go to a spanish restaurant, so of course i did but honestly wasn't that thrilled. certainly not the best paella i've tasted, though passable. the cocktails were good, but definitely on the sweeter side. 

all in all, i had a good time as i went with an amazingly fun crowd on the sunniest sf day this year, and the vibe was just perfect. but thankfully i wasn't paying because i'm sure we broke the bank! gotta love expense accounts lol. Will be back for another fun gals biz lunch though probably never on my own accord.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I've been here a two or three times here now. First off, great location...on the water and next to a long pier you can walk down and see the Bay Bridge lights. Their bar area is a bit cramped  (there can be a lot of people eating there along the sides and at the community table since the dining room is usually booked), but their drinks are tasty and beautiful looking. The Barca is their gin and tonic that I always seem to get. 

As for their food, I always seem to leave satisfied. Their paella for two is tasty and the portion size was on the larger side. I thought I would like their sea urchin open face sandwich, but I liked the smoked salmon one more. I can't get enough of their honey chile glaze on their Pluma (pork shoulder dish). The ribeye is very flavorful, though a bit fatty. The sunny-side egg with shrimp (a bit greasy), gambas, and albondigas are all solid dishes as well, and provide some great sauces for dipping some bread.
author: Rick T.

description:
Came here for lunch with a friend and had an enjoyable meal.  We started with the short ribs and the calamari.  I thought the short ribs were good but the calarmi was great.  Don't expect sliced rings of calarmi.  Instead, you get the whole body separated from the tentacles.  

We also split the paella.  After reading reviews (both on Yelp and professional restaurant critics), I was expecting the holy grail of paellas.  Maybe it was the hype or maybe it was just an off day, but I didn't think the paella was special.  I think the reason I wasn't blown away by the paella is there wasn't any crispy/crunchy rice layer on the bottom of the pan.  

I'll probably come back with a larger group so we can try more dishes and give the paella another shot.
author: Larry L.

description: Food portions are small, cocktails are super expensive and it takes forever to get a refill. Best part is location and decor. Michael Chiarello has a great eye for design. His menu was a little bit of a let down. But, when I'm ready to drop a lot of cash and flirt with a sophisticated crowd, it's not a bad spot.
author: Teisha F.

description:
5 stars for location
and design.

5 stars for good vibes from my server.

Food... lacks soul. Albondigas are tender, almost to the degree of falling apart. Duck and pork get lost in the sauce, tastes more Southwestern than Spanish. I definitely couldn't tell what kind of meat it was. Mushrooms were burnt, had to forage for the larger pieces that weren't overdone and didn't finish 3/4 of the dish. 

I was sold on those mushrooms by my rad server, and let him know how they tasted, and was bummed when they didn't get taken off my bill.

It's not that I expected it, or again, maybe I did. But I'm in the Food and Bev industry so I take responsibility for suggesting a dish and a guest feeling like it was not cooked properly. Thats not preference, that's the kitchen's delivery... 

BOTTOM LINE:

I'd come here for drinks [Go for the Castro! Skip the seaweed Martini] and design / space vibes - probably in that cute outdoor bodega. But other than that nothing about the food or experience tells me there was something to remember.
author: S S.

description:
SPEECHLESS....good service, amazing food and amazing drinks! We didn't make any reservation but wanted to try our chance and see if we can get seats at the bar (you can order food from their full menu even if you sit at the bar). Food was amazing, we were both speechless! I didn't have any drinks but my husband tried 3 of their cocktails and he was pretty amazed. We ordered a bunch of dishes: Patatas bravas (Best patatas bravas i've had so far), Jamon Iberico, Spanish soft cheese (forgot the name but it was really really really good, tasted kind of like the Humbolt Fog by Cowgirl Creamery), Grilled octopus, some sort of shrimps (MUST TRY!!!!) and mini ribs. Everything was perfect!

Trust me, you will not regret coming here, everything was AMAZING!

I WILL TOTALLY BE BACK but next time i'll try to make reservation :)
author: Vickie Z.

description: Cool location and great decor. If only they could cook, this place would be great. Dishes are overpriced and flavors are unimpressive. In addition, the restaurant is crowded and hard to navigate.
author: Gareth C.

description:
The flavors were wonderful but the pricing per portion was very shi shi. 

The chicken and English pea croquettes tasted like mini pot pies but were cold in the middle. The beet salad was very good but tiny. The sangria was just okay, it didn't sit long enough so the fruit didn't absorb any of the alcohol. We had the apple pie for dessert and that was a nice treat! 

The atmosphere was warm and cozy which I appreciated on a cold and rainy day and the service was attentive. All in all it was enjoyable but with several traditional tapas places in the city I expected a little more.
author: Ariana N.

description:
4 star experience! Fancified tapas (even patatas bravas, which are really homey, were done up with individual teeny fetal potatoes, fried individually, each topped with a dollop of mayo). The only minor disappointment was bellota ham that didn't really stand out. Gambas were outrageously good.

Minus one star for the asterisk next to a variety of menu items that corresponded to this note at the bottom of the menu: "What chef Michael is eating now". I'm not a big fan of persuasion by social proof in general, but this specifically, especially in its phrasing, was really out of place an a restaurant that doesn't have donkey sauce on the menu. Unless Chiarello *was* actually was locked in a room eating those exact items for the entire service...please let me know if that was the case, and I'll take it back!
author: Wangston P.

description:
Thought it'll be a year or more before getting to try this place...but we tried our luck when we walked by one Saturday early afternoon and had a choice between a table or at the "chef counter".  We chose the chef counter as the hostess suggested it's a bit more fun.  It really wasn't a chef counter as we were sat across at the "dessert" and "pixto" station but it was still cool watching how some of the times were made.  

What we had:
Kalimotxo - Cola Mexicana, red sangria, cinnamon - $17 - yum
Clara - Estrella dam, rosemary, lemon soda, orange bitters - $17 - very refreshing
House cured white anchovies - $4 - great start
Roasted Padron peppers w/ jamon Serrano and sherry vinegar - $8 - ok, I love Padron peppers and think best when just slightly seasoned w/ salt & pepper. 
Gambas al negro, olive oil poached head-on gulf prawns w/ black garlic and chili - $14 - any prawns cooked head-on is good in my books, good flavor
Whole Monterey calamari on the plancha w/ onion jam and squid ink aioli - $10 - pretty good
Grilled razor clams w/ salsa verde and meyer lemon - $14 - LOVE razor clams and this is really good, it's a must
Baby beets w/ Sausalito watercress, beet vinacreta and tierra, and cabrales blue cheese snow - $8 - ok
Special: summer peppers w/ chorizo dressing and sunny sided-up quail eggs - $12 - LOVE, so flavorful...you wish you had more bread to wipe the little cast iron dish clean
Mar y Montana, sea and mountain - Iberico lardo gently melted over sea urchin w/ jamon iberico de bellota - $14 - OMG, who would guess lard and uni would make such beautiful marriage? 
scoop of the ice cream special - $5 - goat cheese flavor, WOW
cheesecake lollipop - $4 - cute and tasty
pan con chocolate - $4 - ok
dessert pintxos - $4 - cute

Looks forward to returning to try new items and enjoy some of the must haves...
author: Gloria H.

description: Great place for weekend brunch. Perfect for large groups, good food and the staff was really awesome. They brought out a lovely dessert with a little candle as it was my husband's birthday. They also have some amazing Gin cocktails.
author: S B.

description: Strong drinks and excellent tapas. You'll most likely leave this restaurant hungry ;)
author: Christina C.

description: Such a nice restaurant to catch up with friends.. With great food! We ordered a variety of items on the menu and everything was good! Love the decor and the bat area to have some drinks !! Will be coming back soon.
author: Lily M.

description:
We call it cokeheada b/c of the hard to pronounced name and rich banking clientele. Come here for slow service & overpriced everything. Also awesome if you like eating food on newspaper (that's how it's served!!?!).

Work right near by... keep hoping it will become a good spot... but last time (3rd try) we went we went right to the host to ask if they we're serving outside and if we could sit out there (b/c it was great out and we saw others outside eating/drinking. 

The host and 3 other people mulling about the host desk said of course...  and told us someone would be out shortly.

Well we waited at least 20 min before deciding to leave b/c nobody even came by to say hi and offer water. It's not like there were't any servers... we saw at least 4 standing about inside doing nothing and more mulling about the bar.

Maybe I wasn't dressed nicely enough? Maybe it had something to do with the way we looked (one of my group was wearing a turban)... but I'd like to think that's not the case.  

Either way, when I went inside to tell a manager why we we're going to leave I was greeted by the same 3 people just hanging out by the host's desk chatting?! 

I mean... did anyone tell them they are a restaurant? Or are supposed to pay an exorbitant amount of $$$ just to be treated like a burden?

My recommendation... go to Waterfront Cafe about 100 yards away. Better outdoor seating... much better service... and they never make you feel like a jerk.

Wonder if this place is destine to fail just like the last place that was there... LAME
author: Sunset W.

description:
I love the idea of this place. The cocktails are so fun and are definitely 'on trend' with the whole mixology craze. 

However, the place is always a little unorganized. There are some great things on the menu but the Paella isn't one of them. Entirely too salty and missing that savory flavor. The seafood in this last batch made the entire dish taste like fish.

We were too full to finish it so we had them box it and then they gave us the wrong box to take home. We were very surprised when we opened the box. 

Probably just an off night but ya know..
author: Candi M.

description: Haven't had such a pleasant experience at a restaurant  in while. From the moment we walked in every single person that works here was friendly and had helpful suggestions to offer. We had some Sangrias while waiting for a table and they were out of this world!! The fabulous trendy decor+great service and amazing food! Will definitely coming back :)
author: Tathi P.

description: Had another awesome evening at Coqueta tonight. This place is arguably the best Spanish restaurant in this city! Absolutely fabulous. Small servings with a high price tag, but the food is beyond good. Incredible and sizzling flavors. Everything on the menu is spot on. Not a single item is a miss. Definitely the best paella, meatballs, wood-grilled octopus, hot tapas and cold tapas, and sliced cured meats in SF, hands down. Sure the price point is very high but the ambience, atmosphere, service snd the food are just that --- a super fabulous spot on the Embarcadero. One thing --- make a reservation! And come early and enjoy a pre-cocktail hour at the sexy, "flirtatious" covered patio/bar. Stylish crowd. Gorgeous view of the Bay.
author: Ambrose A.

description: Good tapas, great location and fancy presentation, but overall it seems overrated.  It is a good place to have a date or meeting with friends.
author: Jingyi L.

description: The atmosphere is cute. Very small location and even smaller plates. Never and I mean NEVER order the "blood sausage". We ordered a small plate of all 4 types of sausage and this was the NASTIEST thing I have ever tasted. Drinks are nice though. I recommend for drinks only- but not if you're in heels girls. Often times its standing room only! Who does that?
author: Ashley C.

description:
I'm so mixed about Coqueta, our first experience was off the chart wonderful, and then last night we had some glitches that prevent me from coming back, or even recommending it to others.  

The food was still as wonderful as ever, however the comfort level of the seating is an issue.  We were sat at the Chef's counter both times, the first time was fine because we were in front of the action and the staff bent over backwards to make sure we were taken care of....it was like a family affair.  Last night however was a totally different experience, we basically got a view of a staff member portioning ENDLESS amounts of meatballs.  When I mean endless...during our two hour meal he just barely finished when we were signing the check.  I think we were around meatball 60 when our server had a moment to come over and take our drink order.  I have a feeling she was stretched thin, very nice, but I felt like she was busy and I didn't want to have to take up her time to ask questions.  It was a frustrating experience being put in purgatory....

I would ask the management to please reconsider the seating at the counter...not only that but if you are going to force people to sit up there after making reservations, please make the chairs comfortable.  I noticed they now have a cushion, however they are narrow stools that need a back!!  PLEASE listen!
author: Brye L.

description:
I was extremely disappointed with this restaurant. I know this place has great reviews and high status, but I left annoyed and feeling like what a waste of money and with a promise that I would never go back. I was meeting a few girlfriends after work for drinks and dinner, and we had made a reservation a week and a half in advance. After the waiter had suggested that we get 3 tapas each (wayyyyy too much and wayyyy too pricey for a $20 bite of okay food), and were there for about an hour and 10 minutes he told us that they had reserved this table for another party and asked us if we would like to move to the bar....
For a nice restaurant who regards itself with quality food and service I have NEVER had a waiter tell us to move because they reserved this table for another party. How rude!! I would understand maybe if we were a party of eight and were there for 2 hours but there were 3 of us, and were barely sitting for an hour when he asked us to move. He mentioned in a quiet voice that he set up dessert for us in the bar "on the house". We were moved to a tiny area of the bar with a stump like table which didn't even hold the 3 of our drinks. After about 40 minutes, we asked a different waiter if we could inquire about this dessert we were told was waiting for us at our new spot. He was very nice and brought us dessert quickly. About 20 minutes later our first waiter came over and "apologized about our dessert being so late" and claimed it was ready for us when he originally set it up but "someone must have swooped on the dessert and taken it." Hmm. That seems very interesting that he conveniently didn't notice that our dessert wasn't there when he sat us there OR when he came to swoop on our bill that we hadn't even touched yet with our full drinks.
Overall - the bus boys and servers were very attentive and polite, but our waiter was very pushy and untrustworthy. The food was good, but not worth the experience. I've had much better food out of a food truck and the service was much better.
I expected much more out of a top rated restaurant in SF...
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Michael Chiarello's new spot in the city! I've been really wanting to try this place out since I work right next to the ferry building. I finally got the opportunity to dine here for lunch with my team.

We were able to get reservations right when they opened up on a Friday. Upon arrival, the hosts were very accommodating and pleasant, as expected at a place like this. Once we were seated, we all order our drinks (non-alcoholic, not one of those lunches). I had the housemade J & T tonic drink which was super refreshing and great for a nice summer day.

Being a tapas restaurant, and specializing in their small plates, we basically ordered everything from the hot tapas section of the menu. The most notable/plates I would definitely order again include: Chicken and English Pea Croquetas, Sunny side-up egg w/Shrimp, Shrimp Pancake, and Calamari.

We also ordered some of the bigger dishes, including the Pluma and Paella.

Pluma (Ibérico de Bellota Pork Shoulder Loin with Honey-Chili Glaze) - Let me start by saying this was probably my favorite thing on the menu at Coqueta. The pork was just so tender and juicy. It just kind of melts in your mouth and you can't help but smile. Although it's $38 for 8 pieces, this is a must have! With the honey glaze that you coat the pork, you will not regret this decision at all. Enough said. 

Paella - All that yelp buzz for the Paella made it easy for us to cop an order of this. I have to say I'm glad we got it. The Paella consisted of razor clams, chorizo, and prawns. I mean really you can't go wrong with this. It's one of the staples of this restaurant, so just get it. Great mix of flavors and a fantastic way to top off the meal before dessert.

Speaking of dessert, we were able to try a few of the unique desserts that Coqueta had to offer. We chose the chocolate and olive oil ice cream sandwich and the manchego cheese cake served with caramel popcorn. They were both very interesting, but tasty nonetheless!

Olive oil ice cream sandwich - Very refreshing! Surprisingly light and paired well with the chocolate!

Manchego cheese cake - This thing is straight up cheese (at least it seemed like it), definitely a very strong taste. Popcorn is necessary to subdue some of that kick from the cheese cake. Again, magical pairing of flavors!

Our experience at Coqueta was very enjoyable, food/service was great and the overall vibe was very relaxing/homey. Make reservations here, come eat, and enjoy!
author: Jason T.

description: Awesome experience!  I enjoyed the pork and duck meatballs the most! Could've eaten 10 of them,  the kale salad was refreshing with strawberries and chocolate cake crutons, the skewers were a great start and drinks tasty...the chickpea crusted shrimp cake was on the salty side and a little too much of a fried dish for me...service was good but slow sat at the chefs table...
author: Aliyia P.

description:
The good: view, drinks, atmosphere
The mediocre: food
author: Ramya G.

description:
My absolute FAVE, go-to restaurant in SF these days. I go
 at least every couple weeks because I bring all my friends and dates here. It's got the best of all worlds...great vibe, food, cocktails/wine list, design aesthetic, people watching, view...what more can you ask for? Yes, a little pricey, but well worth it.
author: Melanie D.

description: The Martinis/cocktails were really different than anything else Ive tasted. Worth it. We enjoyed the brioche & cultivated mushrooms. cheesecake and apple pie were ok but fun trying something new.
author: Ashutosh T.

description: Unauthentic and overpriced offering combined with sub par service leaves much to be desired. The cheeses were great as were the manchego cheesecake bites.
author: Clayton C.

description: Price and Value well balanced. Good food, service and ambiance. Quality traditional tapas.
author: Mario C.

description:
Getting seated more than a half hour late for a reservation isn't exactly great, but it's apparently par for the course on a busy Saturday night.  Waiting an additional thirty minutes for a simple glass of water or the cocktails we ordered might be pushing things a bit far, though.  Overhearing our neighbors discuss similar issues - and worse - kind of put us on edge at the start.

The cocktail list is long and complex, but the cocktails we sampled tended to be overly sweet and overly savory, with somewhat muddied flavors brought on by the sheer number of ingredients.  We had a hard time finding something simply refreshing, which would have worked well as a foil to the generally salty, savory food.

Speaking of the food - it's good.  Others have laid it out in exquisite detail, but a few notes:  The squid dish was overly salty and inferior to a couple others we chanced upon that week.  Three spears of fresh delta asparagus with a *fuchsia* sauce glopped on one end might be considered by some to be excessively priced at $8.  The paella looked good, if a little overdone, at the next table over.  We opted for Arroz dish, which tasted better than the paella looked.

Service ranged from okay to strange to inattentive.  The bar was exceptionally slow.  The kitchen was decently fast, until we tried to order another round of tapas.  We should have known the snide comment from the waiter about our addition was going to point to trouble.  I mean - it's tapas.  In what universe do you just place an initial order for this stuff and not go back for more when you see the portion sizes?

So - the food is good, if perhaps a bit small for the price.  The cocktail list leaves something to be desired unless you happen to love the house flavor.  And the service would be maddening if the place wasn't so popular.  So why is it that we kind of want to go back for the paella, huh?
author: Albert H.

description:
The food at Coqueta is amazing! We came in here with no reservations and ended up sitting at the bar. The restaurant was crowded and I could tell the hostess was overwhelmed because she was not very helpful but we managed to find seating, totally worth it! The paella was amazing, loved the octopus. 

I want to go back and try one of those cool drinks with flowers inside.
author: Ebeli G.

description: First, skip the review of the person who calls paella "payaya," IM[H]O disqualified to review.  But then I have to correct some waiters when they say "bruschetta" like a brush with etta.  think "brusketta."  But I digress.  Love this place, and have been there with people who lived in Barcelona for a time and they loved it as well.  Great service, wonderful suggestions, host & hostess talked to us with waiter about something I'd mentioned to the waiter and we had a great time discussing it.  We'll return many times.
author: B. C.

description: Coqueta is a delectable haven tucked away on a quiet pier with great views and even better food. Each dish is a work of art and an ode to the Spanish cuisine. Coqueta makes for a great date spot, although be ready to shell out some money for a full meal. But for the food and atmosphere, it is worth every penny.
author: Justine H.

description: Great location, didn't have time for food so we grabbed six different gin & tonics since there was six of us... we sat in the bar and sampled each of them and I was having the time of my life taking photos of each beautifully served adult beverage.  See pics.
author: Shiho F.

description: Pricey but very good tapas. We sat at the kitchen bar so received double the service...attention from the Chefs as well as our server.
author: Anh C.

description: Amazing drinks. My favorite spot for drinks in SF. They are a little pricey for the size but they are quite worth it. Their tapas are amazing specially their papas and the coquetas de pollo.
author: Andrea S.

description:
***I didn't pay for the meal and never saw the bill, lucky me***
Excellent meal, best this year.
Just walked in on a Friday night, again got lucky.
The chef's counter is a great place to experience this place, I don't think I would have enjoyed any of the other seating in this place.
The interior of the main room is fantastic.
Our server was average, rest of the staff was great.
Try the small bites, lots of interesting options.
author: Isley T.

description:
I knew nothing about this place or its celebrity chef before stumbling upon it the other day while walking down the Embarcadero.  We were looking for a place for lunch on Sunday when we saw the bright & airy little bar area overlooking the bay.  We completely missed the actual restaurant, which is through the bar & inside the attached building, so you have to actually know where you're going to find this place.  The menu looked good so we decided to give it a try.

Unfortunately all of the tables were booked, so we were seated on precariously small stools at "the chef's table", which is basically the bar overlooking the kitchen.  It felt a little weird staring at the chefs plating & cooking but I suppose they are used to it.  I was able to watch our food being cooked which was pretty cool.

The menu is Spanish tapas, so we ordered a bunch of dishes to share.  Most of the menu was foreign to me so I let my sis do the ordering.  I only insisted that we order the wood grilled octopus.  This was the most amazing octopus dish I have ever had, and I have eaten my fair share of octopus!  I didn't think it was possible to get it that soft and the smoky flavor was incredible.  We also ordered some jamon (cured ham) with manchego, small toasted uni crostini, razor clams, & beet salad.  Everything was delicious but being tapas, they were gobbled up much too quickly.  We ended our meal with an order of the house made churros with warm chocolate sauce.  Yum.

I still don't know who Michael Chiarello is, but I can see why he has so many loyal fans.  The food here is amazing.  It's just a bit pricey for me.
author: Erin S.

description:
Coqueta...

A Michael Chiarello restaurant...instant credibility.

this is not the place to go after day drinking on a Sunday Funday...youre gonna sit down...youre gonna see the menu...and like me, youre going to want everything on it...thats exactly what we did...we literally ordered at least one of everything (in some instances 2 or 3) off of the Tapas Calientes menu AND 2 paellas to boot...needless to say, everything i tasted was good...the only fail was that they ran out of the razor clams, but i can only image they tasted as good as i imagined them to be...

if you havent been...make your way there...next time around, definitely the dining room for a formal dinner, but sometimes gorging down on great food with loud friends is definitely the biz...
author: Kyu L.

description:
Be careful if you go here - they nickel and dime you for everything!! My husband and I had an event and had to leave by 7 pm to make it, so we had a reservation at 5:30. The service was slow, it took 40 minutes to even get a cocktail. After ordering several tapas, we decided to get some red sangria. Again, it was taking forever. So, the manager came by and asked if we needed anything. We said we were waiting for our sangria. A moment later our server came by and said the sangria was coming. Eventually we got this red sangria which is a pitiful amount for $36.00. As we were being brought one pitcher, another was being brought our way and they turned around, realizing we just got ours. We also had a tapas where they had some very burned bread - the manager came by and asked if we wanted more. We were feeling agreeable and said yes. Four thin slices of charred bread wasn't very good, but we ate it anyway. 

Then comes the bill, but it was so close to 7 we didn't look at it closely as we had to get going. When we got home we were suspicious of extra charges. They charged us for TWO sangria pitchers, when we only ordered one. I am so angry. They even charged us for the damn bread - which was way too burned to eat any way. 

If you want to blow $150 - $200 be my guest. But be wary of any "extra" service - it will show up on your bill. Our bill was $250.00 - two cocktails, tapas and "two" pitchers of sangria. I think I can do better elsewhere.
author: Bonilee P.

description:
Boom. Five stars. Nicole found a way for our group of eight to get a table. Lowell really took care of us at the table; he's a heckuva professional. Combine this with a great view and you'll have a memorable meal at one of my favorite restaurants in SF.

Everything was flavorful, and we ordered a ton of food. With each new dish, a new taste profile and another check in the "good order" column. The ribeye was the hit out of everything - it's definitely worth the wait. 

Other specifics: the sangrias were fun. The paella was lovely. El gran pate featured a nice collection of meat and cheese. The pintxos are small and quite tasty but will fill you up after you sample all of them. The pegboard is perfect for serving them. Coquetas, their namesake, are surprisingly good, creamy and rich while sticking with the small bite theme.
author: Mike H.

description: What an amazing place. We had a late dinner on a Saturday night. The restaurant is very nicely decorated. Our waitress listened to dietary restrictions and made recommendations. The gin tonic cocktails were amazing. So were the sardines, potatoes, kale salad and rice. Highly recommend this great restaurant between the ferry building and the Exploratorium
author: Sharon S.

description: We went in today for happy hour and the out dinner reservations.. No wait staff to help us out( they were not busy).. They then tried to rush us from the bar area to our  seats... The small plates are good but nothing that shouts above and beyond. Our friend ordered a cocktail 3 times and it was finally delivered to her 45 min later... Would not be coming back as the menu is pricey and the service was awful..
author: Das M.

description: Amazing food! A lil bit pricy but it's definitely worth trying most of their tapas. Atmosphere is very authentic from Spai. and service is excellent too. It is also located is a really nice area.
author: Cat A.

description:
I came here on Nov 12 for my girlfriend's birthday. To my surprise we were seated at the kitchen bar and Michael was in the house cooking! Even better he actually stopped to greet us, shook our hands, and chatted a little bit. He later checked with us about the food.

Everything was excellent. The smoked salmon was my favorite, but the octupus and meatballs were excellent as well. Also the fish was quite tasty. For dessert we had the molten cake which was good, but I'm a fan of chili's molten cake which is a different beast.

Definitely check this place out if you've got the cash.
author: Stephen C.

description:
I've here been a couple of times now with the family, and we have had a great experience each time. The place is nice but not stuffy, and the food is just excellent. I also really like their sangria, which is very light and refreshing.

You can start with your cured meats, cheeses, and bite-sized skewers, if you're so inclined, though there is so much other good stuff on the menu we usually just do the jamon iberico, if anything, and then dive right into the good stuff, pretty much making our way down the hot tapas list. We like the roasted padron peppers, gambas al negro, calamari, and duck and pork albondigas. I also liked the smoked salmon sandwich which I tried on the last visit; though it was pretty much your standard smoked salmon on bread, the truffle honey added a little extra something. And next visit I plan to try the mar y montana -- sea urchin and jamon iberico, which sounds really great.

Now, onto the main event! You can of course make a light meal out of the appetizer and tapas dishes, and many people do, but the main dishes should not be missed. If I had to choose, I'd skip all of the the other stuff (as good as it all is), in favor of their seafood paella. It says it's for two, but split it'd be a smallish portion. If you have enough people (or a big enough appetite), also try the "gaucho" bone-in 32 oz ribeye -- it's recommended for four people, and our group of four did both with no problems, even after a bunch of tapas. The paella also makes for great leftovers, so don't worry about over-ordering. In fact, my only complaint was that on our last visit, there was a miscommunication and half of our paella, which we'd wanted boxed to-go, got tossed! The horror!! But everyone was very apologetic, and there's no point in crying over spilt milk and all that, right? Even if the milk is a big portion of delicious paella that would've been great reheated the next day...
author: Shing H.

description:
It was the best of times, it was the worst of times...ok, sorry to go all Dickens on you but felt that was a proper way to start a review of a very uneven meal at Coqueta.

First off, the good:

-I love the space, it feels both brand new and lived in for years at the same time.

-My Barca Gintonic had a refreshing, floral/herbal flavor.

-The chef's selection of meats and cheeses was top notch.

-The Grilled berico Secreto was melt in your mouth piggy goodness.

- The Grilled Razor Clams were pretty much perfect.

And now, the bad:

-We waited 45 minutes past our 8:30pm reservation time. I know you're a new restaurant and there might be people camping out but when you keep someone waiting that long who has a reservation it might be a nice gesture to offer a cocktail or appetizer, anything actually to acknowledge the wait. One of the hostesses seemed very sympathetic but the rest of the staff came across very nonplussed.

-The restaurant had a serious wind tunnel going on, every time the door opened up there was a freezing breeze felt from the hostess stand throughout the restaurant.

-We tried ordering a number of items that they ended up being out of. I get the fact that you run out of something but tell us as we're looking over the menu so we don't get our hearts set on something that you no longer have.

-Some of the food items were laughably small when it came to portion size. I'm looking at you calamari and you baby beets pintxos.

Overall, I was pleased that I was able to try Coqueta so soon after opening but I won't be rushing back until the buzz has died down and the restaurant finds itself in a better groove.
author: phil h.

description:
I wanted to love this place so, so badly. The location is great for the downtown working set, and the views are lovely. With a famous chef and all of these amazing reviews, I was surprised we had such a different experience. 

Our waiter handed out our menu's, and didn't take the time to explain anything. When we did have questions, he was good about answering them if we were very specific, but he seemed more interested in just getting us to add items to our bill. There was no conversation around the things we were interested in enjoying as diners, and just a push to get us to order the more expensive items. 

We ordered a handful of different small plates, and honestly, with the exception of the croquettes, none of them wowed us. Our group loves cocktails and we ordered a variety and passed them around for tasting. We universally agreed that none of them tasted like they really nailed the mix of ingredients. I found myself leaving half of my second cocktail because it was so lackluster... and I am not the person who leaves expensive cocktails in my glass. 

We received the bill which included gratuity even though we were only five people, and it came out to $55 per person for 1.5 cocktails each, and what seriously felt like five bites of food per mouth. 

My suggestion, save your money and head to another amazing Embarcadero location like La Mar, Hard Water or Chaya.
author: Lauren K.

description:
What a fun place! We sat at the communal table and had a few drinks. The atmosphere was chill and our server was very friendly. 
We started with the meat and cheese plate. There were manchego, goat, and blue for cheese, chorizo, salumi(?), and prosciutto for meat. The plate came with quince jam, tomato preserve, marcona almonds and some crackers on the side. The goat cheese was soooo goood! Potatas bravas had aioli and salsa/marinara. Salty and creamy. We then had the wonderful chicory salad and uni with iberico open face sandwich. The sandwich was more like a tartlet. Very tiny albeit delicious. The olive oil that came with the bread was excellent. We even asked for a second round.
For desserts we had the churros and the ice cream and chocolate cookie. I liked the churros here a lot more than the ones at Contigo. They were crunchy and cinnamony. The dish also came with some dehydrated raspberry powder which made the dish. They should start selling those in jars. 
I liked everything about this restaurant. The paella from the couple sitting across from us looked delicious. Will definitely come back for that alone. Well, and the churros.
author: Sunny C.

description: Had a team lunch here with colleagues. Amazing food and sangria! Service was impeccable. Definitely among the better restaurants I've tried in SF. The tapas were especially fantastic. Only negative is that it was really cold inside despite a warm day outside.
author: Tanvi P.

description:
Finally got to try out Coqueta. The service started out uneven, the food was average to good. The menu has enough interesting dishes and there were enough hits that I would go back but I don't think I'll bother with getting a reservation or be in a rush.

We had an 8:45 reservation. When we got there at 8:45 we were told our table wasn't really so we could wait in the bar. No problem but then two different servers tried to give us food menus and when we said we were waiting for our reservation one of them said that we clearly had arrived too early. Then the host came out an said that our table was lingering and was there anyway we would want to eat at the bar. If I had wanted to eat at bar I wouldn't have made a reservation for a table. I didn't mind waiting but the lack of communication and snide comments weren't appreciated.

They did give us two non-alcoholic beverages and a couple small bites for our trouble while we waited. We didn't ask for that and didn't expect it but I think it was nice and appreciated it.

What was odd was that once we were seated there were at least 4 two-top free and the chef himself was presenting dishes to some industry folks. That was the only time we saw him but it's nice to see a celeb chef in his restaurants.

From there the service was pretty good with our main server being informative and helpful. We also had three other people bringing out our dishes and drinks.

The dishes we had:
Pintxos-which are tiny bar snacks that are almost always free in Spain but are $2.50
1.Qual egg Diablo with Jamon was delicious

2.boquerones,anchovies also tasty

Cold tapas
3. house-cured Chiarello Manzailla olives $3-tasty and a good portion with a nice mix

4. Olive oil-poached Delta asparagus with idiazabal cheese and a sangria holandaisse $8
This was good if rather odd with the sangria holandaisse and it was only four spears of asparagus

Montaditos ie. open faced sandwiches although these were smaller than the ones common in spain and were more like canapes

5.Smoked salmon with queso fresco with truffle honey, $8 a play on bagels and lox but the salmon was overpowered by the honey

6.sea urchin with melted lardo with a slice of jamon iberico $14 this was an interesting combo but not exceptional

Hot Tapas
7. Potato Bravas $8 a dish that is literally at every place in Barcelona, the version here is nothing like what you get in Spain, instead of a creamy inside, it's shredded like a tater tot and the sauce is too sweet

8. Grilled Razor Clams with grilled wild ramps and meyer lemon $14 one of the best dishes we had, the clams were cooked perfectly, the ramps and lemon were excellent counterpoints.

9. wod-grilled octopus with fingerling potatoes, pimenton and olive oil $12, this dish was the most similar to it's inspiration. Perfectly cooked octopus and delicous potatoes, it was a bit heavy on the pimenton and the portion was tiny even for a tapas. In Barcelona it would have been twice the portion for a tapas.

10. Grilled Iberico Secreto $22 probably the most disappointing dish. I found the pork overcooked but the tximi-txurri was ok and the watercress salad was dressed very well.

11. Arroz cremosa $22 rice with scallops and english peas. This was a very satisfying dish with lots of flavour, a good portion and nicely seared scallops.

We finished with two desserts. The dessert come in two sizes with smaller single serving treats and larger shared ones.
We got the Sangria Poprocksicles $4, which was basically a sangria granita with poprocks through out the pop. It was very fun to eat but one note in taste not surprisely.

The other dish was a strawberry and rhubarb nitrous frozen ice cream with a rich deep berry sauce. The server had to crack it open and it went everywhere but was a ton of fun to eat and the texture of the frozen treat with the deep flavours of the sauce made it a really interesting dessert.

There is a wide selection of cocktails, a highlighted section of sherry cocktails as well as spanish gin based ones and there was nice selection of non-alcoholic drinks too.

The space is beautiful and surprisingly not very noisy. The lighting is good for the sight impaired and the HOH/deaf and the space was wheelchair accessible. 

When we got there the bar area was less than half full, during dinner the chef's counter was mostly empty and there were empty table in the dining room. On open table there was almost no reservations from 6-8:30 most night which makes me think they are holding tables for walk-ins or doing some reservations by phone only.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
Starting off by saying that my expectations were quite high based on my experience at Chiarello's other restaurant, Bottega (seriously that place has their customer service on point).  So I walked into this joint with the expectation that I was going to be wow'ed again - hence the 1-star off. 

I've been dying to try this restaurant for years and what better excuse to blow hundreds of dollars than for my 25th birthday?  I made reservations weeks in advance and even made a note that I was celebrating my birthday in the OpenTable comments box.  

I arrived before my reservation on a Sunday afternoon- the dining room was beautiful and rustic and it was awesome that they had an area away from the bar space I walk by every day.  At first, I had no idea if I was approaching a hostess - she wasn't wearing any sort of uniform (she was dressed even more casually than I was) and she didn't say anything to me - so after a few seconds of staring at each other, I took a leap of faith and told her that I had a reservation.  Thankfully, I was correct but it was a little odd to me that she didn't say anything first - if you don't have a uniform or dress code, how am I suppose to know that you're a hostess if you don't say anything?  Strange.  

My family and I were shown to our table promptly - truthfully, I was disappointed.  If you make reservations weeks in advance, you'd think that they'd have one of the best tables set aside for you....we were seated by the door in the middle of a high traffic zone - flies kept buzzing around our food and drinks.  When I went to Bottega for my birthday last year, the staff selected a wonderful table on their patio and even had a little card with a birthday greeting - it was seriously awesome.  Coqueta had neither of those.  A smidge disappointing... 

While the staff offered water promptly - it was awhile before we were acknowledged by our server.  But, thankfully, it was all up hill from here - our server was very sweet and helpful.  She took our drink order quickly, had great suggestions for the menu and made sure that we all had a serving of each tapa even though they're usually only three bites.  

The food excelled in some places and left us wanting more in others.  

The El Gran Plat Cap, patatas bravas, and croquetas were AMAZING.  Seriously, I could eat the patatas bravas for the rest of my life.  The albondigas and paella were flavorful, but just didn't wow like we were expecting.  

Drinks were phenomenal - I had the barca gin and tonic and the table had a white sangria that was probably one of the best I've ever had.  

To top of our meal, our waitress surprised me with manchego cheesecake bites for everyone - a really nice touch on a meal that started off a little rocky.

So 1-star off for questionable customer service, but in general, we had a great time and it was a surprisingly filling meal.
author: Jess A.

description: I really wanted to love this place because Michael's other restaurant, Bottega, is one of my top five restaurants of all time. However, the food was just okay. The flavors seemed to be lacking something. The main room is very nicely decorated and you are able to enjoy a beautiful view of the Bay.
author: Josie N.

description:
Delicioso!  Fabulous tapas restaurant, a must try when you are in San Francisco!  Wandered in during a recent crawl of the Embarcadero, and could not have had a better experience!

First, the food is fabulous.  We tried three of the tapas, their pork and duck albondigas (meat balls), the pulpo, and the sunny side up egg.  The albondigas were excellent, very tender and moist, one of the best I have had in a very long time.  The pulpo was beautifully grilled and served with fingerling potatoes, not tough and with a lovely smoky taste.  But the show stopper was the egg, a fried egg served on a gravy made with chorizo, and topped with very thin and crispy shoe string potatoes. I could have eaten at least two of this dish!  Fabulous!!!  There are probably 40 different tapas on the menu, so we will definitely be back to sample the others too!

Although we stuck with some very good Spanish red wine from Toro, we were parked at the bar, so had a ringside seat to watch the bartenders do their magic, and the cocktails looked wonderful and skillfully made ... the assortment of ingredients lining the bar could have made a meal themselves.

Finally, the service was fantastic!  Miguel, one of the bartenders, took care of us, and he was fantastic. Not only was the service good, but he somehow found time to chat with us throughout the evening even though the restaurant was packed.  His personal touch added to the whole experience.
author: Frank W.

description:
I was neither impressed nor displeased with my visit to Coqueta, it was just ok.  Some menu items were good such as Croquetas de Pollo (almost like chicken mozzarella sticks), and the Duck Meatballs.  Other menu items were just ok.  The Bite Size Skewers overall mellow in the flavor department. 

The Paella was mostly rice, the bottom burned to the pan.  Seafood meat was good, but there just wasn't much to it, even split between two people.  All in All it was ok, but I wouldn't get again. 

Drinks are delicious and something not to miss.  Service was just ok as well.  Decor and atmosphere were excellent.  However, would I go back? Honestly?  probably not.
author: Steve A.

description:
I don't get it.   The SF Chronicle went crazy for this place but the few snacks I had were just okay and overpriced.   My razor clams were stone cold, despite being listed in the Hot Tapas section.   Also, they cost $14 for 4 clams.    If you are going to charge Michelin 2-star prices for bar snacks, they should be pretty on point.  

Also, our service was just plain bad.  It was not busy when we got there and it took a long time to get orders in.   We got very little attention afterwards at all,  probably because the layout of the patio makes it so everyone's back is facing the servers and they can barely see if you need anything.  

To be fair I only tried a few things (price tag!)  but I lived in Spain and was excited about this so I am majorly let down.
author: N. C.

description:
This is maybe my favorite place to eat in San Francisco. Their wine list is a nice blend of old world (predominantly Spain) and new world wines.
They have something like 9 different Cavas which is FABULOUS.
