The food is inspired from all different parts of Spain, from the Basque region to southern Spain to Barcelona.

They offer mostly tapas style food-so you can try A LOT! Which is great because everything is so delicious.

The ambiance is party trendy part casual part classy. 

Really this place is so excellent you should go ASAP.
author: Richon S.

description:
Although we had made a reservation, they sat us at the bar area. When I asked about a table they said they could sit us but not sure when, it could be 15-20 minutes of wait until one was available. 
We are from Barcelona and went there to taste some of the foods from home. The food was overall pretty good (except for the tortilla which was mediocre) but service was pretty bad specially for such an expensive place. The waitress forgot about us for a long time between the first round of tapas and the second one. 
Overall, overpriced for what they offer. For Spanish food in SF I still prefer Contigo.
author: patricia p.

description:
Highlight of Saturday lunch at Coqueta was meeting Michael Chiarello himself! He was very gracious and talkative with a lot of the guests.
Coqueta has such a nice feel to it - the decor is impeccable. 
Try gazpacho and crispy shrimp pancake - also the apricot tart for dessert with blue cheese ice cream. What a combo!
Our server was not the brightest star in the sky, he was not very attentive - we ended up asking other runners and bussers questions about the food. We were celebrating an anniversary and he didn't do anything special - all he said was, " I would have brought you cava but I see that you aren't drinking". They should definitely have an alternative, like a free dessert.
author: Ariadne R.

description:
Omg.  An unforgettable experience.  One of the best restaurants I've ever been to.  We tried the white sangria and several different tapas dishes and all were amazing - You have to try the octopus!  It was like butter...so delicate and delicious.  And don't forget the manchego cheesecake!

Great service, great food, great ambience.

My only complaint is that I have to come to San Francisco for it!  If I lived here I would need a second mortgage to afford eating here every day :)
author: Kristen G.

description:
I knew we had to go when Leslie Sbrocco said it was a must.
Well she must know someone on the inside, or like other reviewers mentioned, the owner must have been on hand when they were there.

Our experience was so fraught with inconsistencies I am still processing them all.

We did have a reservation, something to note, reservations are only taken a month out, so everyone has a chance to get the date/time they want, you just need to stay up until midnight a month before you want a reservation.

I personally commend the person who decided to do it this way, one star alone for the possibility of getting a table before my son goes to college.

Now for the dinner.....

Drinks in the bar, were an eye opener. It is as if a vinophile had a hand in the  execution of the drinks. The infusion of favors were taken to a new height with the addition of said favors in the glass, such as star anise.

Taking that one step further, the glasses used, appeared to be a stemless Pinot Noir glass. A large bowl with a smaller rim, to encourage you to waft in the aromatics of the drink before you ever taste it, all my senses were alive, eyes, nose and mouth by these two very different drinks we ordered.

It did not matter which drinks, I noticed everyone's drinks appeared in the same fashion.

A second star for the drinks.

We should have left at this point.

This is a seen and be seen place, way too over run with 'top drawer people'.

Compared to the perfectly executed, Peruvian food at Limon the night before, this restaurant falls short.

Having read many reviews I knew I was looking for the more aggressive items on the menu. We started with the sea urchin with Jamon and breathtakingly thin lardo almost melted on top, you would think this would have been spot on, but it wasn't. The thick, dense and way to dry bread item (something Spanish) it was on did not allow you to enjoy the sea urchin's creaminess, you were far to taken with chewing the bread.

We than ordered the house cured anchovies, let me emphasize, HOUSE Cured.That is why we ordered them, they came right out of the package, bought for $10 a lb. at gourmet food stores, or now Costco.

When I asked about this, I was told they don't always have the fresh anchovies, and these were not fresh.

So that's two down, the pardon peppers were and are a staple, the sliced Jamon really added something, but the menu can't rely on padron's for their review.

The razor clam were a new one to me, and we enjoyed this dish, but the  whole octopus with squid ink aioli, left a lot to your imagination, the squid ink was for color only, it had no flavor, and brought nothing to you're palette. Another poorly executed dish.

We were given desert, because of the anchovies not being as claimed, I would have preferred they just took it off the bill.

Service was good, and the silverware is simply beautiful. The attention to detail was appreciated, I only wish the attention to detail with the food was there.

Overall, I should have gone with my gut, and we should have gone back to Limon for more grilled tongue!
author: Deborah S.

description:
We'd come into Coqueta full of high hopes. Spanish cuisine is our favorite. We've traveled extensively in Catalonia and have eaten at most of the great restaurants as well as many neighborhood Tapas places from Barcelona to San Sebastien. Additionally we are big fans of Michael Chiarrello's Bodega in Yountville. We were excited to get in on opening night. Now, we've been to many restaurant openings (and soft openings) and expect some rough edges. So, this past Saturday night we were not expecting perfection but rather a promise of a great Spanish restaurant. We have several good but no great Spanish places in SF.

Being walk-ins, we were, understandably, relegated to the enclosed, outdoor patio area. Unfortunately we were against the far wall. The bar/table was very narrow and maneuvering plates was tricky. The stools (no chairs in this spot) were small and hard...perhaps one step better than sitting on upwardly protruding nails. I stood for dinner. This space consists of parallel walls of glass and hard surfaces. This is the ideal area for an obscenely loud, a screamingly loud, environment. After a few drinks a lot of the younger gals at the bar just shrieked to be heard. It was on the verge of actual physical pain. Why in the world don't restaurant designers think about these things. The main room, on the other hand, had a far more relaxed, civilized environment...lacking none of the buzz but also allowing for conversation. 

The service was just a bit rough...totally to be expected and maybe a bit better than I was hoping for. The waiter was patient and good natured. On the other hand, another waiter brought me an order of razor clams when I'd ordered the savory Manila clams and tried to convince me that what he was giving me was what I'd ordered. We both knew better. 

Now for the food. The phrase that comes to mind is "tourist trade."  The food was so very disappointing both in preparation and conception. The Savory clams arrived barely warm. The Jamon Iberico de Bellota was sliced too thick and served with croutons rather than bread. The portion size was *far* too small for $30. I know what this kind of jamon costs it ain't cheap. However, there is no excuse for the meager portion of the lack of art in slicing it. The marcona almonds were fine. The Chicken and English pea croquets with cured cara-cara oranges was the best dish of the evening. Very good...the oranges made the dish. The Roasted Padron peppers with Jamon Serrano was OK. The peppers a bit mushy. The "Tatta" Bravas were a joke...watery tater tots. How do you screw up an iconic dish so badly? Why screw with patatas bravas like this? Ego?

How did this place wind up like this? I can forgive the opening night jitters and rough edges and the outside space need a dramatic rethink. The menu...at least what we had...was such a major disappointment that I don't think we'll bother coming back.

1.5 stars
author: Gary C.

description:
This is definitely my favorite restaurant in the city right now.  State Bird really made me appreciate the small-plate / tapas style of restaurant.  It's exciting trying lots of different dishes with your friends, the plates come out faster, and the meal is more evenly paced.  Coqueta is a fantastic restaurant, and between the location (Embarcadero is really nice, and it's convenient for me) and the excellent drinks it's really won me over. 

First, the drinks... the Revolution gintonic ($12) is the one to pick if it's your first time.  Some of their drinks are hit-or-miss, and this one is a hit.  Engine Co. #5 ($13) is also good if you like Manhattans; it's very similar to one.  I didn't enjoy the Championship "Policy" ($12) much, so I wouldn't get that.

Most of the food is good; you really can't go wrong.  They bring around a platter of toothpick-skewers ($2.50 ea.) (you might want to explicitly request it to get your meal started while you order).  The Quail Egg "Diablo" on the platter is a must-try, and I also enjoyed the Boquerones, even though I don't usually like olives.  They've had the Paella (don't remember the price) as a special each time I've gone and it's also good if you want to get filled up at the end.  You need to order it at the beginning of your meal though because it takes 40 minutes to make.  Beyond that, try a bunch of stuff!

The last thing I want to say is I've really enjoyed the wait staff, or one in particular.  We had Brook (dunno if I'm spelling her name right) our first visit, and since then I've always tried getting one of her tables.
author: Steve D.

description:
-------------LUNCH ONLY----------
This restaurant JUST opened (hell, it didn't even show up on Google Maps yet) and I came here for their 2nd time opening for lunch. My cousin recommended this place since she had just eaten it for dinner over the weekend and loved it. Good call cousin, good call.

Ambiance: Beautiful! So much natural light (esp on a sunny day) and it's so open. There's a bar area and the dining area but both are so casual yet really modern. I think people would like this place just for that.

Service: Friendly, attentive

FOOD: It's tapas-style with most dishes being pretty small portioned but a few being a bigger size. I recommend ordering a bunch of small plates and ordering a larger entree (the pasta, etc.) as a filler. If you're a stickler on cash, then this place is a little more pricey but it's along the price range of all the other Embarcadero restaurants.

-Mar y montana, sea and mountain: Sea urchin on a baguette to me. Pretty huge slice of uni and while the taste is really subtle, still good. 

-Sunny side up egg: I loved this. It's got a ton of crispy crunch on the top that added great texture.

-Asparagus: Okay it's 3 freakin' pieces of asparagus with some light pink sauce but it was actually pretty good! Worth ordering? I don't know but I was surprised by how much I liked such a simple dish. 

-The vermecelli pasta - This was the biggest dish we ordered and while it's good, it looked & almost tasted just like the sunny sideup egg dish. So....meh

-Limonada (non-alcoholic) - Big fan.

Lunch for 2 came out to roughly $71 before tip to give you an idea of how much lunch is. Still, I'm a fan and I plan on bringing my husband back here to try it.
author: Diana Y.

description: Best part was meeting chef Michael Chiarello. He was such a sweetie. Food was good, definitely tapas since it was so small in portion and over price for the size of the portion I thought. Paella was good but wish their was more shrimp & chirizo in it. The churros dessert was amazing!
author: Amanda N.

description:
Tapas are always a mix of pros and cons but somehow Coqueta satisfied all my wants. The restaurant is right on the embarcadero with plenty of parking (albeit expensive) around. It's a very unassuming place from the outside, but the inside is very nicely decorated and sets a napa valley like mood right in the heart of the city. 

We started our meals by trying the quail egg skewers as well as the sunny side up egg and wood grilled octopus. Each dish was very well balanced and gave you enough to fill your need while keeping your pallet intrigued. Now for tapas, some complain that while you get to taste a variety of flavors you'll leave hungry and with a large bill. However, we ordered the paella and steak/pork shoulder and we were more than full. 

Moreover, the staff was extremely enthusiastic and helpful throughout the night. Whether it's wine pairings or what dishes are popular they always offered advice and honest opinions about the dishes. 

My only regret is not being able to try their cocktails, but hopefully I'll be back!

***Tip: Reservations are hard to come by, but if you book on a Sunday or Monday you can usually swipe a table.
author: Robert T.

description:
Awesome, awesome. Walking in there at 10 pm on Sunday, I was highly skeptical and doubtful due to the hypes this place has been receiving.. and the impossibility of snagging a table made the restaurant a bit suspicious. 

Every dish this place served us was spot-on: they were adventurous, creative and delicious. I even went out of my comfort zone and ordered a cocktail, and it was just delightful.

I see how some people might think it's a bit overpriced, but hey, if you want to dine around Embarcadero, you're also paying for the view (and the colossal amount of rent that comes with it).. and the artistry of the food. We ordered 7 tapas and their chocolate cake with two cocktails which came up to be $117 dollars and we were very well-fed. I don't think people should complain all that much.
author: Sung C.

description:
If I had written this review after my first visit here, they would have definitely received 5 stars. However my 2nd visit a few weeks ago was not as impressive. 

We had a friend visiting from NY and we were super excited to let him try Chiarello's new place, but all our favorite dishes fell short this time. I honestly think it's because Chiarello was at Bottega that evening, when he had been front and center our first experience. 

Usual Favorites:
Chicken croquette - luke warm
Asparagus w/ sangria salsa - super flavorless, needed some salt
Fried egg w/ shimp - bland

The drinks were still on point, so thank goodness for that! I'm in love with their sangria w/ coke and cinnamon!!!

TIP: So far 1 for 2, hopefully it will be more consistent the next time we dine here.
author: Kristen C.

description:
I'm sure this place has its legion of fans, but really this place is for people who have money to burn. Honestly, I don't even remember what we ate...yea, it was that memorable. Going in, I was very excited about this new tapas joint...I love tapas. But alas! it was a disappointing experience. 

For the price they charge, I expected more...more flavor, more food, more of everything. It seems to me that they're trying so hard to be innovative that they've forgotten the basics of preparing food. We had to order quite a few plates to be full. It cost me over $120 for 2 people, and we don't even drink alcohol. 

In sum, too crowded, too expensive, too loud, too pretentious, too...well, you get the picture. 

The one star is for our wait service, but the receptionist had made me wait in the cold, windy outside for my friend to arrive. Well, how about waiting in the bar area, you might wonder...good luck trying to squeeze in.
author: Lil D.

description: I work in the city and eat at Coqueta periodically.  Today was like most times I have been there.  Exceptional food and great wait service, and a completely obnoxious manager who gets in the way of the hostess and seats you at the bar even though there are plenty of tables and we had made a reservation  and asked for an opportunity to be seated at a table so we could do some business over tapas.  This guy is a complete jerk and rude, and takes away from what would be a 5 star experience.
author: Steven C.

description: Four  stars for what we had! I recommend the Iberia jamon Serrano, $12 , which was served with tasty honeydew melon chunks and small crispy finger sized bread. A lit bit of evoo drizzled over the dish goes a long way. Simple, delish and super tasty. The heirloom gaspacho was flavorful and smooth with a bit of kick to it. The chicken and pea coquettas tasted just like fried chicken pot pie. And the calamari was not fried but served in a bed of squid ink and with some greens on the side. Overall, yummrs! The place fills up quick so come when it's not busy and when you don't need a reservation which would be closer to when it opens at 11:30am!!
author: Laurel P.

description:
Yes!  Yes, yes, yes.

Beautiful location and aesthetic.  Great selection on the menu, evocative of all of your favorites from Spain.  

Of course, this is is an Americanized version of Spain's greatest hits, this is Chiarello, after all.  But the items are solid and overall interesting, with some major hits and some misses, too.  You get the feeling they are still developing their standards.  But the good ones were very good.  Portions vary wildly, as does seasoning.  You get the feeling that they are working out kinks.

Service was mostly good, but with some bad advice from our server (steered us toward more bland items).  Drinks were great.  

I will definitely be coming back here.  Four stars mostly for potential, and for a great place to meet up near the ferry building.  Probably three stars for actual food.  

Still, we are excited about this place and hopeful that they will continue to develop the portions, flavors, and cohesion in the menu.
author: Kate I.

description:
Just visited the bar on my way out of the city. Luis is an artist with all things gin. He even made a special drink that was incredibly refreshing for a nice summer day and kept up fantastic conversation. 

I look forward to checking out the food next time I'm in town.
author: Jon C.

description:
If you like a well made cocktail, Coqueta is your place. Their cocktail program is amazing. Lots of foam-topped drinks, or espuma, as it's called in Coqueta-land. In true Spanish style, there are seven varieties of gin and tonics from which to choose. Until going to Barcelona two years ago, I had no idea the G&T was such a thing in Spain. 

We ate in the covered bar annex, which is the only way to go if you don't have a reservation, which we didn't. 

The tapas are expensive! with prices ranging between $8-13/plate. The Spanish tortilla -- which is the benchmark I use for whether or not a Spanish restaurant is really as good as it says it is -- was good. I appreciated that the menu featured a variety of pintxos, those toothpick-laden bites that are popular in parts of Spain. This is the first menu I've seen in the US with those delicious bites of pintxos goodness. 

I was impressed with the authenticity of the menu, although I wish the experience was a little lighter on the wallet.
author: Lee H.

description:
One of the few places that can make a dish look pretty and taste amazing at the same time. We came with a party of 4 on a Sunday for lunch. (I think reservations on open table are easier to come by during lunch). We ordered a bunch of dishes and my favorite was the steak. I do have to point out that the dishes are pretty small, so you do have to order a good amount to feel full. Another table ordered a seafood platter consisting of two whole crabs. I can't remember if it was on the menu or not, but the plate looked so incredibly amazing! Even the staff stopped to take photos of it.

Also, don't forget to order the gin and tonic. It's the prettiest drink I've ever ordered and it tasted great too! And that's coming from someone who doesn't even like gin and tonics. 

We spent about $200 for 4 people for lunch. Pricey, but definitely worth it.
author: Lily Z.

description:
I know Coqueta has an unbelievable amount of hype due to it's celebrity chef pedigree, but the food really doesn't live up to the hype. 

Some of the dishes were delicious (heirloom tomatoes, potatoes), but the meat dishes we ordered (spare ribs, pork shoulder) were both overcooked, leaving them chewy. The pork (which my served described as the "kobe beef of pork") was especially disappointing, especially considering the whopping $38 price for a smallish plate of pork that came totally a la carte. In the middle, the churros dessert was pretty so-so, and certainly not worth the $11 we paid. 

Service was very attentive and friendly. I'd go back with friends (if they can get a reservation!) but won't be rushing back myself.
author: Aaron L.

description: I'm tired of paying $75pp for a meal that leaves me hungry still!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Finally a restaurant with food to match this beautiful space on the waterfront at Pier 5.  It also didn't hurt that Chef Chiarello was there for nearly the entire night making sure that the food was spot on and that the dining experience was warm, exciting and entertaining.  He seemed to spend at least a few minutes conversing with every table, and even, personally picked out a bottle of rioja to go with our meal.  The wine was delicious (Allende 2006 Rioja), as was the food.

There were lots of hits.  The Ensalade Resorte, Vineyard Greens, wood-grilled octopus, Pluma (pork shoulder loin with honey glaze), and dessert were all excellent.  Not all the dishes quite hit the mark.  The croquetas were a little heavy (though the orange with hot pepper was awesome), some of the potatoes we had weren't seasoned, and the gin and tonics were a great idea but not completely balanced (one was a over-limey, the other was just a little muted).

Service was warm and helpful throughout the evening.  So, probably a 4 if I were to grade just on food, but combined with the service and ambience and the fact that this was something like their third night in operation, Coqueta deserves all 5 stars.

Pro tip #1:  The Pluma is unlike any pork you've had, reminiscent of kobe if it were steak or toro if it were tuna.  

Pro tip #2: For the love of god, get dessert.  We had a little bite of caramel cheesecake on a popsicle stick served with warm caramel corn, oh and, a warm apple tart with (light) blue cheese ice cream just to finish things off.  Both were homeruns.
author: Zac A.

description:
I came here recently with my family to celebrate my birthday. I love tapas but not the price you pay. We ordered plenty of dishes such as uni and lardo open faced sandwich, iberico ham, octopus, quail, paella, branzino and more. Overall I enjoyed all the dishes but in the end, I was still very hungry. 

The service was a bit slow as it took the waiter about 20 minutes to deliver water and about 30 minutes to take our order. Once they took our order the food came out at a steady pace.

One thing I wished was that they had more bathrooms. The usual wait time is about 5-10 minutes.

Overall I would definitely come again, but only for a special occasion.
author: Sean W.

description:
I really like the service and the environment The food was good and it came at  great pace. We sat at the bar because we couldn't get reservations. We saw everything being prepared. It was really nice. It's amazing how many people they employ here. Each person has their own task.

Things we had:

Grilled Octopus - Amazing! Probably my favorite tapas
Had a few skewers - Really good but I can probably make that at home and save my $2.50.
Chef's Meat & Cheese selection - Really good!
White sardines - great presentation in a sardine tin. Very delicious.
Pluma (pork shoulder) - I really liked this. There was a nice sweet glaze. Delicious!
Shrimp thing... - Also very good. I believe it was grilled
Uni tapas thing... - this was only ok. I just didn't like the way it was prepared...
Must Have Dessert - It's basically a chocolate molten cake. I don't think it's a must have....
Churros - Now this is a MUST HAVE. What's better than Fresh Hot churros with chocolate sauce???? Actually..... If they served it with coffee and whip cream.... Then it's to die for!
author: Karen L.

description:
With the 150th anniversary of the Port of San Francisco upon us, we have much to celebrate. Our waterfront is home to a jewel of a ball park, the new Exploratorium, a state of the art cruise terminal, and the excitement of the America's Cup. And now, without much fanfare, a very special restaurant has landed in our neighborhood: Michael Chiarello's, Coqueta. 

Chef Michael comes to San Francisco on the heels of his successful wine country restaurant, Bottega, which was awarded a place on the Chronicle list of top 100 restaurants in its first year of operation. This was only the most recent of Chef Michael's accolades. Shortly after graduating from the Culinary Institute in New York, after opening a restaurant in Miami, he was named Chef of the Year by Food and Wine Magazine. Ten years later the Culinary Institute of America awarded him the same honor. The chef has ventured into television on PBS and The Food Network, his shows garnering three straight Emmy awards. He also writes cookbooks. Perusing one, I learned more about cooking in the first 20 pages than I have ever learned from a cookbook.  Reading it, I became aware of the chefs philosophy of cooking: "Food should tell a story with a sense of taste and place."

But at this time in his life Chef Michael has come back to his first love:  running a restaurant.  He is doing it by covering all the bases. He owns a sustainable 20 acre farm in the wine country which supplies much of the produce needed at his ventures.  Referring to Coqueta, he told me, "Spanish Cuisine is more challenging than my Italian cuisine at Bottega, as I have been more careful about keeping to true tradition." Though," he admits, "I have added some vegetables for Californians, as you have to practically beg for a vegetable in Spain." 

The restaurant is divided into two sections.  Michael acquired the small building next to Pier 5, a dilapidated awninged structure, and turned it into a glass-enclosed room with views of the Bay and The Embarcadero. The room houses Coqueta's bar as well as space for casual dining. The main dining room, entered through this area, is located in the bulkhead building itself and features a seating bar where one can watch the goings on in the kitchen.

The menu is uncomplicated but intense. The first option is one of the beautifully presented sliced, in-house cured meat and Iberian cheese plates. Although we didn't try one of these platters, on a next trip, we will go with friends and order the large, El Plat Cap that comes with olive oil tortas and pan de cristal con tomate, the only bread Coqueta serves (the chef explained that bread is not traditionally served in Spain). This bread is made locally by Panorama Bakery for Coqueta. The only other bakery making it is in Barcelona. 

Chef Michael has an innovative winner in his "minis". These one bite offerings are ordered or taken from a beautiful board, passed around by a server. Of the five offered, I found the Chorizo, roasted artichoke and piquillo peppers delectable, with the artichoke and peppers providing a creamy, rich texture that buffered the chewy but tender chorizo. Another favorite was the Quail egg Diablo. The delicate tiny egg paired beautifully with the pickled mustard seed and small piece of Serrano ham. 

Keeping with tradition, the restaurant serves both hot and cold tapas.  Of the cold tapas, two really stand out. Hands down the restaurant's most winning dish is Ensalada resorte.  The preparation comes in a glass with a vibrant and silky English green pea emulsion at the bottom layered with spring vegetables, sieved egg and Serrano ham croutons.  Another favorite, the Delta asparagus, is both beautiful and flavorful. The large stalks are trimmed back to the delicate white and are poached in olive oil, topped with grated smoky Idiazabal firm goat cheese and Serrano ham bits and accompanied by piquillo pepper aioli. 

Of the hot tapas, the wood grilled octopus is scrumptious. It is fired on the grill, with the body firm but tender, the tentacles crispy. This dish is served with roasted fingerling potatoes, drizzled with olive oil and dusted with pimento powder.  Another standout: the Sunny side-up egg dish, with shrimp, crispy potato and chorizo dressing. As Chef Michael says, "I've always believed anything goes for breakfast, so breakfast should go at anytime, too." I believe him. 

Among the entrées, the winner is the mouth-watering Pluma, a pork shoulder loin imported from Spain especially for Chef Michael. This is the most expensive dish on the menu but easily shared, which makes it the least expensive of the entrees. The preparation time is 30 minutes but the time goes by quickly when you are eating tapas. This tender loin, easily cut with your fork, has a honey-chili glaze. 

We have a super star chef and a super star restaurant at a super star location. The Embarcadero just keeps getting better and better.
author: Carol P.

description: AMAZING. the food was delish. We were sitting next to an open door and it got cold, we asked them to close it and they wouldn't, that's my only complaint, but the food made up for it. hope to get back there soon.
author: Jessica H.

description: This place is grade A, 100%. The ambiance is fantastic Scotty has got to be in the running for best waiter in America, ( waiter is a derogatory term for this guy. ) food is exceptional. They need to clean the windows. But AWESOME.
author: Duncan L.

description:
I was floored by our experience.    The standouts:

'Tattas" Bravas
Grilled razor clams with meyer lemon and wild ramps
Chicken and English Pea croquetas with cured cara cara orange
Tortilla 'Andres' with sweet onion, etc.

I was most impressed by the staff.  We went on opening night and you would think that they've been operating there for years.   I will definitely be back.
author: Fred X.

description:
Sexy place, unique cocktails, and very good spanish tapas with a californian twist. 

Thank God I didn't know that it's owned by Michael Chiarello at the time I went, or I probably wouldn't have tried it in the first place. 

Go and be ruthless for the seats!
author: Yuchi C.

description:
We're fans of Chiarello's Bottega in Napa, so we were excited to hear about his new tapas restaurant right on the Embarcadero. Our group of 7 scored reservations at 5.30p  and even got to meet Chef Chiarello after dinner

Dinner:
- Pintxos Platter: Server came around with a beautiful and colorful platter of little bites on sticks. I tried pretty much everything on the tray; spicy chorizo with cheese, quail egg with proscuitto etc. - all were tasty
- Sea Urchin Crostini: Loved the generous serving of uni spread on the toasted crostini. The thin slice of speck drizzled with a sweet sauce (honey?) was delicious. Highly recommend
- Tator Tots: Someone in the group who wasn't very adventurous decided she needed this in case things got crazy at dinner. It was OK
- Almond Gazpacho: Gorgeous presentation, but not my fave dish. It was a strange mix of dessert sweet and a kick of savory
- Crispy Shrimp: Delicious. Perfectly fried and great for sharing
- Meatballs: Again, ordered by the not-so-adventuruos person. It was OK. 
- Sunny side up shrimp: Would make a great b'fast dish
- Grilled Razor Clams: Yummy; perfectly done, not overgrilled
- Grilled Iberico Pork: Juicy and succulent; loved
- Paella: Beautiful presentation, one of the best paella i've had. Not overdone, not dry. Tasty
- Crab: Succulent, juicy
- Plumas- grilled pork shoulder: Delicious! Loved the flavors. One of my fave dishes of the night. Highly recommend
- Grilled Octopus: Again, perfectly grilled, not overcooked, very tender. Not sure that the potatoes go well with this dish though...
- Churro: Yummy. I mean, it's fried. What's not to like?
- Creme Brulee: It was OK

Great ambience, great location on the water. HIghly recommend
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Great service! I really liked the vibe here.The bartender was super nice. Best Bloddy Mary I've ever tried! I will definitely be coming back to Coqueta on my next trip to the city.
author: Laura M.

description:
I had read about the opening of Coqueta on 7x7, and since I had heard many good things about Bottega, decided Coqueta would have good food. 

My girlfriend made a reservation for 7 at 5:30 p.m. on a Sunday night - yeah, reservations were pretty difficult to come by. I arrived a little early, and the maitre d offered to seat us first. 

We ordered many things on the menu - between the 7 of us, we probably ordered 11 hot/cold tapas, and 3 of the bigger dishes. The tapas were pretty small in size - I'd say you could have 4 people to 1 dish at most. We also got 2 of the pitcher drinks to share. Everything was good and flavorful - almost a little too flavorful at time, but I enjoyed every bit. Just a bit of warning - the peppers under the hot tapas were spicy HOT! 

We got 2 orders of the churros for dessert, which were yummy. Our server was very attentive, and helpful in making recommendations. Total came out to $53 after tip, which I thought was very reasonable for a place like this. 

Parking is also easy if you don't mind paying - definitely a plus. I'll definitely come back again once the hype has died down.
author: Kimberly F.

description: This review is strictly for the bar and not restaurant.  Ambience is awesome!  Located on the side of Pier 5, this bar gives you a feel of hip romance.  We had the chicken croquette, the kale salad, and shishito peppers.  All was very good.  Pricing is as expected of a bar in the city.  One thing I was disappointed with was Michael didn't include his incredible truffle fries...but over all solid 4.
author: Dee Dee L.

description:
This place has all the potential to be a great place, unfortunately it is not there yet.
Seems like nothing is working in the right way. 
Food is extremely overrated.
Service is not professional at all.
We were here twice and both times we kept getting things we never ordered ! ( and I don't mean the tapas)
I don't see any reason to go there again.
author: Marios B.

description: Super fancy boozy cocktails! The music was perfectly Spanish and they've got a lovely open kitchen.
author: Ian S.

description:
Maybe I set the bar too high going in... I LOVE LOVE LOVE Bottega.  (Maybe one of my top 3 favorite dining experiences ever.)  But I just didn't feel Coqueta hit the mark.

The good was good.  Not great.  But good.
The Mar y Montana (uni cracker) and smoked salmon with truffled oil were both terrific.  Really great.  Everything else was good.  Not great, but good.  

We ordered a number of tapas and a paella.  
They could have done a better job spacing out the tapas because they all came on top of each other (with uncomfortable bus service) that felt rushed and then we waited for the paella.  Which, to be fair, we totally understood would take up to 45 minutes - so space out the rest of the meal, is my point.  

And the service: I was pushed into and reached over so many times I lost count.  Lacking finesse.  
Our waitress was WONDERFUL!  She was great.  Can't say enough great things about her.  And the front of the house host was lovely as well.  Charming gentleman.

So like I said - it was good, not great.  Some parts were great, others not so much - which earns 3 stars in my book.  I was hopeful and expecting a 5 star experience from the pedigree of Coqueta's founders and head chef.  

I'll go back - but probably not for a little while.  Plenty of other places in SF that hit the mark a little better than Coqueta.
author: Christie d.

description:
Good drinks. Food is aiiiiiight. Nothing special and a bit pricey for the quality.  I've been 4 times now since the opening, and my excitement never appears when making reservations to this place.  The staff is pretencious, the food is mediocre, and, although I usually dont feel bad for spending $ on food, I never feel like my money was worth the quality/experience.  

It's good ambience, and if you have out-of-towners visiting, its a good place for a late lunch & drinks on a sunny SF day.
author: Chieko H.

description: Absolutely delicious!! We had the chicken croquetas, fried batatas, and two orders of the "sunny side up". The sangria was tasty  as well!! Friendly service and great atmosphere!  Great place!!
author: Liliana B.

description: Loved every bite! Cocktails are amazing, too. While they serve small plates, the plates are good sized. Everyone has a wonderful time!
author: Janell H.

description:
I'm giving this place 5-stars because when the flavors of food in my mouth dance and excite me - the chef, in my opinion, has hit a home run. 

I went with a small group, and we ordered a boatload of tapas, some glorious wine, and ended with a paella.  Each of the tapas was lovely, an assortment of flavors that excited my tongue and left me wanting more. The tapas kept coming to the table, we kept eating, and before you know it, I'm getting full.  

Then the paella arrived. I felt a little hungry again. The rice was moist with a good bite, the seasoning, the chorizo, shellfish all combined to make a fantastic dish. Oh, and the crispy edges of the paella that were crusty and sticking the pan - we fought over those. Crunchy, tasty... I think we all wanted more. 

This place is on Pier 5, with comfortable cozy décor. It was very full, and I saw people waiting to be seated. So clearly they are doing very well. 

I highly recommend this restaurant - you will enjoy it.
author: Marc W.

description: Always love this place and have been coming since it opened.  Really enjoy all dishes and flavors. It's a great place for brining out of town guests, meeting friends, and trying many different flavors. It's tapas and therefore yes they are small plates just like in Spain. The point is to try many different bites... It is not inexpensive but this is that kind of a place.
author: Gari C.

description:
I was disappointed in my meal here and I'm not sure if it's due to the fact that we ate at the bar (Bar Five) versus the restaurant but I believe the menu is the same at both so I would hope the quality of the food and the service shouldn't be vastly different.  

There were some meal highs - the croquetas and "Fantasia" de Fideua were really excellent and I have a feeling if it was available the Mar y montaña, sea and mountain was going to be outstanding (they ran out of sea urchin that night unfortunately).  However, I thought the other things I tried were good but not really noteworthy (boquerones, salmon and truffle honey open faced sandwich, sausage, and pimientos).  

The areas where this place really disappointed were in the service and the cocktails. The service was....cold, a little snide, and dare I say borderline bitchy.  I was really surprised because Coqueta is a nice place and I usually find service in San Francisco to be really great (when thinking of east coast vs west coast service).  But the servers came across as haughty and rude and like they couldn't be bothered to check on us.  Again, I'm not sure if this is a bar vs restaurant situation but if you get bad service at the bar, why would you ever want to come back and eat at the restaurant?  At one point, we asked a server who delivered one of our tapas if we could order an additional dish from her or if we should wait for our original waiter and her tone and response was basically akin to I've kinda got my hands full, don't bother me which was really off putting.  One server was friendly and enthusiastic but after at least 2 servers with attitude, I wasn't really pleased with the service.  As for the drinks, there are a lot of interesting and unique cocktails on the menu.  They are described in vivid detail and I was quite excited to try some of these drinks.  However, I think Coqueta suffers from incredible creative cocktails that I don't think work at all with the food on the menu or maybe even by themselves.  I'm all for trying something new when it comes to cocktail combinations but I don't understand why these two cocktails were even on the menu; the flavors are so overwhelming that I cannot imagine them working well with any of the tapas.  The Dirty by the Sea was a seaweed influenced vodka with a sea anemone and it looked wonderful with the sea anemone but it was so incredibly briny that it tasted exactly like when you go snorkeling and accidentally swallow sea water, it's honestly that salty and briny.  It was overwhelming to the palate and I could only see it working if you ate a plate of boiled potatoes with no seasonings.  I also tried In the Haight which I ordered primarily for the description of its "patchouli memory".  I mean, how can you resist a description like that?  However, the only memory that lingered was the smoky flavor of my vodka that while not as off putting as the Dirty by the Sea, it was still so strong that it bordered on palate destroying.  I felt like someone locked me in a meat smoker after drinking this thing.  I really don't understand the place of such strong drinks on a menu filled with pretty flavorful tapas.  

Even though the food was probably a three star experience, I was so disappointed by the service and the cocktails that I have to give this a two star review because I was really excited to try this place due to the stellar reviews and this was a real let down for me.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I really like this place, it totally reminds me of Spain.  I just came back a few weeks ago and by far it's the best tapas I've had in SF.  Actually before I never cared for tapas until I went to Spain and had the real deal.  This place has authentic dishes that Spain offers but it may not taste exactly the same, but pretty damn close.  They have a cool spot with an indoor dining area and an semi outdoor bar area.  I would definitely recommend making reservations. 

As for food - we loved the 1st  dish under rice & paellas & the sunny side up egg dish are the highlights.  We also tried the manchego & jamon bocadillo, tattas bravas, uni montadito, coquetas, and shrimp cakes.  Also, the sangria & kalimotxo are delicious and refreshing.  

I wasn't thrilled when I showed up on time for my reservation with an empty dining room and they refused to seat us anywhere but the chef's counter.  Doesn't make sense...but it all worked out.
author: Meredith K.

description:
I would have rated this place higher if it weren't for the host.  Went here for brunch on a Saturday with two little ones and the host seemed to reluctantly seat us.  Fail.  Luckily, our waiter was very nice and accommodating which almost redeemed the host's rude behavior.

The food was a bit on the salty side and lacked the authentic Spanish flavors of a true tapas dish.  Their beef ribs which was the special of the day was a bit confusing as it had a more Asian flavor than Spanish.  

The dessert with caramel popcorn was delicious and NOT meant for sharing as you'd want this all to yourself.

One other thing, loved the interior of the restaurant...chairs looked really cool but not very comfy.
author: Em D.

description:
Really enjoyed this place, walked over after an America's cup race, definitely worth the trek!

We stood in the bar/patio area outside and really enjoyed a bit of everything:

The Chef's selection of cured meats and cheese was well sought out
Padron Peppers were a bit smoky but not spicy, good balance
Monterey Calamari not your average calamari! but delicious and meaty!

One of the best items on the menu: Crispy Shrimp And Chickpea Flour Pancake!!! 
Such a unique take on shrimp, kind of like a large crab cake with a batter! super delicious, 1 order is good for 2 people

We ordered a pitcher of Rebujito, a very refreshing drink on a warm afternoon

can't wait to go back and try some of the dinner items, pending we can get a table in the dining room!
author: Kiran J.

description:
If you're looking to spend a day drinking by the water, this is the place. We spent our last day in San Fran doing a bar hob along the Embarcadero and landed at Coqueta for a majority of the day. To be fair, this was the second time I three days we spent at Coqueta. I loved all of the drinks--all of the ingredients were so thoughtful and balanced. My hubs had a margarita with salt foam and it really tasted like salt! 

We never had any of the entrees to speak of, but the tapas and snacks were decent. As a deviled egg aficionado these were just meh. Definitely snacks are needed as you drink all these fantastic drinks otherwise you'll end up on your butt by the end of the night. 

Love the vibe--if I was a local I'd spend all of my paycheck there.
author: Meghan S.

description: freakin amazing ass meal. my friend and her husband and I were attending a wedding in the city and were lucky to score reservations. we ordered a charcuterie board, clams, meatballs, uni, salmon croquettes, paella, pork shoulder, and some potatoes. everything was SO good. the paella was to DIE for and the salmon croquettes were very good as well. of everything if I HAD to skip one next time, it would probably be the long neck clams. their sangria was fantastic as well. need to come back soon. it was everything.
author: Tina N.

description:
I was quite fortunate to know the date Coqueta was opening. I was walking down the Embarcadero that day and wanted to stop in to see what it looked like, and maybe have a drink.  When I poked my head in they politely said that they would be open after 5:00 pm. 

I returned at 6:00 pm to get a drink.  I was greeted most pleasantly by the hostess and Michal Iglesias, the manager.  They kindly explained that it was opening night and they had no available tables.  Not surprised, I told them that I only wanted to have a drink and look inside.  I went to the bar and said I liked bourbon and asked for their best drink.  As a long time bourbon drinker from the South, I was most surprised by the drink they served which was one of the most unique and exquisite drinks I have had in a long time. The ingredients were unusual and the taste surprising.

Within 10 minutes I was approached by the hostess who asked if my date and I would like to eat at the bar.  We of course accepted the invitation, and were seated with a great view of the kitchen.  We immediately noticed the decor accentuated by the beautiful painting on the walls.

I was first introduced and fell in love with Tapas in a random bar in Pamplona.  Ever since I have experimented with different Tapas restaurants in Los Angeles and San Francisco.  This was the first place I have been to that captured the authenticity of what I was familiar with in Pamplona, with added elegance and much better service.  

Mo, our server, was knowledgeable and creative.  I looked at the menu once to order, and afterwards I trusted his judgment.  After inquiring about what I basically liked, he continually surprised me with food I probably would not have ordered, but that I loved.  His explanations were thorough without being over the top.  I was impressed that when Michael was not running the kitchen, he was speaking with every guest.  His visit with us was sincere and personal.  All in all in was one of the most surprising restaurant experiences I have enjoyed.
author: Thomas B.

description: The most beautiful cocktails I've ever seen. Tons of gourmet small plates - we ordered four and got full! Everything tasted wonderful, even the octopus. So, I say try it all! You won't be disappointed. An experience we'll never forget.
author: Laura F.

description:
An amazing experience that should not miss out on!
The food was exquisite and I highly recommend the Gulf Prawns and Paella. Our service was unbelievably attentive as well as he had a great understanding of the menu choices.
author: Jan M.

description:
The interior at Coqueta is beautiful.  You really feel like you're somewhere special when you sit in the dining room - high ceilings, beautiful soft neutral colors and oversized tall shelves filled with interesting bottles, dishes, etc.  But it's really the food that's the star. We went for lunch, and while it's a bit pricey, the food is delicious and very true to the Spanish tapas and pintxos we had in Barcelona a month earlier.  The grilled octopus is fantastic, and our friends had the meat and cheese platter which had a bit of everything, including the requisite "jamon."  I had the cheesecakes for dessert - two bite-sized cheesecakes that were perfect!  I'm still thinking of them. 
I think Coqueta is a great addition to the San Francisco food scene and hope to eat there again very soon.
author: Barbara R.

description:
Yummy!!  Coqueta is a wonderful and beautiful restaurant at Pier 5 in San Francisco.  I recentl enjoyed a late afternoon lunch with friends and everything thing we ordered ( 7 tapas) was delicious.  This restaurant and its menu does remind me of many great meals at tapas bars in Madrid. The menu is on the small side with hand picked tapas that represent Spain beautifully and the quality of the food is perfection.  There are also family style meals for two to four,  like the paella.

The tapas' were very creative and delicious, my favorite was the chicken and English pea croquettes and the egg and shrimp. And my favorites dessert was the fig tartlette with blue cheese ice cream, savory and yet just sweet enough. 


The restaurant is an amazing mixture of industrial and Spanish flair with plastered and textured grey walls and long dramatic curtains over large expansive windows with ocean views.  

Lunch at Coqueta is a great choice and actually quite affordable considering the quality of the food and the excellent service.
author: Edna C.

description: Coqueta is an absolutely amazing restaurant! The cocktails are amazing and are presented beautifully, the food is delicious, and the staff really go the extra mile to make you feel accommodated! Great for date night or just having cocktails with friends!
author: Blair W.

description:
Disappointing.  I expected great things given the reviews I read.  I love tapas and have spent some time in Spain.  The cocktails are fantastic.  We tried 6 of them between the 2 of us and all were creative and great.  The food was disappointing.  

Skewers - small and just not impressive
The beef and pork meatballs were great, but I think anything tastes good with those little crunchy onion things on top.
The shrimp with egg and potatoes was tasty albeit a bit of a random combo.  But potatoes, egg, chorizo, and shrimp all = good
The paella was bleh.  The chorizo and clams were over cooked. The rice tasted  better once we mixed the aioli in, but what wouldn't?  And should we really have to do that to make paella taste good?  Totally not worth the $40 price.
Mini Desserts were yummy.  The manchego cheesecake pops were awesome, as was the olive oil ice cream sandwich.  Desserts were by far the best thing we ate.

Service was ok.  Our waiter was not particularly helpful, and we had to ask a different waitress how to serve the shrimp dish (you mix it up before serving which we didn't know). 

Also, for a place that is so tough to get a reservation, there was a bunch of empty seats. 

Overall, I'd go back for the cocktails, but not the food.  If I want good tapas, I'll go to Zarzuela.
author: Brooke S.

description:
My husband and I had lunch here and thought it was fantastic!  Brought back fond food memories from Spain!
Their G&T cocktails are interesting and delicious - G&Ts are very trendy in Spain so it was fun to see them on the menu.
We shared:
Iberico de Bellota - $29 was a steep price for only a few slices, but it was delicious
Valedon cheese - $6 for a slice but served with tasty treats (Marcona almonds and quince paste)
Grilled razor clams - cooked to perfection
Special of the day -- shelling beans with broccolini and tomato - so delish!
Wood grilled octopus - so yummy!  
Pluma (pork shoulder loin) with honey chili glaze - don't miss this one!
Everything (food & drinks) we "thoughtfully" prepared.
Great lunch - great view of the bay / Bay Bridge - we'll be back for sure!
author: Kelly A.

description: First timer.. Awesome place, great atmosphere, delicious food, and fantastic service. Our waiter Scott, was the best. Great recommendations on drinks and food. Impressed on the overview of each dish as they were served! Will definitely make this a go to stop on every visit to the bay, both for myself, friends, coworkers, and family members!!!
author: Lee O.

description:
Really cool spot down by the water. I feel like most of the spots down in the pier/ferry building area are over priced and mediocre at best. but i LOVED my experience here. The cocktails are super inventive and the food is incredible- i had the meatballs and the brioche with eggplant and this delicious cheese.  Service was phenomenal- friendly and cool.

Vibe is very hip but in an authentic way- not trying too hard/ gimmicky. The kind of place you can make your local spot but is also special enough to do a birthday dinner or other celebratory meal.
author: Olivia H.

description:
Underwhelming, unfortunately. We dined at Coquetta this weekend and walked away unimpressed. There were high notes:  The drinks were tasty, and the octopus with fingerling potatoes was excellent. However, most dishes simply lacked the intensity of flavor we were looking for. 

At Bottega, Coquetta's sibling restaurant, the flavors are big and bold. Our experience Coquetta was mostly timid and flat. By no means was our meal bad, but it simply didn't rise to the occasion the way we expected a restaurant of this caliber would. Most telling was that several dishes weren't even finished by our group, one self serving was often enough.

Our experience rated only three stars.
author: Seth G.

description:
As a kid, I was obsessed with miniatures and as an adult, that has translated into a fondness of restaurants that offer small dishes. I have been trying to find a great tapas spot ever since I moved over from the East Coast and I think I have found it! You may end up with a bill higher than you were expecting but the food is so delicious, it's worth it!

My idea of a perfect meal here would entail the Salmon Ahumado, the Mar y montaña, the Pimientos de Padron, the Pulpo a la Plancha, the Paella, and Pluma (you should probably take a posse with you). The Pluma is served with a warm honey-chili glaze that you pour out yourself. The first time I tried it, I had to use every ounce of my self-control to not pour the entire bottle into my bottle, given that it was a team lunch that included one of our VPs.
author: Tiff Y.

description: situated along upper embarcadero...spanish tapas...starting with cheese plates...three cheeses served with marcona almonds and licorice flavored flat bread crackers...soft, stinky and hard cheese varieties $16....$2 bread charge?...but, acme bread twists...$36 sangria to share and specialty cocktails to delight...various tapas to bite...crunchy fried ham and potato $9...tender octopus tentacle $14....great tasty shrimp and plenty of saucing to dip bread....pass on the $38 pork in sweet sauce and get the $84 steak...steak cooked on the rare side, but extremely delicious...$32 whole fish (branzino, european seabass) is good, but not popular amongst the group...$45 paella is very flavorful, but cooked dryer...balance it with a sweet mix of greens $7....feasting on a big variety and big birthday dinner...$5 per person cake cutting fee for brought dessert....complimentary cheesecake pops to offset...roughly $95 per person for a coqueta feast and drinks...
author: Hen A.

description:
Very fun place for dinner. Food is excellent for the most part and there's definitely quite a few dishes that I am in love with; salmon with truffle honey hmmm..... Just thinking about it is making me hungry again.  I thought the cheesecake was too sweet but I find most desserts at restaurants to be too sweet.  

Service could be better but Coqueta is not a big place and they are always packed so I don't know if much can be done about this. We had reservations for a group of 6, and we weren't seated until 30 mins after our reservation time. The party before us was lagging so it was no fault of Coqueta, however, I would have liked to see better service from them checking in on us while we were waiting. They just left us by the door and left us alone. It would have been nice if they came up and asked if we wanted any cocktails, etc while we waited. 

Overall though, one of the best spanish tapas place in SF. Already anticipating my next visit back to try out other dishes.
author: Carolyn F.

description:
i love this place.
Great location, great view, even the owner offers a good view of himself every now and then (he is just nice to look at, that's all)
Oh the food. Great tapas over all, not so crazy about their patatas bravas, but all other bocaditos, are always great. Been there a few times. I miss their sorbet with pop rocks. That was a blast. I think they have something flambe or w dry ice effects lately.
A new good place I hope it lasts at the Embarcadero. 
cheers
author: Raffi A.

description:
This is just for the bar area. 

I went on a sunny day to see this new restaurant. Ambience was great, not many places on the water with a view and it is bright and airy. A little small so can be hard to get a seat but I got there at an opportune time.

I had three of the Tapas: Smoke Salmon w queso; house cured chorizo w manchego and Tortilla Andres. All three were fresh great flavors (sorry I am not great at explanation of food!) salmon was bright and the cheese and honey were great complement. The Chorizo had this nice spicy taste with the manchego as an offset and the bread was fresh and crunchy. Tortilla Andres was interesting, it was with asparagus, very tasty. 

The wine :): Great wine list focusing on some of the lesser known Spanish regions such as Biaxes (sp?). Had an Albarino that was served at proper temp and was refreshing. The interesting thing was the carafe, it has a spout and it was explained to me that in Spain they drink from the spout without touching their lips and then pass it around. 

Overall, I loved this place. A huge improvement over Lafitte that was there before (it was not very good).

Will return for dinner!
author: Brian P.

description:
OH I so wanted to LOVE this place - have not been to Bottega yet, so this was my first shot at  a Michael Chiarello restaurant.  The Spanish tapas theme is true to fashion  and the overall food quality was superb, HOWEVER, the expectations were just not met - nothing was WOW.  It was good, don't get me wrong, but I am not sure I'd make the effort to go back which is a BIG disappointment.

We were fortunate to get a bar seat inside and did try most everything on the menu with stand out being the calamari, grilled, and lightly seasoned with salt/pepper and drizzled with a little oil.  While we didn't venture into the big plates, we did make it thru most of the hot/cold small plates...worth a shot once, but needs to do more to make us regulars!!
author: Richard D.

description:
Fun, unique Spanish food and great staff at this small spot I've passed numerous times while walking the Embarcadero. 

Food: 4, Atmosphere: 4, Service: 4
Cost to worth it rating: 2.5 (can't get over $2.5 per tiny dime-sized cheese and ham piece, but rest was fine at ~$8-12 for a small plate)
Eve award: best duck meatball 
Return worthiness: yes

Highlights:
- Duck and beef meatballs: large set that had a beautifully complex flavor and melted in your mouth
- Prawns with black garlic chili: loved the twist on the standard garlic shrimp complete with heads and all so beware of the hot squirtage when cutting it off
- Shrimp, egg, and crispies: not sure what it was called and think we ordered it on accident, but I love runny eggs and shrimp so it worked for me. Smaller unshelled shrimp compared to the garlic one and covered in these crispy stringy potato things. I especially liked the roasted tomato sauce mingling with the oils on the bottom
- Calamari: grilled with a nice roasted flavor. Was deciding between this and the octopus and glad I went with the bartender's suggestion 
- Bartenders: very cool. Had a great time sitting at the bar watching and chatting with them
- Plating: artistic presentation like the pattatas in a circle around the sauce in the middle or skewers in a stemless wine glass 
- Space: bigger than I thought. From the outside I expected it to be a small square bar, but there's also a restaurant on the side 

Midlights:
- Drinks: just ok. Was expecting a killer sangria
- Tattas bravas: like tater tots but disappointed I didn't taste the ham 

Lowlights:
- Skewers: as mentioned up top, though I respect quality ingredients, some of the items were spendy for what you got reminiscent of a yakitori bar, but so small to even get much of a taste.

I enjoyed the food and experience here on a spontaneous post-concert snack stop, but would return for a full meal to try more.
author: Eve K.

description:
Really good cocktails, good food, lackluster service. 

Was very excited to try Coqueta as I've been hearing about how great it is for months. I called this past Saturday night and asked if they had any availability that evening for a party of three. I was told they had no availability, they do not accept walk-ins for the dining room, but I might get lucky and find seats in the bar. We showed up at 10:15 to a half empty restaurant and were promptly seated. Why I wasn't offered a reservation, I can't understand. 

After sitting for over 10 minutes a waitress came by with a drink order for another table. We informed her that they couldn't be our drinks because no one had been by our table yet. She apologized, brought us menus, and another waitress quickly arrived. We tried lots of dishes, all good. Nothing out of this world, but I do want to go back and try the items we didn't get. I would not order or recommend the toothpicks they sell for $2.50 with a tiny bite on the end. They should be embarrassed to sell them for $2.50 a piece. I have no problem paying for quality food, but we tried several and they were a joke. I had thought they were a freebie from the manager since they had failed to approach our table for so long until my wife pointed out that we had ordered them. 

All in all, it was a good value for the food, and I will go back, perhaps it was an off night for the staff.
author: Joshua G.

description:
If I were rating the location and the cocktails alone, this would easily be 5 stars. (Definitely try the Conquistador--gin, celery, star anise, lemon, fennel--it was absolutely exquisite.)

The food, on the other hand, is a little less than stellar. Sure, it was beautifully presented and the quality of the ingredients shone...but the flavors just didn't pack a punch. And that's a little disappointing when you're in a beautiful restaurant with a yummy cocktail in your hand. 

But don't let that deter you--I'd definitely come back to enjoy the views of the water over some delicious sips.
author: Eeeeestar T.

description: We made an overnight trip to S.F. just to dine at Coqueta.  The food was incredible!  By the time we were through with dinner our bill resembled a shopping list.  Wow, those small plates sure do add up fast!  Dinner for 2 rang in at $111....and we don't drink alcohol.  But admittedly, Coqueta was worth every penny.  If you get a chance, sit at the bar that faces the kitchen.  You'll see all the magic happen, and the head chef might just serve your dishes himself....and provide a brief tutorial on how best to enjoy them.
author: Trust But Verify 1.

description:
Good atmosphere, food wasn't great.

$5 for a pair of bites of tortilla is not representative of Spain, or US portions at all. In Spain tortilla is a filling and satisfying dish, here is was a small bite of cold hash browns. Pan con tomate is one the most simple and delicious dishes in Spain and here it is served with burnt toast and canned tomatoes in a bowl, turning
it into a forgetful dish . Everything I had felt forced and over priced. I can't imagine that I'm as well traveled as Michael, the restauranteur, but my time in Basque/Northern/Southern Spain I shared more flavorful and fulfilling portions than this place. Very contrived and unfulfilling. I would not recommend spending your time/money here.
author: Kevin C.

description:
TAPAS! + Cocktails!

New restaurant opened by Michael Chiarello near Pier 5 on the Embarcadero. The restaurant has an outdoor bar patio, and an more intimate indoor area. We also ran into Michael Chiarello when we were there as he walks around talking to the guests while managing the restaurant!

FOOD:
Chicken & English Pea Croquettes: Crisp, warm and exactly described similar to a miniature home made chicken pot pie.

Wood Grilled Octopus: Soft, juicy, and flavorful. The octopus tastes fresh and the grill flavor definitely adds to the taste. It comes with small potato pieces which makes it a great pairing.

PORK SHOULDER: This is definitely the highlight dish of the restaurant. I was about 7/8 full when this came out, and I was still able to eat a lot of it as it was that GOOD. The pork and honey flavor is amazing and the pork is cooked to the perfect texture.

Cheesecake: Best dessert in the restaurant. I tried the Sangria Pop rocks but it was okay as it tastes just like a raspberry ice pop. The cheesecake was soft and creamy perfect fit with the caramel.

Gin and Tonic: Probably the most refreshing drink I have had. The Gin and grapefruit go perfectly well together and the presentation of the drink is amazing! Must try.

SERVICE:
Great service overall. The staff was extremely helpful in recommending both wine and dishes, as well as accommodating when food would be served.

Overall: This is a must try restaurant for any occasion. I'll definitely be making my way here after work next time for a quick drink.
author: Stephen C.

description: all of their appetizers are yummy, great spot on the water...Pier 5...Great drinks - a great spot to people watch.
author: Elias N.

description:
We arrived early for a 7pm reservation so we could have a drink in the bar.  A large section of the bar was "reserved" but we managed to find some standing room and get drinks.  The cocktails were very good, but no better than other restaurant/bars in SF.  The bar waitstaff was good and many people had ordered food too.

We were seated 20 minutes late and were told about a yummy special salad with pork belly.  We ordered a pitcher of sangria to get started.

Our waitress returned at 7:28 to tell us that they were out of sangria.  Already out at 7:28pm on a Tuesday?!?  She recommended the Rebujito which tasted like cold mulled cider :( We ordered and then she came back to let us know that the special was sold out...disappointed again....

My favorites were the escabeche, padrone peppers, and the secret pork.  The vineyard greens were very salty and the patatas bravas were very similar to tator tots.  The frozen strawberry-rhubarb gazpacho dessert was underwhelming.  I would have liked something chocolate, but that was not on the menu.  Dinner for 2 was very reasonable at $120.

Maybe we will go back for the escabeche and eat in the bar.

I have enjoyed Botega and also attended the Harvest dinner at the winery.  The atmosphere at both of those locations was very friendly, not just with the staff, but between the patrons.  The atmosphere at Coqueta was disappointing.  In part, having different members of the waitstaff deliver each dish contributes to the feeling that you are just one of many people who will pass through the table during the night.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Definitely not lacking in the cool department. Loved the Gin cocktail, if you could even call it a cocktail because there were flowers and a pine branch floating in it. Seriously good meatballs? Yes. Light, fluffy, crispy, airy churros with dark chocolate dipping sauce? Yes. A Kale salad of all Kale salads? Yes. etc. etc. 

Everything we had was great (and fried). Delicious. Can't wait for to go back for a drink and a bocadillo.
author: Gina P.

description:
FOOD:  5 stars, everything was excellent, wonderful variety, perfectly cooked and fresh enjoyed both smaller plate and meat dishes

DRINKS: 4.5 stars, some cocktails better than others, loved "the presidio",  wine selection was wonderful

SERVICE: 5 stars, prompt and polite, despite the newness of the restaurant

AMBIANCE: 4 stars, beautiful interior, bar area was visually appealing, but crowded and a bit uncomfortable, noise level in main dining room was high but not unbearable

$$$

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
author: Amelia V.

description:
I'm not sure if it was the huge expectations I had coming into this restaurant but I left Coqueta kind of disappointed.  The service was great, and the interior was nice although not that creative, but the food lacked a wow factor.

The drinks were very good and served with a massive block of ice for interesting affect but they barely had any alcohol in them.  The tapas we had were good but the only thing very memorable was the octopus, it was perfectly charred with a nice smokey flavor.

Nothing else really stood out, the paella was OK but nothing jaw dropping.  Same could be said for the beat salad, and the soft egg over shrimp and potatoes.  

The one thing that was exceptional was the service.  Our waiter warned us that a wine selection may overpower our paella and suggested an amazing lighter red for us and everyone staff member was very friendly.

I most likely won't be coming back here for dinner but I can see myself stopping by for drinks and an appetizer every now and then.
author: Ryan J.

description:
I've been dying to eat here! When we arrived, I was immediately pleased by the ambiance and decor.  Loved every bit of it. 

My drink, the Spanish Holiday, was amazingly refreshing.  I could drink it all day.  However, the food was a let down.  The majority of our dishes were salty, and I like salt.  I also love dining out and don't mind  the prices if it's worth it.  But the portions of the tapas were tiny, and the prices were huge.

I'm glad I got to try Coqueta, but I doubt I'll be returning anytime soon.
author: K V.

description: Great ambience for a date night. Nice view of the water. Drinks were vey tasty. Tapas menu so you can try multiple small plates. Only side is very expensive for very little food. The food is also not that great, but the drinks were good. Don't know if I will return to this spot with so many other great restaurants nearby.
author: Purvi S.

description:
Coqueta has a lot to recommend it and just as much not to, at least to me.  In a nutshell, the food is pretty good, but it is expensive.  And wines by the glass seemed ridiculously priced.  The cheapest, on tap, glass of wine was $14.  From there it went to $17 and then over $20.  That doesn't seem to mesh with a tapas, small bites, place.

I was seated along the wall where a cushion goes from one table to the next.  When a patron bounced down at the table next to me I bounced as well.  More serious was that the table seemed a few inches high in relation to the seating.  I came to feel that they didn't want me to get too comfortable.  Get in, get some food, and get out as quickly as possible.  Turn the table.

I started with ensalate resorte which was english pea puree topped with a mince of spring vegetables and accompanied by a slice of ham.  The ham didn't add anything to the dish but I liked the puree and vegetables together.  A nice, small plate of food.

Chicken and english pea croquets surprised me as I was expecting something a bit more substantial that what filled the croquets. It was a puree in which the chicken did little to announce its presence.  Still, I liked this dish.

Finally, Pluma, pork shoulder with a honey-chili glaze.  This was five ounces of loveliness.  And well it might be at $38.  Since I was dining alone, and given the price, it would have been nice if there was something more on the plate.  Some greens.  Olives.  Onions.  Something to make it a course for one person.  But if you are sharing, I can assure you that everyone will fight for every last bit of this.

My server was a bit inexperienced but got the job done.
author: David D.

description:
I love Coqueta! The drinks are delicious and artfully crafted. Octopus and uni crostini are the top dishes for me.

The view is great and really sets the scene for a romantic meal on the bay.


Cons:
Pricey!
Copper cup makes the water taste like metal. 
The super tall chairs make me feel extra small. I heard some other women comment on how it was awkward to have to climb up on the chairs.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Drinks and tapas are really good but the paella is not worth to try.  Ours was burned and tasted more like Mexican rice. Service was OK, manager was very understanding when we complained about the quality of paella. I would definitely go back for the tapas and the drinks.
author: Adelaide B.

description: We had a lot of fun here with our friends. The food was good but not mind blowing but their drinks are really good.
author: Damoon M.

description:
This review is for drinks only

I sat on the patio with some girlfriends and we shared a pitcher of sangria. The service was friendly and attentive, the sangria was tasty and the location is great for people watching. The restaurant is gorgeous; bright accent colors, old dark wood, an open kitchen and heavy glass ware. The drinks are pricey--as to be expected with the location.
author: Cec D.

description:
I was really looking forward to dining here. Unfortunately, most of the dishes weren't exciting and the portions are for little people. 

Go here for the cocktails and the potato croquette.... dine elsewhere.
author: James W.

description:
Amazing food and definitely authentic! I went with friends, so we ordered many different tapas. Loved the ambiance of the place. Here's what I would recommend:

Albondigas a la feria, croquetas de pollo, and manchego cheesecake for dessert

these were my favorites, but everything was amazing! I'd go back if I lived in SF
author: Cinthia P.

description:
Food was good.  Service slightly slow.  Ambiance of restaurant was great.  Chicken Coquettes and Paella were fantastic.  Tapa plates were small even for San Francisco standards.

Overall, an enjoyable evening with my spouse.
author: Upset P.

description: We'd been wanting to go here and finally got a reservation! We decided to go all tapas style so we could try more--delicious! We had the meatballs, short ribs, pear salad, shrimp, tomato & toast, cured meats, churros and flan. Definitely going back to try the family style dishes! Parking is kind of a pain depending on when you go and it's a little loud but you can have a decent convo and the ambiance is nice! Recommend.
author: Dre H.

description:
So, full disclosure, I am a Sommelier at a pretty damn good restaurant here in SF.  So, naturally, I have higher expectations for what I want when I go out to eat and drink, especially since I work around 60 hours a week and NEVER have time to go out. 

Last night, Sunday, a friend recommended I go to Coqueta for a very special dinner I had planned. I typically shy away from the Embarcadero for anything at all, but figured I would give it a try. 

In open table, I left a notation in the reservation statg how special the night was, why and that I also worked in restaurants, so I was expecting, given how wonderful Bottega is, that this place would live up to the hype. 

Sadly, I was gravely mistaken. First, neither the host, the server, any manager or any person at all mentioned my special night, not one bit. I even tried to tell our waitress about it, but she simply talked over me, saying to order a 19$ glass of Not Champagne. 
Then, still no acknowledgement of my night or anything, our preliminary order is taken and we proceed. 

Our server told us that the House cured Jamon Serrano came with around 7 slices, and that we should upgrade by adding, with outrageous sur charge of course, the Manchego. Let me just say, while the flavors were great, we recieved 3 slices of Jamon, and when we mentioned it, the server simply walked away, with ZERO mention of the mistake. 

Then, Croquets. Again, solid flavors, and a great counter point was the supremed citrus, beatifully sweet, sour and savory combo here. However, in each of the 3 (very small portions) there was a small, completely inedible part of the croquet that was as hard as a rock. Almost cracked a tooth! As an aside, they didnt quite understand the concept of clearing before bringing more plates. Had to stack them ourselves.

Next, the uni and jamon lardo open faced "sandwitch", again, all the flavors were there, but it was ruined by how crunchy (near inedible) the mini bagel looking thing could have been a great combo if it was soft and maybe a little salty. But alas, another great idea, poorly executed. 

Lastly, the pulpo or grilled octopus. This was the one bright spot. Not a single problem with this dish. Absolutely perfect. 

All things considered, food could be much better. But my biggest issue is with service and how little acknowledgement we recieved for choosing them the ONE NIGHT we had off to celebrate. I really hope management takes this review seriously. I had not joined yelp for a long time, sad to say it was this experience that provided the impetus to do so.
author: Conor C.

description: We spent $75 for 3 "dishes" and 2 drinks. The portions are ridiculously tiny. A child wouldn't be satisfied after eating here. If you like overpriced, pretentious restaurants with okay service, and you're not actually hungry, then you should try this place.
author: Pasos X.

description:
I am really on the fence about my experience at Coqueta - I think I'd actually give 3.5 stars as it wasn't totally mediocre, but it wasn't so incredible I want to go back right away. 

First thing I have to say is CHANGE THE BARSTOOLS! Even wiith a reservation we were seated at the bar, which is fine. But holy hell, those have got to be the most uncomfortable stools I've parked my ass on. If it was just for a quick drink then fine but for an expensive 2+ hour meal? Not cool. 

On the plus side - 
The pintxos were excellent and a good way to start off - I would recommend the chorizo or the anchovie ones in particular. nice little bites packed with flavor. 

I can barely remember which of the tapas we had, which isn't really a resounding testimonial. What I do remember: 
Albondigas were a standout. I didn't want to share. 
The asparagus was ridiculous. I know they've got high rent, but 3 stalks for $8 is crazy. And the red sangria salsa added nothing. 

Branzino (one of the larger dishes) was cooked perfectly and very tasty. It rounded out our small plates very well. 

Conquistador cocktail was incredible. I will have to go back to try more cocktails as many of them sounded very intriguing. Also appreciate them having of wine on tap and plenty of price options. 

Finally, even if you're too full for dessert you should do yourself a favor and have one of the little cheesecake pops. That's the one thing I will be dreaming about for weeks to come.
author: Mo S.

description:
Wow! As the name of the restaurant literally goes, the food really flirts with you. The Kalimotxo Sangria - like a playful kiss in every sip. Octopus - tender and loving.
