Calamari - flavourful and supple. Duck - soft and juicy. The Pintxos (bit size skewers) are like teasers for your tongue. The sunny-side egg makes you want to lick the dish. The deserts were sensually delightful. Everything just tasted oh-so-GOOD! It just coquettishly stares at you, waiting to be relished!

;)
author: Reema M.

description:
Lunch today produced two of the most memorable dishes I have had in more than recent memory.  The Paella was a breathtaking mixture of perfectly cooked rice (just a bit burned on the bottom to make it caramelized but not overdone, not an easy task) and a lovely combination of meat and seafood on top.  It could not be improved on at all.  
 Dessert was also as good as it gets with the warm molton arroz con leech cake with huckleberries, and arroz con leech ice cream.  Once again, cooked to perfection (any more would be starting to burn) but it was perhaps the best dessert I have experienced in years.  
  We also had the Verduras a la Catalana (curly mustard, green chard Catalan style with caper-raisin puree, pine nuts, raisins and garlic) and thought  it was excellent.  The Pulpo a la Parilla wood grilled mediterranean octopus lost a few points in that the smaller parts of the octopus were so over grilled as to give it a prominent taste of charcoal over everything else.  It's the only thing I would not repeat.  
  Service was friendly, helpful, and professional.  
  More than worth a detour.
author: William F.

description:
My husband arranged to have us dine at Coqueta on opening night - a surprise Birthday treat for me!

I was really impressed with so many details. First of all, the waterfront location is so charming. But there's a wonderful warm sophistication to the interior that makes it feel even more special. Tall wood beams, lovely leather seats in the bar area. My favorite visual touches were the actual ingredients displayed for all to see from near the kitchen on tall shelving. 

Each dish that arrived was presented so beautifully that it really added to the experience of eating them. The grilled octopus and potatoes was served on a plank wood board and arrived hot and perfectly prepared. Mid-meal Chef Michael personally came by with a wildly fun and unexpected treat - some sort of grilled onions wrapped in parchment paper. He told us to peel off the top layer and dip it the sauce and enjoy. It was a memorable part of our night, laughing over the surprise dish and then savoring how good the onions were paired with this AMAZING romesco  sauce. We shared the spiced grilled crab, and got a bit messy only to have the staff bring us perfectly timed hot towels to clean off with. 

Michael, in between working in the open kitchen, really took the time to see how each table was enjoying their meals. He put in our dessert order for us and we ended up sharing a goat cheese cheesecake, playfully served on a wooden stick with a sprinkle of caramel popcorn. We are still talking about the amazing berry gazpacho dessert - a must-have. Lastly we had the churros - delicious.

Besides the amazing meal, we left feeling so well cared for. The entire staff did a fabulous job. Congrats to Coqueta for a wonderful first night. We hope to be back soon!
author: Andrea I.

description: The food was good, but a) the waiter had BO which was pretty unpleasant and b) my date and I ordered 2 separate dishes that each came with 3 of the item (e.g. 3 meatballs). The waiter told us he would "throw in a 4th" for each so it would be an even number for us. Well when the bill came, he had charged us extra for "throwing in" an item for both dishes. Not a huge deal, but felt a bit mislead / kind of tacky on their part.
author: Caroline B.

description:
I like their bar.  Ambiance is very chic. 
If you step outside, incredible view of bay bridge and the water.


FOOD
Went here with my favorite coworkers. I thought for a 90 dollar rib eye, it wouldn't disappoint and come with more flavor. I Dono how you can mess up a big juicy bone in rib eye. Tapas was good and I think the paella was also good. But nothing stood out as extraordinary, except maybe the croquette.
author: Karina H.

description:
With all due respect to Contigo, this is now the best Spanish restaurant in SF.

The concept of "I'm full" simply doesn't exist here. It doesn't matter if you're no longer hungry or how much you've eaten. If the servers brought you something new, you will not be able to resist it. I am seriously tempted to starve myself for 3 days and then go to Coqueta and order one of everything.
author: Doctor L.

description: Really great small plates and great people watching if you sit outside. Sangria was great too!
author: Tracey N.

description:
Absolutely delicious Spanish food and cool atmosphere.  We had sangria and tapas, before digging into the paella, and then wrapped up with churros.  All so so yummy.  I am still thinking about the churros and how I can make paella at home.

We were visiting from out of town - booked a reservation several weeks in advance, and were only able to get a 9pm reso.  And that was on a Monday!  Book early if you can!

My only comment for feedback was that I found the server to be a little on the cold side and not overly friendly.  Other than that we really enjoyed our meal and evening.  I'd go back and recommend this restaurant to anyone.
author: Aymie R.

description:
Came on a Friday night and it was packed by 6:00pm. The outdoor bar area was full. Luckily, we had reservations. Started with cocktails: I had the spanish holiday and he had the sangria. Mine was light and refreshing, perfect way to begin a friday eve after a walk along the embarcadero. 

I moved onto the Castro cocktail- delicious margarita drink with a skewer of fruit. 

For tapas we had:

White gazpacho- it was grainy marcona almond based soup. Not our favorite

Mustard greens - with pine nuts and raisin based drizzled dressing. An OK alternative since they were out of the peppers. 

Tattas Bravas- tiny potatoe square with hints of jamon dipped in a tomato based sauce. Yummmmyyy! 

Octopus- grilled to perfection with potatoes

Calamari- with squid ink- simply amazing

Main Entree- Arroz con scallops. We were fighting for the last spoonful.

Would've given it five stars if the servers we on point but it seemed like we had a few different ones taking our orders over and over. I'm sure the kinks will work themselves out.
author: Maria C.

description: We ended up at Coqueta searching for spanish food. Although the drinks were fine, the food was disappointing, nothing close to Spanish food.
author: Sonia C.

description:
For a Friday afternoon, lunch here is delicious! As a tapas restaurant, the more the merrier and the more to try. I love that it's along the pier, there's outdoor seating for a nice, sunny day, and the main dining area feels VERY cozy and warm with immense amount of light flowing through the windows. 

Afternoon cocktails are a must and it never hurts to start happy hour a little earlier. The selection is enough for an afternoon cocktail and are either fruity, flowery, or all the above and with a kick. 

Favorites in food and drinks?

Jamon Iberico because I LOVE cured meats and have been DYING to try this!

Arroz Cremosa because I love anything remotely similar to paella. Without having to commit to a full two persons paella, the Arroz Cremosa does justice as a simpler version and with more tomato-ness. 

I never thought such a beautiful tropical flower could produce such an amazing flavor. 
I normally don't like gin or tonic water, but there's an exception for everything and the Oracle cocktail is MY exception. It carries those two least favorite drinks and combines together for a light refreshing flavor. 

I was told the dinner menu is even more delicious. I can't wait to come back to try it!
author: Lily L.

description:
Stopped in late in the eve after a show at the America's Cup Paviliion, and I think it was the perfect time to check it out.  No crowds but still bustling.  Sat right at the bar/kitchen ledge and had fun conversations with the staff while noshing on some really tasty dishes.

I don't know why the write-ups compare it to dim sum.  It's small plates tapas, that's it.  Maybe they were trying to make it seem cool like State Bird Provisions.

Nonetheless, the food was gooood!  Octopus hands down the most tender meaty deliciousness.
author: Melanie C.

description: This food and atmosphere is amazing! They have great tapas and delicious cocktails. I got the mojito Costa Brava and it was delicious -- looked like a tasty bubble bath in a martini glass. The service is fantastic, the cheese board is great, and the manchego cheesecake is rich and probably all you'll need to satisfy your sweet & savory tooth after the delectable meal prior. Salud!
author: Katherine W.

description:
Miguel creates the most fabulous drinks. Never have I seen such a talented bartender, everything is made to perfection-from the placement of flowers to the taste of the prettiest drink you'll ever see. The gin and tonic is my personal favorite. 

And in regards to the food, Mr. Chiarello, you're brilliant.
author: Olivia S.

description: Fabulous decor, food, serving, full package. The pop up room is super. Fun date spot. The one bummer was the white lint all over my outfit. Ask for black napkin?
author: Wilson T.

description: The drink my server suggested that I get was delicious! The atmosphere was great! Very much like walking into a old barn but with an updated feel to it. I love the open kitchen concept. I went with 2 girlfriends of mine and we ordered quite a few plates. Some were amazing but overall I felt it was a little pricey for how much we got. I know it's tapas but I've been to similar restaurants and not felt like I was cheated out of a meal. If you want to stop here for a quick bite and a drink this place is perfect. But I wouldn't come here hungry.
author: Rachel H.

description:
So the food is VERY GOOD.  In my opinion, one of the best Spanish places in the city.  I've been twice; the first time the service was quite attentive.... but I can only give 2 stars because of the absolutely AWFUL service my husband and I got last night (Valentine's) at dinner.

Two very egregious errors of service were made:
1. Our drinks (a cocktail from their suggested list and a glass of wine) took 30 minutes to come out.  We had already received 3 separate dishes in this time.  We asked our waiter about the drinks after 15 minutes (when our first dish arrived) and he said they'd be right out.  Around 15 minutes later, we also asked the person who delivered the third dish.  At this time, our waiter actually went to check on the drinks and they soon came out.  And the couple seated next to us (had the same server and placed their order not one minute after us) received not one but TWO rounds of drinks during this time.  Our waiter's response to the situation was to explain three separate times that it "wasn't [his] fault because [he] doesn't make the drinks."  Of course this is true, but doesn't help the situation at all and definitely does not need to be mentioned three times.  Also, they had a two hour limit for Valentine's Day so it's pretty unacceptable to have a 30 minute wait for drinks.
2. Our waiter brought out a dish, sat it down on our table, came back a few minutes later and removed the dish, saying "Sorry, I brought this to the wrong table," then brought it BACK AGAIN a few minutes later saying "I was right the first time, it's yours!"  So weird!  I hope none of the dishes we ate sat on other people's tables for several minutes!

Some other smaller issues happened that bothered me in light of the above two errors:
1. The hostesses asked for the name on our reservation three separate times, including once several minutes AFTER WE HAD ALREADY BEEN SEATED.
2. Our waiter asked as he was clearing a plate away "That was the dish I suggested to you, wasn't it?  Wasn't it a good recommendation?"  We were like "Nope, you didn't suggest it!"  He didn't suggest any dishes to us the entire night.  Weird.
3. When we ordered dessert, we ordered one full size dessert and three "dessert bites."  Our server was like, "Oh no, I do not suggest getting bite ABC, definitely not"  but offered no alternative.  We were like "......ok, just the one full dessert and the two good dessert bites then." WEIRD.

I totally understand that eating out on Valentine's means crowded restaurants and overwhelmed servers but this stuff is unacceptable on any night.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Where do I begin... we have visited Coqueta 3 times since its opening. This is now one of my all time favorite restaurants in San Francisco. This restaurant is sexy through and through from the space, the design, the staff, the drinks and of course the food. 

Before dining in the restaurant a drink or two in the outdoor "fishbowl" bar is a must, get there early to enjoy a bit of sunlight. This space is perched perfectly on the Embarcadero, ocean front with full view of the Bay --- a light and bright space, beautiful design, great energy and they have a wonderful Sauvignon Blanc on the menu "Duckhorn" need I say more and then there are the cocktails... they have mastered a cocktail menu not only of the most beautifully esthetically crafted drinks, but the best tasting. I am in awe with these cocktails in big globe glasses and oversized chunky ice cubes accompanied by exotic fruits, herbs and other garnishes --- you can not go wrong with the "Spanish Holiday". If you like global top shelf gins this is the place for you. Joe is an outstanding bar manager who crafted the entire bar menu.

Michael the GM is stellar - welcoming, knowledable and accomodating. I would want him at the helm of my own restaurant - "it" would get done. 

Now to the main event - the dining experience. I personally know the Interior Designer Caroline so I am biased, but this restaurant is stunning. Take it all in, the hanging lights, the leather chairs, the bar, the wood grains, the utensils, the tableware - but do not neglect to examine the walls closely. The most beautiful Venetian plaster I have seen yet. The color is so dramatic. Just love this space, I could sit in the corner booth for days. 

Michael Chiarello in the kitchen is never a bad view. He is one of the most handsome charming people on the planet and to boot offers some of the best fresh culinary dishes I've had. Which leads me to The Gaucho... hands down one of the best steaks. I have heard this from dozens of others as well in concert. The wooden platter it arrives on is spectacular in its own right, but this steak is above and beyond seasoned and cooked to perfection. I won't even describe it for you because you must try this for yourself. Accompanied by the pepper dish, asparagus and various house cured jamon plates are a sure thing. Do not neglect to order the house churros with pot stirred chocolate. 

Coqueta is an experience that I hope all will have the opportunity to experience and I look forward to returning again and again.
author: Tsuni S.

description:
My husband and I were very excited about trying this restaurant and made reservations by phone one month in advance (the earliest you can make a reservation). We walked from our hotel and found the bar to be overflowing with guests waiting for tables and they kept coming and coming. It was a circus - forget romantic dinner. We were seated close to our reservation time. The dining room décor was sparse and the flooring did not absorb the noise - not my style. Our waitress was quick to remind us that the plates were very small and we should order three each for sharing. My husband mentioned that we do not like the same types of food, so we would each be ordering our own. She went on to say that the chef decides when plates go out and they probably would not come out at the same time. (I guess you can't have it your way here.) Sure enough my two tapas dishes came out andwe sat and sat waiting for my husband's food and we were again reminded by our condescending waitress that the chef decides when a plate goes out, not her. Finally his came out. He had the Spanish sausage dish which he did not like. I had the tomato sandwich which was several pieces of bread with salsa - not what I expected. I also had the chicken croquette which had very little chicken mixed in an herb cream cheese. It was not very good but the cream cheese on the bread. I went to the ladies room and there was a line but the door had a sign that said if you didn't want to wait you could walk down to the public restroom at pier 3 (we were on pier 5).

All in all a big disappointment and we will not be returning the next time we are in SF, nor would we recommend it.
author: MC B.

description:
Big name chef, along the Embarcadero - will it be too pretentious?

Nope - had a great time during week 2 of them opening with two friends from out of town.

Delicious tapas and cocktails.  We ordered mostly seafood - squid (best dish), papas bravas, whole sea bass fish, and shrimp.  

We tried the sangria made of red wine and Coca Cola (sounds weird but is good), sherry-based.   Then I switched to some Spanish reds that I haven't tried before.  Lovely!  

The only thing is that this is a pricey place, and with tapas, the $'s add up quick so be ready to spend.  Look forward to coming back.
author: FoodieGal I.

description:
This place is definitely expensive AND WORTH EVERY PENNY.

Katie was our server. She is delightful. She has also ran with the bulls.

We basically ordered everything on the menu. I love the meatballs, the salmon, and the Pluma the best, but every single item was sensational. 

The cocktails were also amazing. I had the Castro and the Revolution. Both incredible. The Revolution has white peppercorns and a cinnamon stick in it. Ridiculous. Don't get the Sangria, though. It sucks. That is the only thing not impressive about Coqueta. It just tastes like super dry, chilled red wine, there's no true fruit essence or sweetness to it.

The restaurant is absolutely beautiful. From the wooden tables to the wide silverware to the curtains and beautiful warm colors... I loved it.

And Katie was awesome and she explained everything to us in full detail.
author: Jessi M.
Krystle S.

description:
Interesting take on the Spanish tapas menu.  Bold flavors in small plates served in a great location and fantastic setting. 
Best dish I tried was the sea urchin.  $50 per person, including one sangria.
author: Alejandro L.

description: Definitely my favorite Spanish tapas resto in San Francisco! Super cute ambiance, open kitchen, great service and most importantly excellent dishes!
author: Ennie L.

description: Delicious food!!! Awesome drinks! Conquistador is my favorite drink with the Castro a close second. Favorite dishes are the chicken croquetta, octopus, duck/pork meatballs, and the ribeye!  A city favorite for happy hour or a sat night!
author: Michael M.

description:
Since reservations seem really hard to get, I called to find out the best time to get there on a Friday to get two seats in the bar for dinner.  The reservationist said they sometimes fill up by 4:30.  We got there at 4 and there were plenty of seats available in the bar area, but it did fill up before 5.  

The dinner menu did not start until 5, so we had a little chorizo and cheese sandwich  and patatas bravas while we waited.  The patatas were good, but I would have liked some salt on the table for more seasoning.  We really wanted to try to paella, so we had to go light on apps after the 5 o'clock menu was available.  We got the sea urchin and lardo montadito and the whole calamari on the plancha.  The urchin app might seem expensive, but the urchin was generous and it was delicious.  They cut the legs off of the calamari on the plate and so I ate those first.  They were so intensely flavored, I wished that I could get an entire plate of just the legs.  

The paella was gorgeous, but too much food for us after what we had already consumed.  It is a very generous portion that could easily serve four people.

I traveled through the main dining room on the way to the ladies room and it is such a great space.  I definitely want to go back with a proper reservation and eat in that room, but the bar is a great option for those without the foresight to make a res!

Drinks are on the pricey side.
author: Amber B.

description:
I was blown away by how great the food is. It was creative, delicious, and highlighted the ingredients perfectly. I really enjoyed the setting and atmosphere, not to mention the fantastic view.

The two of us ordered the red kale salad (amazing), 4 skewers (it was ok but really tiny and not worth it), grilled octopus (amazing), crispy shrimp pancake (amazing), chicken & pea croquetas (a bit bland and one note tasting), and churros (amazing). For drinks, we had a cocktail called The Sun Never Sets, sangria, and an alborino. It was all very tasty and the service was good. Will definitely look to come back again.
author: Jessie L.

description: Honestly, servers make the difference for a great experience at a restaurant. We've been to Coqueta previously and also Bottega in Yountville, two of Michael Chiarello's restaurants. We haven't always had servers that helped us settle in for an enjoyable dinner at Bottega. Coqueta hit its marks again for tasty offerings with delicious food and refreshing cocktails. However, it was Brooklyn, our server, who gets all the praise for a fun evening on Sunday, April 24. Not familiar with Spanish food, Coqueta's menu can be challenging. Brooklyn helped us select several offerings that proved to be yummy. The "Sunny-side up" Huevo with shrimp, crispy potato and chorizo dressing was delicious as well as the "Patatas Brava" - freshly dug, lightly smoked crispy new potatoes with brava salsa and garlic aioli. The duck and pork meatballs were just okay. Two of us are Italian and can claim tasty meatballs of our own. We're tough meatball critics. Finally, we enjoyed the tender and well-seasoned pork shoulder and it hit high marks. Delicious margaritas, Spanish wine and Rye Whiskey satisfied our drink needs as well. Brooklyn, thanks for a wonderful evening. Love your style, sense of humor and ease of serving. We'll return and request to be in your section.
author: Kathy H.

description:
I am going to give Coqueta a 5 rating because what I want most from a dining experience is great food and drinks. They deserve it for that. (I just returned from Barcelona a month ago, so the flavors of the region and the best preparation of traditional dishes were still very easy to recall.) I could taste Barcelona at Coqueta and that was very pleasurable.
The ambience and service are also first rate.
But, and isn't there always a but. They didn't find my reservation when I arrived. It wasn't under my name. I was offered the bar. No-no! When I gave them my phone number, they did find the reservation at the right time but booked for exactly one week later than I had chosen. Okay. They said I would be seated as I planned. Okay, how about a drink? We went for a drink (we were early), but we could not get the very busy bartender's attention.
So be it. Once seated, excellent!
author: Dorothy R.

description:
If you want an amazing experience at the waterfront, this is the most multilayered and sexy spot you'll find in the city. From the inventive and tasty food, to the creative table top and plastered walls, I found  feasts for all of the senses. The staff welcome you with open arms and make you feel at home with their warm attentive service.  I was shocked that they had only been open for a day before my dinner. We tried as many dishes as we could and were blown away by the variety and flavors. The wine list has the best Spanish wines around and the drink program is super imaginative. 
We will be back for sure.
author: Brooks G.

description: Amazing. We had the Branzino, pork shoulder, Tapas and Greens salad.  With cheesecake for dessert. SUPERB!! A must.we had superb service with a terrific waitress and hostess. This is a must place to eat at. Dessert was equally as adventuresome and a terrific surprise. Great atmosphere also.
author: Lorin S.

description: Third visit and we love all the dishes we have been served!   Tapas style with entrees we always follow the servers suggestions and we have not been disappointed!  The cocktails are fantastic very busy we have always made reservations and been seated immediately!  Great staff, service and ambiance!
author: Roxane S.

description: Aaaaaaamazing. Probs my fav spot in SF.
author: Bree B.

description:
Completely amazing in every aspect!

Cocktails are TO DIE FOR! I am not even sure which ones I had but they were all great and chef gave us some sherry to enjoy while viewing the bay bridge lights!

Go with a group and order as many things as you can! Don't skip dessert! (Or a dessert cocktail!) but make sure you reserve WAY ahead because its small and super popular!
author: Amber M.

description: I really like this place. I'm only giving it five stars because when it's crowded, it's hard to impossible to get service. If they could improve on that a little bit, this place would be five stars.
author: Janell F.

description: Confused service. Had to deal with no fewer than four servers. Cocktails overwrought. Nothing vegetarian on the bar menu. However, the sangria was good.
author: Philip S.

description: Wanted to love it. Service was great. Loved the decor, atmosphere and menu. Mistake came when ordering the paella. Had read rave reviews and normally love paella. What came out had very little seafood, was dry and burnt to the bottom of the pan. Others around didn't seem to be loving theirs either. Server was great and removed from bill. Luckily as it was $45 and had about 6 bites. The deviled eggs were decent. Bikini brioche was better. Should have stuck with the octopus and other tapas. Oh well.
author: Taryn M.

description:
I am a big fan of Michael Chiarello's food and his vision on entertaining his guests and creating ambiance.  Now I feel I have him within arms-reach. Welcome to THE CITY chef.
I was at Coqueta on opening night with a group of eight friends.  We had cocktails at the bar with a spectacular view of the bay. I don't believe I ever had a better tasting gin and tonic as I had that night. 

The restaurant reminds me of a European brasserie. It has an uncomplicated menu,
you don't have to follow the normal rule of choosing an appetizer, a dish from main course, and a dish from dessert.  You can choose your courses from anything that is on the menu and share it freely around the table. It creates a casual dining experience in an upscale restaurant.

Our server was from Spain (basque) and was very knowledgeable about the dishes. I have had many variations of paella, since I spend a lot of time in Catalonia; the Fideua variant was elegant and packed with rich flavors. Once you had the roasted padron peppers, it is hard to imagine ever going back to chips and salsa... The Chicken and English pea croquets croquettes are a must have, crunchy on the outside and oozing with warm flavor on the inside. 

Coqueta is the perfect place to have a cocktail and a few appetizers after work or sit down in the restaurant and dig in on tapas and entrees.
The staff was great and the place already feels like it has been there forever. I can't wait to go back.
author: Nico V.

description: Sure the food is amazing, but our bartender,Jose Luis,made the meal 5+.  It was our third time at  Coqueta, and we look forward to the fourth.
author: lura m.

description: I want to love this place, and it does have some promising qualities. The space is gorgeous, the drinks ARE AMAZING and the servers are professional and warm. But, it is absolutely ludicrous to me that when you arrive for your reservation that you booked a month in advance, the table isn't close to ready and there is literally no relaxed place to wait and enjoy a drink while you wait. The bar area is so so cramped and crowded and between the servers barking at you to move out of the way and the other patrons drunkenly threatening you if you try to take the barstool they've been stalking for an hour, even after you explain calmly that you're waiting for your table, it's incredibly stressful and not an awesome way to start a meal that to be honest is crazy overpriced. The food ranges from okay to excellent and once you are seated they are super nice, but they are rushed and overworked as well so even once you are seated the wait for a drink is 10-30 min. And I think all of this could be manageable but the cost makes it outrageous. We travel to Spain annually and I feel like our favorite restaurant managers/servers in Spain would pass out from shock if we told them what the service looked like and how much we paid. Might be best to hit this place right when they open for a bite and a cocktail at the bar, we won't be attempting a meal there ever again.
author: Natalie D.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco! It gets pretty busy, so you'd want to make a reservation in advance...or you might get lucky and find a spot at the bar. This is my go to place when I have friends in from out of town. It is on the pier and everything on the menu is amazing! The sunny side up "huevo" is a must - shrimp, crispy potato and chorizo dressing. Absolutely delicious!
author: Silvia A.

description: Conquistador and Revolution.  This is a cute spot for a drink in the little green room.  The restaurant decor is impressive.  I didn't eat here, but the drinks were fantastic.
author: Elise G.

description: Best place for GIN cocktails. If you are a gin fan, you must try this place. Food is A-OK, havent had dinner here yet. But drinks are delish delish delish!!!
author: Sania M.

description:
I am giving them a 3 stars rating because they don't have a kid menu nor willing to prepare something simple, the food was amazing but because they didn't have any options for kids, we just took a quick bite and left. Having a couple of kid friendly options on the menu will ensure the adults have a better time. Generally kids eat simple dishes, having them on a separate kid menu will not deteriorate from the main dinning experience. 

We love to enjoy good food (especially spanish cuisine) but if we cannot enjoy it in family we will not return.
author: Rebeca S.

description: Loveeeee the desserts!!! Mama Anna and her team are awesome! Best seats in the house def by the dessert station. The octopus was really good too.
author: Anna H.

description: Honestly, I was a little disappointed. If I could, I would give it 2.5 stars. I feel like Coqueta's getting a lot of credit for a beautiful dining area and great food. presentation. The food itself was bitesize and honestly for the price, we expected to be wow'ed but weren't. Don't get me wrong, everything was ok, but just not that memorable. I remember that the patatas bravas were deep fried mash potato balls and that was interesting... After spending around $30 on lunch, we walked next door to the Strauss ice cream store and got huge ice cream cones.
author: Kara Y.

description:
If you like to have fun trying new things and are looking for an adventure of a meal, this is for you.

Amazing food - I ordered things I never thought I'd try and each dish blew me away. Flavorful and exciting.

A must try. Reserve a month out for the ideal time.
author: Ray T.

description:
Having been a foodie most of my life, ones palate tends to get numb by so many positive food experiences. I often say we are spoiled in San Francisco and it become apparent when we travel and the food isn't as good. 

Needless to say I knew the food would be great  because Michael is an amazing chef, what I didn't know is that the whole experience would blow my socks off. From the minute I walked into the room, the sense of elegance and sophistication in the design was amazing.  That space had charm, energy, warmth all while being sexy too. 

Every course that we had was over the top. Every item prepared just right, from temperature to textures the menu causes one to pause with each bite and savor the experience. The explosion of flavors is right on target not overwhelming but perfectly balanced at all times. 

I think the greatest compliment of the night was from the gentleman dining with us who is from Madrid. He said he has never seen or had Spanish food this authentic anywhere outside of Spain.

To say I was impressed would be an understatement. Bravo!!
author: Tim M.

description: Sampled a bit of food and a couple drinks on a recent happy hour visit.  Everything was great, though the meat balls stood out as being especially popular with the crowd.  Gin and Tonics were excellent.  Looking forward to dining here!
author: Patrick S.

description: This place is just amazing. The drinks are crafted pieces of art. The service is as great as the food.
author: Kitty K.

description: hostess is AWESOME. whoever was manning the station (i am so sorry I didn't get your name) on 4/6 around 5-6pm is probably the type of person you'd want there all the time.
author: Whitne Y.

description:
This is on my go-to list for dinner (in the location formerly occupied by Lafitte).  Came after brunch last weekend with a group of friends just for drinks.  The homemade sangria was just ok (although I did like the unique twist of having grapes instead of citrus).  

Had some nibbles too.  The Churro Fantasia, with sides of drinking chocolate and mixed berry powder was elegantly presented and well-received.  Also the house-cured chorizo sandwich was quite good (although it is small - just a couple of bites.

Looking forward to returning to try the tapas!
author: F. P.

description: A lot of different tastes, very small portions, Very expensive. Perfect for someone on a diet who wants a lot of tastes and doesn't mind the price.
author: Connie C.

description: Lovely restaurant and good tapas, located very nice on the Embarcadero. The restaurant has a wonderful ambiance and the food is great. Have been here multiple times and will be back.
author: Bart N.

description:
I've been here twice now. Once randomly for dinner on a week night and another for a girls' Sunday lunch date. Menus were very similar in both settings. The only thing I didn't get at lunch were the skewers that they had during dinner (servers would walk around the restaurant offering the one-bite skewers) - these were a must try! So much going on in one bite! 

Service was great. Food was great. Drinks were great. 

View was amazing and parking wasn't too bad. 

It's a great place for any occasion with a max of 4 in your group - place is a bit tight. 

I'd highly recommend: Paella and Grilled Octopus  

It's hard to get reservations for dinner on the weekends, so make sure you plan waaaaaay ahead!
author: Ruby B.

description:
I don't give out 5s often but I absolutely loved my dining experience here! 

I took my mom here for Mother's Day and we had a reservation and they seated us right away.  I sat in the main room at the bar and yes the bar stools are uncomfortable but I had a great view of the kitchen and Chef Chiarello was there too. He was quite friendly unlike what some of the other reviews said. 

Now the food. Yes it's tapas and expensive but you get what you pay for.  I ad the best wood grilled octopus ever!! It was so tender but you could definitely taste the smokiness too. The razor clams and open faced uni sandwich were also amazing!! We also had the scallop entree but I'd definitely stick to tapas only the next time I come because the dishes were more unique.  The drinks were good too, I had a berry based gin and tonic and my mom had a pineapple drink. And the dessert! We had the chocolate cake and cheesecake bites...and the cheesecake bites were to die for!

The service was good too. We didn't have to ask for anything..we had plates for sharing and our water was filled and we were checked on at the appropriate times. As a new restaurant their only snafu was they had brought out a couple of the tapas and main course at the same time which caused our food to get cold. Also I do NOT like to be rushed when eating at a restaurant. We mentioned that our main was cold and the waitress immediately took it away. They made a new one and brought it back out at the appropriate time. 

The ambience was nice too..had a rustic atmosphere that didn't seem old but rather inviting and sophisticated in its own way. I'll definitely be back.. And just a note the chef also said bye as we left and he was outside the restaurant soo he seemed to be making quite an effort to be nice to customers
author: Priscilla T.

description:
Went for weekend brunch with two friends. We ordered four tapas, one combo cheese plate and one paella. It was more than enough food for three ppl. Everything was good but the more memorable dishes were the salmon open face sandwich and the grilled calamari with squid ink sauce. Those two were delishhhhh!!!  

The only negative was the price point. $60 per person for lunch seems pretty expensive but I guess we did order quite a bit.
author: Mona K.

description:
Probably one of the best restaurants I've visited in a long time. Outstanding.

We went overboard for sure. Rather than order off the menu we asked our server to just bring us what she recommends. 

Everything we had was outstanding. I'd recommend ordering a few plates and not doing what we did -- because we ran the bill up (over the top) in a very short time.

However it was delicious and if I had to do it again, I'd over order just like the first time.
author: thrasher b.

description: We've been wanting to go there for dinner, you have make reservations a month in advance. On a Sunday afternoon we just walked right into the bar to grab a quick shot and 5 tapas later and the best sangria pitcher we love this place. The sunny side up egg tapa in particular is the best bite you can ever have. Definitely I'll have to make that reservation and go back for dinner
author: Ca N.

description:
After reading some Yelp reviews and hearing plenty of positive comments from friends who've been here, I decided to give it a shot. 

I brought my fiancee here for her birthday lunch back in June. Unfortunately, we weren't blown away with the food nor the service. It was an above average experience at best. It wasn't awful - it just didn't live up to my expectations.

The location of the restaurant was great, with views of the Bay Bridge, Coit Tower, and the Pan-America building. This and the Manchego Cheesecake were the only two things worth typing about.
author: Latimer L.

description: Wow the service was great !  Scotty was the absolute best. He helped navigate us on what to drink and eat. Would so go back again. A must
author: Steve M.

description: Took my mother from Annapolis who had read a terrific review in the Washington Post. The hostess was great, as were the squid and meatballs. Can't say the same for the much acclaimed short ribs which were tough and unremarkable. Great spot. Great drinks!  Give it a try.
author: Billy B.

description:
Coqueta is superb!

I might be biased because I am a big Chiarello fan and it just happened that during our dinner he stopped by and chatted with us and shook hands - so that put our visit over the top.

The ambiance, location, open kitchen and menu are all great. We had a bunch of small plates and they were all good. We split the pork large plate which was good too and so were the deserts and coffee. They also have a huge selection of bite sized appetizers and deserts (on a tooth pick) for a couple of bucks.

I almost want to take half a star away for the very small portions. They just need to double all their portions and charge more. The small plates are REALLY small, e.g. patata bravas literally has 8 tiny potato pieces in it.

I had the Chiarello family wine and it was great!

Will definitely go back.

P.S. not a place for kids.
author: Hari B.

description: I would have reviewed and given 5 stars my first time here, except it wasn't fair because  Michael Chiarello himself was next to us, cooking table-side for his friend Sammy Hagar.  When I asked them for a photo, Sammy jumped to our booth and started hanging out with us!  Next thing we know we are all sharing food and drinks.  Second experience, a few weeks ago, was equally amazing.  No Chiarello or Hagar.  Just fantastic Spanish food, phenomenal wines, and excellent service.  I love this place.
author: Simchok M.

description: Love love love this restaurant.  Made reservations for hubby's b day and we were seated right away. Everthing was perfection from food to the impeccable service. Now it's a tad pricey but well worth it.
author: Sheena T.

description:
4.5 stars!  

What do you get when a chef who's famous for Italian cooking opens up a Spanish restaurant?  Wonderful food.

Situated a couple buildings from the Ferry Building, Coqueta is right by the water on the Embarcadero.  It's not a big place, there's a bar area for those who are walk ins or just want to sit and chat with fellow strangers and then there is the dining room which is small but cozy.

We ordered a variety of things as usual and seeing as how they were tapas, we ordered a bit more.  Some of the tapas included uni and lardo over toast, iberico ham, salmon and cheese over toast, calamari, octopus, duck and pork meatballs and more.  Entrees included branzino, quail and paella.  Some stood out more than others such as the branzino, octopus and salmon over toast.  Paella was decent but I felt it was missing something and that something might have been the aioli that came with it.  My fiancee ordered the modern take of sangria and was it good.  It was more like two scoops of sorbet with some fruit and gelee but definitely pretty cool.  I definitely like the idea they had some modern takes on cocktails which makes it fun.  

Dessert was okay, too much of a salty sweet thing going on for our liking.  Service for the most part was good except for in the beginning it took them nearly 20 minutes before they took our food order and they never brought out a candle or anything even though I reminded the waiter it was my brother's birthday.  Luckily he didn't care since we had a Humphrey ice cream cake waiting for him.

There aren't a lot of great tapa places around so it's a good thing Chef Chiarello opened one because it is definitely worth trying and coming back.
author: Pierre L.

description:
Love the space but the food was just ok. Not sure it's worth the money overall (or the wait for a reservation) but I'm happy I went once. Our server was incredibly nice, which was a bonus.

Standouts:

Pork shoulder (yes it's expensive but DELICIOUS, my boyfriend wanted to steal a bottle of the glaze)

Meatballs: good combination of juicy meats with awesome flavor

Shrimp cake: A little too crispy on the outside but the inside bites were great

Shrimp with egg: Great texture and flavor
author: Amy F.

description: We came a bout two months ago for a date night and were able to get a last minute reservation at 7pm on a Saturday night.  I cannot say enough about the food and the friendliness of Santiago the head chef.  We sat at the bar overseeing the cooking and were able to have extended dialogue with Santiago and watch him in action.  We were very impressed.  Highlights for food began with the traditional free tapas.  The bikini brioche was phenomenal as was the octopus.  My mouth is watering as I write this review.  Pork/duck meatballs were tasty as well.  The one and only negative comment I have was about the girl who had taken our drink orders.  When asked for a recommendation - what she thought was good - she was not helpful and almost snarky.  I would take a half start off for that, but Santiago was such a delight that I kept it at 5.
author: Heather G.

description:
I came here after a busy round at the Ferry Building's farmer's market.  My friend wanted to check this place out and I agreed.  Love tapas.

We came in and I ordered a glass of Albarino and she ordered a cocktail (forgot the name) both very much to our liking.  We ordered the octopus, potatoes, uni crostini like dish, and razor clams.  My favorites were the potatoes (although prepared differently than what I'm used to...almost like a tator tot) and the razor clams.  The uni was very fresh and good too but I felt like it needed a touch of salt to contrast and bring flavors out.  The octopus dish was pretty good too.  Pretty tender but not to sound snotty I have had it another place a lot better.  

For dessert my friend ordered the sangria popsicle while I ordered the churro.  The popsicle was pretty tasty.  There was this poprock like sprinkles on top that when you eat with the popsicle pops in your mouth and gets it tingly.  Kind of fun.  I enjoyed my churros.  I like that they have the chocolate dip for it.  

Overall experience here is great.  Even when busy the server tried to make sure she checked on us.  We did have to hail her down for the check but it was because there was a sudden rush.  On top of that there was a great view people watching since the place is right on one of the piers.
author: Kim D.

description:
Just flew all the way to Coqueta from Seattle and had a very disappointing experience. Ambiance was lovely. Got seated 1/2 hour after our reservation and was told it was a 'fabulous' table- we were wedged between two tables with literally 3 inches apart. The music was loud and we could not even hear ourselves. The Chiarrello Bianca wine was lovely- sangria 'ok' but was only infused with fruit- no fruit in the glass. Cheese plate and olives were tasty but only came with three tiny overdone homemade crackers. And the paialla was stone cold. Our waitress barely addressed us and forgot one tapa and shoved it next to the paella as if it were an afterthought.
 No mussels, just overdone dried clams with paper thin slivers of chorizo that were literally like shoe leather. The broccoli chard was without florets and were reminiscent of dried bitter parsley bits. The four jumbo prawns looked good, but when you picked them up they were cold, and the heads just fell off. Mushy, cold and LAYERED with salt. The rice was mushy on the outside and firm on the inside- not cooked, and unpalatable. Mr.Chairello, very,very disappointing for $200. Didn't bother with dessert. We were intending to visit Bottego on Friday during our trip up to Sonoma- but have decided to can the reservation and maybe take a risk in the bar. MAYBE.
author: Brenda S.

description: Unbelievable how rushed we felt in this place. Super overpriced for the service and for the food. We were a party of 4 and after spending $400 the manager or whoever she was kindly invited us to leave the place because we were there for 2 hours already. I would not recommend this place or not coming back. Save your time and go to a place that is like SanFran, lay back and relaxed!
author: Rizzia F.

description: We ate at this restaurant last nite. While the food was very good it felt frantic as it was so loud and busy. But the biggest problem was that while we had a reservation we were seated at the bar for our dinner. The seats were not terribly comfortable and had no backs. When we asked for a table they said we would have to wait 2 hours. We were stunned. We eat out at many good restaurants and couldn't believe we had not been told when making the reservation that we might only get a bar seat.  We won't return.
author: Andrea R.

description:
Overall a great experience and I can totally understand the craziness surrounding Michael Chiarello's new sf restaurant. Last Saturday was the second time I've gone and I'm torn between 4 and 5 stars because not every dish was a hit and your wallet takes a hit when the bill comes. Granted this shouldn't be a huge shock considering the location, and the view/ambiance is awesome. The interior of the restaurant is really interesting and the outside bar area is a great place for cocktails before dinner.

We arrived a bit early for our reservation and were a little disappointed that they tried to seat us at the bar. Since we made the reservation far in advance and asked if there was a table available, they were nice enough to accommodate but had to wait an extra 35 minutes in the packed bar/tent area.  The outside bar had some of the best and most interesting cocktails I've had. A++ for the conquistador and also high scores for the Revolution. We tried a few others as well and they were good. 

As for food, most of our selections were outstanding but a few were pretty average. We tried the chorizo pinxtos which were fun, bite-sized piece of meat, but at 2.50$ each it's tough to get too many. We also started with the open faced smoked salmon sandwich, a great choice. Another hit was the meatballs. The wood grilled octopus was hit or miss, some in the party loved it, others thought just ok. It wasn't tough, I just think some people don't like octopus. We tried the paella which was a huge portion and it was good to try, but didn't knock our socks off which was a bit of a disappointment. The pork loin dishes are must tries. The pluma is fantastic and has a great sauce with it, but at 38$ for a few bites your left feeling unsatisfied. We got churros for dessert which were forgettable.

The service was good, very helpful, especially giving advice with cocktail options. We will surely be back but dinner wasn't cheap, total bill around 220$ for two. We ordered lots of food because we wanted to try so many things, next time we'll go a bit lighter.
author: Kate N.

description:
We chose this place to celebrate our daughter-in-law's 30th birthday after reading the review of Coqueta's soft opening. Settling for a reservation at 11:30am (a dinner reservation was out of the question unless procured weeks in advance) we went with an open mind and best intentions. 
The drink menu was unusual and exciting and did not disappoint! The waitress patiently helped us in choosing great cocktails. From there, things went downhill. While I realize Iberico ham is expensive,  the minuscule portion and ridiculously inflated price left us feeling robbed. The gaspacho was average and the serving thimble sized. Tater Tots are not Patatas Bravas. Call them something else. The house cured anchovies were good as were the croquettes. 
They did remember to bring the birthday desert, which was decorated nicely, but the person who set it down said he would be bringing his coworkers over to sing to us. So we waited. And waited. Did he forget he just left us there? We never found out. 
I do have to mention the Churros con chocolate was the best dessert item. The raspberry powder was a clever twist. 
Service slowed at the end and the crowning blow was that we left the restaurant hungry after paying over $400 for six people. We ordered a LOT of tapas but the portions were tiny. 
Finally, you don't have to go to Spain to get your wallet jacked. Just go to Coqueta!
author: Madelaine H.

description:
FULL DISCLOSURE: I'm having a very difficult time remembering all the dishes I sampled at Coqueta, however, I do remember it being impressive. Unlike my other reviews, I'll write about my overall experience and not mention/elaborate on specific menu items. 

Coqueta, situated just a stone's throw away from The Ferry Building, is a hip and rowdy establishment. Lunch on a cloudy Saturday? Crowded. Reservations are highly recommended during all hours. A great place to eat and drink, Coqueta has the makings to be a true player in the dating scene. If you're single, check this place out. If you're casually dating, take your girl/guy here. If you're tied down by the old ball and chain, go anyway, the food is delicious. 

Upon arrival, you'll immediately notice their mixologists whipping up specialty cocktails at the bar. Gin and tonics dressed with aromatics like orchids and rosemary stems. Sangria garnished with fresh fruit. Mojitos with a modern twist that would make any Cuban proud. These bartenders know their stuff and they put their skills on full display with each glass. Like a deadly woman, Croqueta's drinks are sinfully beautiful and deceptively strong enough to bring you to your knees once you get close enough. If you're not careful, she'll (the drinks) will burn a whole in your wallet. 

The atmosphere is sexy, rustic and charming all rolled into one. The bar area is surrounded by windows, which gives you a clear 360-degree view of the surrounding area which includes the bay. The main dining room has super high ceilings. With the whole place decked out with beautiful wood and dark tones, it provides a very sultry vibe... I imagine it's even more so when night falls. 

Service is what you expect. Although it's excellent, the staff is a little "firm", almost robotic, with very calculated and precise movements that probably stemmed from formal training. Everything from the way they conversed with us, to delivering our food, to setting down our drinks, everything was done like they rehearsed it a million times. Responses to our questions were always calm and borderline monotone, but clear and to the point. Hand gestures were very proper, almost like a conductor commanding an orchestra. Coqueta's service is great but I prefer a more laid back approach. However, I do appreciate the obvious attention they put into it. 

The food... The undisputed star of the whole production. With everything going on at Croqueta, from the specialty cocktails to the decor to the service, they do an amazing job of letting their food shine brighter than everything else. Small plates. Tapas. Prepared and cooked to perfection. Everything is made to be shared. One order of any menu item will satisfy 3-4 people. Eating here is much like speed dating. It's dish after dish, bite after bite with little time during and in between each one. My party and I probably went through 12 different menu items. Everything from mouthwatering cured meats to duck and cherry meatballs to oilve oil poached prawns to wood-grilled octopus to a watermelon and ham salad to... to... to... can't remember the rest. All I know is that by the time the bill came, we were all very satisfied with our experience. At about $50/person pre-tip, it was a little steep for lunch (this is my one knock on the place).

A restaurant running like a super oiled machine, spitting out incredible food at precision pace, Croqueta won't disappoint. Everything on their menu, including the things we didn't try, are and sound delicious. Eating tapas, to me, is best described as going backpacking in a foreign land without a map - with unexpected twists and turns that lead you to all sorts of pleasant surprises and first experiences. Each stop (dish) is different than the last and keeps you wondering what lies ahead. When you reach your final destination (paying the bill), you can't help but look back on your travels and reminisce your favorite moments. 

And like all great getaways, you can't wait to go back.
author: Bruce C.

description: Late post however better late than never..... It was tough getting a last minute reservation for four but got in by mere luck on a Thursday night.  The food and drinks are very good. I especially enjoyed the Paella. It came in a cast iron skillet, which does wonders for the taste in my opinion. It was so delicious I was full but my self discipline caved for this one. The bar drinks were great and the location with an outside view of the new Bay Bridge was very nice.
author: Nancy C.

description:
The space at Coqueta is divided into two parts at Pier 5: a semi-outdoor bar area and an indoor dining room. We started our evening waiting for our table at the bar area and had a pre-dinner cocktail there (more about that later.) It was definitely crowded, but there was a nice ocean breeze blowing through. We were then seated at a 5 person table in the dining room. The room has a warm, really jovial feel to it with a beautiful open kitchen. The next time I come, I'd like to sit at the bar seats facing the kitchen so I can watch Chef Michael cook. That would be super fun!

The drinks:
1. Barca Gin & Tonic- Now I am NOT a gin girl, but this drink was absolutely amazing. It was so crisp and refreshing and went down incredibly smooth. I would come back just for this cocktail alone.
2. Tariff Gin & Tonic (minus the iberico)- This just didn't do it for me. I normally love blood orange anything, but this drink was nothing out of the ordinary. Maybe the iberico ham is the x factor that I was missing (since I don't eat red meat.)

Tapas Frias (cold tapas):
3. Baby Beets- this salad with watercress, beet vinaigrette, beet tierra, and blue cheese snow (yes, snow) was really delicious.
4. White Gazpacho- I am not a huge fan of gazpacho, but this one was creamy, rich, and incredibly flavorful. The almonds really came through each bite.

Montaditos (open-faced sandwiches):
5. Pan con tomate- this never arrived 
6. Smoked Salmon- I tend to find smoky flavors a little too meaty, but I thoroughly enjoyed the queso fresco truffle honey spread on this dish.
 7. House-cured chorizo- I don't eat chorizo, but those who did loved this dish so much that they ordered a second round. Must have been pretty great!

Tapas Calientes (hot tapas): 
8. "Tattas" bravas without ham- these were probably my least favorite item of the night. Vaguely glorified tator-tots. I usually love patatas bravas, so this was a bit disappointing.
9. Gambas al negro- these head on prawns came in an amazing olive oil, black garlic, chili sauce that was to die for. They seriously need to bottle and sell this sauce alone as a bread-dipping condiment. YUM.
10. Grilled razor clams- The clams were a little chewy, but the meyer lemon & ramps "salsa" mixture on top was super flavorful.
11. Whole Calamari- These were really fresh and delicious.
12. Crispy shrimp & chickpea pancake- Definitely one of the highlights of the night. The texture was great and the flavor didn't overpower the shrimp. SO good!

Raciones (family-style):
13. Arroz con Vieira- This grilled tomato rice was cooked to perfection and the scallops on top were perfectly cooked and seasoned. I wish I could have this alone for dinner once a week. YUM!

Dessert
14. Churros with chocolate sauce- SO amazing! I really really loved the warm flaky churro (and definitely ordered a second round.) Several people at my table may have even been seen eating the chocolate sauce after the churros were finished. 
15. The apple pie- the apples were sliced in a beautiful thin presentation that fun to look at and eat. It was served with a cold blue cheese ice cream.
16. The cheesecake- they were out of cheesecake which hurt my heart a little bit.


A few lows points of the meal:

1. The wait staff was amazingly kind and friendly and incredibly helpful. They seemed to be having some trouble with getting things out or items getting lost between the kitchen and our table. Our first food items came out before our drinks which I found a bit odd. At one point we had only eaten about 4 of the many items we ordered, and we were told we only had 1 item left to come out- very confusing. We had to clarify the long list of dishes that had not yet arrived. Fortunately, our waitress handled all of this in the best way she possibly could- she was incredibly apologetic and helpful. I'm sure these kinks will be worked out in no time.

2. The cana de cobre cheese and pan con tomate never arrived.

3. At two points during the meal I asked Chef Chiarello to take a picture with me.  The first time we were at the bar waiting for our table and I shook his hand and asked and he said he "would come right back." He never returned. I did have a quick 20 second chat with him outside the bathroom though! The second time was about half way through our dinner and he was taking a picture with a neighboring table and my cousin asked on my behalf again and he said "Sure! Let me just take something off the grill." Now I don't think it is necessary for a chef to take pictures with the diners, but given that both times he said he would, I was disappointed. This was especially true because a) I drove 45 minutes each way to eat dinner there because I'm a fan of his and b)  I saw him drinking wine, taking pictures, and chatting with a bunch of other diners, and I felt excluded. Granted, some of them were friends of Chef Chiarello, but still there was no way I'd ask a third time because that would just be lame. Sadface.
author: Vinitha R.

description: Went for lunch. Overall it was good although the dish I was most looking forward to was a miss for me. Enjoyed the grilled octopus and the duck/pork meatballs. Octopus was very tender. I was very excited for the Mar y Montana (uni/iberico) sounded amazing and I was disappointed. It was very off balance with way too much uni and barely any iberico. The bread was also really hard. We also had a pear salad which was ok.
author: Carla F.

description: The food here is amazing! The staff are very accommodating and the wine selection was great. The line was put the door, but the waiters were nice enough to let us sit inside with bar stools instead of waiting two hours. We got the cheese plate, octopus, meatballs, tiny potatoes, and Paella. All of these dishes were amazing and would definaetly recommend this place to anyone trying to decide.
author: Kate B.

description:
Absolutely love this new hot spot.  Despite the fact that it was an old douche-bag Ex with his feminine voice raving about this place... But it was other friends and my date that influenced me to venture out here... we were so glad we did.
Refreshingly new ambiance with super friendly customer service... perhaps we were lucky, our waitress was awesome... in fact we just saw her at her other job at Cotgona. She was very patient and knowledgeable in explaining all the variety of dishes.  And her recommendations were phenomenal.  Cocktails were exceptional as well.  Can't wait to come back!
author: Myra M.

description:
Reviewing for the Bar only..

In all honesty, Coqueta could easily become a 3.5-star restaurant because of its service. It takes forever and a day to wave down a server, and then you wait some more for them to bring you your drinks... then it's another painfully slow wait for them to take your food order. The bill can also be quite high. Yes, i know it's Tapas, but still.. $150 for two and we were merely standing by the bar and munching (or are we really fatties??) 

But in reality, I have such a damn good time every time that I'm there, that I feel obligated to give this place a 5-star review. 

The adult beverages are not only good, they are beautiful to look at. Perhaps we ordered one too many gin & tonic because of all the pretty flowers that come with them. The service may be slow, but it is because they are usually swamped. I mean, who doesn't love to sip on a pretty drink in a chic space right on the Embarcadero? Anyone who's swanky needs to stop by here right after work with your red-bottom heels and name-brand bags. (ok, too far but you get my point.)

The food is wonderful too. Everything we ordered was flavorful, and hence you don't really need THAT much food. I suggest going with a few people and trying a few dishes from each section of the menu to get the full experience of what Coqueta offers. 

So all in all, well-crafted drinks and a well thought out menu. Definitely one of the top spots along the North Waterfront.
author: Lynn C.

description:
It's all about first impressions, and let me just start by saying, Coqueta successfully knocked it out of the park.  The food, service, ambience, etc.  all, spectacular!

Greeted by friendly staff, sat promptly, and immediately welcomed by our server.  The first recommendation was their gin & tonic. I'm not a gin or tonic person at all. It is basically my least favorite drink of all time.  But this came highly recommended, so I went for it:

Barça Gintonic $12
bloom london dry gin, fever tree mediterranean tonic, grapefruit, juniper, and local pine 

Wow. No joke, this drink was amazing. I loved it so much, now every morning I wake up and immediately have a glass full of gin waiting for me next to my bed.  Ok, that part isn't true, and I doubt I'll ever order another gin & tonic as my drink of choice, but when I return to Coqueta, that is a different story.  It was just flat out delicious and crazy refreshing. A perfect drink to kick off the dinner!

So for the rest of the selections, here we go:

* Baby Beets with sausalito watercress, beet vinagreta and tierra, and cabrales blue cheese snow: $8.00

* Smoked Salmon with queso fresco and truffle honey: $8.00

* "Tattas" Bravas crispy potato and jamón nuggets with bravas salsa and alioli:  $8.00

* Wood-Grilled Octopus with fingerling potatoes, pimentón, and olive oil: $12.00

* Paella the classic, made with bomba rice, jamón serrano-shellfish broth, roasted tomato, chorizo, gulf prawns, clams, and lemon alioli. (please allow 30-40 minutes to prepare)  (serves 2):  $40.00

We were very happy to have our server recommend each of these dishes along the way.  Everything paired extremely well with the following selection.  I was incredibly impressed all the way through.  The only thing that fell short was the Paella in my mind.  Compared to everything, just didn't hold up. And was also pretty full by that point, which played a factor.  And it was a lot of food.

But that last bit is minor, and doesn't detract from my rating. Because Coqueta is awesome. I will definitely be back.  And if you aren't on Open Table trying to book a table, you need to be.  Seriously, get on there right now, try and book a table, then get frustrated because they are booked. But keep trying, it's worth it!
author: John R.

description:
I was planning to take my family to Coqueta for NYE since they are offering an special event but I had the worst experience dealing with its employees.
Today is the third time I call since we are a group of 12 and their online ticket system only allows to buy 10 tickets per time, anyway I called just to make sure they could accomodate all 12 of us before making the purchase. The first day I called no one knew a thing about the event, the second day I spoke with the supervisor who told me he will contact me because he did not have the information at the time...I am still waiting for his call. And the third time I was transfer to a very rude hostess that basically treated me as a stupid. 
Such a shame that a good restaurant is managed by careless employees who just lost $1800 in sales. I would never recommend this place!
author: Beatriz G.

description: I have been here several times now and I think you should try it for yourself.  Interesting menu items,  Portions are small so you get to try a lot of different things.  Personally I don't love the flavor combinations of the dishes, but that is my pallet.  I prefer German style sausages over Spanish, and within "Spanish"  I prefer Piperade over Coqueta, but I think I am in the minority on that.  It has a good drink menu, good staff and well run overall.  Great setting on the water and nice rustic style ambiance.
author: Neal M.

description: Very good food, great service. Louis may be the best bartender in SF.  Terrific tapas.
author: Dan B.

description:
The roasted lemonade with rosemary is AWESOME as were the grilled albondigas (duck and pork meatballs). The grilled octopus, arroz cremosa with dayboat scallops, and beet salad were all fine but nothing amazing. The crispy shrimp was just weird. It was basically a ball of fry with shrimp in it. Entirely way too my fry for my liking. 

I'm struggling between 3 and 4 stars here. The food is close to good enough for 4, but I generally thought it was a bit overpriced. Though, you certainly can't beat sitting outside on the water on a nice day.
author: Sydney L.

description:
This place is so awesome!!  Love, Love, Love!  There are so many positives...the view, the food, the ambiance, and yes, even Michael Chiarello was there!  The space is tiny and there's tons of buzz, so it's going to be a challenge to get into this place, but so worth the wait!!

Here's what we had;
author: Kim D.

description: Great place. Amazing tapas (a little over-priced but worth it). Wait staff great. The custom gin and tonic was superb. Get it!
author: Mac W.

description: Another trip to the city and another delicious meal at Coqueta. Hubby loves Paella, so we went a different route this time and did more of a traditional dinner with a couple of tapas as appetizers and a couple of the larger dishes as entrees. We had a lovely and enthusiastic server who sang the praises of a pork shoulder "Pluma" dish with honey chili glaze and a side of mushrooms. I took her suggestion for my own dinner and it was delicious. Hubby loved his paella and has dinner now for the next couple of days since it's a serving intended for 2-3 people and he was eating it all by himself (I'm not a fan of paella). We had the yummy, smoky patatas bravas again and they were just as good as I remembered. We also had this yummy brioche with apple and goat cheese inside it and a side of quince honey. Our server described it as "a little bit sweet, a little bit savory. It's delicious!" She was right on again with her recommendation. It was delicious. We were too full for dessert this time, but we'll look forward to dining at Coqueta again and trying more delicious items!
author: Goldi J.

description: Would not go here again. The food was super salty, the service was SLOW (and we were there at 5 pm), and I'm a little ashamed to have gone given Michael Chiarello's unfortunate reputation.
author: Heather K.

description: My new favorite restaurant in SF. This place takes me back to on of my favorite trips to Spain. The fever tree gin and tonic is the best I have ever had. The authentic and excellent Spanish cuisine is absolutely amazing. Thank you Michael Chiarello!!
author: Jeff M.

description: Nice setting, pretty building on the waterfront. From the inside room most tables have no view of the water though. Found the food to be expensive, small servings, and not great. I Read a Chronicle review saying the paella was the "best dish in the best restaurants" so we got this. It was very dry, not that great. Other apps were two small pieces of bread with ham (ie open face sandwich), and croquets. Drinks were good. Service was very good.
author: Joshua P.

description:
Great food. Mostly fairly traditional tapas, but taken up a notch or three. Very nice presentation, well balanced flavors. A real treat.

Great cocktails: inventive new takes on tradition (fresh aromatics added to the gin and tonic made it *pop*), and wholly new concoctions like the Oracle which spouted fog as it arrived, for added effect. 

Definitely on the bookmark-and-come-back-to list.
author: Too Much S.

description: Loved this place!  My friend Robert and I were celebrating our birthdays.  He's Spanish(100%) and wanted some Spanish food.  We were seated at the counter near the kitchen.  We started with Spanish olives, and then had the Paella for two.  Was it the best Paella I ever had?  Nope. The best Paella I ever had was in Spain.  But, this Paella was cooked like Paella is supposed to be cooked.  The rice was perfect!  The hot Spaniard liked it.  Our wine was Propriedad, Tempranillo, Rioja.  Robert was a little bit in shock, because I don't drink red wine, but I loved it!  Since we were celebrating our birthdays, we shared the very delicious chocolate cake.  Nikko was our wonderful server, and she gave us complimentary Manchego Cheesecake with Caramel Popcorn pops for more birthday celebrating!   OMG!  These pops were sooo tasty!   And, the guys in the kitchen were totally hot!
author: Blondie R.

description: The cocktails at this place are amazing.  I specially loved the Barca Gintonic.  While the food is tasty (I loved the arroz de verano), I felt it was overpriced.  $38 for a pork dish ("the pork comes from Spain so it is good quality" was what our waiter told us, however, I wonder what is better in Spain that in California as far as pork is concerned?).
author: Eduardo B.

description: Coqueta is located on the Embarcadero, and has a pretty nice view of the bay. Finding seating can be a little challenging because the place is always busy. During the summer time, it can get quite hot within the sun room part and it can be really uncomfortable. I wouldn't really recommend the food that they serve there. I usually only go for drinks. They have a big selection of drinks to choose from, so there is something for everyone. Their gin and tonics are what they are known for, so I would highly recommend that you check those out. I would recommend this place if you're looking for a nice first date. It's a great place to grab a quick drink and have a great time.
author: Mitoon D.

description: Service was definitely 5 stars, as was most of the food. The chorizo sausage wasn't as good as I hoped, as the little hard breads it came with didn't do anything for me. The octopus (Pulpo a la Parilla) was so unbelievably tender that we had to ask our waitress how it was even possible. She even let out the secret, though I won't post it here. All I can say is that it's brilliant.
author: Nathan P.

description:
Michael Chiarello's new restaurant in SF!

A good friend of mine, who is also a huge Michael Chiarello fan due to his restaurant Bottega in Napa, was able to secure reservations for my super late birthday dinner here and I was excited to see what the fuss was all about.

Needless to say, I was pretty impressed and so was the rest of my party. The staff was friendly, the ambiance was nice and rustic, and the food was amazing. Everything we ordered was bursting of flavor which is right up my alley! The only thing I didn't care too much for were our seats (since there were three of us, we had to sit at the bar, which made it hard since we ordered so many dishes!). Also, I was not a big fan of their tiny skewers (2.50 a pop!) and some of their portion sizing (Pluma; was rather small for $38 bucks. I have to admit, I was expecting a bit more after seeing some pictures of it on Yelp. Maybe they ordered a bigger portion?) 

Other than that, a one of the main highlights of the night was that Michael Chiarello himself was there! He was working the kitchen which I thought was GREAT and also took time to take photos with us as well. It's always nice to see the face behind the food. Overall, great new dining restaurant in SF!
author: Teese N.

description:
Really great new restaurant. We came in without a reservation but the manager Jessica helped find us a spot in the bar area that ended up being perfect. 

Some really unique mixed drinks here (Ham infused cocktail?) and an excellent selection of small plates that would get anyone excited. Really enjoyed the octopus and the house-cured anchovies were spot on. Skip the "Tortilla Andres", very bland next to everything else. 

Prices are a little up there for the plate sizes, but you're paying for the whole experience which makes it a good value. 

Kudos to whoever put together the wine list, some really interesting choices on there.
author: Michelle A.

description:
Chiarello's newest establishment on The Embarcadero is a winner in my book. The food was delicious. A little on the pricey side, but I guess that's just a part of being on The Embarcadero (cause other places we have stopped at there, have also been about the same price point) let alone him being a celebrity chef. Having been to Bottega a few times, we had some high expectation for Coqueta and it didn't disappoint. The service was great and the place is nice and mellow so it was an enjoyable Sunday lunch for us. 

Loved, loved the churros. Was telling my husband I was craving churros and was very excited that it was on the dessert menu so couldn't pass it up. The grilled albondigas was one of my favorites right next to the mar y montana. We did some damage with our bill when everything was done. But definitely will be back to try more stuff off their simple menu.

4.5 stars would be 5 but slightly high price points does make this spot a not everyday, not even every week, spot.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Of the seven dishes and four drinks we tried all were good or above average.  The recommended grenache was great and offered at a reasonable price.  Cocktails are delish, interesting and high quality.  We ordered the cheese plate, which was perfect for what it was, nothing out of the ordinary, but what can you do with a cheese plate, the price was fair.  The deviled eggs were interesting, but not that great, wouldn't order again.  The server recommended the pork shoulder and mushroom shared items, now these two are shining stars and I would go back just to have more of them.  The warm honey chili sauce on the pork was to die for and the enoki mushrooms with fried garlic, OMG.  Desserts were good, service was perfect for the experience.  Hostess needs to be replaced, she was a b.... The bill wasn't cheap, for quantity, but for location and the experience was worth every penny.  Would definitely go again and look forward to it.
author: Melissa G.

description:
How good is Coqueta? Well, I made a reservation for a return visit as I was leaving the place after a three hour tapas marathon, if that tells you anything.

The highlight for us was the octopus. We're cephalopod connoisseurs and the octo at Coqueta does not disappoint. It's both tender and meaty, with a crispy seared/grilled exterior that makes my mouth water just thinking about it. Some of the best I've ever had! In fact, it's so good we got a double order. For two of us.

Also yummy  are the pequillo peppers with jamon, the delicious egg and shrimp with shoestring potatoes in a chorizo dressing and the warm churros with chocolate and freeze dried berry powder.

Given the quality of the above mentioned dishes, the shrimp/garbanzo fritter and the short ribs were a relative disappointment. The fritter was heavy and greasy and the short ribs a bit chewy and tough with an acidic glaze that IMO didn't compliment the meat.

The staff was attentive and friendly and the space is attractive and comfortable. It was crowded but we didn't feel crowded. And as busy as it was they seated us as soon as we got there. 

Coqueta, I'll be back soon to try your delicious-looking paella and grilled steak. And definitely more of your stellar octopus.
author: Gelsomina L.

description: Tapas executed very well. Started with  "El Gran Plat Cap", a tasters and foodies plate of wonderful meat, cheese, spreads and bread. Jamon Iberico, Chick Pea Soup, Grilled Short Ribs, Classic Paella. One phrase says is all...We got our "Goucho" on. 32 oz. of Prime Bone in Rib eye. Serves four. Barley made it. .Ended with the delicious Churro's with Chocolate dipping sauce. Chef Michael Chiarello has a winner. Everything was wonderful. Definitely going back.
author: J G.

description:
We went to Coqueta for lunch on a Saturday. The small dining room is beautiful, with high ceilings and a rustic vibe. There appeared to be plenty of space in the indoor/outdoor bar space, as the casual walk-in crowd ebbed and flowed. 

As for the drinks, the cocktails are all in the $9-12 range. We had 2 sangrias, the Presidio, and a mojito that replaced the Powell Line, which was on the menu but unavailable. All were worthy of San Francisco artisan cocktails.

As for the food, it's Spanish tapas style, so you are encouraged to share a variety of small plates.
