I had the "salt air" margarita which is salt infused foam as the air and an excuse to give me less margarita so it's 60% foam and 40% liquid. The glass is already a small so felt more like some sips of margarita with your foam. My friend had a spicy margarita with chili pepper in it but she requested a bit mild on the spice side and was just ok. 

Then we had the grilled octopus which was very good - tender on the inside, charred on the outside. The duck/pork meatballs were a tad gamey but tasty (3 included). We had another dish with squid and shrimp with puffed vermicelli. The shrimp were fabulous (2) but the other parts of the dish were not very notable. Finally, we had patatas bravas and they were cute little round balls with aioli on them.  

Overall, pretty disappointed for the hype and left hungry so we went across the way for some fresh seafood which never lets us down. 

Our server in the dining area was great though and she was very helpful and warm but overall just couldn't make up for the rest of the experience. There are many other great tapas places to go to without the snooty attitude and more value.
author: Kuishingal F.

description:
Tourist trap.  Come eat at a celebrity chef's restaurant right on the SF Bay!  
Food was mediocre at best; I can easily think of four better Spanish Tapas restaurants in SF.   The $4 chips on the menu are a blatant giveaway that this place targets unknowing out-of-towners: Lay's style chips topped with a little bit of shaved cheese and a sweet vinegar sauce?  You're being serious?
We had reservations at 7:30.  Didn't get seated till 8.  Ordered a bunch of small plates and an entree.  I enjoy a casual pace to dining, but it is inappropriate to have your diners sitting at the table for 40 minutes without food.
author: Eric F.

description: We had a great time at Coqueta last night.  We had an early reservation and Kevin, the gracious host, let us hang out in the bar for a while even though we were due to be seated.   Darrick is an amazing bartender,  He is super creative and showed us how he was experimenting with a device to spray dry ice in a glass.  He was also using smoldering wood chips to impart a smokey flavor in the glass.  He definitely makes some of the best drinks in SF, which is no east feat.  The food and the pacing were excellent and the view of the bridge is a great backdrop.  I am also a fan of Bottega and Michael Chiarello is on point in both restaurants.
author: Scott C.

description:
The place itself is very cute. Staff is attentive and the drinks menu great. Barca G & T was enjoyable.
The menu because it has many things on it is great for a group of people. We went here on a team dinner and so there was a lot to enjoy.
The Pimientos and the Meatballs were my favorite. The bistec was good too. The only thing I didn't enjoy were the skewers. Lacked flavor and freshness and even at $2.50 a pop I thought it was over priced. Oh wait wait and the Sangria I thought was extremely average and 'processed'. Lacked any character and depth of flavor.

Would definitely go back. It's a fun place and right by the bay so nice to go for a walk post dinner or for a drink at the bars and other places within a couple of minutes.

I am not sure why I am hesitating with a 5 star - can't just be the sangria. Maybe I am that college professor that takes and takes but never gives - so I'll cut a deal. If a return visit satisfies me again with other menu selections I'll add the extra star.
author: Neil B.

description:
The gin and tonic is 5 stars. but the food is just okay.
I feel like people who are giving it 5 stars have maybe never been to spain and/or have never experienced real spanish tapas.
I have to say the service was wonderful.

Food:
gazpacho geltina
pan con tomate
bikini - the best one i think
arroz cremoso - YUCK! we actually had to wait about 30 minutes for this too and it was really bad.

On another note and worthy of ZERO stars - there was a super drunk guy passing out at the table next to us and then finally vomited on the table. And then he left. His dinnermates, covered it up with lots of napkins and then asked the servers to take them away - WITHOUT WARNING THEM THERE WAS VOMIT ON THE NAPKINS. Not only is this a health hazard, but it is also unbelievably rude. I think it was pretty obvious that he was too drunk to be there as soon as he sat down and they should have kicked him out long before he had the chance to disgust everyone nearby. This isn't some dark, dive bar. People pay good money to come to your restaurant, please have the courtesy to refuse service to guests that are clearly not fit to stay.
author: Kerry F.

description: Cute neighborhood restaurant with great food. They have good selection of wines and the service is very good. Overall very happy with the restaurant.
author: June C.

description:
to behave amorously without serious intent.- lively fun place- delicious friendly staff-
delicious Croquetas de Pollo- reservations a must on friday & sat!
author: Leslie E.

description:
Talk about a dinner and a show! Everything about this place makes me want to come back for more. Stopped by Coqueta after 4 long months since they opened for dessert and drinks. Sat at the patio bar - which I highly recommend since you get a direct view of the Bay Lights. The bartenders are amazing!! Miguel was friendly and hospitable, chatting and offering to take our picture and was just in good spirits. All the cocktails were impeccably made and a craft of their own. Cups of garnishes filled the bar, and I just waited to see what the bartenders would do with them. My drink had a layer of meringue on top and torched for a crispy shell right before my eyes. I got the frozen gazpacho for dessert, which looked like it was freeze dried, so they had us try a piece before the sauce was poured on and we got to breathe "smoke" out of our noses which was a fun touch. Everyone at the bar took turns pouring wine straight into their mouths with the wine canter and it was a hoot cheering each other on. 

I'm coming back for sure.
author: Christine A.

description:
After I checked out Yelp reviews and pictures, I decided to book my anniversary dinner here. I made to sure to mention that it was our anniversary when we made the reservation since (1) they asked if it was a special occasion and (2) the delicious looking anniversary dessert pictures on Yelp! However, we checked in with a cold hostess, had an unfriendly waiter (who just throws down dessert menus without saying anything and then leaves?) and we didn't get any special anniversary dessert, or even any mention of our anniversary!

It wouldn't have been that big of a deal except for the fact that we were sandwiched in between 2 other couples celebrating their anniversary and they got the whole performance. Friendly waiter, asking how long they've been together, free dessert. So yeah, that was kind of irritating. Especially when one couple told the waiter it wasn't actually their anniversary and that they just lied to get a table. GRRREAT! We sure did feel super special then.

The food is good, the atmosphere is lovely, but don't go for a special occasion. 

3.5/5
author: Maria Y.

description: This is by far the best tapas I have ever had on either coast.  Excellent home-made jamon with great local and Spanish cheese selections.  Wide selection of wines.
author: Scott L.

description: The food had some great flavors and the service was decent but something about tapas style restaurants just drives me insane.
author: German L.

description: Overpriced, yes, but that's what you get when you want tapas along the waterfront in a beautiful setting. The grilled octopus was out of this world. The beet salad and smoked salmon toast things were delicious as well. Pretty good sangria, though not necessarily worth its price tag. I'd go back for a drink and plate or two at the bar with a beautiful view, but wouldn't drop all that money on a light lunch again.
author: Orly S.

description: I was really excited to try this restaurant and it didn't disappoint.  The location was great, especially on a beautiful sunny day.  Came for lunch, and were quickly seated in the bar area without a reservation on a Friday (not bad).  The restaurant was pretty but the seats weren't very comfortable - small price to pay though for the view we had.  I was happy that the menu was designed as small plates to share (and they were actually a pretty decent size).  We ordered a variety of items and I will start with the so-so and then mention the incredible - so I was pretty disappointed with the octopus... felt it was a tad overcooked, and a little chewy because of this.  The duck and pork dumplings and head on gulf prawns were my two favorites.  The cheese and meat platter was also very good.  I thought the restaurant was enjoyable but with all the amazing food in San Francisco, not sure I would go again.
author: Kristina D.

description: food was great, highly recommend the iberico! Farmers market punch was amazing. Can't wait to come back.
author: Briana B.

description:
I had been waiting to try Coqueta for months and finally came here to celebrate my birthday. It fully lived up to my high expectations!  I reveled in the inventive flavor combinations, nice ambiance, great small plates for sharing/tasting and a beautiful waterfront location.  The octopus and lox with truffle honey were my favorites although there was not a bad dish in the bunch.  

The real stand-out for me was our server, Ryan Patrick O'Neil.  Yes, I asked for his name because he really was that AMAZING at his job.  Ryan provided fantastic drink recommendations and food pairings.  He took our limited descriptions of what we liked in general and converted these fragmented thoughts into perfect menu selections in terms of the type of dishes we ordered and overall quantity of food.  He was also welcoming of our special requests and a friendly and pleasant addition to our dinner party.   He was perfectly attentive but not obtrusive.  I drink an unusual amount of water and my cup was always full without ever noticing him slip in and fill it up.  I give Coqueta five stars but Ryan deserve a full seven stars.  I frequently entertain clients for work at many high end restaurants in SF and he is far and away one of the best servers I have ever had.  I will certainly be coming back and asking to sit in his section!
author: Kristy D.

description:
Last weekend I Finally got to try this upscale tapas restaurant that everyone keep talking about. And I was not impressed, not a bit. I guess high prices carry high expectation, and mine were not fulfilled. Given that said the restaurant itself is a piece of art, a multimillion dollar   project in on the finest location in town, the atmosphere invites you to love it. I decided to go to town and order at least 9 different tapas of the menu, skipped the paella since that would have been too much food. I'm not a food snob nor expect to be blown away with innovative culinary techniques, I just know how real tapas in Spain taste, I just want to be able to enjoy some tasty dishes with a beer while enjoying the company of my wife, not hard to please at all! You are not starting off with the right foot when you display a Pincho de Tortilla as a microscopic portion of the fancy version Catalan version of it, in a 2 inch  cazuela that can still fit 2 pinchos in it, that was the most expensive real estate portion of food I 've ever had, a reminder that we are definitely in San Francisco. 
I won't detail every dish I had but while there where tapas that were worth to trying like the mushrooms, precisely one of the few things in the menu that  were simple and to the point , along with the brioche, elevated by an outstanding melting Cana de cabra cheese that was the one really  satisfying bite I had all night.The overall  presentation of the dishes was outstanding(well except those terrible and pretentious Patatas Bravas,they should  just stick to the basics on dishes that are already really good).  Desserts are not memorable either ( I ordered the flan and the churros)
Overall the service was not as great as expected(friendly staff though ) and at the end I walked out with $150 less in my wallet and partially hungry due to the tiny portions offered. Not sure if I'll come back...or maybe to try the cocktails!
author: Raul A.

description:
Service, what service?  Out of fairness I cannot write about their food because they turned me off from trying. I strolled by to get a gift certificate for a client. I waited patiently for about fifteen minutes for the personality-less day manager and wondered why it took the day manager to fetch a gift card.  After she completed her lengthy conversation she told a fellow employee that the cards were currently unavailable because they were under a chair or box or something. By the way, this day manager, who clearly realized that I was waiting for her never acknowledged my presence.

Anyway, I paid for a gift card, provided an address that the card should be mailed to and left. Interestingly, my credit card was charged two days later and after another five days passed I called to inquire about my gift card. Getting through to a live person via telephone was difficult at best and I finally reached someone at a sister restaurant called Bottega Napa Valley and ultimately I received apologies about my experience from the director of communications when I asked them to refund my money. The director of communications insisted on sending me a complimentary dining card or voucher and ultimately someone at Coqueta called and insisted on personally delivering the card. I really did not want to go through this and asked him, politely, to mail it and that I would try Coqueta and again consider purchasing gift cards for client referrals. I have been waiting for that card since May 10th so somehow, I don't think it is coming. 

I have never been a chef in life but here is an open suggestion to the restaurant owner Michael Chiarello. There are many wonderful restaurants in San Francisco and restaurants do not live by reputation alone! Hire caring people who understand attention to detail and ultimately do what they say.
author: Chocoolate I.

description: Great vibe/scene and the service was excellent despite how busy it was. We were able to find seats in the bar area fairly quick. Started off with sangria....I've had better but they were not bad. The skewers are amazing and definitely recommend those. Next was the kale salad. Great flavors from the squash and the chickpea dressing. Lastly we finished with the prawns and short ribs. The prawns were good and I recommend getting extra bread to soak up the sauce. The short ribs were average--they were not tender and a bit fatty. Overall I definitely recommend paying a visit.
author: Neil P.

description:
My wife and I went here for her birthday and overall we enjoyed ourselves.
The location is a bit small and cramped, but it is the city so understandable. We made our reservation 3 weeks in advance and were seated at the chefs table overlooking the grilling station.
The service is what you would expect in a fine dining establishment. We had a great server who was knowledgable of the menu and even had a bit of sarcasm which we enjoyed.
The food was very good and full of flavor. Some of the highlights were duck and pork meatballs, shrimp pancake, pluma, and the razor clams( which i love but can never find anywhere in the bay area)
The wine and drinks were inventive and good as well.
What makes this a 3 star and not higher was the pricing. For tapa's of this size the prices were probably about 40% more than what you could find elsewhere with similiar food. I know its a celeb chef location and pricing is somewhat based on his name attatched.
One other note Gavin Newsom was dining near us.
author: Cassandra C.

description: I don't get it. I've heard so much buzz about this place and - maybe aside from the drinks - didn't find anything noteworthy. In fact, there was more to be disappointed by. The experience started off with being ignored by the host for about 15 minutes. Apparently if you don't have a reservation, you're not a real person. He couldn't even bother to make eye contact with us but seemed to be more than happy to seat those with a reservation, even though the place was more than half empty. We waited through that for some reason and were only rewarded with mediocre tapas and inattentive service. The drinks were creative and delicious - I'll give them that - but they're not enough to make up for the rest. There's no way this place is worth the high prices. Save your money and your time by skipping this one.
author: Brett B.

description: Worst customer service ever.  Have not tried their food yet, but making a reservation is very difficult.  No one ever answers their phone and I'm constantly in a holding pattern.  Trying to book a private party is an act of Congress. Only one person handles it, their GM, Michael Iglesias, and he takes forever to respond, and only does so by email.  I need to send multiple emails before getting a response and only when I push for confirmation and menus did I get it.  Will never book a private event with them again and calling is no use.  If you're looking for an efficient planner on their end, don't bother.  Very uncommunicative and response time is so slow. Can't say enough bad things about their customer service and management skills.
author: Jenn N.

description:
Can't comment on the food or drinks as never had the opportunity to try either. The hostess steered our party of two to the single open seat at the counter in the main dining room, and said we could hover there until a second seat opened. We were at the very end of the counter, smushed up against a post. After being ignored for quite some time, I managed to catch the eye of someone behind the counter, who asked if we "needed something." We said we'd like to order drinks. His response was "what do you want?" Obviously, we didn't know, and asked for a wine list, which was met with an eye roll. 

Time passes, and another gentleman walks up behind us and says, "This seat is reserved. You have to move." Um. Okay. We explained that the hostess had seated us there and we were waiting for a second seat to open up so we could eat. He responded, "There's no need to get excited. This seat is reserved. You can sit in the bar." We explained that we were not, in fact, excited, but did not want to sit in the bar. He replied, "I'm the General Manager. All of these seats are reserved. You can sit in the bar." Sufficiently shamed, we hung our heads and walked into the bar with him, and he pointed to two stools in the corner. At that point, we concluded that they clearly didn't need or want our business, so we left. 

On the way out, we encountered what seemed to be an owner, and explained why we were leaving. He was quite apologetic, and much nicer than his General Manager.
author: Carol L.

description:
Coqueta's arrival in San Francisco has resulted in my absolute worst dining experience EVER (my wife including).  And with my constant eating out and never ending search for the best and most unique dining experiences, #trustme that says a lot.

We had dinner reservations for two and were seated by the hostess in the crowded outdoor bar/patio area amongst a combination of waiting, walk-in, and reservation customers.  Our table was a communal piece which is shared with about a dozen others.  Right away I knew that our dinner would not be pleasant due to other crowding customers who constantly placed their drinks in our area.  IMHO the the bar/patio area is not suitable for customers with reservations and instead should be used strictly for walk-ins and waiting customers.  I requested with our host that we be moved to the main area but was told that it was not possible as "those tables are also reserved."  This statement clearly made me feel like a 2nd rate diner as I was never given the option of choosing between the bar and the main room when making our reservation.   In fact, I feel we were regulated to the bar area based on our lack of "star power" or political eliteness.  Among our hundreds of fine dining experiences (which includes several Michelin Star restaurants), my wife and I have never been made to feel like this, especially with proper reservations.  However, based on my Coqueta experience and after reading other negative reviews on this newly opened celebrity restaurant, it is clear to me that Chef Chiarello is more concerned with entertaining celebrities and the SF political elite than operating a restaurant of fine dining quality (during our visit, we personally observed Chef Chiarello greet and take a few pics with some main room diners including Tour de France announcer Bob Roll.  My wife and I were standing near the exit as he walked out, and he didn't even bother to look our way).

The food itself was good but not absolutely great.  The best dish (out of the seven tapas we ordered) was between the Ibirico Secreto Pork or the honey-glazed Pluma pork shoulder.  And the wood grilled octopus???  We had better at a pizza joint in Philly (see Osteria).

The single highlight of the night was our friendly waitress Christin.  Based on the tools (or lack of) provided by her management, I believe she went above and beyond her duty to see that our experience was tolerable.  At one point, she even shoo'd away some waiting patrons who were leaning on our dining table.  The one star of this review solely belongs to her.....Thank you.
author: Adonis M.

description: They deserve more than 5. Everything is incredible. Octopus, branzino, manchego bites and the service. I seriously have died and gone to foodie heaven. Basically-- come here. ASAP. Bucket list people. Best meal of my entire life. And Antonio is the MAN. Be good to him and he will be very good to you!
author: Allison G.

description: Amongst the people who I know who are into food, Michael Chiarello seems to be a polarizing figure. They either love or hate him. Not much in between. I happen to love Bottega and I had good feelings for what Coqueta had in store. I had been hanging out with friends in the earlier part of the day, had  a business meeting and by the time early evening rolled around, I wasnt ready to leave yet. So I headed to the bar at Coqueta. Low and behold a couple of other friends were sitting near by. So I joined them at their table. Got the Fideua, Gambas Negro, Iberico de Bellota, and the boquerones. All very tasty. Now the waterfront property means prices are up there, and Id say thats the only real drawback here. Our server knew my friends from another restaurant so I got taken care of by association. Id like to have a full large meal here and see how it compares to Madrid, Barcelona, Valencia and the Basque Country but for snacks it's pretty solid.
author: Kim N.

description:
I live about 25 mins south of SF, so when my husband said we're having dinner with one of his colleagues and says to pick a restaurant, I jump at the chance.  I've been wanting to try this place for a while, upon a friend's recommendation.  And, I'm so glad I did!  The only disappointments were the servers lack of any type of emotion: minus 1 star, and the patatas bravas were VERY different than the ones shown in users photos.  The ones we had were just small purple potatoes.  This version to me, wasn't even restaurant worthy: minus 1 star.  Everything else was pretty tasty.  Whenever I'm with my husband he tends to order a boatload of food.  Here is what the 3 of us had:
* croquetas de pollo : MY FAVORITE OF THE NIGHT
* grilled octopus: good, flavorful, not memorable
* duck & pork meatball: Rarely eat meat, this tasted like a "fauncy" meatloaf, quite delicious
* paella: Meh.  Wouldn't recommend; I've had better elsewhere
* patatas bravas: not worth mentioning
* ensalada de kale: good, loved the fresh garbanzo beans and strawberries, would want a slightly less acidic dressing
* setas al ajillo: mushrooms!  tasty, but a little too oily, not really memorable
* gambas al negro: MEH. took as recommendation from server - not worth the $14. 

May come back to try other dishes.  Location and venue is great.  The company made up for the lack of amazement.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Went here recently to celebrate a special day with my girlfriend and we both absolutely loved it! We had heard good things about it and she had never had Spanish food so I thought it would be a god idea to go. I do NOT regret it

Atmosphere:
The place is kinda hard to describe its a sort of like a small industrial hanger meets cowboy/Spanish ranch. I know that sounds silly but its the best I can do... Despite having the kitchen in the same room the place was fairly quiet even when it was packed. I just felt so cool eating at this place. Also its comfy and in a BEAUTIFUL location.

Staff:
The staff was professional but incredibly laid back. They were so comfortable with each other and making little jokes left and right. My only complaint was that there were lots of staff members which just seemed excessive to me, considering they tended to leave us alone for the most part.

Food:
-We got: Pan con tomate (with ham), an organic tomato salad (special), patatas bravas, croquetas de pollo, the "Bakini" (basically an eggplant sandwich), Chesecake, Chocolate fantasia and the pan con chocolate. 

NOTE this was about $75 before the tip if youre hungry id expect to pay about 30 to 40 a person.

So we ordered what seems like a lot of food but the portions here are small! I feel dumb saying this but, I do not recommend coming here if you're starving.
The food was all delicious but  our favorites were: the chicken croquettes, the special salad and the potatoes (honorable mention to the bread though, that was great too). My only complaint was with the "bikini"; although it was still a yummy bite, I thought the blue cheese was just too overpowering. Even the sweet sauce it comes with had to take a back seat to the cheese flavor, and you can forget about tasting anything else they say is in the sandwich. Other than that the dinner courses were top-notch and from what I remember of Spanish food very authentic, though the chef does have his interpretation of things.
As for dessert we both enjoyed it but I felt it was of SLIGHTLY lesser quality than the main courses. That being said, if youre coming here I recommend getting at least the Curros and chocolate dish, if you like cheesy cheesecake then youll like theirs. As for the pan con chocolate I wouldnt really recommend it, the ice cream is bland and the chocolate cake is not chocolaty... in fact I found it salty if anything.

Conclusions:
Though I may have sounded harsh at times we both loved eating here and once I save up enough money I would be happy to go back again! Definitely the best and most authentic Spanish food in the bay, probably even in all northern California. This is really as good as it gets.
One last thing. If you have a "party" larger than 2 or 3 people I highly recommend getting a reservation a couple days in advance they get pretty busy.
author: Josh L.

description:
The flavors are incredible!  The service Outstanding! 

The favorite food was the Plumas and the meatballs! 

The drink was the Gin and Tonic!
author: Allen B.

description: Tourist trap.... enough said.
author: Anwar H.

description: Great wine! Delicious churros and loved the music. super cute place for a date or just to hang with friends.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
I had really high hopes for this Spanish restaurant, but unfortunately the food just was not that good.

What's great: the service and view of the bay. My husband and I received a very warm greeting as soon as we arrived. We sat in the bar area, and we had constant attention from various staff when it came to ordering/refilling of water cups/asking for more drinks/etc. 

What's also good: the decor. The bar area where we sat had some great seating, and I really appreciated that my bar chair had a back to lean on, as I noticed some people were using stools, which probably would not be as comfortable for long periods of time.  

What's not so good: the food, oh no! I wanted this so badly to be yummy. My husband and I spent approx. $194 (w/tip) on dinner, and it was so lackluster. Here's what we had - 

** Mar y montana, sea and mountain ($12): small, just one bite, of iberico meat over sea urchin on toast. Too small of a taste to really appreciate anything. 
** Sopa de ajo ($6): small bowl of bread and garlic soup, with egg. It was good, my husband thought it had a heavy, oil flavor. I thought presentation could be better.
** Gambas al negro ($14): 3 prawns. no flavor at all, and in fact, it tasted old to me (like that freezer burnt, defrosted flavor). Not a winner.
** Whole Monterey calamari ($10): 3 calamari pieces. It came out tepid, so that was a bummer. Texture was nice, flavor was ok.
** Grilled razor clams ($14): 3 clams with some wild ramps inside. This was a little smokey, but it worked well with the lemon.
** Wood-grilled octopus ($12): we got to try this twice, as the chef sent out a first batch that he thought was too small and then subsequently sent out a little more. The first batch was not good - too chewy, tough and way too smokey (I think it's the paprika).  It came with little slices of potatoes, but it added nothing to the overall flavor. The second batch of octopus that came out was better: hot, good texture, not as smokey. So it may be hit or miss with this one.
** Grilled albondigas ($11): 3 meatballs of duck/pork. It was coated with what tasted like BBQ sauce, so the meat could have been anything, and I wouldn't be able to tell because of the sauce. The sauce is too smokey.
**  Vineyard greens ($6): GET THIS ONE! If you get anything on the menu, then get these mustard greens. I know, the simplest thing here on the menu, but the flavors of raisins, pine nuts and garlic are amazing. 
** Grilled Iberico Secreto ($22): Pork slices with watercress. The pork was good, a little tepid, but solid flavor with the simple spices for seasoning. I might get this one again.

Final tally: Out of 9 plates, just 1 stood out. :(

Drinks: Tried 3 - Andalucia $10 (sherry cocktail, very very sweet), Kalimotxo $17 (wine/cola, sweet), Tariff $12 (gin/orange/cava, slips right down!).

What's random: I thought the music didn't really match (for example, I heard a mix of the Fugees, then some Spanish music, then some hip hop).

I wanted to like this place, but the menu needs some adjustment (read: less smokey!). Service and decor is great though, hopefully I'll be able to come back with a small group of friends.
author: Michelle S.

description: Went there on Friday afternoon for drinks at the bar, four of us.  We sat at the bar.  Once again, a very weak host experience -- the host and hostess are so busy looking at their computer that they have forgotten that there are customers RIGHT THERE, IN FRONT OF THEM, needing attention!  Nice bartender, but it wasn't until 15 minutes after we sat down when we were asked what we wanted to drink.  To Michael, you need to increase the staff in the "drink factory" behind the bar in order to meet the high demand for drinks in the bar and restaurant.  The bar experience has not worked BOTH times that we've been there.  Please work on the bar!
author: Thomas M.

description: This place has delicious great quality food but it's very over priced. Came to lunch with my girlfriends and after ordering 200$ worth of tapas and a few drinks between the four of us we were still hungry. Had to go home for my real lunch. It does have a great ambiance, maybe better for just a drink spot.
author: Nina M.

description:
It's disappointing. Walking into a restaurant your first impression is the hostess. If not for the horrific experience I endured at the hostess stand, this review would have definitely gotten five stars. The two ladies are covered from head to toe in some retro get up (that did not match the brilliant spanish ambience one bit). I walk into this gorgeous spanish restaurant delighted, feeling as if I was stepping into a piece of spain and I look up to see the hostess' dressed as cashiers from Ross a couple streets away in Union Square. This caused me quite some hesitancy. I approach the two ladies who cannot seem to look me in the eyes, one of my biggest peeves. I let them know that I am just walking in and they try for about ten minutes to find my reservation. As I am slightly confused I try to re-iterate that I have no reservation but it seems as though the hostess could not figure out her seating software and was more engaged in trying to sort that out than to get me seated. Terrible. After ten minutes she directed us to the bar area, not informing us if we can have a table in the dining room, or the bar, or anywhere! It did not matter! We just wanted to eat some food! We stood there waiting around for what felt like a half an hour before I checked back in to get a rude - "sit at the bar there, right there".  I was floored. I almost left.

Though - I was glad I stayed.

What made up for the horrific hostess? The server. The bussboy. The bartender. The food. The server was incredibly informative, sweet, and always there when we needed her. The bussboy never let my water glass get less than halfway empty and made sure to check that everything was running smoothly. The food was beyond incredible taking me back to Spain with each bite. The tapas style is definitely a favorite of mine. 

After finishing the meal off with one of the best dishes, the churros, I paid the bill (making sure to give a hefty tip to quite an extraordinary server) and made sure not to even glance at the hostess stand as the ending to the meal was too amazing to ruin.
author: Jon M.

description:
With a great location by water in Embarcadero and tapas this place seem very tempting. However, the service is super poor! We went here during the week for a quick dinner as it's within walking distance from our apt. We asked the staff if they can seat us quickly or not because we needed to pick up someone from the airport and we were in rush. The waiter told us that it should be less than 10 minutes. He gave us a menu and said why don't you wait here. I would take care of you as soon as the table outside becomes available. We did as he had asked us. 

The first problem is that because the restaurant has a nice view people continue seating there for over 30+ minutes after paying their bills. The bigger problem is that the waiters are not trained enough to turn around the tables quickly. I have never been a waiter, but I presume you can ask the guests if they need anything else, take all the glasses and paid bill from their table to signal that you need to empty the table. We didn't witness any of these while we were waiting at Coqueta. 

Since the place is tiny and the waiter pretended that all the tables are managed by him, we presumed that all the tables are seated by the waiter and are not first come, first served. So we politely waited on the side until we would be seated by him. While waiting, we saw that different people are trying to push and get some seats. I walked to the waiter a few times and said it's more than 20 minutes we were waiting here and I saw different people grabbed some seats. Are you sure you are opening up a table for us soon? He said yes, yes. Anyways, after 40 minutes of waiting there, no table and no signs that any table would open up soon. I saw a couple standing at the table we were supposed to be seated at like two eagles giving bad looks to the ladies who paid their bill 40 minutes ago and yet hanging out at that table. At that point, I was sure that these tables should be first come, first served. I walked to the waiter and described the situation. I said, "It seems this couple also are keen for the same table. Are you sure you will seat us there and this is not first come, first served?" He said no no! That table IS first come, first served. I had smokes coming out of my head!!! He started apologizing, but it was too late! We were there for over 40 minutes while he was supposed to seat us in 10 minutes. Poor and deceiving service! We will never be back here.
author: Yasi B.

description: All in all the food was tasty. however the portions were tiny (and inconsistent with the tables next to us) additionally the service made us feel like we were second rate customers.   After vacationing in the San Francisco and Napa for a week it was the only disappointing meal i had and mostly based on the experience from wait staff and hosts.  highlight of the night was desert we sat at the bar where they were prepping it and the pastry chefs were well informed (more so than the waitress) and made some good recomendations for desert.
author: Matt C.

description: Pricey but delicious. A couple coworkers and I had a leisurely lunch here (don't tell my boss...) Highlights were the grilled octopus and paella. We also ordered the chicken and pea croquetas, padron peppers, and something with jamon Serrano. I echo the sentiments of other reviewers who commented that it's expensive for what you get, but it's fun for a special occasion when you feel like splurging.
author: Bella L.

description: Small restaurant, you have to get a reservation to get inside, love the tapas menu, it's good when you love small plates and portion wise, The paella is great for group and also the skewer.
author: Bryan T.

description:
As a fan of Bottega in Yountville, I've been excited to try Coqueta since I first heard about Michael Chiarello's plans to take over the Pier 5 space.  While there are several Spanish restaurants in San Francisco, there are few that are remarkable.

In an ideal location in one of the historical Pier buildings along the San Francisco waterfront, Coqueta offers a unique dining environment.  There are two distinct spaces offering a choice of dining experiences.  The bar or patio room is a glass-enclosed space that offers stunning views of the bay and busy waterfront.  With only counter space and a bar-height communal table in a room of floor-to-ceiling glass and iron, this is a high energy, lively and perhaps a little cramped cocktail and dining area.  But what you give up in creature comforts, you gain in a true San Francisco Embarcadero waterfront experience with some of the most inventive and tasty cocktails I've found, even with the current mixology craze.  Traditional cocktails and unique San Francisco inspired cocktails are found along side some truly Spanish traditions with a unique range of gin and tonics and sherry cocktails and a sangria that's on it's own level.  

Moving into the main dining room you'll find a beautiful, warm, and very sexy dining room with the kitchen at its heart.  Deep rich colors, exposed wood beams, soaring ceilings, artfully done rich plaster walls, fire-scorched wooden tables, classic marble counters and a kitchen that doubles as theater for those lucky enough to be seated at the bar, all create an immersive experience that you don't find in may new restaurant spaces these days.  When we were taken to our table (on time by the way, which was a surprise given that they have just opened and are already booked up) there was Michael at the center of the kitchen behind the bar counter like a captain steering a ship.  It's comforting and unique these days to see someone with as much public presence as Michael Chiarello, still very hands on in every detail and every dish.

Now for the food and service.  Given the tapas format, we were able to try a wide range of dishes.  And I must say that all but one were excellent!   A few were standouts.  The pinxtos or small one-bite tapas are artfully skewered and served vertically on a tray with the perfect combination and balance of flavors to highlight the main ingredient of quail egg, anchovy, or chorizo.  While the white gazpacho might be easy to skip over on the menu, please don't!  It's a traditional Spanish soup that you can't find here in San Francisco and it's outstanding.  Also the grilled octopus and grilled pork were exceptional.  Both were fresh, tender and with the flavor of the wood fire grill.  And while I cannot remember the name of the dish, there was dish served with shrimp, a fried egg, and fried potatoes that will be number one on my brunch list the next time I wake up with a hangover!  And finally, for dessert, again there were a wide range of excellent options but two that stood out were the Sangria popsicles with pop rocks (just try them), cheesecake bites served with caramel corn and the apple pie with blue cheese ice cream.
And for a restaurant that has just opened, the service was outstanding from the hostess at the front to the waiter, buss staff and bartender. 

I can't wait to go back to try many of the dishes we missed.  And in addition to a destination location for dinner or lunch, Coqueta seems like the perfect place to stop off when a casual cocktail and a quick bite or two are in order when you're down along the waterfront.
author: Jeff H.

description: Small servings with a high price tag, but the food is sooo good. Best paella in SF, hands down. Sad that it's a restaurant reserved for special occasions and splurges, but it's a bougey spot on the Embarcadero.
author: Amy S.

description:
Opening night.  Seated within 15 minutes of our 5 PM reservation at the bar.  Menus were still being printed upon arrival.  Michael Chiarello actually in the kitchen tonight making sure everything ran as well as it could.  For an opening night, I am confident in giving this restaurant five stars.  Chef Chiarello outdid himself with his new San Francisco outpost.  The menu is a wonderful combination of comfort and excitement.  Husband and I started with a variety of pinxtos (one bite tapas), the best one being the house cured boquerones (white anchovies with olives and peppers).  We then proceeded to order our fair share of tapas including, roasted padron peppers, patatas bravas, tortilla spagnola (called "Andres" here), crispy shrimp in a chickpea flour pancake, grilled albondigas, chicken & english pea croquettes -- each tapas was well seasoned, beautifully presented and more importantly so full of umami with a nod to authentic Catalan cuisine with the freshness of California produce.  Cal Pep would be proud of this place.

We ended our meal by sharing the Fideua, a traditional Catalan noodle dish similar to paella.  The dish came with a number of large tender shrimp and Iberico ham.  It was a really good version, almost as good as the one hubby and I had in Stiges at a fabulous beachside restaurant called La Santa Maria (but perhaps the setting played a part in why their fideua is still so memorable to me today).

Service was impeccable -- hats off to the maitre d' for running a tight ship.  Our server, Moe, was congenial, efficient and balanced the right amount of friendliness with professionalism.  

The restaurant itself is beautiful to look at and I love the bar seating to table ratio -- any restaurants with a pintxos bar needs a large bar!

I have never done this before to an opening night, but I am so excited with this restaurant that it truly deserves five stars.
author: Hannah H.

description:
The original incarnation of this location (Lafitte) holds a special place in my heart, but I was curious to see what Michael Chiarello had done with the joint.  It's lovely, though I feel like the waterfront location and soaring ceilings were better suited to the light and open look it had previously, versus this cozy Spanish vibe they were aiming for.  Maybe because it's summer, and we were there for dinner fairly early so it was quite "daytime" - it may work better when it's dark out.  The servers uniforms are cool, but just this side of costumey.  The staff seems very knowledgable, especially for not having been open very long.
An unexpected Chiarello sighting (being swarmed by excited, middle aged women) was a fun perk.  
The tortilla was good, as were some of the pintxos, and the board of meats and cheeses.  The chicken and pea croquetas were a standout - they were basically little chicken pot pies.  The octopus was tender, the gigantic steak was delicious (though gritty - I imagine that was pepper, but it felt like rocks), and the pan con tomate, while not traditional at all, was delicious.  A word of caution - pass the glass jar of tomato separately or it might slide off the board and shatter all over the table and everyone's food.  And that's where they lost me.
Cocktails were so-so to completely watered down (don't get me started on the nearly flavorless sangria).  The gambas were super fishy and unappetizing, as was the paella, but I'm not a fan of strong fish flavors, so maybe you'll be more impressed (I felt the same way about the anchovies, which I know I don't like but tried anyway, and the razor clams, which I skipped on account of knowing for certain that I don't like - though neither did anyone else at the table).  The tattas bravas tasted oddly chemical, the beet salad was okay but nothing special.  I liked the addition of raisins and pine nuts to the vineyard greens, but they weren't great.  I didn't try the churros (donuts are donuts), but I snagged a bite of one of the cheesecakes - eh.
There is better, more affordable Spanish food elsewhere in the city, but if you're a fan of MC, or looking for a swanky waterfront locale, it's worth a try.  Just don't come expecting great sangria.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I came here with a party of 4 for a birthday dinner and absolutely enjoyed it!  I'm a Michael Chiarello fan (although this review remains unbiased!) and didn't find the food as great as at Bottega, but it was still good nonetheless.  I really liked the decor of the dining room and high ceilings...the bar area was also nice if you can't get a reservation.  They actually have a bar island in the middle where you can sit across from your company so it's easier to chit-chat.  

I had the grilled octopus, which I really enjoyed b/c it had a crispy char to it and was soft at the same time.  The star of the night though was definitely the "gaucho"...so tender & juicy!  It's $20/person for the dish and the serving is quite small (think 2-3 tiny thick slices per person and a big bone), but still very good!  I also tried the roasted green peppers, calamari, tomato appetizer, and potato side - in general, all the vegetarian dishes weren't as good.  As for drinks, I had some sort of melon, honeydew special that was very light and refreshing - think of something that's a mix between vitamin water and a melon gatorade.  The pitcher of sangria is a pretty good deal (4-6 glasses)...I really liked the fact that they put all the fresh fruit into a brand new cup and then poured the sangria, so I was able to eat the fruit at the end w/o it being all bitter from being soaked in wine for really long.  The goat cheese ice cream with apricot tart was very interesting to try, but I don't think I'd order it again.  

Great place to go w/ a group of 3-4 so that you get to try a little bit of everything!
author: Chinh T.

description: What a meal! Started with a delicious Spanish wine. The chorizo was just spicy enough to interest us, then came the potatoes, egg and shrimp. The egg was hot and the yolk was perfect and runny. Mixed with the crispy potatoes and shrimp, it was so full of different flavors I wanted to taste more. The meatballs came next - what a surprise. Just the right balance of salty and savory with the mix of lamb,  duck and spices. A little treat before the most impressive meat dish ever. The gaucho rib eye was a sight; enormous, yet appetizing and overwhelming at the same time, It was amazing. Too much meat for us but we really enjoyed the medium rare steak cooked perfectly with a slight char and a fleshy texture that was buttery and tender. The most perfectly cooked meat I've ever had. The veggies were super tasty too. Greens cooked with pinenuts, raisins and garlic. Not too tender, but sauteed with a slight crunch. A nice partner to the meat. The chance for a perfect 5 was missed only for the fact that after waiting a month for a table, we were seated at the bar. It was cool, but would have preferred a table. Maybe next time. Can't wait to go back. BTW - we saw the chef and owner, Michael C. That was nice. Should have said hello and thanks for a lovely dinner.
author: phil b.

description:
We walked in after Exlporatorium After Dark. Food was amazing. The ambiance is lovely. Service, though, is a different story. 

We walked in, and the hostess was charming and accommodating. We were seated in the bar area, and were excited to try Michael Chiarello's San Francisco establishment. Waterfront location with a view of the Bay Bridge and the Bay Bridge Lights for the next two years. Can't go wrong. Our waitress approached us, took our drink orders and gave us a few minutes to decide on our tapas choices. We ordered the House-cured chorizo sandwiches, Chicken and English pea croquettes, Whole Monterey calamari on the plancha, and the Warm Pimenton chocolate cake with tamarind crema for dessert. 

It was noticeable there was some confusion with the front of the house. Another party's drinks were brought to us minutes after we received our drinks. Afterward, our chorizo sandwiches walked by us as a food runner approached each group sitting in the bar area asking if they had ordered the sandwiches. We had to politely flag him down and let him know it was our order. Next, our waitress brought us a dish we did not even order while the dishes we did order were 'walking around' the same way our chorizo sandwiches did until our waitress grabbed them. Lastly, we were presented with the wrong bill.

Overall, it was an okay first experience. The food is amazing, although slightly over priced. The bread for the chorizo sandwiches had a nice crunch, and the chorizo itself had great flavor. The croquettes were a little hot at first. But once they cooled, they were tasty. The piece of grapefruit after was a nice finish. The calamari had to be my favorite of the savory dishes we ordered that night. The squid ink aioli and greens on the side balanced the dish nicely. The chocolate cake - I would definitely come back for that. You need to give the kitchen notice as it does say on the menu it takes about 220 minutes to make the dessert. But it's well worth it. The drinks were good - we ordered the Presidio and the Spanish Holiday. Again, you can't go wrong with loving the ambiance and location. But the one downfall this time was the service. I would still come back and try to sit in the main dining area. The food is too good to completely say no to this place. Try it for yourself at least once :)
author: Mogi D.

description: Loved the crispy shrimp and chick pea pancake and the patatas bravas. The grilled octopus and the paella are good, and I loved the Barça Gintonic--a work of art in a glass. Looking forward to coming back.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
i finally made it here for dinner after wanting to try for a long time.  it's impossible to get a reservation, so my friend and i finally did for 845 on a tues night.  even w/ a reservation, we only were able to get bar seating.  i love bar seating tho, so it was fine.

we got the quail egg w/ serrano ham pintxo, the tortilla, vineyard greens, gambas, shrimp w/ crispy potatoes chorizo dressing and sunny side up egg, and the short ribs.  the shrimp and egg was by far the best dish.  i also loved the greens.

i would come back to try more next time.  their drinks are also interesting, and i had the seasonal cocktail which was warming.
author: Helen T.

description:
An amazing opening night, as a present for my wife on her birthday. 

Slow start getting seated, but I understand that earlier diners just didn't want to leave! Started with the patatas bravas, followed with the excellent tortilla, the croquettes, and the roasted (?) crab.  Great wine, inventive drinks. Service bordered on extraordinary - multiple servers between the bar and dining room knew exactly what we'd ordered where.  Exactly the right level of attention and polish.

Impressive to see the chef both working the crowd, as well as preparing food. When I visit a "named chef" restaurant, I want them involved with the cooking, not just smiling and shaking hands. Chef took the opportunity to actually *talk* to diners, and listen to their feedback, not just make jokes with them.  Well played.
author: Ryan I.

description:
Out of 5
Food = 4
Value/Price = 2
Bus Service = 4.5
Waiter = 2.5

My wife and I came here for lunch on a Friday on a date day.  We didn't have reservations but we sat at the bar and found it a great place to sit, particularly if you enjoy watching the food prep.  

Bus service was prompt and attentive.  Waiter was largely absent.

My particular gripe with the restaurant is the price for the food vs. portion size.  We had the "larger/family style" pork shoulder and it barely feeds one person...$38.  Unbelievable.  $100+ for lunch for two (with Sangria) seemed rather obnoxious.

Food is very good and the overall experience was enjoyable and that's what matters. 

We don't plan on coming back due to the price/portion size disparity.
author: Jason N.

description: EVERYTHING we tried was super delicious, tapas, dishes, cocktails. Definitely the best place we've been to in the embarcadero/market area.
author: Kia A.

description: I would give 4.5 if there is one. Super impressed with the creativity of the drinks. I sat at the bar and watched a whole mixology show! Food is great too, but not as worth mentioning compared to drinks. Mini skewers looks great but taste ok.
author: Mengmeng C.

description: This restaurant was in unexpected pleasure. Delicious well cooked Spanish Tampas. Never had anything like this. We had reservations at 10:30 pm but we dropped by at 7 pm. We got lucky ...seated early . Great service eclectic atmosphere.  We asked the waitress to recommend a few dishes. We had white anchovies with arugula, octopus with potatoes, shrimp in a delicious sauce with bread and medallions of pork and duck. Great Cosmos too!
author: Terri L.

description: Cool vibe, fun drinks...go for the Castro (spicy and delicious).  I also liked the conquistador (not really sure how to describe it, but earthy and refreshing).  Great bar and small area of outdoor seating.  I'm definitely going back, so many other menu and drink items I want to try!
author: Jennifer B.

description: Very cool spot on the embarcadero! It was extremely packed when we came for lunch so we only got a few seats at the bar. We ordered the tortilla Andres, gambas al negro, wood-grilled octopus, duck albondigas, and had some wine. I would say that the octopus was the best out of everything we had, and the wine we ordered was delicious. It's definitely a great place to grab a bite to eat with a cool vibe in SF.
author: Sheeva G.

description:
really loved the food and service. our server was really good at letting our party of four know that this dish only comes in two or three and did we want to add one or two more for the whole table. the only one they didnt give feedback on that was hard to share was the pintxos trio.  its tapas so its small bites but still it would have been nice to have them mention how shareable it was for four.  also the bench seating against the was was really tight.  hard to get in and out.  the space between the bench and table was pretty tight as well.

started with Caña De Cabra soft, goat.  it was nice and mild and came with some nuts, crackers and  i believe a tomato gelatina.

the Red Kale Ensalada with roasted squash, fuyu persimmons, roasted pumpkin seeds, and warm rancho gordo chickpea dressing was really delish.



the mini open-faced sandwich Mar Y Montaña, Sea And Mountain * ibérico lardo gently melted over sea urchin with jamon ibérico de bellota was the best sea urchin i had...ever.

we had some hot tapas that were really awesome.  the Grilled Albóndigas duck and pork meatballs with tart cherry - tempranillo pureé and crisp shallots was so melt in your mouth good.

the Whole Monterey Calamari On The Plancha * with onion jam and squid ink alioli was really nicely done.  not chewy at all.

what took awhile was the family style Paella the classic, made with bomba rice, jamón serrano-shellfish broth, caramelized root vegetables,chorizo, gulf prawns, clams, and lemon alioli. (please allow 30-40 minutes to prepare) this gave us a nice break to have our tummies settle and make room for more food.


for dessert we had the Manchego Cheesecake with Caramel Popcorn which was a nice rich bite sized treat.

the Flan Espanola with fennel-citrus fritura wasnt as dense as i thought it would be. it was also not too sweet.

the Churro 'Fantasia crispy spanish doughnuts with drinking chocolate and mixed berry powder was definitely crispy and the chocolate dipping sauce went so well with it.

Pintxos Trio - three very mini bite-size skewers. Trio De Pintxos: salted caramel with pimenton, tomato gelatina with basil, and olives dulces with chocolate glaze.  i liked the caramel and olives.  the tomato wasnt my thing for dessert.

the roasted sparkling lemonade was really delish and refreshing.
author: she q.

description: The best dish turned out to be the mushrooms but we expected the Paella to be the star the show at $45 but it was missing a lot of seafood. Croquettes and manchaego cheesecake were worth the wait and the margarita was fantastic. Service wasn't as attentive especially considering we were there at 2 pm. Liked the food but expected way more for the price.
author: Michele M.

description: Spending an evening in the embarcadero is always enjoyable. That day me and my friends were thinking  of trying something different to eat in the city! Browsed , and then I said we are having Spanish food. Got to the restaurant and sat outside on a table with other ppl that we don't know, mingling or also the "SF kinda thing". This restaurant most certainly has a location advantage. The setting and scene was very comfortable, service was GREAT,  and finally the food was overall alright. Rib Eye was ok and not very special. But, the grilled octopus and  the Spanish mushrooms were delicious.
author: Sulaiman B.

description: Checked this place out after a great walk from the Marriott Marquis... Beautiful day in the city!!... Interesting selection of Spanish theme tapas !!.. Very tasty but small portions!.. Definitely will return.. Michael was a no show!
author: Jim L.

description: Who doesn't love Tapas? Heard great things about Coqueta. But as they say you don't know unless you try. Sure glad we did! The drinks are a hit. Try their version of a tequila sunrise. (I know Tequila sunrise. What are we back in the 80s?. Trust me, It's amazing. The Shishito peppers, perfect. The manager of the bar (despite a 1.5 hour wait even after a booked reservation), was the perfect trying to ensure the rest of the evening went without a hit.
author: E ..

description: I could live on Coqueta's patatas bravas! Had a very delicious meal and both our Bar and Dining Room waitresses were absolutely helpful and friendly. Great service - thank you for a memorable meal!
author: jeannie l.

description: This place is really good- great vibe, really cool decor. Both the bar and the dining room (reservations needed for the dining room) have the same fantastic menu. I've been here a handful of times and loved every single thing I've tried. The octopus, the albondigas, all the cocktails and wines- delicious. But the other night we came here and decided to try a bigger dish- the paella- which we assumed would have been absolutely fantastic given the restaurant's theme and our previous experience there. It was mediocre to say the least. The clams were tiny (there were like 5), the prawns were barely seasoned, and the sort of sausage or chorizo they put in there was dry. The rice was poorly cooked and seasoning overall was pretty bland. We've had much better paella on the east coast in non-spanish-themed restaurants, so this was a big disappointment. Would not recommend it but everything else,  I recommend whole heartedly. Oh, and the dessert was TO DIE FOR- some sort of dulce de leche cake with dulce ice cream. Huckleberry. Man, unbelievable.
author: Tiffany L.

description: A+ for the food and service. The place is a little small especially the dining area no wonder you need to make a reservations in advance. I really like the atmosphere the location and seriously the food is definitely good and the prices is ok not so over the top. I highly recommend this restaurant no doubt i would want to come back and try other stuff on the menu.
author: Joiera C.

description: Even for tapas sizes, portions are SMALL.  Also food comes out on newspaper clippings.  Weird.  I hope they wax the paper at least because that's kind of gross.  Chicken and pea croquettes were the highlight of the meal.  They were perfectly crispy on the outside with a juicy, savory inside.  The paella was a real disappointment though.  It was more of a stew.  Lots of sauce.
author: Sharon L.

description: Let me preface this review by saying that I signed myself up just to write this review. Also, I am a server and , in general, don't like to dabble in giving reviews because even a crummy experience holds so many unknowns. For example , you don't know why your food is late but in the kitchen they have a broken stove . I know it sounds silly but all too often a horrible dining experience is often a comedy of errors happening behind the curtain. That being said ill go on. I found out about coqueta from a customer it seemed exciting so we made reservations ( which is a must) . Such an amazing experience! All around wonderful atmosphere , service and the food is heavenly. I wish I could remember our servers name : a young man with a bun in his hair and glasses who was enthusiastic and friendly . He didn't tell us what to choose which he would have If we would have asked but he happily cheered on some of our choices . He was lovely. We are big eaters that enjoy our cocktails so we had many of their gin drinks ( a must) we passed them around the table to try them all. Their wine list is no joke everything for every price range I was impressed by their nickel and nickel Cabernet merlot blend and their duckhorn selection. Ok the food: we ate everything. The octopus and calamari are to die for as well as the razor clams. Ordinarily I wouldn't order these dishes because they are so temperamental and when poorly executed you are eating a leather boot. Not the case all wAs cooked to perfection and a squid ink aioli that I'd punch a family member for. The duck and sausage meatballs are not only a creative mix they were fantastic. We ordered so much more but ill move to the dessert portion. A fig tart with olive oil ice cream was so yummy they are two such delicate flavors that work so well. My personal favorite was the manchego cheesecake. We had dessert along with some port  and sherry. Delightful. This place is fun and exciting the service is great without feeling smothered . Plenty of wine, bubbles, beer ( even a sour ale, amen) , dessert wine and cocktails to die for. Perhaps this isn't the place for your meat and potatoes type although they do have a steak the size of a body builders forearm . I'm sorry for the person who wrote one crappy review about the small portions and price. First off I dare anyone to find inexpensive eats in that area in general and the price is beyond reasonable based on quality alone not to mention atmosphere an area and SERVICE . We love food and aren't afraid to spend on a worthy meal . We had a 400 bill for 5 people who had a few drinks each and most of the menu. Ill call it a steal. I'm so happy that one day a customer of mine told me about this place. Go! Take a group of friends and enjoy every flavor. And take care of the awesome wait staff.
author: Natalie E.

description:
Very good food, great service and very creative kitchen.
3 stars because the jamon iberico de bellota portions were super tiny for the $28 price, forcing us to order 4-5 portions. Being a jamon expert / lover, i must say, they were the smallest & stingiest portions i've ever seen at a tapas place...be it USA or Europe.
Everything else was perfect and I will definitely go again soon, but not for the jamon.
author: Frank B.

description: Definitely a cool place but surprised at how slow service was at the bar over lunch. There were definitely people there but not so crowded to wait well over 10 min to be asked about ordering food after finally getting a drink - which also took over 10 min. Then wait even longer for the food to arrive. Guess it's meant more for lunch just rolling into dinner type day. Would probably go back - when I feel like spending a lot of cash and have a lot of time...
author: Lee J.

description: Very fun place for a happy hour with friends. The food is really tasty, however some of the drinks are a little funny and not so pleasant. This place gets packed, so if going with a large group, recommend making a reservation or you'll wait around forever.
author: Haleh H.

description:
Fantastic all around. Greeted by a friendly host.  Admired the design and touches like the dishware. Lovely bottle of spanish wine.  The coqueta was great.  Favorites: shrimp chickpea flour pancake and sunny side egg dish.  Pork was sliced to perfection with a marinade.  The side of greens was great.  Did not love the olive oil ice cream sandwich, but loved the manchego cheese cake balls. 

next time try: 
escabeche 
grilled razor clams
author: around town e.

description:
I made this reservation to surprise my boyfriend for his pre-birthday celebration for a 9pm reservation.  When we arrived we were greeted with a wonderful smile and escorted to the bar, since we were early to our reservation.  We lucked out and got two seats in the middle bar area that is very small. Not a place to go with a big group, not nuless you get here when they open.  When it was time for our reservation we were escorted to our table and had the nicest waitress ever!  Shelby was her name.  In fact she was so nice and helpful that I decided to write this review.  She made several wonderful recommendations and we decided to go with all of them.  The octopus calamari stands out the most. Ugh!  Wish I had more.  We also got the sangria pitcher.  the sangria was very delicious.  its made with sherry, so its not too tart or sweet.  Very mild. To top off the evening we got the apple pie wiht blue cheese ice cream.  Holly comolly!  Very nice!

Good job Coqueta! I will be back and thank you Shelby for your amazing service!  You made it that much more enjoyable.
author: Carlee M.

description: Great alcoholic drink! looking forward to revisit for a drinking session!
author: Ying L.

description:
We very much looked forward to Coqueta opening, being long-time fans of Michael Chiarello, all the way back to his Tra Vigne days. Unfortunately, our experience last night was underwhelming.

1) Service: 2 stars. We had 7:15 reservations and were kept waiting for nearly an hour. We were offered either seats at the counter or in the bar when the delay got to 30 minutes. Usually, we would've taken these options with no problem, but at this restaurant both these options are problematic. The seats at the chef counter were the most uncomfortable wobbly wooden stools. It's an unpadded rectangle of 8x12 inches. I had perched painfully in this seat at the bar while having drinks (my husband abandoned it and stood). It would have been unpleasant to have an entire meal this way. The bar had better chairs at the communal table, but given that it's a semi-open space, was really cold and drafty. So we opted to wait. Once seated, the service was fine and our waitress had great recommendations. But keep in mind that at this restaurant, you don't REALLY have a reservation unless you're willing to go into these sub-optimal overflow areas. That is just their policy.

2) Drinks: 5 stars. The cocktail menu was wonderful. It had a big selection of gin and tonics all made with special flavor tonic. I had the Barca and it was delicious. One can definitely make a habit of this for happy hour! Wine list also nice, with a good selection of reasonably priced Spanish wines.

3) Food: 3 stars. We *SOOO* wanted to love the food here. Unfortunately it was just OK. Between the 2 of us, we had 6 tapas (duck/pork meatball, asparagus torta, octupus, smoked salmon bocadillo, chicken/pea croquet, and fried egg with shrimp in chorizo sauce). Of these, only the egg/shrimp really knocked it out of the park (unbelievably flavorful and well cooked). The rest were fine but nothing special, the kind of thing you could get at just about every neighborhood tapas place in Barcelona, and of average or below average quality. I was especially disappointed in the octopus, since the ones at Bottega was the best I've ever had. But this version was tough and flavorless. Portions were small. We are not big eaters, and you really need at least 3 each to make a meal.

So, if you've never had tapas in Spain and would like to try it, I would say this is a good choice and I think you will enjoy the food. But if you are familiar with this style of cuisine, the food here is very average, and I think not up to Chirarello's normal high standards. I hope this is just growing pains of a new restaurant, and it improves in the future. And please, buy some proper chairs/stools for the chef's counter!
author: Judy D.

description:
I think I'm in love. The boyfriend and I came here for lunch today on a random excursion to San Francisco. We got seated at the chef's table, which I loved because we got to see all of the action going on behind the counter. My first impression was that the overall the decor of the whole place gives the restaurant a nice feel, except those bar stools were pretty rickety and could do to be more sturdy. Onto the food:

The smoked salmon montadito had some amazing layers of flavor. The uni montadito was delicious as well, with surprisingly delicate flavors and nothing overpowering the other. Melting the lardo over the uni was a great touch. 
We also ordered the olive oil poached shrimp, which I can say I would be able to eat a whole pound of probably. Not only were the shrimp cooked perfectly, but then you had all that goodness inside the head. The olive oil with black garlic added a nice hint of garlic flavor to the shrimp whilst allowing the natural sweetness of the shrimp to shine through. 
Our favorite dish of the meal was the grilled razor clams. We've never had these clams before but I think we've found our new addiction. My boyfriend was quite literally blown away by this dish, and I mean he swayed backwards in disbelief at how amazing the texture and flavor of this clam was. A few parties around us had ordered this dish as well and we were tempted to steal one from their plates. 

Of everything we ordered, there was only one dish that didn't really stand out - the albondigas. It wasn't that the dish wasn't good, it just didn't taste as good as the description. The flavors reminded me a bit of chinese cha shiu pork, but extremely tender and juicy. 

My compliments to the chef for creating such wonderful dishes and definitely props to the kitchen staff for their excellent coordination and composure. It was a pleasure and great entertainment to see everyone working in such great unison in the kitchen and to eat food carefully crafted by them. I can't wait to come back again for my next meal.
author: Grace C.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!!!!!!! One of my favorite places to go and grab a drink and enjoy a quick bite. Had a lot of things on the menu and even though im not sold on coming here purely for a meal I love coming here and sitting in the bar area (which you dont need to have reservations for) and having an appetizer or two. The chefs meat and cheese platter go great with pretty much any cocktail on the menu. I love there gin & tonic, i think its called the barca, which is there signature cocktail as well the spanish holiday which is a little bit more on the sweet side but it does have vodka which is always a plus for me. Staff is also very friendly which is always a plus!!!!! The bar area isnt huge so i probably wouldnt recommend coming here with a large party however i think its the perfect environment for a party of 2-4 people.
author: Dmitriy G.

description: We worked with Coqueta's special events contact to plan a client dinner for 12, and they did a fantastic job planning and executing our dinner. They helped us brainstorm thoughtful touches to incorporate into the meal to ensure the event was memorable for everyone, and they were very accommodating to our special requests. The ambiance, food, cocktails and service were impeccable. Thank you for a fabulous evening!
author: Anna H.

description:
The four of us did lunch here last Saturday. Amazing place! Great tapas and a nice wine list heavy on the Spanish side.
Our best tapas experience on the west coast of the US. Better than Bravas Tapas up in Healdsburg. I think this is the best Chiarello venture yet.
Don't miss it!
author: Jerry P.

description: We made a lunch res.  We had some concerns about service after reading some of these reviews but it was all for naught.  The man, himself opened the door upon our arrival.  Michael Chiarello is gracious and warm.  We were surprised to see him in the middle of the week at lunch!  We ordered about six different items starting with a cheese plate.  My daughter had the foamy margarita and I had the conquistador. We ordered the kale salad and it was just amazing.  The apple and pear salad, also delicious.  We also ordered the pan con tomato and the patatas braves. Everything was just fabulous and the service was perfect. Looking forward to going back for dinner!
author: Elaina S.

description: We had a pleasant lunch sitting outside. The food is tasty, but portions are very small and the prices are very high. Yep, it is a tapas place and so you need to order about three dishes per person and the average price is $10 per dish, add drinks and that lunch is about $45+ per person. Just setting your expectations.
author: Karrot L.

description:
I came to this restaurant with a group of friends for cocktails and apps shortly after it opened. I loved the drinks and the apps were tasty so came back for lunch when I was in the area today. I have to say it was disappointing enough that I am going to cancel my anniversary  dinner reservation that  I had  made for next month.

Here's why... food is very tasty but portions are ridiculously small for the price. We ordered an appetizer, small but its an app, OK (Calamari, grilled.. very wood oven smoky tasting, excellent) Then my son and I ordered one of the dishes recommended for "2 or more" the pork came and it was delicious, but enough for 2 or more?? Not even close!! I am a petitie female with an average appetite and I was with my 20 yo son.. That dish would have been an app for him and a good SOLO lunch portion for me... $38.00 for approx 5 oz of sliced pork..

Service was OK.. not great. Had to remind waitress to bring my drink after the appetizer arrived. 

Overall food very tasty but  minus two stars for tiny portions and big prices. Lots of good food in SF .. spend elsewhere.Or for a better deal on a great meal visit Michael's place in Yountville, Bottega!
author: Jean T.

description: Awesome food, incredible service (They come to our table between dishes and clean the table!) And I always have a weak spot for restaurants who serves quality tea, Everything was so flavorful and well potioned, and paella was awesome! Recommended.
author: Takahiro K.

description: Been to this place about 10 times and counting,  can't get enough. Cocktails, food, service and atmosphere are absolutely the best! Reservations are highly recomended for those who desire formal dining, but the bar area is even more fun !
author: Nutty V.

description: Such a lovely spot for lunch or an afternoon drink on a clear day. The tapas are, for the most part, awesome. The place feels cozy and vibrant at the same time. Ive sat at the bar a number of times and always had a great bartender who was game to surprise us with delicious cocktails. I've experienced the staff to be very friendly and professional and haven't had a bad meal yet. That said, it is a bit pricey for the small tapa servings but, its SF, what would you expect?
author: Kym J.

description:
A vibrant, celebratory restaurant that walks a very fine line between being a neighborhood focused, locals place and a special occasion "destination" restaurant. Michael Chiarello generally is able to pull this dual requirement off rather well (his Bottega in Yountville is a sterling example) and this somewhat unimpressive-looking joint does the trick. 
The creators of this restaurant made some very bold decisions with this locale that will either work out nicely or may potentially backfire. Time will tell. 
The first thing that strikes you is just how small the space is. The Embarcadero has a very spacious, expansive feel to it, but this restaurant feels much more cozy, controlled, focused, and intimate relative to its environs. The entry space is phone-booth tiny and the main dining area is not much bigger--a far cry from the often cavernous tapas bars that predominate in this country. There will be no rollicking, boisterous good cheer at this otherwise sunny-bronzed and energetic space. It is simply too small. Even the greenhouse-like bar area feels a bit cramped and it has a rather hurried, wedding-tent-rental feel to it., even it if it is dazzling in its burnt orange hue (a nod to Bottega).
Another decision (and one that adds to the feeling of feeling somewhat constrained) was to not make this a "view" restaurant. While it has a very strong sense of place what with requisite skaters and joggers passing by as if on TV, there is a decidedly detached feeling one gets when seated inside. There are windows, but there is a kind of privacy to the interior that seems somewhat jarring. One does not feel a part of the scene of the Embarcadero when dining here. You are indoors and yet feel like you should be outdoors.
This may not be a bad thing. First off, the Embarcaero is not a good place for an outdoor cafe (too blustery and, frankly, too much bird poop). Second, view restaurants are famous for distracting you from mediocre food and this place is nothing like a view restaurant. The food is sumptuous, lovingly and expertly prepared, and has hits aplenty. The menu has been carefully crafted with several strong renditions of Spanish classics that anchor the menu, with some truly inspired flavor combinations delivered in a playful, almost whimsical way that allow the diner to get creative.
The best view in the house is at the bar itself where the full menu is available. The scene feels more like a farmers market than a cocktail dispensary, what with all of the insanely fresh fruits and vegetables that combine with locally sourced, top-shelf, and artisanal liquors and mixers. This may be the only place on earth to get very intoxicated and feel like you are getting healthier in the process. 
I highly recommend the octopus and anything with shrimp in it. The Sangria is delicious as well. 
I recommend taking your time here. Michael Chiarello's restaurants operate on a different time frame than other restaurants.
