So many people come to his outposts after going to great lengths to get reservations only to become frustrated if they are not served or waited on immediately. People need to relax and take in the scene like they do in Europe. Watch the highly trained servers do their thing with confidence and unhurried brilliance. Your food will come, my friend. And at just the right time. You have not been forgotten, I assure you. Take time to read the wonderfully detailed wine list, which is clearly a labor of love in its assemblage. There are stories and informative tidbits about the wines of Spain that make you want to order everything on the menu. Shut up and learn something about Sherry or Cava, for example.
A final note: pay attention to how full you are getting. The portions were a bit bigger than I was expecting after reading some other reviews on here about poor bang for the buck and I got quite full after splitting four tapas with my wife without any mains. A disciplined diner should be able to get out with your belly full for 70 dollars sans booze and about 150 with an extremely solid buzz. Not bad for such a great meal.
author: Blue B.

description: HOLY CRAP! This place is amaze balls! Such a beautiful space, excellent service and the food is a bit pricy but oh so delicious! I just love how many items you can try due to the small plates. I could not get over how happy I was when I left. Just overall a GREAT experience.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Nothing spectacular. We tried almost every dish on the menu. I can't see any dish was memorable. In addition, they requested a $5/person cake cutting fee!
author: G M.

description: AMAZING!!!  YUM is all I have to say.  The drinks are probably ones of the best that I have in the city.  Went here with the Cousin Brother In Law when he was in town for business.  We ended up getting sitting at the bar, which was fine given there was the 3 of us.  We started the evening with an amazing g&t, and I am not a gin person.  The food was amazing.  Had the potatos (which were above average), the Tortilla "Andres which was amazing.  Will be going back very soon.
author: Sheetal P.

description: The food is fantastic! Layered flavors the do a dance in your mouth. The wood grilled octopus was spectacular! Taking one star away because the seating (at the chef's counter) is incredibly uncomfortable for anything more than a quick drink.
author: REN S.

description: Thanks for adding a coat check!  Food was still fantastic when we returned.
author: ML ..

description: The food is authentically Spanish, with Estrella beer too. The maitre d' this afternoon was cold and uninviting. Drinks took way too long to receive.
author: lance l.

description: Very disappointed in my favorite chef Michael Ciarello. The dishes were oily and lacked flavor, the sangria was bitter and flavorless and the service was way below par for the price. The ambiance was okay, but we won't be returning.
author: Molly D.

description:
I had such high hopes for Coqueta.  I'm a HUGE fan of Bottega and was excited to celebrate my birthday dinner last nite at Michael Chiarello's latest venture.
On the plus side, our waiter was terrific,...he was expert at his knowledge of the food and drinks.  Ambiance was cozy and we had a wonderful corner booth.
And the drinks were really interesting and delicious.
As for the food, the only item that had my table-mates licking their plates was the Monterey Calamari.  We  enjoyed the Chicken & English Pea Croquetas and the Grilled Albondigas, but that was about it.
On the "meh" side were; Jamon Serano (what's the big deal?), a good yet not amazing Branzino, and pretty common roasted Padron Peppers.
The worst item was the Crispy Shrimp Chickpea Flour Pancake.  Not "meh"...it was "feh"...overcooked and greasy.
While I liked the Manchego Cheesecake pops and Churros, they weren't memorable endings to our meal.
One really annoying part of our dining experience was the music.  There was a large speaker over our table and the tunes sounded like something out of an old "Loveboat" episode.  C'mon,..how about some Spanish guitar?
All in all, a disappointing birthday dinner.  Next time I want great tapas, I'll head over to the Mission and order up some deliciousness at Esperpento.
author: Dennis S.

description:
I wanted to LOVE this place. I loved Michael Chiarello - I loved watching him on Top Chef Masters, I like his cookbooks, etc. etc.

And I can say I loved the decor, because it's truly amazing. Opulent and rustic all at the same time.

I can say I liked the cocktail I had - not too heavy or sweet.

But the food? I didn't like the food! I *wanted* to! But the menu was a little confusing and what we ordered, almost to a dish, was underwhelming, with many dishes lacking (oh, I'm cringing at the overused word, but it's the only one that fits) - balance. We had a quail egg skewer that was way too savory, a pea salad - same thing - too savory, needed some salt / acid (even though it was so fresh I swear they must have just harvested the ingredients themselves twenty minutes ago). There was one pork dish with herbs that was tasty, but for the price? Not what I'd order again.

The one REMARKABLE dish was the apple pie with blue cheese ice cream. That was crazy delicious.

Worth a trip back? Probably not. But definitely worth ordering.
author: Rachael S.

description:
It started out BAD! Here's my vent...below is the Food review! 
The host, for what I thought was the host who didn't great us...well, was actually the manager. If I'd run the place he'd be fired instantly...and FYI - I complained and said it exactly like this.
We walked in with our baby and he stood there and just ignored us...then he greets us with "Yes?"...Well, I have a reservation, I replied under this name..."You reserved for 2"..That already got my blood going...because I booked on Open Table and where you can't book for adults and kids but I wrote specifically that we would need a high chair. His snobby attitude didn't change even after he saw the note below. He treated his fellow employees just as bad.
YOUR FIRED!!! If you can't handle the heat get out of the kitchen.

4 stars because of Manager attitude!!!

Well, the hostess who should be the manager (Please promote her) came by unknowingly about the situation and was so pleasant and so helpful and respectful it made us smile again. 
Dear hostess (Manager by now? ;) who was so nice to us...I'm sure you know who we are..Don't ever cover for your bosses unacceptable attitude. It's not your fault. ;)

Ok, now to the food...the food service FYI was also very good..:)
The food...Yes, I read some reviews below and some people tend to forget that this is a Spanish restaurant...TAPAS!!! Not American football sized plates for crying out loud...
The food was excellent...we came for lunch and still had to wait because it was packed and rightfully so.
We had the croquettes,...3 small ones that I had control myself not to inhale...Tapas are meant for sharing...yeah I know..lol
Oh they were good...next came the Octopus..a little salty like some other reviews stated and I believe it happens when they sprinkle the salt on before it's send out. Still DELICIOUS.
Short Ribs...Short for short lived...they were gone faster than you pronounce the full name on the menu..including the pomegranate seeds. Perfectly cooked with a nice sauce..OMG. I'm hungry again and some bread with tomato something...I forgot...it was gone in an blink of an eye.
In between some Sardines...also very tasty and at the end the cheese plate...I couldn't walk out..I rolled out. ;)

So, the final word on this place. 

Some other reviews complain about the price. Well, it's not your Taco Bell and this is prime location and the food is of top notch quality. If you decide to come here, which I can only encourage you to do if you're a foodie like me, come in a group...make reservation in advance and have a fantastic time like we did. (except the check-in part). 
It's worth a trip!!!!
Take it from a world-traveled-foodie expert.
buena Appetitt
author: Jeff S.

description: Great food, great food, and excellent warm service.  Every item is savory and delicious.  The servers are able to pair wines with each dish, and you will want to come back again and again.  Michael knows.
author: John K.

description:
New favorite restaurant in SF, and I've tried a good portion of the top 100.  Sit at the bar for the view, but better yet, for the best bar action (I'm talking blow torches, dry ice, smoked glasses!) and the nicest/coolest bar tenders in town. Zero pretentiousness (hard to find at popular spots in SF). Sent us free dessert at the end. Perfection all around. Definitely coming back. 

Favorites:
Salmon ahumado montadito
Pulpo
Sunny side up
Albondigas
Manchego cheesecake pops
author: Candice C.

description:
True Basque food has been sadly missing from the Bay Area dining scene - until the past year when three spots: Coqueta in San Francisco, Donostia in Los Gatos, and Mundaka in Carmel have (thankfully) opened to introduce some pretty authentic riffs on this under-represented cuisine. 

Coqueta is a fun, quality and idealized version of a tapas tavern, and a definite recommendation for anyone interested in testing the waters of Spanish cuisine. Michael Chiarello brought his A-game with this hip, inviting and exciting space that is no way intimidating or pretentious. Bring an appetite, and plan to test drive a lot of different flavors.

Disclaimer: I'm a big fan of Chef Chiarello (Bottega every Mother's Day and the owner of all his cookbooks), so it was super exciting to see him working the line the night we visited.The man did not disappoint. He was his usual charming, gracious and oh-so-brilliantly smiling self. He posed for photos, inspected almost every dish exiting his kitchen, personally plated and served an enormous paella to a large party, chatted us up about the new space and even shared plates of a special paella AND offered two complimentary glasses of Syrah from his family's vineyard. The man is an exceptional host - fun and charismatic. I absolutely adore this guy.  

We arrived on a Wednesday evening at 5:15 with Open Table reservations. Here's our experience.

The space: waterfront with a clear view of the Bay Bridge. The décor: NapaStyle all the way. You can't fault the guy for using the space as an advertisement for his housewares chain - but he pulled it off with style. Vaulted ceilings and huge picture windows let in light and the water view, with the interior decked out in warm, rustic fashion. Hightops perforate the walls, a huge communal table - which probably seats 20 (but I believe can be broken into smaller sections) is stationed in the center of the space, and a open-air kitchen with a wood-fire oven is flanked by a long, marble-topped bar. Chiarello was savvy enough to install a "pintxos" display bar, mimicking the way tapas is laid out on bar counters in San Sebastian. There's also an outdoor space that - in the summer / warm days - looks like a great spot for a cocktail and small plate. 

The food. We tried: 
* House-cured boquerones: Fun presentation (in an anchovy can) and bright pop of flavor. Served with lightly dressed greens. Well done. 
* White gazpacho w/ marcona almonds and grapes: Sweeter than what I've experienced in Spain. Interesting concept, but fell a little flat on flavor and more almond-centric than I expected. But will give it another shot. 
* Olive-oil poached asparagus: Beautifully cooked asparagus, but the red wine "aioli" was lost on us. Again - interesting concept, but the flavor seems muted. 
* Pan con Tomate: The bread is stellar - like a cross between ciabatta and lavash - is airy and crisply. Traditional pan con tomate is simply tomato rubbed on warm bread, perhaps with olive oil and a sprinkle of sale. Coqueta's version is more like a sofrito on the bread, a mixture of cooked down garlic, onions and tomatoes.  
* Roasted pardon peppers: Perfectly cooked, but a slightly heavy on the sherry vinegar, which wasn't evenly distributed across the dish.
* Whole Monterey calamari: Excellent. 
* Grilled razor clams: 100% delightful and we could have ordered them all evening. 
* Wood-grilled octopus: Nicely charred. Good flavor. 
* Grilled albondigas: Nice flavor, slightly mealy texture. 
* "Tattas" Bravas: Artistically plated. The bravas salsa was bright and sweet and spicy. 
* Vineyard greens: Hands-down FAVORITE dish of the night. A must try. 

Drinks: My partner had a gin and tonic - which must be the unofficial cocktail of Spain. He ordered the Spanish Holiday, which was beautiful and extremely refreshing. Like the razor clams, Coqueta is only a handful of other restaurants in the area (Donostia) that serves authentic Basque cidre (cider) - the Isastegi label. Fresh, dry, a perfect apertif. The wine menu is fair - but I thought the by-the-glass list a little lacking in European style whites and reds. 

Service: We couldn't take a sip of water without our glasses refilled, the service was so hyper-attentive. Plates were removed quickly, our space repeatedly cleaned up, and we never had to search for a server. Hats off to the staff for being incredibly friendly and observant. 

Seriously though, Coqueta has all the qualities of an exciting food-find: hip but in no way intimidating, rustic decor with a modern edge, old school without the kitsch, welcoming without the forged frenzy and a wonderful, fully approachable selection of tapas. 

A great date place and a fun, utopian, semi Wine-Country-ized version of a tapas bar. Definitely recommended
author: Gigi G.

description:
DEFINITELY the best tapas I've ever had, and the service was excellent too! The food, cocktails and dessert are all super unique and tasty - this is a place I'd come back to again and again.

All of these were delicious and unique, so I please try them all if you can (but I've also prioritized, with 1 being the highest, in case you're too full):

Dinner - 
1. Paella - BEST PAELLA OF MY LIFE.
2. Salmon Ahumado - the subtle truffle honey flavor is remarable 
3. Albondigas a la Feria - I don't like pork or duck, but these meatballs were out of this world
4. Jamon Serrano - the apricot-sherry glaze made this bite-size skewer super unique
5. Purple Kale Salad (not sure if this is still on the menu though)
6. Grilled Octopus - simple but delicious

Dessert - 
1. Manchego Cheesecake Pops with Caramel Popcorn - MUST TRY
2. Asturian Apple Pie - I was very skeptical about the blue cheese ice cream, but it was super unique
3. Molten Chocolate Cake - YUM YUM YUM with the crem anglaise on top
author: Gia K.

description: I loved this place!! fun atmosphere, didn't feel overpriced. Great food & wine.
author: Claire b.

description: Spanish restaurant, what a delight, very good service and food quality. the wine is served in 250ml which gives you 2-3 glasses.
author: George S.

description: Tasty food for small portions.  The food is so rich, that's all you really need.  You end up leaving happy and satisfied.
author: Claire C.

description: I went there for a medium (~20 people) corporate event. They took a while to seat us, but I didn't coordinate the event so I have no idea whose fault that was. Once we got seated, the food was heavenly and the service was extremely attentive. I could tell they were working their tails off to keep us happy. My favorite was the smoked salmon. It had a little something extra in terms of flavor, even more so than most good smoked salmon. The gaucho steak was mouth watering. The cheese was so rich and flavorful. Pickled garbanzo beans in the kale salad. Espinacas was somehow the least exciting thing I tried, and even that was more than passable. I know this is a serious crime, but I was too full and approaching food-coma levels of incoherence to try the paella. But seriously, A+ on the food. I can't imagine this was a cheap event by any means, so keep other people's comments on the price in mind if you're going on your own recognizance.
author: Laura H.

description:
The urban dictionary defines coqueta, as flirtatious, or a girl who flirts. As a fan of Michael Chiarello, this doesn't surprise me one bit. His charm in the kitchen and behind the camera eludes just that, Coqueta. However, in relation to his new Spanish style tapas, it's easy to imagine how this would pertain to his many playful tapas. Having been to Michael Chiarello's Bottega in Yontville several times, this is a step away from his familiar farm to table Italian roots. 

Although I had planned on visiting Coqueta soon after they opened, I actually ended up walking by during my lunch break. Why not? Since it was in the middle of the day, Michael wasn't there, although one would get a sense of him through the food, open kitchen, and slightly off the norm outside bar area. When you walk through the bar area to go through to the restaurant, you almost feel as if you're being transported from a coastal European bistro, to a secret underground dining club. Not in the literal sense, but once you transport yourself from the bar into the dining area with a small open kitchen, it's as if anything can happen. From the coarse wooded columns to the eccentric wine decanters, it feels like a supper club, anyone would want to immerse themselves into.

I indulged in 4 different tapas. From the cold tapas, I started out with the white gazpacho, and from the hot tapas I chose the crispy shrimp and chickpea flour pancake, the wood-grilled octopus, and grilled albondigas made of duck and pork meatballs with a tart cherry and tempranillo purée.  Every dish was served to perfection. It was an art how each plate was presented in a new and unique way.  The anticipation just continued to grow from dish to dish, but the white gazpacho intrigued me the most.

Visually, the white gazpacho with macron almonds, grapes, syrah reduction and syrah-grapeseed oil was almost too pretty to eat. It was beautifully served in glass, filled about half way with the gazpacho, crowned in an array of color. The gazpacho itself was white, like a blank canvas. The presentation was a visually stunning culinary experience. The surface was painted with a splash of colors from the red wine reduction accompanied by carefully placed drops of golden oil. And finally, the center of the gazpacho was strewn with almonds adorned with a delicate, edible yellow flower. The flavor profile was equally enticing. The cold, velvety consistency of the gazpacho itself was delicate and light. The flavor was unique, combining a soft balance between savory and sweet. Hiding at the bottom of the gazpacho were thinly sliced grapes that added a sweet bite that balanced out the marcona profile. To round off the perfect taste, the spoon does all the work as it gently lifts all the flavor profiles into one flawless bite. This is coqueta.
author: Holly W.

description:
Everything's delicious and beautiful!!  Came here last night with my foodie friends.  We were all excited and pleased with our first experience at Coqueta and chef Michael Chiarello!!

Here are what we enjoyed:

- Pintxo 
  -  Quail Eggs (this is what I had, good, but no jaw-dropping)
  -  baby beets
  -  Chorizo & Grilled Artichoke
- Asparagus with pink sauce (strawberry? not sure)
  - tender, juicy, fresh and naturally sweet with the sauce and I'm still not sure what's in the sauce
- Cod Ensalada
  - ok
- Shellfish Escabeche
  -  Love it!
- Grilled Razor Clams
  - never had razor clams before and these were excellent first experience!
- Padron Peppers
  - delicious but had better
- Wood-Grilled Octopus w/ Fingerling Potatoes 
   - just ok, not sure what I missed but thought the octopus was not as flavorful as I anticipated
- Grilled Adbondigas (duck and pork meatballs 
- Jamon Serrano and Cana de Cabra cheese
  - good
- Grilled Iberico Secreto 
  -  tender, juice Iberico pork slices, WOW, medium-rare pork and delicious!!
- Scallops Arroz Vieiras 
- Warm Chocolate Cake
- Churro Fantasy
- Sangria Popsicle
- Pan Con Chocolate with Olive flavored ice cream
  

** Drinks **
- Sangrias
   - very good, not too sweet, slightly bitter/acidic just the way I like it!
- Columna Albarino
   - good, not WOW certainly had better
- decaf Coffee
   - delicious!!  Forgot the name of the brand I ordered.  They serve two local coffee brands


Also love their hot water/tea pot, stylish and easy to maneuver.  I only ordered hot water this time, will definitly give their tea selections a try my next visit.

The service was wonderful too!  Our waiter was attentive, patient for our questions and very knowledgeable!  Other service staffs assisted him in serving our table were professional too.  The BEST part was chef Michael Chiarello personally brought a dessert dish to our table (I think it's called the frozen sangria moderna)!!  He was super friendly and polite not just to us, but almost all his customers last night!  I didn't recognize him at first and asked if he is the pastry chef.  Agggghhh, it's officially a new addition of my most embarrassing moment list now!!  He didn't hesitate when we ask him to take pictures with us.  You, your creative art works, your restaurant and staffs are awesome Michael!!  I can't wait to bring more foodie friends and families to your restaurant to try more of your art works!

Welcome to San Francisco!! 

p.s.  The ambiance is aesthetic as well but I was too busy savoring the art, talking about the art work on the table and didn't get to pay much attention to the details of the interior decor this time.  When I'm with a smaller group or by myself, I'll update my review on that.
author: Gina W.

description: Amazing food, AMAZING. However hands down the WORST service I have ever encountered at an upscale restaurant. Or any restaurant for that matter. I ordered a glass of wine, 45 minutes go by, nothing. Then he presents the bill, with the wine on there of course. That is just one example of how horrendous the service was. But the food rocks!
author: Pilates G.

description: We came here for my husband's birthday with a group of 11 friends and had a wonderful time! Our table was reserved in advance and they were  flexible in having us sit at the table even before everyone had arrived. We chose to have cocktails at their bar first and it was a very fun atmosphere there. You can order appetizers at the bar too. Once we were seated, it was really easy to order family style for the entire table. The waiter made great recommendations and everyone seemed to enjoy their food and cocktails. We had a blast trying a little bit of everything and socializing with our friends. It was a lovely restaurant and the food quality was fantastic!
author: Shadi B.

description: Food, service, wine...it all came together.  Hard to suggest any improvement.  Lovely in every respect.
author: Robert M.

description: Damn good.  Everything was exceptional.  Definitely up there in meals I've had...ever.
author: Kelvin S.

description: Fantastic.  My wife and I have wanted to try this place of a while.  We finally got a chance this weekend.  Everything was excellent.  Food, service, cocktails.  We will be back.
author: Robert B.

description:
This place is amazing.  The food was well conceived and executed.  Flavors were balanced and played off well against each other.  The selection of meats and cheeses were outstanding.

We focused mainly on the small plates, meatballs, apple and pear salad, chicken and english peas croquetas, octopus and the sunny-side up egg.  Each was delicious, various cooking methods brought out the natural flavors of each.  The octopus was smokey and tender, apple and pear salad was cool and crisp.  The only off note was the sunny-side up egg with shrimp, the shrimp flavor was concentrated and was a little overpowering for the egg and potatoes.  

The wine list was comprehensive and varied, it was a pleasure learning about some of the more unique wines they had.

I also need to mention someone that brought all aspects of our dinner together, our server, Shelby.  Prompt and pleasant, Shelby was very knowledgable about the wines and the menu and spoke about flavors and pairings when we were trying to decide what to order.  After helping us navigate the menus, she timed the dishes so we were never without food but never overwhelmed.  

A+ all around.

I'll definitely be back to explore the menu more.
author: Mike I.

description: Had the best Mother's Day dinner. Love their pineapple brûlée cocktail! All the tapas were so exciting and wonderful presentation. Best grilled octopus legs, it's so tender and tasty; and that uni on bagel was out of this world, razor clam was tender and FRESH! Sautéed vege was exceptional good. Must order that cheesecake lollipops with caramel popcorn. Can't wait to go back. Oh, it had the best view of the Bay Bridge at night when it lights up.
author: Shirley T.

description:
We went to Coqueta on opening night and the food and ambiance was amazing. We arrived about a half hour before our reservation and grabbed a drink at the bar...I don't drink gin and neither does anyone in my party, but the gin and tonics at Coqueta were unbelievable, they were going down like water. Even though it was opening night, our table was ready on time and as we walked into the dining room there was Chef Chiarello in the middle of the kitchen overseeing everything. Service was great, everything came out on time and tasted delicious. The staff was so well trained and felt as if they had been working there for years. 

Our favorite tapas of the night were:
Over-easy egg with shrimp and crispy potatoes on top (I would go back just to have this dish) 
Grilled razor clams
Chicken and English Pea croquettes with cured cara cara oranges
Grilled rib-eye

Dessert: I had the churros with the chocolate dipping sauce and it was amazing. I also heard the molten chocolate cake was good, but I didn't try it.

During dinner Chef Chiarello made his rounds to every table to see how everything was. He even stopped to take a few pics with fans (like myself). 

Overall we had a great experience at Coqueta and cannot wait to go back. Congratulations to Chef Chiarello and his team and wish them all the best of luck!!!
author: Penny V.

description:
Michael Chiarello's show was my absolute favorite. I couldn't wait to try Coqueta.
My Husband & I were given dinner at Coqueta's for our Anniversary. Without a doubt, it is a Dining Experience...We enjoyed it so much that we brought our friends back last weekend.
The food excellent and cocktails artistic and delicious...There were 8 of us so we tried a very nice variety of dishes and each were excellent. My favorite was the wood-grilled octopus. Our service was over the top..Thank you Heather & Nicole for making our evenings enjoyable!
author: Arlene D.

description: One of the most fun meals I've had in a long time, and I enjoy eating out often!  We sat at the chef's counter and absolutely loved the atmosphere.  The wine was fantastic, the service impeccable.  We sat here for hours and absolutely enjoyed everything we tried.  The drinks were fun and the decor was great.  Love, love, love this restaurant!
author: Janelle C.

description: Superb food, amazing view, and friendly staff. This is a go-to place for me when I am getting together with friends after work.
author: Chuong N.

description:
Fantastic!
Well-priced wine list with lots of variety. 
ALBONDIGAS. Amazing. Don't miss the cheesecake pops for dessert. You really can't go wrong here. 
Get the coquettes! 
Michael was there when we were there. Fun! Crispy shrimp was amazing. 
Bring your checkbook- it ain't cheap, but it's SO worth it. Enjoy!!
author: Mary D.

description: Good food, service was fantastic. Meatballs, squid, octopus and pork shoulder were our favorites. Save room for dessert churro, cheesecake and/or salted caramel. Hard to go wrong at this place!
author: Alexis M.

description: Great restaurant with great atmosphere. The tapas were amazing. I highly recommend beginning with the meat and cheese plate. I tried almost everything on the menu and it was all superb. One of my favorite restaurants in SF
author: Louis L.

description: Don't come here if you have a little one. The entire restaurant has only 1 high chair.
author: Lani N.

description:
Went in knowing nothing about Coqueta. Came out loving everything about it. Every detail seemed to be thought out - the silverware, the cups, the plates. Everything had style. The drinks looked like works of art. The food was unreal. Everything was unbelievably amazing. Service was top notch.

Personal fave: The "Gaucho" bone-in 32 oz. natural beef ribeye.

Can't wait to go back.
author: Simon M.

description: Bad service. We had a reservation at 9,30 pm. Actually, when we arrived on time, we were told to wait for other at least 20 minutes and invited to wait outside in a bar near the pier. We are turists and didn't know where to go. When we got back we waited for  more than 10 minutes. When we ordered to drink, they served us the wrong drinks. In the end, we asked foe desserts cheese cake, but they don't have any left, so they came up with a couple of bites of it. Nice place but worst service ever.
author: T F.

description: Had a fantastic lunch at Coqueta today sitting in the sun at one of their two outdoor tables.  The servers were very accommodating, facilitating our moves from the main dining room to the side bar area over to our final destination outside, where we feasted on calamari a la plancha, grilled octopus, arroz cremosa (with scallops) and a side of vineyard greens.  The seafood was all perfectly cooked (I've experienced a lot of gross rubbery octopus in past, but this was anything but), and wonderfully seasoned.  We also tried two of the small bite desserts - cheesecake pops with salted caramel popcorn, and the three pintxos.  Each bite was a creatively scrumptious combo of sweet and salty.  The chocolate covered olives were a particularly interesting dessert.  Coqueta is worth revisiting for sure, for lunch again and hopefully dinner in the not-to-distant future.
author: melita s.

description: The food and service were amazing.  Definitely take more people so that you can order the 32 oz Gaucho for four.  Must get the sunny side up eggs, paella, pluma, sun never sets and the pluma.
author: Suz L.

description:
Giving it 3 stars reluctantly. Come on guys,really? My son and I, having read all the wonderful reviews, decided to go to an early(11:30) lunch there, Seated in the bar area, on stools I needed a stool to reach, we looked at the menu and ordered 3 tapas, 2 salads and desserts.
We got 9 toothpicks with various little tidbits on them., 3 mushrooms with little meatballs,2 very small salads , and then desserts. Got to talk about the desserts. 3 more toothpicks (one inedible) and apple pie with blue cheese ice cream. We both tasted the ice cream and could not believe how bad it was! My reaction was 'how dare they experiment on us ? If they tasted it before serving it they never would have served it. After paying our $90.00 for lunch, my son left hungry, and wanted to stop at the nearest hot dog  stand for something to eat!
author: Roberta Z.

description:
Went here with a couple friends for a birthday. The food was average. I actually think the best part of the meal was the cocktails.

We ordered the Grand meat and cheese plate to start. It was nothing special. It was certainly tasty, and certainly devoured, but it did not have anything more spectacular than any other restaurant's meat and cheese plate.

We also had the sunny side up egg. This was mediocre. It was kind of greasy, and the flavor was nothing more than eggy-greasy-potatoes. It's hard to go wrong with that, but it didn't add some sort of imaginative twist to that mixture.

We also got the octopus. Small portion. Chewy. I have had way better octopus.

The razor clams were raved about, and yes, they were pretty tasty. But the serving was outrageously small, and frankly, I would not order them again for that very reason.

We ordered the short ribs lastly and the ribs were chewy. 

Lastly, everything we ordered that should have been hot was tepid, and sometimes cold. That probably took away from the flavors.

The atmosphere is very cool. The service was great. And we had a fun time. The food just didn't impress.
author: renee H.

description: Great place for drinks! Infused unique concoctions. the Gin and Tonic with the juniper, rose and grapefruit is delightful refreshing!
author: Lauren D.

description: awesome tapas place!  Michael Chiarello never disappoints!  His plate presentations are elegant, modern, but not pretentious!  This space is very masculine with leather and brown fabric, but without being off putting to the female crowd.  They have iberico pork imported from spain that is a pork lovers dream.  Great cured meat and cheese selection, hot and cold tapas, and a few larger plates.  A small dessert menu, but each item seems to be well done.  Will return soon.  Great location with a few parking lots on broadway.
author: Rebecca W.

description: After being away in Italy for the past couple years and often venturing into Spain, having this place at home waiting for me definitely helps with the separation anxiety. Many tasty and thoughtful options, I'm looking forward to returning here. Good quality cocktails too.
author: Caitlin T.

description: Met some friends here who live in the SF area. One of the hottest spots going. We had to make a reservation  months ahead. They were extremely flexible when we called to change the time and number. Fantastic cocktails best G&T's EVER !! As a tapas place they do a great job with the dishes. Excellent flavors and a great variety of menu items. Not cheap but worth it. Excellent service, very nice with great personality. not in that kind of way haha.. cute as a button actually hot :) she handled our group with youngin perfectly. We had a group of 6 adults one child with cocktails,  3 deserts and a couple coffees it was appx. $70 ea.  Go check um out if you get the chance.
author: James F.

description:
Tried this place out tonight and while the design of the restaurant, the presentation of the food are all quite gorgeous, I thought the food we did have were hit and miss.  The service that we have from our main server was that of benign neglect.  On to the food:  My favorite was the razor blade clam, cooked tender-crisp, giving a slight resistance on the initial bite but otherwise very easily chewable and tastily digested.  But at $14 for 3, it is a rather steep taste.  The next dish that I very much enjoyed was the grilled squid, richly flavored, very tender baby mollusks.  We ordered a total of 6 tapas, tried all of the 1-bite skewers, and the apple pie with bleu cheese ice cream.  The one dish that I won't order again is their version of Tortilla Espanola.  Though prettily adorned with edible flowers, it is a totally bland potato pie.  On to service:  Because our main server is so inattentive to us, we have to hail different servers/other staff to order a second round of tapas, check on our drinks, etc. Good thing the others are better at their jobs.  

So, in summary, we'll probably end up here again in the future.  But I for one am not looking to rush back here anytime soon.
author: Yvette F.

description: Really good food in a casual atmosphere.  I highly recommend the gin drinks to start.   The are fun but not too crazy.  All of the tapas we ordered were amazing.  I really liked the octopus and the squid.  Our server was great as well.  The best restaurant on my last trip to San Fran.
author: Craig O.

description: This place is pretty expensive for the amount of food you get but the execution is pretty awesome.  We only ate here at the bar but we can't wait to go back for din din.
author: Fatty A.

description:
what a letdown.  we're not sure why there is such a wait to get into this place aside from the fact that it isn't very big.

the food was average, basic, uninspired, overly verbose descriptions and poor execution.

we had a salad, uni sandwich, 3 sausage platter, pork shoulder entree.  all of these were barely memorable that i had to refer to the menu again on the website to remember what we had.

we've eaten several times at michael chairello's place in yountville and there is no comparison.  should there be?  maybe in the quality of food if nothing else and coquette pales by comparison.
author: C C.

description: so, it was super expensive. like really expensive and i left sober and hungry. i'd come back for the uni - on someone else's dime.
author: Thao T.

description: I had a Friday lunch there with a friend. We got a few small plates sitting at the bar. Great cocktail - Conquistador! Octopus and potatoes were good. Squid was very tasty. Escabeche meh. Asparragos was good but came with a strange raspberry foam, which I think they referred to as aioli. Hmm. Duck meatballs were meaty, but very soft. I guess I like my meatballs crispy. You might like them soft. Very tasty!
author: Bowen D.

description: Tried Coqueta in May for our anniversary. Really really good. We commented that the food actually reminded us of our trip to Spain. The owner clears pays close attention to the little details that delight the customers and add to the ambiance. We had montonitos, pardon peppers, asparagus, secreto de puerco iberico (I'm likely butchering the spelling), and other gems... And a mean gin and tonic. It's worth noting that having reservations might also have you sitting at the kitchen counter. We were surprised by this but wound up delighted to see the kitchen in action and chat with the chef. I recommend this place to friends.
author: Bing B.

description:
I was excited to try the new Spanish restaurant, remembering fondly of all the tasty food we had in Spain years ago.  The food did not disappoint.  

House cured ham was delicious (came in 4 pieces.)
The plate of olives kept us busy while waiting on our dishes and the green ones were my favorite.
White gazpacho with almond, grape and syrah was not only visually stunning but tasty too, with a wonderful and subtle blend of nuttiness and sweetness.  Definitely something to enjoy at a restaurant and difficult to replicate at home.
Razor clams were good and not rubbery at all.  My husband thought it was fun to try but didn't seem to care to ever eat it again.
We both loved the octopus.  He claimed it was the best octopus he's had.  I wasn't about to draw the same conclusion but fail to come up with a good contender.  The flavor was savory with a hint of spice and the meat was so tender. 
I loved the garlic shrimps.  For $14, you get three (no dishes here come cheap of course).  They were giant, but not over cooked. The blend of spice and olive oil was so perfect.  
For dessert, we had the manchego ice cream bite which was really fun, really cute and really tasty (think salted caramel with a cheesecake flavor.)  The churros were good, but didn't beat the ones I had recently at Padrecito.

Other elements of the restaurant like the decor and service were a mixed bag.  I get the rustic look, and the meat and wine bottles stacking up looked very fitting, but the boxes sitting on top of the wine cabinet just makes me think of possible earthquake scenarios. Plus, I don't get the aesthetic appeal of these boxes.  Or the giant printer next to the bathroom. 

The server was cordial and did what she had to do. But the whole time I felt like she didn't want to be there. And she quietly gave us our check without any of us having asked for it or explaining something like "hey, my shift is over, so here is the check, take your time, blahblahblah." And then she never came to pick up the credit card and someone else had to come to get it.  I am usually not that picky about service ---I mean, I know I am not sitting at Gary Danko, but still, plenty of SF restaurants have friendly servers that make you feel like they are happy to see you, or at least they don't hate their jobs.  

Anyway, despite the service, I will definitely come back.  There are a lot of other dishes on the menu that I'd like to try next time!
author: Candice B.

description: My company rented out the entire restaurant for a private party, so my experience there was atypical. The drinks were amazing, and the food was delicious, however, so I definitely want to go back to see what a regular evening looks like.
author: David R.

description: Amazing.  The view, the service and the food was insane.  Have the sangria, its a must as is the shrimp cake.
author: Stacey W.

description: So can't review the food but thought I'd share my experience. As a former sf resident I love to visit my favorite tapas spots when I am in town. A buddy recommended Coqueta so I walked down @ 5 pm.  I was traveling alone and I can usually grab a bar seat at most popular places. My experience was just weird....the dining room was 80 percent empty. Outside bar place was full. I asked for a bar seat and was told to wait for a spot....apparently all the indoor bar seat, while empty were reserved as with all the empty tables. I was asked to stand in the outside bar area to wait while people were enjoying themselves and servers were bustling along. There was no room and I felt pretty weird standing there. It seemed the hosts really did not know how to handle people waiting? They were polite and all, it was just awkward... I felt like I was at a party I wasn't invited to. So I left, weird leaving an empty restaurant..but I guess it works for them.
author: Jim F.

description: Amazing amazing amazing! The service & the food were out of this world. We tried 7 different small plates, 2 cocktails, and 2 desserts and every bite and drink was pure joy! Heather took great care of us! This is a must try, but books up very quickly, so try to make reservations at least a week in advance.
author: Lauren Z.

description:
The food was just okay. Meatballs were interesting, but otherwise the stuff that was great, they didn't make, like the chorizo or the cheese. That's not the only reason for a lowered rating. I made a reservation for two,  weeks in advance and had never been there before. Nothing on open table indicated that I had to say no I can't sit on a barstool that is 3 1/2 inches in depth, with no back. We arrived, excited as I love his other restaurant in Yountville. The hostess took us to the bar with the seats I described and never moved asked, is it okay to seat you at the bar. We get there and my guest knew I have a back condition and couldn't sit on seats they showed us to, and frankly, neither could she as they were quite uncomfortable. I immediately told the hostess who shrugged it off as whatever- it's all they had, not even a bs I'm sorry. I pointed out another area, an actual table for two and said, I have an injury, may I sit there. She said no it's for others arriving later. I always bring pillows with me to make it more comfortable and can usually make do, but not with the bar they offered us. The hostess said no that's for another but you can wait. Wait at 9:10 for a table, after making a reservation  weeks back and only 9 pm on a Sunday was available? My guest had the idea, could we start there and move over to other location when it became available. She reluctantly said okay. Then she came back about 10 minutes later and said you're in luck, you can move  to the table you pointed to earlier. I said, great because I'm in so much pain here. She never said she was sorry, and instead, blocked my ability to get up while she retrieved our glassware, which they swapped out at the new table. Then as I'm trying to get off  the stools and out of the area, a busboy cuts me off almost knocking me over.  So I let him pass, and then I tried again and he did it again!  I told this hostess that I was shocked they placed us at the bar without asking, and her snarky response 3 times was that open table tells me we may be seated together. I assume she meant with others. But as I told her- how does that tell a patron that they could be seated at a bar and that if they can't sit on a 3 1/2 inch seat that is heighten and ungodly uncomfortable with no back? She just kept hostilely repeating open table says you may be seated together and that I should have told them in open table.  I take issue with placing the burden on someone with a disability to know your restaurants layout. In my opinion that's a violation of the ADA and Unruh Acr.
They placed us at the other table and then every time someone passed by our table they kicked my chair hard.  (The whole night!)  I want to believe the latter stuff wasn't intentional, but no one said I'm sorry or excuse me, even the server who said he knew of back problems.  It's sad because the tables are so on top of each other and with it being tapas, the staff makes 4-6 more time the trips to each table then they would for a regular meal so, they are constantly (I assume unless their bumps and kicks to me were intentional) hitting folks' chairs. I won't go back.   I did say something to the other hostess who told me the first gal was young, as if to suggest manners cannot be trained. I won't be back. Tapas and manners are better elsewhere.
author: Traci H.

description:
I was really excited to try out Michael's new place, so I booked our 5:30 reso about a month in advance (not bc we like to eat early...bc that was the only option!). The space is very open - he did a good job with the aesthetics of it. We sat at a "family" style table with another couple, but most tables looked like two-tops. I also think the bar seating was by reservation, which I would make sure to say I didn't want when making a reso (just better to have a table with backs on our chairs). I think the outside area is first come/first serve, but I didn't ask. Ok, now on to the food. We really enjoyed each of our dishes and would definitely return, but we aren't in any hurry. I think it would be a great place for apps & drinks after work though, so maybe I'll try it out sooner than I think. The two of us spent $100 and left full, so that's great:) Everything was bite size, so keep that in mind...

- Chicken & English Pea Croquettes, 3 of them to an order. So yummy, seriously a melt-in-your-mouth chicken pot pie!
- Tattas Bravas - little friend tater tots, with melt-in-your-mouth mash potatoes inside (maybe 7 to an order). Great little dipping sauce too.
- Wood-grilled octopus with fingerling potatoes, pimenton, olive oil. The grill flavor really made this dish.
- Pork and duck albondigas with dried cherry and tempranillo, 3 of them to an order. These were sweet, and a little crunchy with fried onions on top. Was Canada's favorite.
- Arroz Cremosa with Slow Cooked Bomba Rice, Day Boat Scallops and squash with squash blossoms. I really liked the squash and scallops, but otherwise was probably our least favorite dish (and was our "main"). Just tasted quite fishy to me (others around us ordered the paella, which looked bomb).
- Manchego Cheesecake bits w/ Caramel Corn, 2 to an order - these were just so yummy, and I never order cheesecake. The people next to us ordered them, so I had too...
- Molten chocolate cake. This again was good, interesting flavors with the tamarindo spices, but I preferred the cheesecake bites.

Overall I would recommend it bc it's the new hot restaurant and I am glad we hit it up.
author: Jenn D.

description: First, this is a review about horrible service and lack of basic humanity and empathy, as I didn't eat here, I just stopped by this restaurant to have dinner with my in-laws who are visiting from Spain. My two year old had fallen sleep, and her aunt was carrying her in her arms.  I spoke to the host to ask for a table. The restaurant was empty inside, none of the tables had any people. The bar was full of people. He asked if we were having dinner and I said that two people would have full dinner and two people would have drinks and appetizers. HE said I should sit at the bar and I explained that I have a sleeping baby and I need a table as I don't have a stroller, he said he didn't have a table for THAT. I left and will never return. Hope this review serves for this person to change and for this restaurant to give a good look at their policies because I love spending my money in great restaurants where the food is great and there is PEOPLE working there, not money making machines who can't think out of their quota per person for a table. It is sad to have experiences like this.
author: Daniela J.

description: What a terrible experience.  It is hard to believe that this restaurant has received so many good reviews.  What happened?  Upon arrival they tried to seat us at the counter, even though we made a reservation for a table, and had confirmed by phone earlier the day of the reservation.  They gave us the table with the comment that someone else deserved the table after having made a reservation over a month ago.  Trying to guilt us out of the table I guess.  Let the games begin.  Clearly, they intended to serve us and get us off the table as soon as possible.  Our cheese plate came with a few crackers, and then they brought the entree, paella, within 15 minutes, before bringing our next tapa.  All our food within 20 minutes, in a tapas restaurant, and on a tiny table.  We asked for more crackers, and when the bill came, they charged $6.00 for five or six extra crackers.  The paella was burned, seemed to be reheated, and had four mushy shrimp, and Serrano ham that was overcooked, and as tough as jerky, with an abundance of overcooked rice.  The waiter was patronizing, and told us their orders were to keep things moving.  Shame on you Michael.  It was awful, and we paid the bill, and tipped the waiter about 18%, without causing a scene because we have class, but will never be back.
author: Rita O.

description: Had no idea this was a Chiarello place when we went for a casual lunch date mid week but he did not disappoint. The squid was particularly amazing but I don't recall anything was disappointing. We'll be back.
author: Krista M.

description: I had high expectations for this place - I used to live in Spain and absolutely love tapas restaurants. Coqueta had great reviews online so we decided to give it a shot. First, the ambiance is wonderful. It's a really cool atmosphere and reminiscent of some of the tapas joints in Spain. Unfortunately, the service was extremely slow, which I didn't mind too much given I was prepared to spend a good deal of time there and enjoy the atmosphere. However, after 15 minutes spent waiting for something to drink, it became frustrating and not enjoyable. Now, on to the food. Food was decent but horribly over priced for the portion sizes. Yes, I understand they are tapas, but what you get for the money is way less than what you get at tapas restaurants in other cities (I haven't been to any other tapas places in SF, solely comparing to NY, Philadelphia, and Chicago). Also, in my opinion none of the food had any flavor, it was all very bland. The manchego was delicious. My recommendation would be to come for 1 drink (wine seemed to be a good deal - 1 glass was a big portion) and 1 tapa per person as an appetizer and enjoy the ambiance then head out and get your dinner elsewhere.
author: Katie K.

description:
This is a review for the bar, and food service at the bar. 

Truly, this was one of the best nights out we've had in a while. I went with a friend I haven't seen for years, and my husband. We were there on a Friday night. Joe Cleveland was behind the bar, Michael Chiarello was in the kitchen and roaming the floor. Joe and his bar staff really provided wonderful service and I would go back in a heartbeat. I'm sure the restaurant proper is great, but if Joe was behind the bar (and probably even if he wasn't), I'd still choose to sit in the bar. 

The Drinks
I started the night not drinking... so I had a "J&T" - juniper and tonic. It's amazing. The best non-alcoholic cocktails I've ever had. Things moved on from there and we ended up trying quite a few of the alcoholic cocktails. Not surprisingly I can't remember their names nearly as well, but they were inventive and fresh without being pretentious or silly, and were a joy to experience. 

The Food
We weren't that hungry so ordered only tasting bites, though you can order from the full menu at the bar during meal service times. My only gripe was that the small skewers that cost $2.50 each, are really small. Like, tiny. Truly it's a half a bite of food. Other than that, the food that we did have was great (Patatas Bravas and beet salad). The Patatas Bravas were amazing. Smokey and crisp. 

Service
Truly wonderful. Even though we were sitting at the bar on a Friday night, and not spending a particularly huge amount of cash, we were never once rushed out, or made to feel like perhaps we should move on. Service was unobtrusive when we were obviously engaged in conversation, and chatty when we weren't. We actually had to ask for our bill at the end of the night, and they let us sit there and chat and catch up for as long as we wanted. Which was a long time, as we were the last to leave and closed up the bar with the staff. 

Go here. Take a friend. You'll love it.
author: Samantha W.

description: Good service, good ambience, good food, good cocktails, good wine. What else can you ask for? Have eaten here several times and am never disappointed. If you are a foodie this is the place for you.
author: E B.

description: This place has been getting great reviews, so I had to try it. They don't have valet parking, which I think they should consider for the long-term. Overall, I thought the food was excellent and its best to share. I would hardly recommend the whole fish and pork which is there signature dish. The service is pretty good, and the ambience doesn't seem stuffy. You don't really need to dress up. This place makes is great for hanging out with friends, but not on a romantic dinner. For a romantic dinner I would stick with Danko, Benu, or Coi. The only other thing that I didn' care for in the restaurant is the high seating. Most of the tables you have to sit in a high stool or booth, so having dinner with friends for over 2 hours can feel a bit uncomfortable. I would reconsider changing the high seating. Overall, the food, location and view is wonderful. I'll be back within a year or so...
author: Mark L.

description: We were able to get a seat in front of the chef/cooks on Sunday morning. Warm and welcoming staff. The food was fantastic: tattas bravas, grilled octopus, shrimp with sunnyside up egg, and the shrimp pancake. To finish, the churros, manchego cheesecake bites, and blue cheese ice cream. It was quite the enjoyable experience.
author: Dustin B.

description: Had a great dinner here for my wife's birthday.  The food, drinks, ambiance, and service were great.  The only drawback was that the host was not very helpful when we first arrived, and we waited about 20 minutes even though we had a reservation.  But, the food and drinks more than made up for it, and we had a great time.  It's a great place for a great dinner.
author: Brian L.

description: I'm going to keep this very short. The food was good, but the fig tart with blue cheese ice cream was unbelievable!  An absolute must while still in season.
author: Jeffrey V.

description:
Pros: very nice atmosphere: bustling, w/ spacious high ceiling, and great food aroma. Good service. Very good meatball tapas, grilled octopus tapas, egg&shrimp tapas, jamon&queso, and spanish crispy donuts. Reasonable prices.

Cons: a little loud. Unexciting sangria and crispy shrimp tapas.
author: George F.

description: I was treated to Coqueta for dinner, and I was soooo pleased! The ambiance, great, great location, decor, and the food was "delicioso!"
author: Lupita P.

description: Sangria and Machanga Cheesecake all I need in this world.
author: Sandra R.

description: I was visiting A for the weekend and wanted to take her to lunch near the Ferry Building.  For some reason A is terribly unimpressed with the Slanted Door - my first suggestion - so instead we agreed on Coqueta.  A was ecstatic to add to her treasure trove of open table points ....  Sometimes I let A get away with too much but that story is for another day.  The space is near Pier 5 and has an open airy feel both indoors and on the deck.  It struck me as a sophisticated girls night out type of a establishment with craft cocktails - wine and sangria offerings - as well as tapas to share.  The name meaning flirt in Spanish is appropriate.  We were seated at a communal table with a group of 40 something ladies enjoying cocktails and small bites.  We started with a gin and tonic.  The presentation and balance were the most impressive I have seen to date.  There are several pictures of the cocktails in other reviews - simply magical.  Having lived in Spain for some time I was excited to try the food.  All of the Pintxos were wonderful - my favorites being the Chorizo and Tortilla de Espinacas.  I also enjoyed the duck and pork meatballs to a lesser degree.  The prawn dishes were my least favorite due to texture and consistency.  While I could not help but look into A's eyes for most of our time at Coqueta - it is a great place to people watch with an exceptional gin and tonic.
author: Andrew L.

description: Really great location, tapas, and drinks. It would be 5 stars if there wasn't a big hair in my food. Brought this to the servers attention. He didn't seem too interested.
author: Eric D.

description: I definitely lagged in writing this review. Lagged by a few months. But I just need to get it out there that we had some of the very best cocktails and tapas we've ever had. Sorry to be slim on the details. Just go and be adventurous by ordering any cocktail or any finger food, I highly doubt you'll be disappointed. I do remember my delicious cocktail: yummy (Hendrix?) gin with Fever Tree tonic, wedge of grapefruit, juniper berries, and a sprig of some type of pine. And the service was just as excellent.
author: Jaime W.

description:
totally vibrant spot. been twice, sat outside at the bar facing the water. sat inside at the chef's counter. complaint: [chef's counter bar] seat backs would be a NICE CONSIDERATION for diners who enjoy a lengthy conversational tapas meal.

- galleon gin - clean, lightly fruity. personal preference to save for a brunch.
- engine #5 - bourbon & sherry. hit the spot. a rich musky bite, enjoyed 3. in love.
- all pintxos are tasty - fav being the chorizo
- padron peppers - generous portion. they do it right with vinegar, jamon
- iberico - *almost* what one enjoys in spain? a melty, buttery treat.
- chef's cheese selection - bleu, manchengo, goat.  marcona's.  really enjoy the crispy texture tortas.  yes please, nom. nom. nom.
- albondigas - smoky sweet & succulent  
-cheesecake bites - soft creamy inside, very sweet, caramely.  one is just perfect.
author: FancyPant S.

description: What a totally fun place!  My gin and tonic drink had potpourri in it and I ate a lot of tater tots.  Kind of a scene but that's expected at a tiny place on the water run by a celeb chef.
author: Poppy C.

description:
The scoop on the rating: volleys between a 3.75 and a 5. Sometimes a dish comes out too oily and the next time it is perfect, so that is why I rated it four stars. But when it is perfect, it is very very good! The Chef's selection of cured meats is a wonderful appetizer, especially with friends around the table. We order lots of dishes - mostly tapas- and then happily dive in. Some of our favorites:

My all-time favorite - and it is always perfect - the sliced pork loin with the honey-chilli drizzle sauce. Incredible and I am not usually a pork fan! Fabulous. You MUST order this dish.
The octopus - so fresh it practically walks up the dock and throws itself on your plate, all dressed in wonderful.
The manchego skewers - divine, and interesting.
The calamari with squid ink and yummy onion jam.
The duck and pork meatballs - more wonderful. Very tasty.

The ambience couldn't be better, lovelier or more interesting. The bay views are exceptional and you're right on the water, almost like a stable boat. The decor is all about texture and textural contrasts: glossy glass with nubby sack cloth. Polished and hammered metals, chunky woods and steel. If you just want a great bar, this is separate from the restaurant but accessed through the same glass vestibule and hostess. It is a small bar, and instantly crowded when they open. And, reservations are a MUST for the restaurant!
author: Haley M.

description: To me, the prime location to enjoy a restaurant is at the bar. You essentially enjoy a bit of theatre- the bartenders creating their concoctions, the food being prepped in front of you, seeing the menu items come alive in front of you...  Coquetta is one of those great experiences. Carefully crafted preparations in whimsical kitchen ware, delicious as well as beautiful, great theatre and great food. Sharing is best. Chiarello's take on local California Spanish cuisine- unpretentious & fun. So, do the bar, watch the prep & choose from there. Octopus delish, his take on ceviche... Just yum.
author: Stephanie R.

description: Very disappointed in my favorite chef Michael Ciarello. The dishes were oily and lacked flavor, the sangria was bitter and flavorless and the service was way below par for the price. The ambiance was okay, but we won't be returning.
author: Molly D.

description:
Currently my favorite restaurant in SF. Great spot to take people when they visit, if you can actually get a reservation. 

Love the ambiance and the decor. Amazing service. Yummy cocktails. Every dish we ordered was great. My favorites were the octopus and the paella. Such a great meal. Only complaint is that I'm having a hard time getting another reservation!
author: Ghazaleh K.

description:
I was hoping I would have been over the moon but I wasn't.  I went in the middle of the afternoon (2pm) without a reservation and had a few choices of where to sit.  I was pleasantly surprised to find that I had the option of a table for one person.  Good news as I had some work to review and the table was perfect.  
What was missing was any explanation of the restaurants, how to navigate the menu or what additions were available.
I ordered a few items that were favorites on Four Square which we good choices.  However, the food came before the drinks and the restaurant wasn't full.  I order the beverage before the snacks (10 mins before) and the drink came after the snacks arrived.  Same timing with the next courses....wine was late to the table.
I wish my server had engaged more and told me about the menu, space and options for additions but it never happened.
I'll try again for dinner to see if the service and offerings are a bit different.  Overall, great location, nice menu offerings and a great beverage and wine list.  A gem for the embarcadero and having an open line kitchen is a huge plus!
author: Karin K.

description: We did one of each of the main tapas - they were absolutely divine! We also tried the paella but tht was disappointing... The cook came out to give his tips and the staff was brilliant. Bit small but it's cosy and the food is amazing. Only one toilet which could easily be improved.
author: Joana P.

description: Everything was tasty but portions are small for the price. The cheese platter featured three yummy cheeses but was served without bread or crackers, just a sweet toasted tortilla. My husband liked the smoky roasted potatoes best.
author: Jane B.

description: One of the most amazing dining experiences I have ever had. The ambiance was perfect, the food was delicious, the service was exceptional and the drinks were unique and tasty. It was so romantic and such a memorable night. The reason I gave it a 4 star instead of a 5 was for pricing. We paid $130 for a few small plates and 4 drinks. Overall great night!
author: Nicole S.

description: Food was great. Service was prompt. Too bad there was too much oil and butter in all the dishes!
author: Benny C.

description:
Are these people high or just tourists?  This is place is way too pricey, ridiculously high on concept and pretension and disappointingly low on execution.   The flavor combinations and palette are meh at best.  In a city known for its stunning cuisine, this place has no place.  If you are dropping the duckets on fine cuisine in San Francisco, put them on real cuisine, not the essence of foam of cuisine.  

On a rare sunny SF day I was drawn to the new glass box on the Embarcadero.  My friends and I stopped into the lounge.  We had speciality cocktails and our "tapas" consisted of what were passed off as skewers, but were really toothpicks with half a quarter sized pieces of salami, some mediocre patatas bravas, and forgettable shrimp dish with somewhat mealy shrimp.  The point of tapas, especially at the size they serve them, is exquisite ingredients or fresh and superb flavors.  These tapas deliver none of that.  Plus the sangria tastes like wine water, the tequila cocktail with egg is just a bad idea, and the mojito is more than disappointing with its essence of mint with no actual mint.  

Skip it people, that good money could be well spent on seriously fantastic food.  I have given points for ambiance and presentation however.
author: Rukiya L.

description: One of my favourite restaurants in the City. Amazing food, wine, and the best gin and tonics around. A little on the expensive side, but you get what you pay for.
author: Laura G.

description: Food just ok...overpriced and created for those who jump on the Trend bandwagon and care more about looking good at dinner than eating a good meal. The joke seems to be how uncomfortable can you stand to be while being price gouged. This applies the the too tall, too narrow for an overage backside bar stools, the too soft and squishy upholstered benches and the lack of consistency in the height of the stools as well as the food. Room temperature tap water served in tarnished copper " glasses"? Food served on wooden boards? Trendy bullshit goes just so far...to me a good meal is about what's it's served on, good value, and good service...all 3 fall short here. I'm sorry, but when I go out to a nice dinner I don't care for the waiters and servers "qualifying" me to see if I deserve their good service I see them give others that might be dressed better. Save that for the art galleries. Too many great places to eat in SF for this nonsense.
author: Mrs. S.

description:
Two visits, two great experiences.

My first visit was at lunch -- I think the second day they opened for lunch -- and Michael Chiarello was in. We sat at the bar and he was working right there. A gracious and enthusiastic guy, that's for sure. He made some suggestions and we loved every one: had the tortilla Andres, Delta asparagus (my goodness), tattas bravas, roasted Padron peppers, wood-grilled octopus (super), grilled albondigas (meatballs), ribeye bocadillo (sandwich and yum), and sopa de ajo (which Mr. Chiarello insisted needed to be eaten with a splash of hard cider, and he then provided it. Wonderful).  Each dish was memorable. Service was fine. 

Came back for a birthday celebration. Couldn't get the time we wanted, but I was desperate to try everything else on the menu! So we ate dinner on a Sunday at 5:30. Had a lovely, comfortable booth in the corner. Great, I mean great, service. Again, the meal was memorable. Our bill was sky-high, but that might have been because I asked the server to bring us everything on the small-plates menu...This is what we had and what we loved:

El Gran Plat Cap, a plate of cured meats and cheeses, some pan de cristal bread with a tomato spread, almonds, quince gel, oh it was very nice. Served four of us nicely, too.
Grilled razor clams. Perhaps our only disappointment. Somewhat bland.
Some pintxos. Everyone tried something different. Nice idea. One member of our party thought the quails egg Diablo was to die for.
House-cured white anchovies, some loved them, some though they were a bit too pickled.
Clam and mussel escabeche, another pickled item, served with a shaved fennel salad. We fought over this one.
Tattas Bravas, a soft tater tot, but on a whole different level. Love this one, too.
Chicken and English pea croquetas. Think the best chicken pot pie you will ever taste.
Sunny side-up egg with shrimp, crispy potato strings and chorizo dressing. OMG, this looked somewhat pathetic when served, but our waiter mixed it up for us and it has to be the best tapa I've ever had anywhere. Don't miss this one.
Crispy shrimp and chickpea flour pancake. Wait. Maybe this is the best tapa I've ever had.
Wood-grilled octopus with fingerling potatoes. Another one to fight over. The octopus was meaty, tender and had just enough wood fire on it. 
Grilled albondigas, these duck and pork meatballs were wonderful.
Whole grilled branzino. Everyone enjoyed this one, juicy, done just right -- it was somewhat small, which didn't matter to us since we were just interested in tasting it, but I think it might have disappointed if this was the only entree someone ordered.
At this point we had to cry "uncle" and tell our server to stop!

We had sangria and a couple of bottles of a well-priced Tempranillo, too.

We also had two desserts, but no one remembers what they were because the four of us finished off all that sangria and wine.

Thinking about our meal, I'm hopping on Open Table right now to get back for another meal as soon as possible. I can't wait to try the paella, which smelled so good passing by I almost went over to ask the party if I could, please, have just one spoon of it.
author: Diane K.

description:
I was excited to see how the space of the former Lafitte was transformed into Coqueta, and get a taste of how Chef Chiarello interprets Spanish tapas.  I've never been to Spain, and I can't say I have much experience dining in Spanish resturants beyond Jose Andres' Jaelo.  I've eaten at Bottega numerous times and have a fondness for Chef Chiarello's ability to cook great food and with his celebrity status from being on TV its always refreshing to see him on the line in his restaurants plating, cooking and doing service tasks while posing for photos and talking with googly eyed patrons.  

Last night was no exception. From the moment I was seated at the bar in front of the open kitchen, I was close witness to Chef Chiarello's charm and care he puts into his restaurants and his food.  Starting off with a glass of wine and some cheese, I made a few plate choices based on my likes and the cost.  I was trying to try a number of plates without breaking the bank.  I ordered the squid with onion jam and the octopus plates.  The freshness of the plates were great, but I feel like they could have been a little more seasoned to pop.  So since I was seated all night on the other side of the bar from Chef Chiarello, I decided, why not ask the Chef himself what he suggests, which made his eyes light up and he began throwing suggestions at me.  I went with his suggestion and my gut but getting the egg and shrimp dish, which was topped with peppers and fried onions.  I could have had that dish over and over all night.  Well seasoned, spicy peppers and great egg made for a wonderful dish.  

Next I tried a little cold dish of Iberico ham and sea urchin uni on a toasted mini-bagel.  That was quite good.  There were a number of little toothpick items passed my way, which started elevating the evening past my first two dishes. I noticed on the menu that the items that were very good were also listed under "What the Chef is eating", so for those looking to try Coqueta and get the best of it, I suggest going with those.

Overall, the space is still very much like Lafitte, but  with a number of color and style touches that makes the space more homey.  Chef Chiarello was very charming and open to chatting with his patrons, me being one of them, which made for a great look into his love of his craft.  Its also great watching him run his kitchen while chatting it up, cause on a number of occasions he had me thinking he had eyes in the back of his head with his quick turns to correct plates leaving the pass and getting his wait staff to get the items from the pass before they died without missing a beat of the conversation he was having.

Wait staff was great, attentive and friendly.

I'm expecting that they have numerous wrinkles to iron out of the restaurant, and so far its off to a great start.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I love Bottega in Yountville.  It's my favorite Italian place in wine country.  In fact, I ate there for lunch today and the bartender, who was fantastic, said I had to try Coqueta in the city.  I like Spanish food, as well, so I thought it would be great.
    Oh boy.  It's a busy place.  No issue there.  That's par for the course with trendy SF spots.  I waited almost 40 minutes for someone to get up from the bar.  (I was by myself). Again, not their issue.  But when I tried to sit down at the bar, I was told I had to be seated by the hostess.  At the bar.  Whatever....
      5 minutes later, she seats me at the seat I had tried to occupy earlier.   I'm laid back, I thought, "they're just busy...."  I sat at the bar with people working in front of me, walking behind me, clearing things, taking orders, ect.   Doing everything but talking to me.  I sat for 20 minutes.  At. The. Bar.  
      Finally, a nice young man asks what I'd like.  Poblano Peppers and Sangria.  30 minutes later, they arrive.  Again, I don't want to hate, but it took half an hour to get a Sangria.... At the bar.
      I try once more.  It is a tapas place, and I love Chef Michael.  Meatballs, please.  And I see them come out quickly!  Oh wait, those aren't mine.  Oh, here they come.... Nope!  I watch 6 orders of meatballs fly around the place, not one of them is headed to me until a server asks how everything is going.  I tell him I thought I had some meatballs ordered.  1 minute later, I have them.  So what do you say? 
    The server, once I got him, was very nice.  The food tasted good, once I had it.  I was just astounded how loose this place was run, knowing what a machine Bottega is in Napa.  
      Maybe I caught them on an off night, but based on what I saw, who would want to go back?
author: Langdon S.

description: The food and cocktails, although pricey, were delicious. The service was atrocious, at least for us. We went Thanksgiving weekend for my husband's birthday. We arrived a few minutes early for our reservation, but they seated us right away. We were provided with water and menus, but our server was slow to take our drink and first tapas order, and even slower to bring us anything to actually eat or drink. It took 25-30 minutes just to get our first food item, and 5 more minutes to get our drinks. Our server apologized, but clearly no effort was made to remedy the situation because we ordered about 5 tapas and 3 drinks and we were there for 2 hours. We would have ordered more, and dessert, if they actually paid any attention to us. They weren't even that busy for a Sat. night; the table next to us was empty for half the time we were seated there. I can't believe other diners were offered free samples, etc. We were treated like they couldn't be bothered with us. For a place this expensive for which you have to make a reservation a month in advance, I expected better service. Still giving them 3 stars for the food because it was pretty amazing.
author: Jenny R.

description: In general I try to avoid restaurants along the Embarcadero because, as a local, I find the food at most of those places sub-par and catering to out of towners.  But I really enjoyed this restaurant.  Great ambiance, terrific and attentive wait staff.  My boyfriend took me here for an early birthday celebration -- lunch.  Both of us love seafood and small plates.  We arrived a little before the reservation and the host let us know our table was not ready but invited us to hang out in the bar which we did.  Sangria was our first ingested item which I enjoyed -- not too sweet, refreshing (yes, even in December).  Once we were seated, we had a number of great small plates, including Brussels sprouts, the cheese plate, octopus,  the seafood fantasia and the paella.  I thought the octopus was a little salty (but still very good) and the paella was a bit on the sweet side which is why I docked the restaurant a star.  LOVED the Brussels sprouts.  The fantasia was good but not so unusual as to be more excellent than anything I have ever had.  Ditto with the cheese plate.  Wine list was good.  I would return and would recommend this restaurant to others.
author: Heather L.

description: After eating at Coqueta, I had to write a review. Thank God for this place! My husband and I have been to Bottega in Napa (another one of Michael Chiarello's restaurants), but I must say, I enjoyed the food here better, maybe because my palate is used to more Spanish style food than Italian dishes. My husband got their Magnolia IPA to start. We then ordered some tapas (Fantasia de Fidua and Coquetas de Pollo) and they were both very good. We sampled some Pintxos or skewers and they were all good as well! We also ordered their Paella wth alioli and we were more than satisfied. It says that it serves 2 to 3 people I think, but it was enough for me and my husband since we finished everything! The only thing I noticed was that the chorizo was a little bit on the hard side (looks like we got the skin or outer part of the chorizo) but it was good as well. I noticed because I had just gotten braces and it was actually difficult to bite at first. Maybe my teeth are just sensitive. For dessert, we sampled the Manchego Cheesecake paired with some caramel popcorn and it as sooo good that I wanted more! We definitely had a very wonderful experience, the staff and even some chef's by the chef's table (where we sat) were very attentive and cordial (and it is a very busy place too). I also couldn't believe we were able to make a reservation the day before Valentine's Day and get seated right away. The parking was street parking but we didn't have problems as well (maybe because our reservation was a little later during the night). The prices aren't bad at all. We will definitely come back to try their other dishes.
author: Cindy S.

description: LOVED IT! My son spent 2 years in Spain and he even thought it was authentic. Right on the water, great atmosphere and wonderful small plates. Highly recommend!
author: Lori L.

description:
I went to Coqueta for my 24th birthday dinner with 4 girlfriends; reservations can be made up to a month in advance and reservations of more than 3 people automatically are placed at a table, as opposed to the bar.  

So I called a month in advance, and the guy who took down my reservation completely butchered it.  First of all, I called when it opened for lunch exactly a month before the day I wanted to dine, but was told it was only possible for me to make a reservation at 5:00 PM or much later in the evening, since most tables stay occupied between 6:00 and 8:00 PM...  Okay, 5:00 PM was fine with me.  Then it seemed like he completely butchered my phone number, name, and number of guests.  (It really bothered me, so I called the next day to reconfirm and to make sure everything was correct, which it wasn't; thankfully, the woman who answered this time was MUCH more helpful.  After she finally figured out which reservation was actually mine...)  Unfortunately, this experience made me apprehensive.
