Fortunately, when we arrived at the pier, we were quickly taken to our table, which was right next to the kitchen.  For the meal we tried:

- Pintxos: The quail egg was my favorite; I probably could have sat there the entire night just eating those.  The combinations were definitely spot on.
- Patatas bravas: Such a simple dish, yet SOO DELICIOUS!  The garlic aioli that came with it was UHHHMAZING.
- Gambas al negro: I thought they were perfectly cooked and super juicy.  My girlfriends let me have all the shrimp heads, so that was a bonus for me!
- Monterey calamari: Pretty good, but I'm a huge fan of squid and felt like I've had better.
- Octopus: SO UNEXPECTEDLY TENDER!  We loved it, the flavoring was on point too.
- Duck and pork meatballs: We all thought it was interesting...; definitely did not expect it to be sweet, so I guess that threw us off.  Probably wouldn't order it again.
- Paella: SOOO, I had expectations for the paella, and it did not reach my expectations.  There was nothing outstanding about it.  We shared 1 order of the paella between 5 people and that was enough.
- Churros: DELISH. The raspberry dusting was a great combination.

Our waitress also was very informative and was accommodating in adjusting each dish so that each of us had at least one serving of everything.  We really wanted to try to uni open-faced sandwich, but was told they weren't able to acquire any uni for that day.  The drinks were also great; definitely stand out and interesting.

BUT THE SERVICE. The service started off really well.  Our waitress was attentive, but a quarter through our meal, she stopped serving us without explanation even though she was still serving other tables, and we got another server, who checked in very little.  It seems once we placed our orders they were just waiting for us to finish.  For the price of the meal, the service was definitely not on par and not what I expected.

In conclusion, it was definitely a must on my list of restaurants to try in San Francisco.  Not a fan of the price tag of each plate for the amount of food you are getting and the service, but the dishes were delicious and I could tell each component of each dish was well thought out.  I would give this place a 3.5 if I could, but the flavor combinations were on point and I'm a sucker for tapas, so 4 stars.
author: Becca T.

description: The food here was delicious and the drinks were absolutely amazing. The service at the bar was fantastic, but when we finally got seated our server was very unattentive. We waited 15 minutes for him to greet us and had to ask for him the other 2 times that he visited our table. Overall: 5 star food, 3 star service (except from bar which gave us 5 star service).
author: Chloe A.

description: To the reviewer who says " it doesn't look Spanish", please be assured it is very typical of a Barcelona Tapas bar.  It's casual yet stylish.  The decor is authentic Catalunian Spanish.  Congrats to Chiarello for capturing the spirit of Barcelona in both the wonderful decor and the fabulous food.
author: Bev P.

description: I was very underwhelmed with my overall experience at Coqueta. The restaurant is rustic inside and reminded me of a lodge or cabin feel. It is in a great location with gorgeous views of the water. My husband and I had a 9:30PM reservation on a Monday night in July. The restaurant was packed as if it was a Saturday evening in DC (I found this the case at both dinners we went to in San Francisco during the week). We sat at the chef's counter and to begin, we ordered the El Grand Plat Cap (chef's selection of cured meats and cheeses). It never showed up at our table. When I finally asked the waitress she basically said she forgot and then I said forget it. We tried a few other dishes and our favorite was the Sunny Side Up Huevo. We also enjoyed the kale salad with grilled strawberries. The other dishes were just ok, not good enough to mention. For dessert we had the manchego cheesecake pops. They were fantastic; especially for someone like me who doesn't love dessert. The waitress took the dessert off our bill to apologize for the lapse in our first order. The whole time we were eating the chef was expoing and flirting with a girl that seemed to be a hostess or manager. It was really awkward to watch while we were eating. They were directly in front of us. Neither of them seemed to mind...
author: Audra B.

description: Arrived 5 minutes before our reservation time. We were seated 45 minutes later. We told hostesses we had to be gone in under 2 hrs when we checked in with them and went back to them a few times to ask how much longer the table would be. We kept being told " the people on your table are paying  ".  Now I do understand that tables can get backed up, and although I was not pleased with the delay they could have redeemed themselves somewhat by buying us a drink ( we bought our own ), or even by sending us over an appetizer to tide us over. Any gesture to let us know they felt badly and realized we were still there waiting. The cost to the restaurant would be a few dollars and they could have won us back. Instead I feel compelled to tell you that by the time we got any food we had been there over an hour, and for this reason I will not be going back. Food was good, but there are too many other restaurants in SF that have good food AND are professional enough to know how to turn a negative situation into a positive one.
author: Dusty J.

description:
As a midwesterner, I hadn't heard about Coqueta. Luckily for me, I read about it on a flight from Detroit to Phoenix. I was on my way to meet up with my French relatives for a grueling "vacation" from Phoenix to San Francisco, visiting all national parks in between and spending 6+ hours per day in the car. As a Food Network fan and foodie, Coqueta was my light at the end of the tunnel.

Coqueta was a fantastic experience. Despite the fact that my online reservations hadn't gone through-Bryce Canyon is not reliable for internet service-the staff were able to accomodate the nine of us, including three children, at the last minute.

Our server and service were impeccable. Despite the fact that only my boyfriend and I spoke English, they managed to make the whole table feel welcome. As an added bonus, Chef Chiarello was there. He signed menus for us, took a picture with us and even demonstrated making the strawberry rhubarb dessert for the kids. Excellent!

And then there's the food. Given that there were nine of us, we ordered practically everything on the menu and it was fantastic. The only thing that we weren't crazy about were the razor clams. Having never had them before, I can't say if they were good or bad, only that I didn't care for them.

If you find yourself in San Francisco, be sure to eat here. It is well worth the trip.
author: Leslie S.

description:
We only got a reservation because one of our party lives in a fancy condo with a concierge.  When we arrived (just before the reservation) the host ignored us then brushed us off.  So there we are trying to find somewhere to stand while waiting for our friends and table, getting shoulder butted by one busser, then another, and forcefully told to clear a path so he could set a "reserved" bar table.
Once seated, the actual service was great: attentive, informed and gracious, though half our party froze since our table was directly adjacent to the door which they kept open all evening.  
The food was interesting and mostly delicious but overly salted across the board.
Crispy shrimp pancake was great but derivative of many similar apps around town (think thai shrimp corn cake).
I will say the gazpacho was maybe the best I've had and not at all ordinary.
Very good paella.  Wonderful cheesecake pops with caramel corn desert.
In the end, it is a concrete space in a pier. If you're not there to show off, or need to be able to say you ate at a famous chef's joint, or a tourist: why bother.
author: Jeff P.

description: I have been eager to try Coqueta out for the longest time, and finally had a chance to do so for a friend's birthday dinner. I made a reservation a month in advance. We were running a bit late, and called to let them know. We were under the impression that they would hold our table for us. By the time we arrived, we were greeted by a host who coldly told us that they had to give our table away, however, another table would be made available very soon. We wandered over to the bar to wait  for our table and browsed through the cocktail menu. A server rushed over to the bar to grab his drink orders, but dropped his tray, spraying beer all over my legs. He didnt acknowledge me until he saw me trying to find something to wipe my legs clean. He then offered to grab a towel, but never fulfilled his promise. I periodically checked in with the host, but was constantly brushed off. Finally, our table was ready, but it took awhile for our server to greet us. After taking down our order, food and drinks arrived quickly. Overall, food was creative, but did not impress me enough to justify the high price of each dish. Service was disappointing, perhaps I came on an off night, but I wont be back to give it another shot any time soon.
author: Kellie C.

description:
There are so many great restaurants in San Francisco.  I can't imagine why anyone would choose this one.

The place has more of a club than a restaurant vibe.  Like so many other reviewers for this restaurant, we waited in the packed bar 20+ minutes after arriving a couple minutes after our reservation-time.  We were then escorted to the bar in the restaurant. by someone who looked more like he should be standing at a velvet rope than working in a restaurant.  While waiting we saw some other couples  who arrived later directly seated.

Maybe it was just my mood at the time, but the restaurant also also didn't seem to be that enjoyable a place.  It felt to be a lot of tourists and people who didn't look all that happy.. It's not just the crowd.  Park Tavern for example is crowded and fun.

The food I guess is OK, but the food's OK in lots of places where spending a couple hours is much more pleasant.

I guess this place is doing well right now, but you can add me to the list of people who will never return and hope it's someday replaced with a place that treats its diners better.
author: Michael E.

description: yeah i love this place!  we thought we were sly to show up on  a sunday night about 30 minutes after they opened and they were packed!!  what the what!  luckily we didn't have to wait long for seats in the bar.  we ordered a bunch of tapas....surprise surprise...but some of my favorites were the coquettes, chorizo, branzino...the cocktails!  we wanted to try the steak, but the order is for 4 and we didn't have enough peeps....ah well we have to save something for our next visit!!!
author: Mao K.

description: Came here for a team dinner last night and the experience was fabulous! The food was all super tasty and the service was spot on. I could not recommend this place enough!
author: Jessica W.

description:
I dined at Coqueta last Thursday and was so blown away that I returned with a group of friends again Sunday night.  They all confirmed my initial impression that this restaurant is all that. They commented on how fun it was to experience a new taste sensation with each bite. Bites recommended by an informative and attentive waitress named Katie. Katie treated us like were related to Chef Chiarello and made sure that the interesting Spanish wines that were recommended never made it to the bottom of the glass.  
All and all a wonderful event locale in a beautiful space surpassed somehow by the view of the Bay Bridge and the full moon between the bridge spans.
author: Kevin Q.

description:
Quite the perfect spot for something a little different in SF.  Started with a specialty cocktail with a unique Fever Tree tonic with gin and grapefruit- very tasty and refreshing.  Then moved into the restaurant- pretty small space with lots of atmosphere.  Tried the appetizers- small bites of amazing flavor and moved on to specialty meats; calamari; a fish as they were out of crab and a paella-like dish.  All very tasty- favorites were the quail egg and the chorizo small bites and the calamari.

I thought the service was excellent without being hovered over (which I don't really appreciate).

All in all- a great addition to the SF group of restaurants and I would place it on my recommended list to out-of-towners.
author: g p.

description:
Coqueta, being newly opened in our neighborhood, was our venue of choice this week to meet friends while discussing our vacation plans.  It was a delightful surprise to see Michael Chiarello in the kitchen - that's where a good chef should be! I wasn't expecting much since new places still have some kinks to iron out but not in this case. The staff was alert and friendly, the food was delicious, special care was taken in all details. 
We've been here once before when it was Lafitte, I like the wall drawings of the Iberico pig and the bull. Our table was well-located,  we could see all the food coming from the kitchen so we could decide on  what to order next. Imagine to our surprise: Michael comes out of the kitchen with paella pan in hand and showing off his beautiful paella - of course we put in an order..and THEN another, it was so delicious. I particularly enjoyed the grilled razor clam, simple but perfectly done. 
When we told him we were to get together to plan our trip to Barcelona, he sat down and gave us a list of restaurants we should try when we're there ~ nice guy!
I can't wait to come back to taste the cocktails and the other items on their menu. 
Keep it up and you'll have a loyal following!
author: Flaneur E.

description: I LOVE LOVE LOVE the cocktails here. The beautiful barca gintonic blows me away. The space is great. Cute bar area (though most seats are usually marked with reserved signs) and lovely decor in the main dining room. Reading through the menu, your mouth will water, but I have found (on multiple visits), the food fails to deliver. Nothing is bad, but my usual satisfaction that comes after a night of eating tapas is absent after a meal here. The flavors and sauces leave me wanting something more.
author: claire c.

description: I had been to this place once before with a friend and the food struck me as better than average (and the gin and tonics unique). But upon a second visit, found the food very disappointing. Pork is their thing here. If you try that you probably won't be disappointed, but MANY of the other items on the menu were not up to par. And the gin and tonics were colorful, but had strange tastes that just didn't work. Oh - and our waiter had an extremely unpleasant affect and presentation. Yikes.
author: Denise N.

description: If you like overpriced, mediocre food with a wait staff that has the speed of a turtle and the professionalism of street vendor in the Congo, then you will love this place. (No offense to street vendors) ;)
author: John H.

description: Ok so I read a lot of travelers magazines and articles in newspapers and read enough good things about this place to convince my husband to check it out with me while we were in San Francisco.  He obliged. It was maybe 6pm early evening and by no means to capacity and we attempted to check in with host.  I swear, he barely (if at all).looked up at us and motioned us away to find a seat. We had a follow up question about seating and he was clearly busy doing  something else and appeared to be annoyed with our presence so even though the food and ambiance looked good from the outside we could not in good conscience spend our money on a meal there.  We simply thanked him and excused ourselves....   Not even a glance up, soooo strange.  We ended up eating at a fancy seafood restaurant along the pier which was phenomenal.
author: Susan P.

description:
BEWARE.

Couple of disclaimers (which will make sense as you read further into the review- if you choose to):
1.  This restaurant was undoubtedly one of the worst I've ever experienced. So much so that it converted me from a simple lurker to reviewer status on Yelp (this is my first review).
2. I am black
3. I have had better service in Bulgaria where people were neither used to seeing black people nor too eager to serve them.

So my friend and I made reservations for an 8:30 dinner on a Wednesday. Nice, right? Figured it'd be relaxed enough as it's not too close to the weekend. We made it at about 8:33, checked in by the front little area, and were told wait a bit for a table. We asked if we could grab drinks by the bar and proceeded to the bar area. My friend attempted to order our drinks, was ignored, and we figured, hey, they're probably busy and don't want to be bothered by two people who don't have a table or a tab yet. That's OK. We settled for water, grabbed a glass, and continued to wait. Our hostess relayed that we had the option of two counter seats or a table. We opted for the counter and sat down to look at the menus. I would guess that it is about 9 pm at that point. We were served water and begin patiently waiting for our server. We keep looking around, smiling, and politely nodding and gesturing for servers to come over. No one came for about 15 minutes. At that point, my friend motioned over to the center kitchen staff and asked if someone could call a server over to take our orders- it made sense, we were seated right there anyway. I could tell they weren't too happy about being disrupted but they called over a server for us. 
About 10 minutes later, someone arrives. We order a glass of white wine and mineral water. He does a speedy walk through of a dish we asked for information about and vanishes. Fast forward to 20 minutes later, we are still patiently waiting, but were not even served our drinks. We both keep looking around, seeing if our server is maybe close by. At this point, I start getting a bit annoyed and details that weren't as noticeable become apparent. I notice that we are the only people of color visible in the dining area, I notice that folks next to us (left and right) are being served drinks, food, are being asked questions and talked to. I try to shrug it off, engage in some lively chatter but I can't help but feel annoyed, peeved, uncomfortable, and insulted. So I ask the center kitchen staff AGAIN (third polite attempt), if we could get our beverages and if someone, could take our order. Right at this point, the Chef  (Michael) decides to come out and we engage in a short chit chat about the restaurant. We thought this was a good sign that someone may actually notice we needed service. He leaves, no one else comes for about another 15-20 minutes and it's about 10 pm- more than an hour into our arrival.
No drinks, no food, and no one to take our food order.
At this point, the general manager or maitre d comes over, asks about what
we ordered and takes our order AGAIN.  We re-ordered our wine for the millionth
time and proceeded to wait. It took another 15-20 minutes before I decided that I really did not want to dine in a place that seemed to take pleasure in deliberately ignoring us. I use the word ignore because nothing else describes having this targeted experience while everyone else is being attended to. And please spare me the "what if it wasn't what you think it is? what if it was just busy?". Unless you've had the pleasure (read sarcasm) of deliberately being ignored, followed, watched, or any of that in a place where you just want to pay to get services, you do not know how any of this feels. At that point, we got up proceeded to the front waiting area, offered to pay for the glass of wine, and relayed that we would no longer be dining there. Even then, they simply brushed us off, did not ask what was wrong, did not offer any apologies, nothing whatsoever. It was almost as if they were pleased to not be dealing with us anymore. So clearly I am upset, insulted, angry, and more than that, just horribly disappointed. I did a quick scan of social media reviews which all shed light on the sub-par service people have come to expect however, it is a much different feel when no one around us seemed to be having the challenges we were experiencing.

Despite the hype and grandeur that surrounds the dining experience at Coqueta, the minimum acceptable treatment is courteous, respectful, and timely. And to be quite honest, there's no need to dance around the issue but yesterday's experience, was one that fell into a specific category that begs the question: are certain groups of people not welcome at this establishment? Because the palpable feeling is that, no, some people are not welcomed and will be treated differently. I'd be curious to know if other folks of color have experienced the same or if this is just "business as usual".

Wouldn't go if you paid me.
author: Moget G.

description: I agree with past reviews.... all about cocktails and smoke and mirrors. Food was uninspired and a easy rip off on what is truly Spanish Tapas. Sleek decor and fancy cocktails does not make a reason to return.  Papa Bravas was a easy rip off on  a French preparation that was lacking in both execution and creativity. Everything else followed suit. Very disappointed. Missed opportunity.... I give it less the six months.
author: Tony A.

description:
Outstanding experience at Coqueta last night.  We sat at the counter, which is always our favorite spot when we eat out.  Very much enjoyed the bartender's recommendations, which were all spot on.  Don't miss the cocktails, which use molecular techniques; they are creative and quite delicious. The staff was super friendly and efficient.  The bar manager and general manager introduced themselves to us and chatted for a while. 

We really enjoyed the food, which is an interesting, fresh, creative take on traditional Spanish tapas.  Our favorite dishes of the night included the calamari a la plancha, the house-cured chorizo, the vine greens and Fideua. The pinxtos were fun as well.  We're not big dessert people but we followed the server's recommendations to try some of the "bite-size" desserts, including a chocolate and olive oil ice cream sandwich and a manchego cheese cake served with popcorn. Both were heavenly and not too sweet or heavy.  

Coqueta did not serve its paella option that night so we'll have to come back.  Just a lovely evening overall, with a beautiful view of the Bay.  You can tell great attention is paid to the details, including the food and drink menus.

Would be a great place for dates, special occasions or groups;  nice vibe and very fun.
author: S C.

description: The drinks are great albeit take forever to make but it's worth it. The food was excellent but the service takes this place to the next level. From the host to the server to the bussers, they are all extremely kind, accommodating and professional. My husband and I went in for an anniversary dinner and had a wonderful experience. We ordered patatas bravas, duck meatballs, grilled octopus, braised greens with raisins, deviled eggs, chicken coqueta. The only thing that wasn't to die for was the deviled eggs, just a little dry paired with a potato. Everything else was amazing!!
author: J F.

description: Went for the first time for dinner on Saturday night, with reservations. We ended up waiting an extra 30 minutes for our table due to the previous party which had not finished their dinner. Fortunately, the manager (probably a more upscale title to use here), refilled our beverages on the house and even brought out a few small pinxtos to make up for the wait. We really enjoyed the food and the wine selection is excellent. Since this restaurant is new, we chalked up the delay to the newness of it all. We will be back again!
author: Tracy T.

description: Finally a place that sells top us but actually resemble what you would get in Spain. I'm so tired of going to restaurants who claim to have tacos but instead just give you small plates, basically appetizers and call them tapas. Coqueta is a beautifully designed restaurant with a first class location on the water with views, One of the best cocktail list so I've seen anywhere in SF and outstanding authentic Spanish tapas. I will be coming back again and again and again.
author: Ashley K.

description: Excellent food but not worth the price!  Congratulations Michael!....you have mastered the art of ripping people off!
author: Demetrius T.

description: everything was delicious... tastes that i have never experienced before. brilliant.  pricey, but its worth it, i think.
author: KC F.

description: great food. nice atmosphere. i had the black garlic shrimp, the smoked salmon crostini, and an olive oil ice cream sandwich. nothing innovative or inventive really, but just very solid well done food.
author: Regina C.

description:
So, need to preface by saying that I'm not a foodie, so don't look for an highly analytical review here.

Coqueta was a great restaurant.  The service was wonderful from the moment that we walked in the door.  They accommodate special requests, gave great menu recommendations, and were just all around welcoming and non-pretentious.

The tapas was great as well; a lot of variety, and some better than others.  Definitely try as much as you can, because undoubtedly, there will be some crazy winners and one or so losers for your palate.
author: Jon S.

description: Omg!!! AMAZING service!!! People are super polite and awesome here. Im in love! Food is delicious. Cocktails are great. But really, what amazed me the most is the service!!! 10 STARS!!!!!
author: Leonardo A.

description: Everything is a la carte. I would not recommend going there if you're hungry or you'll be paying $$$$. The food was just ok and definitely not worth the money. The drinks were good though. I'd much prefer La Mar over this place.
author: Mary L.

description: the food was good, but prices are really on the steep side for what you get. e.g., the octopus dish is ~$12 and basically consisted of two small tentacles. i know this is SF and all, but i feel i could have had a more worthwhile meal for the same price elsewhere. however, the drinks are unique and good--so i'd go back for that, just not the food.
author: stefanie h.

description: I found that restaurant pretty pleasant and food was good. But I did not find it as extraordinary as others may. The paella was good, but not particularly exceptional. And I felt it was a little pricy for what we get. I would return, but not make a special trip there.
author: sandrine r.

description: the bartenders know what they're doing especially the twins.  the drinks are awesome but the food was just OK imo.
author: tiana w.

description: I'll start by saying this place had been hyped up for me by a local friend so I was disappointed to encounter not only mediocre food but quite poor service. A group of five of us came on a Sunday night. The place was active but not packed. We were seated and orders taken but it was clear pretty early our waitress had little to no sense of humor or real interest in our table. I started with their red sangria. I love sangria and did enjoy their's but you must LOVE cinnamon as it had a ton. We then split about 10 dishes including the paella, which the waitress hyped when we first arrived. I'd say 2 dishes were very good, 6 were just okay including the paella (basic flavors, undercooked shrimp) and 2 were just plain bad. My favorite was their meatball tapas. That was delicious. They were out of half their desserts so we skipped that final touch. The oddest and most upsetting part I must say was the service. The waitress was quite absent. They were very focused with removing dishes but when does a waitress remove an empty drink glass and not ask if you'd like another. I had to practically hunt her down to order a 2nd sangria. My friend wanted some advice on wine and she seemed totally clueless yet didn't bother to go find someone who might know better. Overall all 5 of us had the same feeling which was the food was okay but the service would keep us from probably coming back. Too pricey to be ignored for sure.
author: Holly H.

description: I really like their sunny side egg huevo and selection of mixed drinks, and their salmon montadito is very good, but otherwise their menu is pretty underwhelming.  Perhaps it is a matter of unrealistically high expectations - I have heard several people rave about this place and it has won numerous awards - but I think it is good, nothing more.
author: Josh Q.

description:
I just want to give Coqueta the kudos it deserves. From reservations, to service, to cocktails, ambience, location and, of course, the food, this place ROCKS and deserves 9 stars!
I had the pleasure of receiving service from Alli who was so so sweet and took good care of my whole group of guests. She was very attentive, knew the menu very well and provided solid recommendations.  We arrived a little late but they kept our table open and she was there to introduce herself. Can I say I love my server? I loved the service and she deserves 5 of those stars.
The Barca gin tonic was a big hit and all the tapas were on point. Even the kale salad was so yummy! And I DON"T LIKE KALE! At least not until now. The pintxos, which is actually Basque and not Spanish, were a hit and I even asked Alli for seconds on a couple of platas, including the delicate croquetas and the grilled octopus. If you have kids or teens, do try the J&T.
The location is perfect, close to the picturesque Bay Bridge and easily accessible from wherever you are in the Bay area.
Why 9 stars? Well, the price can be dizzying! But you do get what you pay for. This is a must visit and great place to hang out with friends. If you can, ask for Alli! Salud!
author: Eric T.

description: Coqueta is delicious. My favorite was the ham and cheese croquetas.... tasted like a chicken pot pie. Yum! Pretty much everything was delicious here. Make sure you make reservations as it gets really crowded!
author: Jeanne C.

description: Coqueta offers a classic Spanish dining style with a unique modem "Italian" spin, presented in a beautifully decorated rustic, yet contemporary, space. Michael offers varied flavor profiles across all dishes, and never failed to deliver a delightful punch. I'm looking forward to coming back, but hoping to see the menu offer less gambas (shrimp) and more seafood and meat options. Grazie y gracias, Michael!
author: Matt D.

description: Came here for dinner with my husband and the food was great. We had reservations and we arrived late but I called and they said it was ok... When we got there we ended up waiting for 30 mins. There's a great ambiance, beautiful views, great food and service. Just wish the wait was a bit less.
author: Karen P.

description: Vastly overpriced. Overly precious small plates priced to kill. Although there were no flaws in preparation the value wasn't there. A small piece of fish splayed on a wooden board for 30+ dollars. Are you kidding?  Basically they are pricing as if they were producing awe inspiring food when in fact they are churning out preciously small portions of uninspiring stuff. And then there is the Disneyland decor. Why pretend to be something you're not?  Sorry this all adds up to a place to avoid unless you don't know better.
author: Jeff K.

description: awesome space at pier 5.  after strolling from ferry building to pier 15, stopped by for a lunch snack (no reservations for space outside).  the tapas are expensive for the size though.  but the ingredients are high quality, and the dishes are tasty.  for example, Sunny side-up egg with shrimp, crispy potato, and chorizo dressing.  everything you'd want in a dish.  the bocadillo pan con tomate with chorizon and manchego -- wished the bread was hot.  ensalada resorte with spring vegetables, English pea puree, sieved egg and Serrano crouton is good for getting some veggies.  finally, tried Wood grilled octopus with fingerling potatoes, pimenton, and olive oil.  simple, salted, grilled, tender.  best to share, and I think most will enjoy the flavors.
author: Rob C.

description: Great experience, chef Dominick was fantastic a wonderful experience in all.  Food was great and Jessica was wonderful. Would highly recommend.
author: Annette G.

description: Everything was great. The cocktails were excellent. The food was perfect. The service was attentive and friendly. Love this place so much!!
author: Alanna S.

description: Fantastic! Great great food! The tapas to die for.  Great ambiance. Happening place, beautiful location.
author: MariaTeresa F.

description: This place was amazing. One of the best SF restaurant experiences I've had in a while. A new owner took the place over in 2013 and made some beautiful enhancements to the interior. But, while I know most of my Yelp review readers appreciate how much I get into decor, it's all about the food and drinks! The cocktails are unreal here. "The" most creative cocktails I've had in the world. Yes, I said it, in the world. If you know me, I have traveled everywhere and drink ...well, I drink a lot, we'll leave it at that. The traditional cocktail art has returned in force in San Francisco, London, New York and many other places. I particularly enjoy the old fashioned recipes, but it's the new twists that take the palette to far away places. Last night I had one that was particularly wonderful and timely for the season. There was roasted pumpkin, white chocolate and many other delights with cava and gin. It is an unbelievable place. If you enjoy Spanish tapas, then you have to try this place. If you have been to Spain, and dream of a return, then you need to visit Coqueta. For now, it's our little Spanish gem on the bay.
author: Darin A.

description: I came here for the first  time a couple  months back.  This place is an amazing place to come with a few  people as the menu is tapas and meant to share. We ordered everything on the  menu and everything was AMAZING. They have the most amazing cocktails and make them look so creative. It can get pricey but it you  pay for the quality of the food. Its a pretty trendy restaurant and is hard to get reservations as its always booked. I would definitely go back!
author: Ani A.

description: I am a huge fan of this place. Food is delicious, atmosphere is super fun, but what really gets me are the drinks.  YUM!  Also, I like the big bar area - when you are looking for a place to stop by for drinks and small portions then Coqueta is a great spot.
author: Jenny B.

description: What a gem of a restaurant! Great staff, amazingly creative dishes, good ambiance, and creative decor. You can't ask for a better restaurant on the waterfront of SF, walking distance from the Embarcadero Center, and easy access by ferry from the East Bay and Marin. It is a bit on the expensive side, so be prepared for that, but it was worth it!
author: Princess J.

description: The quality of the food is exceptional - but the plates are very small. Having spent time in Spain there is a much better balance between amount of food and cost. At Coqueta, the dishes may leave you hungry and your wallet empty. The pintxos are about half the size of what you would get in Spain (to help you gauge). We had 1 beer, 6 pintxos, the meatballs (combo of duck & pork that were amazing), the croquettes, bread with fresh tomato, olives and almonds. The wallet was $70 lighter but our bellies were still hungry.
author: Kristin J.

description: It's ok. One of your frou frou sf restaurants where there seems to be more attention to fancy sounding preparations, flavor combinations, and presentation than actual taste. Could just be a personal preference but I've had much better tasting food for less $. The sangria was below average IMO. I was looking forward to the kale salad but the dressing was so sour and contrasted harshly with the goat cheese. We had the branzino which was good but the greens that went along with it were fairly forgettable (ie surprisingly bland). I won't be in a rush to return here. There are too many other options out there.
author: Tina N.

description: The paella ($40 for 2) was over-cooked, dry and not as hearty as I've had at home or other Spanish restaurants. If I ever come back, it'll only be for the exotic cocktails.
author: Team C.

description: Went for dinner in a group of 5.  The service was excellent and the waiter, Steve, adjusted portions to ensure everyone got what they wanted.  The food was delicious.  The only disappointing part was the cocktails.  We had heard they had great creative cocktails, but they were just OK.  I'd go back for the food though!
author: Garrett H.

description: The drinks here were great and the atmosphere was awesome. However, the food was far too overpriced for the portion size. Would not recommend this place for tapas at all.
author: Jared J.

description:
The meal of my life. And it was bite-sized

The fates were kind to me when I lucked into a reservation for Sunday night at Coqueta. My anticipation was at effervescing level by the time Sunday rolled around. I'd walked by the place twice, peering into to catch a glimpse of something. 

I'm so excited, that I make my dining partner arrive 15 minutes early for our 9:15 reservation. Oh, those sweet fates; our table had just been set up. Only when they led us through from the bar, did I realize that actual restaurant was larger than just the space I'd been trying to see. I had been looking just the bar side. The bigger space takes up the former LaFitte space. And it's gorgeous.

Now, believe me, I'm not a gusher. I'm usually not  impressed by celebrity. (There is a point to this). I'm sitting perusing the menu thinking "It would be kind of great if Michael Chiarello was actually here tonight. But it's late and Sunday...I doubt it". The words are still hanging in my bourbon-infused airspace when a hand is thrust into my menu's general area. "Good evening and welcome." It is Chef Chiarello personally thanking me and my dinner guest for coming tonight. I regale him of my anticipation and ask what he suggests. He patiently and graciously reviews a number of items he suggests, including the Tatta tots "They are a pain in the ass to make, but they're delicious". It is only after he has left the table, that my guest leans in and says "you just peed a little, didn't you?". I am loathe to admit, I did. He also communicates that I have asked the chef what he recommends while the menu CLEARLY says "Here's what the chef recommends".  Tourist.

After our incredibly lovely server brings us a bottle of Spanish rose, we begin to think about tucking in. The Chef had recommended the iberico pork, so that was already settled, but we reviewed the list of his recommendations. Here's how they played out: 

* Asparagus with sangria hollandaise: Mother of Pearl, this was good. I know what you're thinking. Sangria? Hollandaise? Believe me. It works. The hollandaise is light, fluffy and so balanced. It's not sweet, but has the perfect note of red wine. 
* Tattas Brava: Fancy schmancy tater tots. Creamy, crispy with some aioli. Fantastic
* Chicken/Spring pea croquetas: Gorgeous, crispy. Like a chicken pot pie in finger-food form. 
* Crispy egg over shrimp and polenta with chorizo sauce: hands down my favorite. A perfect sunny-side up egg, shrimp and spicy chorizo. This could possibly the last meal I ask for. 
* Grilled iberico pork: Just typing this makes my mouth water. Simply put, this is one of the best things I've ever tasted. Apparently, these porcine pals are fed a diet of acorns, making them taste like nothing I've tasted; the perfect grilling didn't hurt, either! 

Service was without a flaw. Attentive, yet non-intrusive; always knowledgeable. I get the distinct impression that people actually like working there. Everyone seems relaxed and really enthused over what they're doing. 

My bill came and I actually thought it was a mistake. No, hold on. In a  good way. It was far less than I had anticipated and, in my humble opinion, worth every single cent.
author: Patrick R.

description: The bar was fun. The hostess staff was too pretentious and a bit rude. The food is overpriced and not that special and the gin cocktails are very good! Go to the bar have a cocktail or two and have dinner somewhere else.
author: Tom M.

description: Went here for lunch during a recent weekend, the place was packed so we sat at the bar to order food.  Delicious dish after delicious dish, plus a few glasses of sangria really made for a great weekend!
author: Dagny C.

description: I had an early lunch here a couple of months ago  - 11:30am - but this afforded us the opportunity to sit at the bar, facing the water and to be served by the fantastic bar tender!  We started out with Wood-grilled octopus that was so great I ordered another and while we were waiting, the bartender apparently had some extra time to devote to us and started a free 'wine tasting' for us of some obscure but wonderful Spanish wines. This extra attention (and wine) started us off on a very long and wonderful lunch of several dishes - all fantastic. So the food, coupled with the wonderful wine and the amazing service by the bartender made this repast worthy of five stars. However, as the noon hour approached, the place became a zoo; loud, cramped and hectic. That would be my only complaint. Had we not been seated were we were, I might have given only three stars, but given all the extra service, I'll grant four.
author: Kevin M.

description: One word, yummy!  I enjoy tapas style and sharing and everything we had was wonderful. We had the deviled eggs, charcuterie and cheese tray, duck and pork meatballs and grilled octopus. Everything we ate was perfectly cooked and seasoned and I would eat any of them again. We also ordered the cocktails for sharing, the Clara and one that resembled a sangria. I would love to come back to Coqueta when I am in San Francisco again.
author: Tracy G.

description: hit & miss. overall, disappointed in Michael Chiarello's waterfront SF restaurant. 3/5 stars. sexy, loud interior but I expected much more from a Next Iron Chef finalist. we returned one dish simply because of the amount of grease. not kidding but it made the blooming onion at Outback seem healthy. and the paella was also overly greasy and bland. I asked for a toothpick and was told they don't have any. really? better luck next time.
author: A.D. C.

description: My daughter took me here for my birthday and we both really enjoyed it!  The non-alcoholic lime drink was just wonderful!  The two stand outs to me were the kale salad (to die for!  And we weren't even going to order it until our waiter told us it would go well with something else we were ordering - thank you Lowell! ) and the calamari - absolutely the best calamari I have ever tasted!  After we finished one of the early dishes we ordered, I took a furtive look around the restaurant to make sure no one was looking and I quickly licked the plate!  I just couldn't let those wonderful juices go to waste! I should mention that the service was just wonderful, from our waiter Lowell, to the maître d' to all the people behind the counter with whom we interacted.  I am very critical of bad service, when I get it, but when I get such wonderful service, I really appreciate it.  It makes a fabulous tasting meal into a perfect evening.  A very memorable birthday dinner.  I can't wait to go again.
author: Ruth L.

description: High marks on all fronts. This is an incredible remake of the Lafitte space on Embarcadero with decor that does justice to the menu. The staff accommodated a late reservation for 10 at lunch (the boss wanted to take our group out) and we arrived at 11:30. The waitstaff was very helpful in getting us settled in with the appropriate drinks and suggesting many great food options. They had suggested 2 or 3 tapas per guest on top of a main dish, but we basically did one each with a couple of paella (vegetarian and regular) and the whole grilled branzino (from the dinner menu, but they did it for us at lunch on request). The tapas were shared and we had several - each was unique. Olive oil-poached prawns, Monterey calamari with squid ink aoili, fried shrmp cakes, poached asparagus with Idiazabal cheese and jamon Serrano, they just kept coming. There was hesitation on the paella (vegetarian), but the server offered a vegetarian version - both were delicious. However, the winning dish of the day for me was the branzino. I'm not usually a drinker, but the server suggested a galleon which was perfect. The only slight hitch was that tapas were ordered by individuals and the runners kept plopping them randomly on the table. The dishes are so exotic it took us a minute to realize, but it all worked out and every single thing was so delicious no one seemed to mind. Beware, when we left at about 1:30 it was total chaos trying to get in - so go early if you can.
author: Robert M.

description: Although the service was not the best, the food was fantastic. Our server didn't seem like she wanted to be there and she knocked our table at least tens times while we were dining, which was quite uncomfortable. Hopefully, we will get a better server and/or table next time me go!
author: Melissa P.

description: I can't say I would go here for a formal sit down dinner but for anything this place is fantastic. Great location, great ambiance, great service, and fantastic food and drink. The pork loin alone is worth the visit. As if Coqueta wasn't enough, after dinner  you can always walk one block to Hard Water, a great bourbon bar.
author: Benzee B.

description: There is a commandment in dining:  Restaurants with great views shall have sucky food.  Coqueta breaks this commandment.  The food is inventive and delicious.  Fantastic atmosphere, super creative cocktails and professional yet fun servers.  It's my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Matt W.

description: Very interesting dishes with great flavors.  Meatballs.  Don't question me, just order them.  Yum!  Fantastic wait staff, very helpful and explained the dishes well.  And our waiter had an opinion on her favorites - I hate when you ask "what's good" or "what do you like" and they respond "everything"...  Not the case here.  And save room for dessert.  I'm not much of dessert eater but I made an exception here and was not disappointed.
author: bill l.

description: Wow, what a gem on the Embardero waterfront.  We came here for an anniversary lunch (I wasn't able to get dinner reservations a week ahead), and Coqueta made the celebration really special.  We opted to sit at the bar to watch the chefs in action, and the staff could not be more friendly, professional and knowledgeable.  Even though it was 2pm, the restaurant was packed, and the staff was incredibly busy, but they took the time to explain things to us and patiently answer our questions.  You can tell their intention is to make each patron's dining experience a positive one.  We asked one waitress about the house-cured Fuet dish as she was plating it, and not only did she explain the dish, but gave us a free sample as well.  Watching the staff execute and plate each dish was an entertaining show in itself and made us want to order everything.  Coqueta was great for a luxurious leisurely tapas meal, where you take your time to savor each small dish.  It's definitely not a place to go if you have kids with you and you are in a rush.  The staff was amazing.  At one point, I noticed a hair in my Almond Joy drink and the waiter not only brought a new one, but deducted that drink, as well as dessert from our bill. Completely above and beyond what's expected, and very much appreciated.  Some stand out dishes were the Grilled Razor Clams, Churro Fantasia, Wood-Grilled Octopus, and Grilled Iberico Secreto (pork) dishes, but honestly, every dish looked amazing.  Each dish was unique, elegant, and beautifully executed.  If you sit at the bar, you will likely want to order every dish you see!
author: Bonnie C.

description: Our reservation was relatively last minute, and 9:45pm was the only thing showing available on that particular day; we took a chance and showed up at 9:15 and the place was half empty - so I wish we'd called directly for earlier availability.  I love authentic white anchovies that I can get in Spain, so I was happy they have them at Coqueta.  We followed the anchovies and the roasted padron peppers - which had a nice fresh pepper flavor - definitely not spicy.  For our "main" we shared the whole grilled branzino, which was perfectly seasoned and tender.   The wine list was extremely large and focused on Spain, which was of course perfect.  It was a nice visit for a lighter meal.
author: Rachel G.

description:
It was good, with high points and some mediocrity.  The ambiance is its greatest asset, the food is good but not great, and the service is generally strong but varies greatly within the team.  To be fair, my husband and 10-year-old son think am being a little too harsh in my assessment.

The Food:  The menu is a high point, from its design to the wide range of tapas and other options and their descriptions.  We ordered six tapas, and all were good to very good, but none were to-die-for-I-must-have-it-again.  The dishes are creative and presented well.  The house cured boquerones were delish, as were the house-cured white anchovies.  My son's fave was the Sunny side-up egg with shrimp.  The crispy shrimp pancake was interesting and crunchy, but I am always turned off when I see sauce that has been applied through a squeeze bottle.  It screams "bulk food" no matter how haute.  Lukewarm on the grilled albondigas, but to be fair the eaters are more used to ground beef.  We went for the paella, which was something of a letdown after all the tapas.  It should have been the piece de resistance, but was under inspired.  I would definitely skip it next time, and spend the $40 on more tapas.

The Ambiance:  Great, very comfortable, rustic yet open, perfect size crowd, spacious.  I'm looking forward to a cocktail in the pop-out, heated bar next time.

The Service:  It was good, but there was a noticeable inconstancy in the runner staff.  Some of our tapas was plunked on the table, and announced as the runner turned and scuttled back to the kitchen for the next service.   No presentation or time for questions.   Other tapas was presented, stirred, mixed, or served with a smile and interest.  Please train all of your staff to do that!

In sum, the food lacked the like-water-for-chocolate excitement I would expect from celebrity-chef Spanish cuisine.  However, the setting and restaurant itself are great spaces, and I would go back again for just a cocktail and a few tapas with friends.
author: Julie B.

description: Nice atmosphere in this tapas restaurant. Food was just ok. Not as good as tapas in Spain, but still a nice place to try out.  Their dessert churros and hot chocolate was not  like the ones in Spain. i liked the atmosphere, decor and service best.
author: Felecia W.

description: Huge fan of this spot. The food is fantastic and the service the best I've had in SF. I cannot way enough about this restaurant except to add that I will be back again and again! Love it.
author: Laurene R.

description: Over the top decor, looks like an old but nicely renovated barn you would find in the country side and not on a pier in San Francisco.  Some great tapas, some underwhelming, salty desert that I don't think you would find in Spain (e.g. Manchegio cheese cake, olive oil and chocolate etc).  The seafood dishes were excellent, the meat or vegetarian dishes not as much.  For a place that is so hard to get a reservation to, it's slightly deceiving.  Wine selection was great though.
author: Laurent G.

description: Was really really looking forward to this place when I made our reservation over a week ago. Im a big foodie and love trying new restaurants in SF. Had a reservation set for Jardiniere, Spruce, and Coqueta. Opted on Coqueta for several reasons: new restaurant, famous chef, great location (pier 5), fun atmosphere, and solid reviews  on Yelp. Took about 7-8 clients out for a celebratory dinner and when I called to make the reservation I requested the best table that is available and she said it would be no problem. So...we get there at 7:45 for our 8:00 reservation. I checked in with the hostess and walked to the lovely but very busy bar area to get a cocktail.  It was IMPOSSIBLE to get a drink. There were only TWO bartenders for the bar area and dining room....from what I counted. That is ridic! When I did get the bartenders attention he looked at me like "what do you want"...and said he was trying to get the attention of the hostess so he never took my order. He was rude. Next, I asked a nice waitress I saw walking around for a cocktail list and ordered with her. Around 8:15 the hostess pointed out a communal bar stool long thin type table in the bar area would be "ready for us soon." Ummm....a communal...can't even have a conversation bc it's so loud table is the best you can do for a reservation?? I told her this just wouldn't work. So the manager, whom was very pleasant and tried his best to be helpful told us a table in the "dining room" would be available in 35 minutes approximately. So we asked if we could order a bunch of apps and cocktails at this so called table they were initially going to seat us at. They were cool with this and happy to make us comfortable until our table was ready. In the meantime, we STILL have not gotten our cocktails...holy crap, really? It was almost 8:30 and we have yet to get a drink. We were trying to spend some money and it was difficult to do! We literally received about 4 apps before a DRINK! In my opinion, this is unacceptable. Hire more bartenders, Coqueta. You're going to be a busy restaurant!! So after trying about 10 different apps, 2 pitchers of Sangria, and a few cocktails, our table was finally ready at 9:15...9:15. I know they did their best on the table thing, but they should ALWAYS let people know ahead of time of this table that is located in the bar area, bc it is very casual and a very small table. And the fact that its communal for a work dinner is not cool. So now on to the important part...the food. Food was good...some plates very good...some decent. Obviously, this is tapas style so easy to share. I think we literally ordered everything on the menu. Spent almost $1,000 and didn't leave super full. Cocktails were yummy, and the desert was super yummy. I will definitely give this restaurant another shot, especially once they have outdoor tables, but if they don't hire more bartenders they will not be worth the wait. There are tons of great restaurants in SF that mix up some wonderful stuff so I hope Coqueta steps it up a bit. They really could be a great place once the odds and ends get worked out. Until next time!
author: nicole s.

description: Eat here.  We had a fun and delicious experience.  The cocktails were creative, and the tapas were very interesting, different and tasty.   The desserts, especially the doughnuts with the chocolate sauce, were fantastic.  The service was also very good.  The only issue is that it is hard to get a reservation.
author: Stephan E.

description: The pork. Is. To. Die. For. And everything is perfection. Be careful, once you eat at Coqueta, everywhere else will pale.
author: V A.

description: I had a great experience here.  I loved  the food and ambiance.  I have not been to an SF restaurant in a long time that goes the extra mile in providing all the details such as cutlery, linens, decor, creative drinks, etc.  Everything was fun and exciting.  The food was pretty good albeit pricey.  I think they have a high rent to pay!
author: K L.

description: Such a fun place to have drink and small bites! Love their version of the gin and tonic - get it - you won't be sorry.
author: Jenny T.

description: Had a wonderful lunch here today. Great service. Fabulous tapas. Loved the housemade tonic with anise. And the dessert, wow. Apple tart with blue cheese ice cream.  My only complaint is the napkins. I know, I know...this is not fair. But both my husband and I walked out with white napkin lint all over our black pants and black sweaters.
author: Claudia S.

description: I had lunch here and it was absolutely fantastic.  We couldn't decide on our five plates because everything on the menu sounded amazing.  Our server was very helpful in guiding us in the right direction and we loved every plate we had.  The space is also very cool- they did  a great job with the design.  I will definitely be back.  If you go, be sure to try the wood-fire grilled octopus, sunny-side up egg with shrimp and chorizo sauce, and the coquettas- all delish!
author: Nancy U.

description: Excellent food n service. From the meat cheese platter, octopus, anchovies  to the pluma and the honey chili sauce to dessert, the food was outstanding. The sangria delicious. Steve was our server and treated us attentively but not overbearing. He gave great service. Great experience n would go again when back in town.
author: Michael S.

description: First let me say the food was incredible!  The customer service not so much.  We arrived 20 minutes early so we could have a cocktail.  The bar was packed and we shared an outside table. They were out of a few cocktails and tapas, we had the albodingas and tata's bravas, enjoyed them. We were seated one HOUR past our reservation time!  They bought a round of drinks for us and brought additional orders of tapas and as many pixtos as we wanted but it was bad!  We also had the octopus, shrimp and chickpea pancake, olives and almonds, arroz cremosa, the pork shoulder and finished with manchego cheesecake. Everything was beautifully prepared and full of flavor. I would go back for the pork alone, but I'd make reservations for earlier in the evening -- possibly the first seating.  If the food wasn't so good I'd never go back.
author: Rose L.

description:
This was my first visit to Coqueta.  I consider myself to have a sophisticated palette, having been to some of the best restaurants in the Bay Area, including Napa and Sonoma.  I pass Coqueta every day on my way to work so I thought I would finally give it a try.  My friend and I ordered the Sangria which was pretty tasteless and seemed watered down.  The waitress asked if we were ready to order and we said we did not get menus.  She said we had to open the drink menu all the way.  The menu is on a piece of paper folded in half and half again.  The food menu is on the inside.  She said everyone asks the same thing.  Really?  OK, if this is a problem, perhaps it should be addressed?  My friend and I both thought the menu was hard to navigate with way too much crammed on one page.  We ordered four small plates to share.  The beet salad, chicken croquettes, duck and pork meatballs and the crispy shrimp pancake.  All portions were ridiculously small.  I've been to many Tapas restaurants where the small plates were worth sharing.  Not the case here.  The beet salad, although tasty, was so small it was laughable.  The only other dish that was tasty were the chicken croquettes.  The meatballs were greasy and the shrimp pancake was just a mound of fried dough--could not taste the shrimp at all.  Dessert was a disappointment as well.  Greasy donuts and bite size cheesecakes not worth the effort.  My cappuccino was served in what I consider to be an espresso sized cup.  My friend's regular coffee was also served in the same size cup.  When he asked for more coffee the waitress said "our French press is broken."  What?  Really?  Speaking of our waitress, she seemed tired, bored and not interested in waiting on us.  The rest of the staff removed our dirty dishes so fast, we felt rushed throughout the entire meal.  After spending over $100.00 on dinner, I feel I should not leave a restaurant hungry.  The only thing I did appreciate was the design.  As a Designer, its not bad.  The animal skins glued to the floor is a trip hazard and a law suit waiting to happen.  I was leaning against heavy drapery on the back of the seat bench which was getting annoying after awhile.  One of the staff members came up to our table to reach behind me to open the shade.  This was ackward and rude during dinner.

This place is trying WAY too hard to be cool and hip but in my opinion is failing miserably.  With all the other really great restaurants in the area, Michael better step up his game if he's going to survive.  Perhaps they need more time to get the kinks out, but in the meantime, my friends and I will not be going back.
author: Jane F.

description:
There are some restaurants that definitely live up to the hype (like Rich Table) but Coqueta is NOT one of them.
I made a reservation a month in advance (on a Tuesday night, and only 2 of us) and still had to wait for our table.  When they were ready to seat us they said they were going to seat us at the bar in front of the kitchen.  Ummm, I don't make a reservation a month in advance to sit at a bar.  And, if you were planning on seating me at the bar, how about ask me if that is acceptable when I checked in for my reservation.  Anyway, the host and hostesses were not friendly, they were condescending.. not helpful.  The service was slow slow slow, our waitress was nice but slowwww and she ended up forgetting one of our plates (the one they pushed on us) and never apologized for it.  The food was nothing spectacular, very un-exciting.  The best plate was their duck/pork meatballs despite the hard sell for their pepper dish that every last employee came to our table to tell us how delicious it was.  It became very uncomfortable to have so many people try to push a dish.  . I've never experienced any restaurant push so hard to sell a dish.  When we got it, it was just "ok".
Suffice to say, I doubt I will go back to Coqueta.
author: Kelly B.

description: Very underwhelmed.  Doesn't come close to the tapas and pinxtos we had in Spain. Small portions of average food at a high price.  Having said that, the ambiance and service were above average. Food just didn't live up to some of the rave reviews. Will keep looking for good Spanish food.
author: Karen T.

description: SO GOOD!  I love the ambiance here as well as the service.  The food is incredible and reminds me of being back in Spain!  The paella is off the charts and the little bites are to die for.  Don't skip the sardines!
author: Rachel S.

description: I've eaten here twice now.  The first time was great.  The second time was disappointing.  Among other things, we ordered the pinxtos--ham and manchego cheese.  At $7 each, for 3/4 inch squares, these were the biggest culinary ripoffs ever.   $2 would have been more like it.  The service was great.  If they can rationalize their food servings/costs, it would be highly recommended.
author: Susan K.

description: Food is a solid 4 stars. BUt the staff went out of their way to get us a table even though we didn't have a reservation. And the solid service just continued during dinner, this is probably the best service I've experienced in San FRancisco. Combined with a super ambiance they deserve and get 5 stars.
author: Peter J.

description:
Dear Michael,

My wife and I have been to Bottega several times, and it still remains our favorite, so we decided to take our cousins to Coqueta. We disregarded several of the other tripadvisor reviews and wanted to form our own opinions. While your food remains quite delicious (stars were the smoked salmon, the sunny side up egg, and the albondigas) it did seem to be a bit overpriced (don't bother with the pinxtos or razor clams while the paella and octopus are just so-so). The biggest surprise on our visit was the service, or rather the lack of service. The restaurant was packed and we were seated promptly but waited at least 5 minutes before receiving water. After we finally ordered cocktails our server forgot to put our order in correctly and my cousin didn't receive her drink (it should be noted that the server was apologetic and did end up providing the drink on the house which was a nice and appreciated touch). Another disappointing note was the fact that it was a rather hot day in he city and we were all looking forward to a pitcher of sangria but were informed that they were out of it by our 6:45 reservation. Overall experience was that the restaurant was in an awesome location on the water, the food was hit or miss depending on the order (but overpriced regardless) and the service was lacking when compared to Bottega.
author: Frank B.

description: Everything we had was solid, but nothing was exceptional.   The octopus, squid, chickpea and shrimp pancake and duck/pork meatballs were the best dishes we had; the chicken croquettas were quite bland.  The paella was really flavorful and their housemade chorizo was excellent.  Based on the ratings and hype we expected more; none of the food compared with what we had in Barcelona this spring.  Also, our server was quite weak - she didn't seem very knowledgable and was not around much.  It was nice to see Michael in the kitchen - he was very attentive.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great location over looking the water. The Duckhorn Sauvignon Blanc!!
author: Jenny J.

description: Five stars for everything! Excellent service, food, drinks and ambience. Especially loved the pluma, sopa de ajo, vineyard greens and sunny side up egg with shrimp. Top it off with apple pie for dessert and you'll be booking your next reservation for seconds!
author: Kim F.

description: Ok, so this used to be my favorite lunch spot.... However, things have gone downhill lately....  I'm really bummed about this because it's so close to my work. The duck meatballs was an all time favorite dish until the last two times I have ordered them they have been over cooked, and the cherry sauce was burnt. Also, when I decided to come in for dinner after work last week with some friends, the snooty "manager" who sat us at a crowded table proceeded to loudly flirt with the older gentleman at the table next to us bending from the waist showing off her fishnet tights. (Really?) It was somewhat a challenge to get the waiters attention with her in the way. I thought this was a classy place, apparently not run by classy people....Finally, after fifteen minutes of awkwardness with this going on beside us, our polite and professional server took our order. On the upside we had really wonderful gin cocktails and the cheesecake dessert was exceptional. However, with the bill price and the carnival circus act we saw, we we're put off and gave the two star review. I sure hope the food returns to its former glory!
author: Pat Y.

description:
My friend and I got lucky and scored a seat at the counter at  Coqueta shortly after opening.  I was really excited for this place to open, because I love Spanish food.  I'm very particular about food from countries I've visited, however.  I had high hopes based on all of the press though and I was not disappointed. Michael Chiarello even chatted with us throughout our meal!  I love the vibe. It makes you want to hang out all night (probably why some of the folks on here complained about a wait for their table).  

We started out with a couple cocktails--I had the Tariff and my friend had the Conquistador--and they both lived up to our expectations.  I don't like gin, if I'm being honest, but I am a sucker for Cava.  The Tariff was delicious.  I didn't try any of the other cocktails, because I wanted the Blackbird Rose on tap served in a porron--so cool, love that!

We ordered a couple hot tapas, a couple cold and one larger dish.  I dreamt about the boquerones pinxto.  Seriously, if you like white anchovies, order this skewer.  We tried the Serrano & Manchgeo pinxto too.  Ham & cheese, how can you go wrong?  The chicken & English pea croquetas were perfectly crisp on the outside and oozy and creamy on the inside.  Just be careful when you eat these babies, because the inside is HOT (our server did worn us, thankfully)!  I will be back, if only to order these tasty balls of yumminess. We also ordered the sunny side-up egg, on Chef Chiarello's recommendation.  Holy cow, it's the perfect hangover dish! I wonder if he makes it for himself the morning after a "long" night.  We also tried the duck meatballs.  I loved the savory duck with the cherry jam on the top.  It was the perfect combination of salty & sweet.   The only larger dish we ordered was the arroz with the scallops. It wasn't too rich, which I really appreciated about the dish.  The scallops were set, perfectly cooked, over a tasty sea of tomato-y creamy (but not heavy) rice (also perfectly cooked).  The peas added a nice texture to the dish too.  For dessert we had the churros and the Manchego cheesecake pops.  I'm not big on sweet desserts and these two were great choices.  Neither were over the top sweet and the hot chocolate with the churros took me back to Barcelona.  The churros themselves were nice and crispy on the outside and soft in the center.  Clearly, the Manchego cheesecake pops are a hit!  I don't like cheesecake, but my friend wanted to try them.  For me to say I like cheesecake is major.  I liked this cheesecake, a pleasant surprise.

To sum it up, I will be back.  All the time, if I can get in!
author: Madeleine G.

description: Amazing new hot spot for SF. Great food and awesome atmosphere. You get the pleasure of watching Chef Chiarello dance through the open kitchen to create the delicious menu items you will savor every bite of. Fresh, local ingredients provide vibrant flavor explosions in your mouth of this Spanish cuisine. My girlfriends and I really enjoyed the cocktails too. Overall a very creative new project seems to be a success. I can't wait to go back.
author: Michelle W.

description:
Michael Chiarello could make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich seem like some kind of out of mind, taste extravaganza.  Coqueta is absolutely the best restaurant to hit the SF waterfront in years.  Fun, Hip and an unbelievable Bar to boot.  Seeing Michael Chiarello in the kitchen and occasionally roaming the rooms is the ultimate treat.

We tried several of the drinks and favored the Presidio and fine wine selections from Spain.   Make sure you belly up to the bar and watch the mixologists at work.  It is like seeing an artist work a canvas pulling form the multitude of fresh items in copper jars on the bar.  

Next we ventured into the beautifully crafted dinning room and experienced the best tapas this side of Barcelona, (ok.... maybe better).  Michael has combined his ability to update any dish into a tastebud orgasm.  The menu can be a bit overwhelming, but our waiter Josh could not have been more adorable and helpful.  He literally took our likes and dislikes upfront and proceeded to bring out a wonderful sampling of the menu.  Favorites were  many but here goes:  The "Tattas" Bravas are the best tater tots you could ever imagine!  The Sopa de ajo, Bread and Garlic soup with green garlic pesto and hen egg was devine, Grlled albondigas, duck and pork meatballs were a favorite at the table, Dungeness crab was grilled and uniquely tasty, Vineyard Greens, a small portion but directly from Michels garden we were told, and worth every bite.  Favorites:  The Arrozo Cremosa, slow cooked rice with day scallops and Fideua, vermicelli pasta cooked like paella with shrimp and asparagus.  We sampled some of the sliced cured meats and although pricey, Jamon Iberico de Bellota was worth every morsel.  Also fun were the Pintxos which a server presents to the table throughout the dinner, $2.50 small skewer samplings,  a fun way to try Michael's creative food creations.

The desert menu is creative.  We shared a version of a cheese cake on a stick and apple pie tart with blue cheese ice cream.  Both were worth every calorie.  How Michael can make a cappuccino into a uniquely devine experience is beyond me, but please don't leave without a coffee drink....is it the glassware, Mr. Coffee???  One will never know if is just the spell of a Michael Chiarello meal!
author: Nano G.

description: amazing tapas plates, try the scotch cocktail perfect balance and smokey flavors.
author: Danny c.

description: Wow!  Who knew?!  First, the scene is vibrant but not trying too hard.  The ambiance is great - spacious yet cool, hip yet intimate and cozy all at the same time (if that is even possible).  Then there is the food - Yowza!  I don't even eat meat but when this caliber of food is being served I make an exception.  The pork was out of this world!  The service has none of the kinks of a new place and everyone seems to act as if they take ownership of what is served.  Finally, Michael is an unbelievably nice guy.  I have to admit I had no idea he was a "celebrity chef" when I met friends there (I don't watch TV).  However, I dine out all over the world.  For me he was the guy who was residing in my friend Russel's old space (where La Fitte used to be). Michael made us feel so at home and he clearly really cares about the patron experience.  He is passionate about food and cares deeply about service and the whole evening was truly memorable.  And the food was outstanding!!
author: L B.

description: I went to Coqueta for lunch on 5/2/14.  This was the first time I tried the restaurant.  I was seated in the gazebo area by the hostess after being told there was a 40 minute wait in the main dining room.  I was seated at an empty table with nothing on it.  After 15 minutes with no acknowledgement by the wait staff and other guest coming and getting set ups and drinks, I asked to speak to the manager.  A lady came out and I asked her if I was sitting in the dead zone of the restaurant--all I received was a blank empty stare--she had no idea what I was talking about.  I explained that I had been waiting for service, other diners had come in after me and were served and nothing had happened.  I ordered three items from the menu;  the "El Plat Cap" a selection of cured meats was overpriced $28 for the quality, quantity, the platter was mostly covered with bread and homemade crackers there was also a pile of salt on the platter-salt with cured meats?, the "Sunny side-up egg" was very greasy and there was a pool of grease on the plate when finished, and lastly the Churro dessert the chocolate sauce was boring and the strawberry powder was intense and I really didn't know what to do with it.  After spending $65 for lunch I walked out unimpressed with the service, and the food--what a disappointment.
author: Richard K.

description: Always suffer from tapas menu anxiety:  not sure what or how much to order.  Waiter was very helpful, and we (2 of us) enjoyed the shrimp/chickpea pancake, the tatas bravas (perfect little tater tot thingies), duck and pork meatballs, couple of the cheese pinxtos, and the tortilla Andres (wedges of potato and onion), along with the pleasant (and fruit filled) sangria, and the chocolate cake dessert.  Don't know how they do it, but the dishes followed each other perfectly timed, allowing us to focus on and savor each individually.  And they're all worth spending time with.  The decor is warm and expansive.  We sat at the chef's bar, and I wouldn't go out of my way for one of those perches again...you don't really get to see much in the way of cooking and the stools are not the most comfortable.  When I return, and I will, I intend to explore the bar--a quaint, separate structure that fronts on the water.  Looked like fun.  Only cautionary note:  the menu can get pricey.  But I got my money's worth.
author: Keith J.

description: I hate to rag on a restaurant that has such high reviews (whenever I use yelp reviews I get so confused by the extreme differences) but I am relieved to see others (Albert H for example) experienced the same lapse in service that we did.  We didn't make reservations but happened to be on the Embarcadero at 5pm on a Sat. night so we decided to see if they had room for walk-ins.  The host stand was a mass of confusion but we were seated almost right away at the long bar.  The bar stools are far from comfortable and that's coming from a gal who likes to sit on bat stools!  Despite this, we were eager to try the menu.  After about 15 minutes of watching servers running around doing anything from folding napkins to chatting with the line chef (there were only about 3 tables seated and a few folks at the bar like us - I mean it was 5:00 which is a bit early for dinner) a server finally asked us if we would like a drink! I ordered a cocktail which is rare and again Albert H was spot-on - I just wanted a gin and tonic and ended up with a cucumber infused bitters laced froo-froo drink.  But at least I got my drink!  My husband's wine didn't show up for another 15 minutes after which I grabbed an elusive waitress and advised them he never got his wine - it was clearly lost in the shuffle.  By this time the waitress actually assigned to our station showed up and we placed our order for a few plates.  I think some of the delays may have been due to tardy staff, but even if that is the case, there was an excess of servers whose stations were empty - I don't get how you can miss an agitated person sitting at the bar trying to catch someone's attention - any attentive waitstaff worth their salt can recognize these signs.  Anyhow, the waitress happened to notice that I wasn't touching my gin and tonic and asked me if I didn't like it to which I said yes and she said she would take it away.  On the plus side, my husband's wine was delicious so I ordered a pour for myself (and they are generous pours for the $$).  I was disappointed to see that the gin and tonic was not removed from the bill.  All in all the loss to a business like that for a returned drink (which if the cocktails are as good as some folks claim probably doesn't happen often) is nil but the good feeling it engenders in the customer is irreplaceable.  The food was ok - nothing stellar that I can recall (we had the mixed meat and cheese plate, calamari and some fried something or other potatoe or cheese thing) but with service as lacking as that (maybe it is different for reservation folks but really as a restaurant you are going to have different standards of service for walk-ins vs reservations?!?!) we won't go back anytime soon.
author: Kim G.
